hebrew_text: כָּל כִּינּוּיֵי נְדָרִים — כִּנְדָרִים,
human_translation: all substitutes of vows are like vows.
llm_translation: All designations of vows - vows.

hebrew_text: וַחֲרָמִים — כַּחֲרָמִים, וּשְׁבוּעוֹת — כִּשְׁבוּעוֹת, וּנְזִירוּת — כִּנְזִירוּת.
human_translation: dedications are like dedications, oaths are like oaths, and nazirite are like nazirite
llm_translation: "And cheremim - like cheremim, and shevuot - like shevuot, and nezirut - like nezirut."

hebrew_text: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵרוֹ ״מוּדְּרַנִי מִמָּךְ״, ״מוּפְרְשַׁנִי מִמָּךְ״, ״מְרוּחֲקַנִי מִמָּךְ״, ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״, ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״ — אָסוּר.
human_translation: one who says to another: I am avowed from you, I am separated from you, I am distanced from you, That I eat yours, That I taste yours, forbidden.
llm_translation: One who says to his fellow, "You have made me a nazarite from you," "You have separated me from you," "You have distanced me from you," "That I will eat for you," "That I will taste for you" — it is prohibited.

hebrew_text: ״מְנוּדֶּה אֲנִי לָךְ״, רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הָיָה חוֹכֵךְ בָּזֶה לְהַחְמִיר.
human_translation: I am ostracized from you, Rabbi Akiva was uncertain to rule stringently about this
llm_translation: "I am a m'nudeh for you," Rabbi Akiva was arguing on this to be stringent.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ ״כָּל כִּינּוּיֵי נְדָרִים כִּנְדָרִים״, מַאי שְׁנָא גַּבֵּי נָזִיר דְּלָא קָתָנֵי לְהוּ לְכוּלְּהוּ, וּמַאי שְׁנָא גַּבֵּי נְדָרִים דְּקָתָנֵי לְכוּלְּהוּ?
human_translation: all substitutes of vows are like vows, What is different with regard to Nazir that it does not teach all of them, and what is different with regard to Nedarim that it teaches all of them
llm_translation: Gemara: "All designations of vows are like vows," what is the difference between a Nazirite vow, which does not teach for all of them, and a regular vow, which does teach for all of them?

hebrew_text: מִשּׁוּם דְּנֶדֶר וּשְׁבוּעָה כְּתִיבִי גַּבֵּי הֲדָדֵי תָּנֵי תַּרְתֵּין, וְכֵיוָן דְּתָנֵי תַּרְתֵּין — תָּנֵי לְכוּלְּהוּ.
human_translation: due to vows and oaths are written next to each other teaches two And since it taught two it taught all of them.
llm_translation: Due to the fact that regarding a vow and an oath it is written, in the matter of Hadadei, he taught two, and once he taught two - he taught for all of them.

hebrew_text: וְלִיתְנֵי כִּינּוּיֵי שְׁבוּעוֹת בָּתַר נְדָרִים! אַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא נְדָרִים דְּמִיתְּסַר חֶפְצָא עֲלֵיהּ, תְּנָא נָמֵי חֲרָמִים, דְּמִיתְּסַר חֶפְצָא עֲלֵיהּ. לְאַפּוֹקֵי שְׁבוּעָה, דְּקָאָסַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ מִן חֶפְצָא.
human_translation: let teach substitutes of oaths after vows. Since it taught vows, whereby an object becomes forbidden to one, taught also dedications, whereby an object becomes forbidden to one. to the exclusion of an oath, one prohibits himself from an object.
llm_translation: And to teach the designations of oaths after vows! For it was taught: Vows, which involve the restriction of one's desire, are also designated as cherem, which involve the restriction of one's desire. To come to an oath, which restricts oneself from one's desire.

hebrew_text: פְּתַח בְּכִינּוּיִין ״כָּל כִּנּוּיַי נְדָרִים״, וּמְפָרֵשׁ יָדוֹת: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״מוּדָּר אֲנִי מִמָּךְ״! וְתוּ: יָדוֹת אִינְּשִׁי?!
human_translation: began with substitutes All substitutes of vows and explains intimations one who says to his fellow: I am avowed from you. And furthermore, forget intimations
llm_translation: He began with designations "all my designations are vows," and he explains: one who says to his fellow, "I am vowed from you!" And furthermore: are designations human hands?!

hebrew_text: אַיְירִי בְּהוֹן, וְחַסּוֹרֵי מִיחַסְּרָא, וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: כָּל כִּינּוּיֵי נְדָרִים כִּנְדָרִים, וִידוֹת נְדָרִים כִּנְדָרִים.
human_translation: is dealing with them, and is incomplete and is teaching the following: All substitutes of vows are like vows, and intimations of vows are like vows.
llm_translation: אַיְירִי - the ones who say, בְּהוֹן - and they, וְחַסּוֹרֵי - and the ones who lack, מִיחַסְּרָא - from the lacking, וְהָכִי - and thus, קָתָנֵי - it is taught: כָּל - all, כִּינּוּיֵי - designations, נְדָרִים - of vows, כִּנְדָרִים - are like vows, וִידוֹת - and expressions, נְדָרִים - of vows, כִּנְדָרִים - are like vows.

hebrew_text: וְלִיפְרוֹשׁ כִּינּוּיִין בְּרֵישָׁא!
human_translation: Let explain substitutes first,
llm_translation: And to explain the designations at the outset!

hebrew_text: הָהוּא דְּסָלֵיק מִינֵּיהּ, הָהוּא מְפָרֵשׁ בְּרֵישָׁא. כְּדִתְנַן: בַּמֶּה מַדְלִיקִין וּבַמָּה אֵין מַדְלִיקִין? אֵין מַדְלִיקִין כּוּ׳.
human_translation: the with which it concludes is the one that it explains first, as we learned With what may one light and with what may one not light One may not light etc.
llm_translation: That one who ascended from him, that one explained at the beginning. As we learned: With what may one kindle a fire, and with what may one not kindle a fire? One may not kindle with...

hebrew_text: בַּמֶּה טוֹמְנִין וּבַמָּה אֵין טוֹמְנִין? אֵין טוֹמְנִין כּוּ׳. בַּמָּה אִשָּׁה יוֹצְאָה וּבַמָּה אֵינָהּ יוֹצְאָה? לֹא תֵּצֵא אִשָּׁה.
human_translation: In what may one insulate and in what may one not insulate One may not insulate etc. With what may a woman go out and with what may she not go out? A woman may not go out
llm_translation: In what are we allowed to carry on Shabbat, and in what are we not allowed to carry? We are not allowed to carry in a cavity of ten handbreadths. In what way is a woman permitted to go out on Shabbat, and in what way is she not permitted to go out? A woman shall not go out carrying an item.

hebrew_text: וְכׇל הֵיכָא דְּפָתַח לָא מְפָרֵשׁ בְּרֵישָׁא? וְהָתְנַן: יֵשׁ נוֹחֲלִין וּמַנְחִילִין, נוֹחֲלִין וְלֹא מַנְחִילִין. וְאֵלּוּ נוֹחֲלִין וּמַנְחִילִין.
human_translation: And wherever it begins, it does not explain first? But didn’t we learn There are inherit and bequeath, inherit but do not bequeath, and these inherit and bequeath,
llm_translation: And every place that opens does not explain at the beginning? And we learned: There are inheritors and those who cause inheritance, inheritors but do not cause inheritance. And these are the inheritors and those who cause inheritance.

hebrew_text: יֵשׁ מוּתָּרוֹת לְבַעֲלֵיהֶן וַאֲסוּרוֹת לְיִבְמֵיהֶן, מוּתָּרוֹת לְיִבְמֵיהֶן וַאֲסוּרוֹת לְבַעֲלֵיהֶן. וְאֵלּוּ מוּתָּרוֹת לְבַעֲלֵיהֶן וַאֲסוּרוֹת לְיִבְמֵיהֶן.
human_translation: There are permitted to their husbands and forbidden to their yevamin , permitted to their yevamin but forbidden to their husbands, And these are permitted to their husbands and forbidden to their yevamin .
llm_translation: There are those permitted to their husbands and forbidden to their brothers-in-law, permitted to their brothers-in-law and forbidden to their husbands. And these are permitted to their husbands and forbidden to their brothers-in-law.

hebrew_text: יֵשׁ טְעוּנוֹת שֶׁמֶן וּלְבוֹנָה, שֶׁמֶן וְלֹא לְבוֹנָה. וְאֵלּוּ טְעוּנוֹת שֶׁמֶן וּלְבוֹנָה. יֵשׁ טְעוּנוֹת הַגָּשָׁה וְאֵין טְעוּנוֹת תְּנוּפָה, תְּנוּפָה וְלֹא הַגָּשָׁה. וְאֵלּוּ טְעוּנוֹת הַגָּשָׁה.
human_translation: There are require oil and frankincense oil but not frankincense. And these require oil and frankincense. There are require bringing near, and do not require waving; waving but not bringing near. And these require bringing near.
llm_translation: There are requirements of oil and frankincense, oil without frankincense. And these are the requirements of oil and frankincense. There are requirements of bringing near and no requirements of waving, waving without bringing near. And these are the requirements of bringing near.

hebrew_text: יֵשׁ בְּכוֹר לְנַחֲלָה וְאֵין בְּכוֹר לְכֹהֵן, בְּכוֹר לְכֹהֵן וְאֵין בְּכוֹר לְנַחֲלָה. וְאֵיזֶהוּ בְּכוֹר לְנַחֲלָה וְאֵין בְּכוֹר לְכֹהֵן!
human_translation: There are firstborn with regard to inheritance, and not firstborn with regard to a priest, firstborn with regard to a priest and are not firstborn with regard to inheritance. And who is firstborn with regard to inheritance not a firstborn with regard to a priest?
llm_translation: There is a firstborn for inheritance, and there is no firstborn for a Kohen; a firstborn for a Kohen, and there is no firstborn for inheritance. And who is a firstborn for inheritance, and there is no firstborn for a Kohen!

hebrew_text: הָלֵין, מִשּׁוּם דְּאָוְושׁוּ לֵיהּ, מְפָרֵשׁ הָהוּא דְּפָתַח בְּרֵישָׁא.
human_translation: these because there are many [ avshu ] explains which it began first.
llm_translation: Those, because they were embarrassed for him, explained that which he began with initially.

hebrew_text: וְהָא בַּמֶּה בְּהֵמָה יוֹצְאָה וּבַמָּה אֵינָהּ יוֹצְאָה דְּלָא אָוְושָׁא, וְקָתָנֵי: יוֹצֵא גָּמָל!
human_translation: Didn’t With what may an animal go out and with what may it not go out? that does not have many and teaches: A camel may go out
llm_translation: And this, in what case an animal goes out, and in what case it does not go out, because it is not a burden, and it is taught: It goes out even a camel!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו דַּוְוקָא: זִימְנִין מְפָרֵשׁ הָהוּא דִּפְתַח בְּרֵישָׁא, זִימְנִין הָהוּא דְּסָלֵיק מְפָרֵשׁ בְּרֵישָׁא. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: יָדוֹת אַיְּידֵי דְּאָתְיָין מִדְּרָשָׁא, מְפָרֵשׁ לְהוֹן בְּרֵישָׁא.
human_translation: Rather, not particular Sometimes it explains first that it began, sometimes it explains first that with which finished. And if you wish, say intimations, since they are derived from exposition explains them first.
llm_translation: Rather, not specifically: sometimes he explains that which he began with initially, sometimes he explains that which he concludes with. And if you wish, say: the hands are the witnesses that come from the study hall, he explains to them initially.

hebrew_text: וְלִיפְתַּח הָדֵין בְּרֵישָׁא! מִיפְתָּח פָּתַח בְּכִינּוּיִין דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא בְּרֵישָׁא, וַהֲדַר מְפָרֵשׁ יָדוֹת דְּאָתְיָין לֵיהּ מִדְּרָשָׁא.
human_translation: let him begin with that, first. begins with substitutes in the Torah, in the first clause, and then explains intimations, which are derived from exposition
llm_translation: And to Iftach the judge in the beginning! From Iftach he began with the designations of the Torah in the beginning, and then he explained the hands that come to him from the Midrash.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר כִּינּוּיִין לְשׁוֹן נָכְרִים הֵן. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר לָשׁוֹן שֶׁבָּדוּ לָהֶן חֲכָמִים לִהְיוֹת נוֹדֵר בּוֹ, מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: This works out well according to the one who said substitutes are foreign language. However, according to the one who says language that the Sages invented to vow what can be said?
llm_translation: He left it for the one who said that kinuyin are foreign language. Rather, for the one who said that the language that the Sages made vows in, what is there to say?

hebrew_text: מִי קָתָנֵי יָדוֹת? וְלָאו חַסּוֹרֵי קָא מְחַסְּרַתְּ לַהּ? אַקְדֵּים נָמֵי וּתְנִי יָדוֹת: כָּל יְדוֹת נְדָרִים כִּנְדָרִים, וְכׇל כִּינּוּיֵי נְדָרִים כִּנְדָרִים, וְאֵלּוּ הֵן יָדוֹת: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ, וְאֵלּוּ הֵן כִּינּוּיִין: קֻוֽנָּם, קוּנָּח, קוּנָּס.
human_translation: Does teach intimations Do you not consider it incomplete, also precede and teach intimations All intimations of vows are like vows, and all substitutes of vows are like vows. And these are intimations: One who says to his fellow: And these are substitutes Konam , konaḥ , konas .
llm_translation: Who is the one who enumerates hands? But isn't it lacking that she is lacking? Let us establish and teach hands: all hands of vows like vows, and all designations of vows like vows, and these are hands: one who says to his fellow, and these are designations: kunnam, kunnach, kunnas.

hebrew_text: וְיָדוֹת הֵיכָא כְּתִיב? ״אִישׁ כִּי יַפְלִא לִנְדֹּר נֶדֶר נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר לַה׳״, וְתַנְיָא: ״נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר״ — לַעֲשׂוֹת כִּינּוּיֵי נְזִירוּת כִּנְזִירוּת, וִידוֹת נְזִירוּת כִּנְזִירוּת.
human_translation: And where are intimations written, “When a man shall clearly utter a vow, the vow of a nazirite [ nazir ], to consecrate [ lehazir ] himself to the Lord” And it was taught “ nazir lehazir ” to render substitutes of nazirite like nazirite and intimations of nazirite like nazirite
llm_translation: The Talmudic text states: "And where are hands written? 'If a man makes a special vow of dedication to the Lord as a nazirite,'" and it was taught: "'nazirite to be a nazirite' - to make the designations of naziriteship like naziriteship, and the hands of naziriteship like naziriteship."

hebrew_text: אֵין לִי אֶלָּא בִּנְזִירוּת, בִּנְדָרִים מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אִישׁ כִּי יַפְלִא לִנְדֹּר נֶדֶר נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר לַה׳״, מַקִּישׁ נְזִירוּת לִנְדָרִים וּנְדָרִים לִנְזִירוּת; מָה נְזִירוּת עָשָׂה בּוֹ יְדוֹת נְזִירוּת כִּנְזִירוּת — אַף נְדָרִים עָשָׂה בָּהֶם יְדוֹת נְדָרִים כִּנְדָרִים.
human_translation: I have only nazirite from where vows? The verse states: “When a man shall clearly utter a vow, the vow of a nazirite, to consecrate himself to the Lord.” juxtaposes nazirite to vows and vows to nazirite Just as nazirite rendered intimations of nazirite like nazirite so too, vows, it rendered intimations of vows like vows.
llm_translation: I have only in Naziriteship, where do we derive vows from? The Torah states: "When a man makes a vow, the vow of a Nazirite to separate for the Lord." It compares Naziriteship to vows and vows to Naziriteship; just as Naziriteship involves the restrictions of Naziriteship, so too vows involve the restrictions of vows.

hebrew_text: וּמָה נְדָרִים עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל יַחֵל״. וּבְ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״ — אַף נְזִירוּת עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל יַחֵל״ וּבְ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״. וּמָה נְדָרִים הָאָב מֵיפֵר נִדְרֵי בִתּוֹ וּבַעַל מֵיפֵר נִדְרֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ — אַף נְזִירוּת הָאָב מֵיפֵר נְזִירוּת בִּתּוֹ וּבַעַל מֵיפֵר נְזִירוּת אִשְׁתּוֹ.
human_translation: And just as vows, transgresses He shall not profane and You shall not delay so too, nazirite he transgresses He shall not profane, and You shall not delay. And just as vows, a father may nullify the vows of his daughter and a husband may nullify the vows of his wife, so too, nazirite a father may nullify the nazirite of his daughter and a husband may nullify the nazirite of his wife.
llm_translation: And what vows does one transgress with "Bavel Yachel" (Babylon will be destroyed)? And with "Bavel Te'acher" (Babylon will be delayed) - also Naziriteship transgresses with "Bavel Yachel" and with "Bavel Te'acher." And what vows does a father annul of his daughter, and a husband annuls the vows of his wife - also Naziriteship, a father annuls the Naziriteship of his daughter, and a husband annuls the Naziriteship of his wife.

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא גַּבֵּי נְזִירוּת דִּכְתִיב ״נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר״, נְדָרִים נָמֵי הָא כְּתִיב ״לִנְדֹּר נֶדֶר״, וְהֶיקֵּישָׁא לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: What is different with regard to nazirite which it is written “ nazir lehazir ,” vows as well it is written: “To utter a vow [ lindor neder ],” Why do I the juxtaposition
llm_translation: What is the difference regarding Naziriteship, as it is written "a Nazirite to consecrate himself," and regarding vows, as it is written "to vow a vow," and why were they juxtaposed to each other?

hebrew_text: אִי כְּתַב ״נֶדֶר לִנְדֹּר״ כְּדִכְתַב ״נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר״ — כִּדְקָאָמְרַתְּ, לָא צָרִיךְ הֶיקֵּישָׁא. הַשְׁתָּא דִּכְתִיב ״לִנְדֹּר נֶדֶר״, דִּבְּרָה תוֹרָה כִלְשׁוֹן בְּנֵי אָדָם.
human_translation: If had written: A vow to utter [ neder lindor ], as it wrote a nazirite, to consecrate himself [ nazir lehazir ],” as you said, there no need for the juxtaposition. Now that it is written: “To utter a vow [ lindor neder ],” the Torah spoke in the language of men,
llm_translation: If one wrote "nedar lindor" as it is written "nazir lehazir" - as you said, it is not necessary to make a comparison. Now that it is written "lin'dor neder," the Torah spoke in the language of people.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּאִית לֵיהּ דִּבְּרָה תּוֹרָה כִּלְשׁוֹן בְּנֵי אָדָם, אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּלֵית לֵיהּ דִּבְּרָה תּוֹרָה כִּלְשׁוֹן בְּנֵי אָדָם, הַאי ״לִנְדֹּר נֶדֶר״ מַאי עָבֵיד לֵיהּ? דָּרֵישׁ לֵיהּ: לַעֲשׂוֹת יְדוֹת נְדָרִים כִּנְדָרִים, וּמַקִּישׁ נְזִירוּת לִנְדָרִים. ״נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר״ דָּרֵישׁ לֵיהּ: מְלַמֵּד
human_translation: This works out well according to the one who holds the Torah spoke in the language of men, but according to the one who does not hold the Torah spoke in the language of men, What does he do with this “To utter a vow [ lindor neder ]”? He expounds it to render intimations of vows like vows And juxtaposes nazirite to vows a nazirite, to consecrate himself [ nazir lehazir ],” he expounds: teaches
llm_translation: The one who has the Torah, speak it like the language of people, but the one who does not have the Torah, speak it not like the language of people. What does this "to vow a vow" do for him? It teaches to make the hands of vows like vows, and it compares Naziriteship to vows. "A Nazirite to be a Nazirite" it teaches, instructing.

hebrew_text: שֶׁהַנְּזִירוּת חָל עַל הַנְּזִירוּת.
human_translation: that a naziriteship takes effect upon a naziriteship.
llm_translation: The Naziriteship takes effect upon the Naziriteship.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר דִּבְּרָה תּוֹרָה כִּלְשׁוֹן בְּנֵי אָדָם, וְ״נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר״ דָּרֵישׁ לַעֲשׂוֹת יְדוֹת נְזִירוּת כִּנְזִירוּת, שֶׁהַנְּזִירוּת חָל עַל הַנְּזִירוּת מְנָא לֵיהּ? הָנִיחָא אִי סְבִירָא לֵיהּ כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר אֵין נְזִירוּת חָל עַל נְזִירוּת. אֶלָּא אִי סְבִירָא לֵיהּ כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר נְזִירוּת חָל עַל נְזִירוּת, מְנָא לֵיהּ?
human_translation: And according to the one who says that the Torah spoke in the language of men and he expounds “the vow of a nazirite to consecrate himself [ nazir lehazir ]” to render intimations of nazirite like nazirite from where does he naziriteship takes effect upon a naziriteship? This works out well if he holds in accordance with the one who says naziriteship does not take effect upon a naziriteship; however, if he holds in accordance with the one who says naziriteship takes effect upon a naziriteship, from where does he
llm_translation: And for the one who says that the Torah spoke in the language of people, and "Nazir to Nazir" expounds to make the laws of Naziriteship like Naziriteship, how does he derive that Naziriteship takes effect upon another Naziriteship? If it is satisfactory to him like the one who says that one Naziriteship does not take effect upon another Naziriteship, but if it is satisfactory to him like the one who says that one Naziriteship does take effect upon another Naziriteship, how does he derive it?

hebrew_text: נֵימָא קְרָא ״לִיזּוֹר״, מַאי ״לְהַזִּיר״ שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ תַּרְתֵּי.
human_translation: Let the verse say: To consecrate himself [ lizor ]. What lehazir ? Learn two from this:
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: "Neima kra 'lizor', mai 'lehazir' shamat minah tartei." English translation: "It was stated: The verse says 'to crown,' what is 'to adorn'? You have heard two from it."

hebrew_text: בְּמַעְרְבָא אָמְרִי: אִית תַּנָּא דְּמַפֵּיק לֵיהּ לְיָדוֹת מִן ״לִנְדֹּר נֶדֶר״, וְאִית תַּנָּא דְּמַפֵּיק לֵיהּ, מִן ״כְּכׇל הַיֹּצֵא מִפִּיו יַעֲשֶׂה״.
human_translation: In the West, say: There is a tanna who derives intimations from “to utter a vow [ lindor neder ],” And there is a tanna who derives this from “He shall do according to all that proceeds out of his mouth”
llm_translation: In the West they say: There is a Tanna who derives it from "to fulfill a vow," and there is a Tanna who derives it from "he shall do according to all that proceeds out of his mouth."

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: וּמָה נְדָרִים עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל יַחֵל״, וּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״. בִּשְׁלָמָא ״בַּל יַחֵל״ דִּנְדָרִים מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ, כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר כִּכָּר זוֹ אוֹכַל וְלֹא אֲכָלָהּ — עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: The Master said Just as vows, one transgresses He shall not profane, and You shall not delay, Granted, you find where He shall not profane, in vows. For example, where one said: I will eat this loaf, and he does not eat it, he violates He shall not profane his word.
llm_translation: Master said: And what vows transgress "do not delay" and "do not violate"? Regarding "do not delay," vows that one forgets, for example, if one says, "This loaf I will eat," and does not eat it - he transgresses because of "do not delay in fulfilling his word."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא ״בַּל יַחֵל״ דִּנְזִירוּת הֵיכִי מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ? כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״ הָוֵה לֵיהּ נָזִיר. אֲכַל — קָם לֵיהּ בְּ״בַל יֹאכַל״. שְׁתָה — קָם לֵיהּ בְּ״בַל יִשְׁתֶּה״. אָמַר רָבָא: לַעֲבוֹר עָלָיו בִּשְׁנַיִם.
human_translation: However, He shall not profane, in nazirite how can you find these Once he said: I am hereby a nazirite, he is a nazirite ate he is liable for He shall not eat drank he is liable for He shall not drink Rava said: to render him liable for two
llm_translation: Rather, "Bal Yachel," how does one find a Nazirite vow? Since he said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite," he becomes a Nazirite. If he eats - it stands for him in "Bal Yochal." If he drinks - it stands for him in "Bal Yishteh." Rava said: To transgress upon it in two ways.

hebrew_text: ״בַּל תְּאַחֵר״ דִּנְזִירוּת הֵיכִי מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ? כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״ הָוֵי לֵיהּ נָזִיר. אֲכַל — קָם לֵיהּ בְּ״בַל יֹאכַל״? בְּאוֹמֵר ״לִכְשֶׁאֶרְצֶה אֱהֵא נָזִיר״. וְאִי אָמַר ״כְּשֶׁאֶרְצֶה״ לֵיכָּא ״בַּל תְּאַחֵר״!
human_translation: You shall not delay, in nazirite how can you find these Once he said: I am hereby a nazirite, he is a nazirite ate he is liable for He shall not eat. when he says: I will become a nazirite when I wish, But if he said: When I wish, there is no You shall not delay,
llm_translation: "Do not delay" - how does one forget about the vow of Naziriteship? Since he said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite," he becomes a Nazirite. If he eats - does he fulfill it with "he shall not eat"? Rather, he says, "When I desire, I shall be a Nazirite." And if he does not say, "when I desire," there is no "do not delay"!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר ״לֹא אִיפָּטֵר מִן הָעוֹלָם עַד שֶׁאֱהֵא נָזִיר״, דְּמִן הָהִיא שַׁעְתָּא הָוֵה לֵיהּ נָזִיר. מִידֵּי דְּהָוֵה הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשְׁתּוֹ ״הֲרֵי זוֹ גִּיטֵּיךְ שָׁעָה אַחַת קוֹדֶם מִיתָתִי״ — אֲסוּרָה לֶאֱכוֹל בִּתְרוּמָה מִיָּד. אַלְמָא אָמְרִינַן כֹּל שַׁעְתָּא וְשַׁעְתָּא דִּילְמָא מָיֵית. הָכָא נָמֵי, לְאַלְתַּר הָוֵי נָזִיר. דְּאָמְרִינַן: דִּילְמָא הַשְׁתָּא מָיֵית.
human_translation: Rava said: for example, when he said: I will not depart the world until I become a nazirite, as he is a nazirite from that time just as it is who says to his wife: This is your bill of divorce one hour before my death. she is prohibited from partaking of teruma immediately. Apparently, we say every moment perhaps he is dead Here, too, he is a nazirite immediately, as we say perhaps he is now die.
llm_translation: Rava said: For example, one who says, "I will not become a Nazirite until I become a Nazirite," for at that moment he becomes a Nazirite. As soon as one says to his wife, "Behold, this is your bill of divorce, one hour before my death," she is immediately forbidden to eat Terumah. This proves that we say, "Perhaps you will die at any moment." Here too, immediately become a Nazirite. For we say: Perhaps you will die now.

hebrew_text: רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב אָמַר: כְּגוֹן דִּנְדַר וְהוּא בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: where one vowed while he was in a cemetery.
llm_translation: Rav Acha bar Yaakov said: For example, if one takes a vow while in the cemetery.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר לָא חָיְילָא עֲלֵיהּ נְזִירוּת מֵאַלְתַּר. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מֵאַלְתַּר חָיְילָא עֲלֵיהּ, מִי אִיכָּא ״בַּל תְּאַחֵר״? וְעוֹד: הָאָמַר מָר בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי: חָיְילָא נְזִירוּת עֲלֵיהּ מֵאַלְתַּר, וְכִי פְּלִיגִי — לְעִנְיַן מַלְקוֹת פְּלִיגִי!
human_translation: This works out well according to the one who says the naziriteship does not apply to him immediately. However, according to the one who said applies to him immediately, is there a You shall not delay? And furthermore, didn’t Mar bar Rav Ashi say naziriteship applies to him immediately and when they disagree with regard to the matter of flogging, disagree,
llm_translation: He left it for the one who said: the prohibition of nezirut does not apply to it. Rather, for the one who said the prohibition of nezirut does apply to it, is there not "do not delay"? And furthermore, Mar Bar Rav Ashi said: the prohibition of nezirut does not apply to it, and when do they argue? They argue regarding the matter of lashes!

hebrew_text: אֲפִילּוּ הָכִי קָם לֵיהּ בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״, מִשּׁוּם דְּקָא מְאַחַר נְזִירוּת דְּטָהֳרָה. אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: הוֹאִיל וְכֵן, נָזִיר שֶׁטִּימֵּא עַצְמוֹ בְּמֵזִיד — עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תְּאַחֵר״ דִּנְזִירוּת טָהֳרָה.
human_translation: Even so, he is liable for You shall not delay, because he delays a naziriteship of ritual purity. Rav Ashi said: Since this is so, a nazirite who intentionally renders himself ritually impure violates You shall not delay, a naziriteship of ritual purity,
llm_translation: Even so, he is liable for "do not delay," because he is delaying the completion of his purification vow. Rav Ashe said: Since this is the case, a Nazirite who intentionally delays fulfilling his vow transgresses the prohibition of delaying the completion of his purification vow.

hebrew_text: רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִיקָא אָמַר: עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״ תִּגְלַחְתּוֹ.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, stated he violates You shall not delay, his shaving.
llm_translation: Rav Ahah son of Rav Ika said: One who passes through Babylon should delay his haircut.

hebrew_text: וְלָא מִיבַּעְיָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר תִּגְלַחַת מְעַכֶּבֶת, אֶלָּא אֲפִילּוּ לְמַאן דְּאָמַר תִּגְלַחַת אֵינָהּ מְעַכֶּבֶת, מִצְוַת גִּילּוּחַ מִיהָא לָא מְיקַיֵּים.
human_translation: And is not necessary according to the one who says shaving is indispensable but even according to the one who says shaving is not indispensable at least he does not fulfill the mitzva of shaving
llm_translation: And not it-is-necessary for-who that-said shaving inhibits, but even for-who that-said shaving does-not inhibit, the-commandment of-shaving from-her not fulfilled.

hebrew_text: מָר זוּטְרָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב מָרִי אָמַר: עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״ קָרְבְּנוֹתָיו.
human_translation: Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, stated He transgresses You shall not delay, his offerings.
llm_translation: Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said: One who passes through Babylon should delay his sacrifices.

hebrew_text: וּמִן הָכָא נָפְקָא לֵיהּ? מֵהָתָם נָפְקָא לֵיהּ: ״כִּי דָרֹשׁ יִדְרְשֶׁנּוּ״ — אֵלּוּ חַטָּאֹת וַאֲשָׁמוֹת!
human_translation: Is this derived from here, It is derived from there, will surely require it Those are sin-offerings and guilt-offerings,
llm_translation: And from here it derived for him? From there it derived for him: "For he shall surely be inquired after" - these are the sin offerings and guilt offerings!

hebrew_text: מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: חִידּוּשׁ הוּא שֶׁחִידְּשָׁה תּוֹרָה בְּנָזִיר.
human_translation: lest you say that a novelty that the Torah innovated with regard to a nazirite
llm_translation: What is the reasoning: it is a novelty that the Torah innovated regarding a Nazirite.

hebrew_text: מַאי חִידּוּשׁ? אִילֵּימָא דְּלָא מַתְפֵּיס לַיהּ לְחַטַּאת נָזִיר בְּנֶדֶר. הֲרֵי חַטַּאת חֵלֶב, שֶׁאֵין מַתְפִּיסָהּ בְּנֶדֶר, וְעוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״!
human_translation: What is the novelty If we say that he cannot accept himself the sin-offering of a nazirite through a vow, the sin-offering of forbidden fat, which one cannot accept through a vow, and one transgresses You shall not delay,
llm_translation: What is the novelty? Perhaps that one cannot bring a sin offering for a Nazirite vow. Behold, a sin offering is of fat, which cannot be brought for a vow, and one transgresses "do not delay"!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: מַאי חִידּוּשֵׁיהּ — סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וְאִם אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״ אֲפִילּוּ מִן חַרְצָן — הָוֵי נָזִיר לַכֹּל, אֵימָא לָא לַיעֲבוֹר עֲלֵיהּ מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תְּאַחֵר״ — קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Rather, what is its novelty enter your mind to say since if he said: I am hereby a nazirite, even from grape seeds, he is a nazirite with regard to all say he does not transgress You shall not delay. teaches us
llm_translation: Rather: What is the novelty of this? I would say: Since if one were to say, "Behold, I am a Nazirite," even from his thoughts, he becomes a Nazirite for everyone, lest one say that he should not transgress it due to "do not delay" - this teaches us.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר כִּי נָזִיר מִן חַרְצָן הָוֵי נָזִיר לַכֹּל, אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן דְּאָמַר אֵין נָזִיר עַד שֶׁיַּזִּיר מִכּוּלָּן — מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר? וְעוֹד: הַאי חִידּוּשׁ לְחוּמְרָא הוּא!
human_translation: This works out well according to the one who said when a nazirite from grape seeds he is a nazirite in all However, according to Rabbi Shimon, who said he is not a nazirite unless he vows to be a nazirite in all what is there to say? And furthermore, this novelty is stringent
llm_translation: He left it for the one who says: When a Nazirite abstains from wine, he is a Nazirite for all, except for Rabbi Shimon who says: A person is not a Nazirite until he abstains from all of them - what can be said? Furthermore, this is a novel stringency!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: מַאי חִידּוּשֵׁיהּ? דְּסָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל
human_translation: Rather, what is its novelty enter your mind to say since
llm_translation: Rather: What are its innovations? Since it has entered your mind, I say: Let it be.

hebrew_text: וְאִם גִּילַּח עַל אַחַת מִשְּׁלׇשְׁתָּן — יָצָא, לָא לַיעֲבוֹר עֲלֵיהּ בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: if he shaves upon one of the three he has fulfilled he does not violate You shall not delay, it teaches us
llm_translation: "And if he shaved on one of the three - he fulfilled his obligation, not to transgress upon it with 'Do not delay,' this teaches us."

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: מַאי חִדּוּשֵׁיהּ — מִשּׁוּם דְּלֹא מַתְפִּיסוֹ בְּנֶדֶר. וְהָא דְּקָא קַשְׁיָא לָךְ חַטַּאת חֵלֶב — חַטַּאת חֵלֶב קָאָתְיָא לְכַפָּרָה. חַטַּאת נָזִיר לְמַאי אָתְיָא?
human_translation: And if you wish say: What is the novelty because cannot be accepted through a vow. And that which a difficulty for you a sin-offering of forbidden fat A sin-offering of forbidden fat comes for atonement, for what does the sin-offering of a nazirite come?
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: What is its novelty? - Because it does not take effect with a vow. And that which is difficult for you, the sin offering of fat - the sin offering of fat comes for atonement. For what purpose does the sin offering of a Nazirite come?

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי חַטַּאת יוֹלֶדֶת דְּלָא אָתְיָא לְכַפָּרָה, וְעָבַר עֲלַהּ מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תְּאַחֵר״! הָהִיא — קָא שָׁרְיָא לַהּ לְמֵיכַל בְּקָדָשִׁים.
human_translation: But the sin-offering of a woman who gave birth, which does not come for atonement, and transgresses due to You shall not delay. That permits to eat consecrated food.
llm_translation: Behold, the sin-offering of a woman after childbirth does not come for atonement, and he transgressed it due to "do not delay"! That one - it is permitted for her to eat from the holy things.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: וּמָה נְדָרִים, הָאָב מֵיפֵר נִדְרֵי בִתּוֹ וּבַעַל מֵיפֵר נִדְרֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ — אַף נְזִירוּת, הָאָב מֵיפֵר נְזִירוּת בִּתּוֹ וּבַעַל מֵיפֵר נְזִירוּת אִשְׁתּוֹ. לְמָה לִי הֶיקֵּשָׁא? תֵּיתֵי בְּ״מָה מָצִינוּ״ מִנְּדָרִים!
human_translation: The Master said Just as vows, a father may nullify the vows of his daughter and a husband may nullify the vows of his wife, so too, nazirite a father may nullify the nazirite of his daughter and a husband may nullify the nazirite of his wife. Why do I the juxtaposition Let come through What do we find, from vows.
llm_translation: Master said: And what about vows, if a father annuls the vows of his daughter and a husband annuls the vows of his wife - so too with regard to Naziriteship, if a father annuls the Naziriteship of his daughter and a husband annuls the Naziriteship of his wife. Why do I need this difficulty? Let it be included in "What have we found" from vows!

hebrew_text: דִּילְמָא גַּבֵּי נְדָרִים הוּא דְּמֵיפַר, מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא אִית לֵיהּ קִיצּוּתָא. אֲבָל גַּבֵּי נְזִירוּת דְּאִית לֵיהּ קִיצּוּתָא, דִּסְתַם נְזִירוּת שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם, אֵימָא לָא — קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: perhaps with regard to vows that he may nullify because there is no limit but with regard to naziriteship, which has a limit, as unspecified naziriteship is thirty days, say no, it teaches us
llm_translation: Perhaps regarding vows, it is that he annuls, because there is no finality to it. But regarding Naziriteship, which has finality to it, for a Nazirite is closed off for thirty days, I might say no — it is not heard for us.

hebrew_text: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ מוּדָּר אֲנִי וְכוּ׳. אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: בְּכוּלָּן עַד שֶׁיֹּאמַר, ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״, ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״.
human_translation: one who says to his fellow: I am avowed Shmuel said: In all until he says: that I eat yours, That I taste yours.
llm_translation: The one who says to his fellow, "I am a nazirite, etc." Samuel said: In all these cases until he says, "that I will eat for you," "that I will taste for you."

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: ״מוּדָּר אֲנִי מִמָּךְ״ ״מוּפְרְשַׁנִי מִמָּךְ״ ״מְרוּחָקֵנִי מִמָּךְ״ — הֲרֵי זֶה אָסוּר. ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״ ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״ — הֲרֵי זֶה אָסוּר! הָכִי קָתָנֵי: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּאוֹמֵר: ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״ ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״.
human_translation: raises an objection I am avowed from you, I am separated from you, I am distanced from you, he is prohibited That I eat yours, That I taste yours, he is prohibited This is what is teaching: In what is this statement said in one who says: That I eat yours, That I taste yours.
llm_translation: The Tanna raises an objection: "I am vowed from you," "I am separated from you," "I am distant from you" — this is prohibited. "That I eat for you," "that I taste for you" — this is prohibited! Thus it was taught: In what case are these matters said? When one says, "that I eat for you," "that I taste for you."

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא אִיפְּכָא: ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״, ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״ — אָסוּר, ״מוּדְּרַנִי מִמָּךְ״ וּ״מוּפְרְשַׁנִי מִמָּךְ״ ״מְרוּחֲקַנִי מִמָּךְ״ — הֲרֵי זֶה אָסוּר! תָּנֵי הָכִי: ״וּכְבָר אָמַר מוּדְּרַנִי״.
human_translation: But isn’t it taught the opposite That I eat yours, That I taste yours, he is prohibited I am avowed from you, or: I am separated from you, I am distanced from you, he is prohibited. Teach as follows: he already said: I am avowed.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught oppositely: "I will eat for you," "I will taste for you" — prohibited, "I am forbidden to you" and "I am separated from you" "I am distanced from you" — this is prohibited! It was taught thus: "And he already said, 'I am forbidden.'"

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, הַיְינוּ רֵישָׁא! וְעוֹד: ״אָסוּר״ ״אָסוּר״ לְמָה לֵיהּ לְמִתְנֵי?
human_translation: If so, this is the first And furthermore, why does teach prohibited prohibited
llm_translation: Thus, this is the same as the beginning! And furthermore: "forbidden" "forbidden" why does it need to teach it?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא, אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״ ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״, הוּא דְּאָסוּר וַחֲבֵירוֹ מוּתָּר.
human_translation: Rather, Shmuel said The reason is he said: that I eat yours, that I taste yours; that he is prohibited and his fellow is permitted
llm_translation: Rather, Shmuel said: The reason for saying "I will eat for you" or "I will taste for you" is that the former is prohibited while the latter is permitted.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל אָמַר ״מוּדְּרַנִי הֵימָךְ״ לְחוֹדֵיהּ — שְׁנֵיהֶן אֲסוּרִין. כִּי הָא דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: ״מוּדְּרַנִי הֵימָךְ״ — שְׁנֵיהֶן אֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: However, he said only: I am avowed from you, they are both prohibited like that which Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: I am avowed from you, they are both prohibited.
llm_translation: "But he said, 'You are forbidden to me' in his presence - both of them are forbidden. For this is what Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina, said: 'You are forbidden to me' - both of them are forbidden."

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: ״הֲרֵינִי עָלֶיךָ חֵרֶם״ — הַמּוּדָּר אָסוּר, אֲבָל מַדִּיר לָא. כְּגוֹן דְּפָרֵישׁ: ״וְאַתְּ עֲלַי לָא״.
human_translation: We learned I am hereby to you dedicated the one to whom the vow was said is prohibited but the one who made the vow is not where he specified And you are not for me.
llm_translation: We learned: "Behold, I am placing upon you a ban" — One who is banned is forbidden, but one who bans is not. For example, as it is stated: "And you are not upon me."

hebrew_text: ״אַתְּ עָלַי חֵרֶם״ — הַנּוֹדֵר אָסוּר, אֲבָל מוּדָּר לָא. כְּגוֹן דְּפָרֵישׁ: ״וַאֲנָא עֲלָךְ לָא״.
human_translation: You are to me dedicated the one who makes the vow is prohibited but the one to whom the vow was said is not where he specified And I am not for you.
llm_translation: "You are under a ban" — One who vows is prohibited, but one who consecrates is not. For example, if one says: "And I am not upon you."

hebrew_text: אֲבָל סְתָמָא מַאי? שְׁנֵיהֶן אֲסוּרִים. הָא מִדְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: ״הֲרֵינִי עָלֶיךָ וְאַתְּ עָלַי״, שְׁנֵיהֶן אֲסוּרִים, הָדֵין הוּא דִּשְׁנֵיהֶם אֲסוּרִין, הָא סְתָמָא — הוּא אָסוּר וַחֲבֵרוֹ מוּתָּר!
human_translation: But unspecified what, are they both prohibited From that it teaches in the latter clause I am hereby to you, and you are to me, they are both prohibited it is in this both are prohibited, but unspecified he is prohibited and the other is permitted
llm_translation: Talmudic text: But what about a case of doubt? Both are forbidden. This is derived from the latter clause: "Behold, I am upon you, and you are upon me." Both are forbidden. Thus, in the same manner, when there is doubt, both are forbidden. But in a case of doubt alone, one is forbidden and his fellow is permitted!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָכִי אִתְּמַר דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: ״מוּדָּר אֲנִי לָךְ״ — שְׁנֵיהֶם אֲסוּרִין, ״מוּדְּרַנִי הֵימָךְ״ — הוּא אָסוּר וַחֲבֵרוֹ מוּתָּר.
human_translation: Rather, this is of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, was stated: I am avowed to you, they are both prohibited I am avowed from you, he is prohibited and the other is permitted
llm_translation: Thus it was stated: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina, said: "I am vowed to you" - both of them are forbidden. "You have vowed me" - he is forbidden, and his companion is permitted.

hebrew_text: וְהָא מַתְנִיתִין דְּקָתָנֵי ״הֵימָךְ״, וְאוֹקִימְנָא לְמַתְנִיתִין לִשְׁמוּאֵל: בְּכוּלָּן עַד שֶׁיֹּאמַר ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״ וְ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״, הוּא דְּאָסוּר וַחֲבֵרוֹ מוּתָּר, אֲבָל בְּ״מוּדְּרַנִי הֵימָךְ״, שְׁנֵיהֶם אֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: But didn’t the mishna teach from you, and we established the mishna, according to Shmuel, in all these it is only he says: That I taste yours, or: That I eat yours, that he is prohibited and the other is permitted? However, I am avowed from you, they are both prohibited.
llm_translation: The Mishnah that states "Heimach," and we establish for the Mishnah according to Shmuel: In all of them until he says, "I am tasting for you" and "I am eating for you," that is what is prohibited and his friend is permitted, but in "Mudrani Heimach," both of them are prohibited.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מֵעִיקָּרָא דִּשְׁמוּאֵל הָכִי אִיתְּמַר: טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״ וְ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״ הוּא דְּאֵין הוּא אָסוּר אֶלָּא בַּאֲכִילָה. הָא ״מוּדְּרַנִי מִמְּךָ״ — אָסוּר אֲפִילּוּ בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: Rather, this is how of Shmuel was originally stated: The reason is that he said: That I eat yours, or: That I taste yours. that he is prohibited only from eating I am avowed from you, he is prohibited even from benefit
llm_translation: Rather, from the outset of Shmuel the Babylonian it was stated: The reason for saying "I will eat for you" and "I will taste for you" is that it is prohibited only in eating. But if one says, "You have obligated me to you," it is prohibited even for benefit.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, לֵימָא שְׁמוּאֵל הָכִי: וְאִם לָא אָמַר אֶלָּא ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״ וְ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״, אֵין אָסוּר אֶלָּא בַּאֲכִילָה.
human_translation: If so, let Shmuel say as follows: And if he said only: That I eat yours, or: That I taste yours, he is prohibited only from eating
llm_translation: If so, let us say: Shmuel says: If he did not say specifically "I am eating for you" and "I am tasting for you," it is only prohibited in eating.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָכִי אִיתְּמַר: טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״ וְ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״, הוּא דְּאָסוּר. אֲבָל אָמַר ״מוּדְּרַנִי הֵימָךְ״ — לָא מַשְׁמַע דְּאָמַר אָסוּר. מַאי טַעְמָא: ״מוּדָּר אֲנִי מִמָּךְ״ — לָא מִשְׁתַּעֵינָא בַּהֲדָךְ מַשְׁמַע. ״מוּפְרְשַׁנִי מִמָּךְ״ — דְּלָא עָבֵידְנָא עִמָּךְ מַשָּׂא וּמַתָּן מַשְׁמַע. ״מְרוּחֲקַנִי מִמָּךְ״ — דְּלָא קָאֵימְנָא בְּאַרְבַּע אַמּוֹת דִּילָךְ מַשְׁמַע.
human_translation: Rather, this is was stated: The reason is that he said: That I eat yours, or: That I taste yours; it is that he is prohibited However, he said I am avowed from you, does not indicate that he said prohibited What is the reason I am avowed from you, indicates: I am not speaking with you. I am separated from you, indicates: I am not doing business with you. I am distanced from you, indicates that I will not stand within four cubits of you.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rather, thus it was stated: The reason for when one says, "I will eat for you" and "I will taste for you," it is prohibited. But if one says, "I am a nazirite for you," it does not imply that it is prohibited. What is the reason? "I am a nazirite from you" - I do not rely on your offering. "I am separated from you" - for we do not engage in transactions with you. "I am distanced from you" - for we are not within four cubits of your produce. English translation:

hebrew_text: לֵימָא קָסָבַר שְׁמוּאֵל יָדַיִם שֶׁאֵין מוֹכִיחוֹת לָא הָוְויָין יָדַיִם? אִין, שְׁמוּאֵל מוֹקֵים לַהּ לְמַתְנִיתִין כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּאָמַר: יָדַיִם שֶׁאֵין מוֹכִיחוֹת לָא הָוְויָין יָדַיִם.
human_translation: shall we say that Shmuel holds ambiguous intimations are not intimations, Yes, Shmuel establishes the mishna in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, who said: Ambiguous intimations are not intimations.
llm_translation: Let us say, did Samuel hold that hands that do not establish are not considered hands? No, Samuel establishes it according to the Mishnah like Rabbi Yehuda, who said: hands that do not establish are considered hands.

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן, גּוּפוֹ שֶׁל גֵּט: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם״. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: ״וְדֵין דְּיֶהֱוֵי לִיכִי מִינַּאי סֵפֶר תֵּירוּכִין וְאִיגֶּרֶת שִׁבּוּקִין״.
human_translation: As we learned The essence of a bill of divorce You are hereby permitted to any man. Rabbi Yehuda says And this shall be to you from me a document of divorce [ teirukhin ] and a letter of dismissal.
llm_translation: We have learned in a Mishnah: The body of a bill of divorce states, "Behold, you are permitted to all men." Rabbi Yehuda says: "And the judgment should be according to my opinion, the Book of Esther, and the letter of manumission."

hebrew_text: אַמַּאי דָּחֵיק שְׁמוּאֵל לְאוֹקוֹמַהּ לְמַתְנִיתִין כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? לוֹקְמַהּ כְּרַבָּנַן אַף עַל גַּב דְּאֵין יָדַיִם מוֹכִיחוֹת?
human_translation: Why Shmuel strain to establish the mishna in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, Let him establish it in accordance with the Rabbis that although there are no obvious intimations
llm_translation: Why did Shmuel insist on establishing it according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda? Let him establish it according to the opinion of the Rabbis, even though the hands do not serve as proof?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מַתְנִיתִין קְשִׁיתֵיהּ; אַמַּאי תָּאנֵי ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״ ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם לָךְ״? לִיתְנֵי ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל״ ״שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם״! שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ בָּעִינַן יָדַיִם מוֹכִיחוֹת.
human_translation: Rava said: The mishna was difficult for him. Why does it teach That I eat yours, That I taste yours? Let it teach: That I eat, That I taste, Conclude from this we require obvious intimations,
llm_translation: Rava said: The Mishnah is stringent; why does it teach "that I eat for you" "that I taste for you"? Let it teach "that I eat" "that I taste"! Learn from it that hands are conclusive.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר, יָדַיִם שֶׁאֵין מוֹכִיחוֹת. אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: הָוְויָין יָדַיִם, וְרָבָא אָמַר: לָא הָוְויָין יָדַיִם. אָמַר רָבָא: רַבִּי אִידִי אַסְבְּרָא לִי: אָמַר קְרָא ״נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר לַה׳״, מַקִּישׁ יְדוֹת נְזִירוּת לִנְזִירוּת. מָה נְזִירוּת בְּהַפְלָאָה — אַף יְדוֹת נְזִירוּת בְּהַפְלָאָה.
human_translation: It was stated ambiguous intimations. Abaye said: They are intimations, and Rava said: They are not intimations. Rava said: Rabbi Idi explained to me The verse states: nazirite, to consecrate himself [ nazir lehazir ] to the Lord” juxtaposes intimations of naziriteship, to naziriteship. just as naziriteship with a distinct articulation, so too, intimations of naziriteship with a distinct articulation
llm_translation: It was stated: hands that do not prove. Abbaye said: they were hands, and Rava said: they were not hands. Rava said: Rabbi Idi reasoned for me: The verse says, "A nazirite to consecrate to the Lord," comparing consecrated hands to consecrated hair. Just as consecrated hair is extraordinary - so too consecrated hands are extraordinary.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא בִּפְלוּגְתָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבָּנַן קָמִיפַּלְגִי? דִּתְנַן: גּוּפוֹ שֶׁל גֵּט ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם״, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: ״וְדֵין דְּיֶהֱוֵי לִיכִי מִינַּאי סֵפֶר תֵּירוּכִין וְגֵט פִּטּוּרִין וְאִיגֶּרֶת שִׁבּוּקִין״. אַבָּיֵי דְּאָמַר כְּרַבָּנַן, וְרָבָא דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה?
human_translation: Let us say that disagree with regard to the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis. As we learned The essence of a bill of divorce You are hereby permitted to any man. Rabbi Yehuda says And this shall be to you from me a document of divorce, a bill of release, and a letter of dismissal. Abaye, said in accordance with the Rabbis, and Rava, said in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Let us say in the dispute of Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis, what is the disagreement? For it was taught: "The body of a bill of divorce states, 'Behold, you are permitted to all men.' Rabbi Yehuda says: 'And the judgment should be according to my opinion, that a document of betrothal, a bill of divorce, and a letter of manumission are valid.' Abaye said in accordance with the Rabbis, and Rava said in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ אַבָּיֵי: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בָּעִינַן יָדַיִם מוֹכִיחוֹת אֶלָּא גַּבֵּי גֵּט, דְּבָעִינַן כְּרִיתוּת, וְלֵיכָּא. אֲבָל בְּעָלְמָא — מִי שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ?
human_translation: Abaye said to you: I say even in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yehuda says we require obvious intimations only with regard to a bill of divorce, as we require severance and there is not However, did you hear him generally
llm_translation: He said to you, Abaye: I, who said even according to Rabbi Yehuda. Until here Rabbi Yehuda did not say that we require hands as proof, but regarding a bill of divorce, where we require cutting, and it is not so. But in general - who would listen to him?

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא אָמַר: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבָּנַן. עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמְרִי רַבָּנַן דְּלָא בָּעִינַן יָדַיִם מוֹכִיחוֹת אֶלָּא גַּבֵּי גֵּט,
human_translation: And Rava said: I say even in accordance with the Rabbis. The Rabbis say that we do not require obvious intimations only with regard to a bill of divorce,
llm_translation: Rava said: I, who said even according to the Rabbis. Until here, the Rabbis did not say that we require hands as proof, but regarding a bill of divorce,

hebrew_text: דְּאֵין אָדָם מְגָרֵשׁ אֶת אֵשֶׁת חֲבֵירוֹ, אֲבָל בְּעָלְמָא — מִי שָׁמְעַתְּ לְהוּ?
human_translation: as a man does not divorce the wife of his fellow, However, did you hear them generally
llm_translation: A person does not divorce the wife of his fellow, but in general — who has heard of such a thing?

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: ״הֲרֵי הוּא עָלַי״, ״הֲרֵי זֶה [עָלַי]״ — אָסוּר, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא יָד לְקׇרְבָּן. טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר ״עָלַי״ — הוּא דְּאָסוּר, אֲבָל לָא אָמַר ״עָלַי״ — לָא. תְּיוּבְתָּא דְאַבָּיֵי!
human_translation: raises an objection It is upon me, This is hereby upon me, is forbidden, because it is an intimation an offering. the reason it is forbidden is he said: Upon me. However, he did not say: Upon me, no, a conclusive refutation of Abaye,
llm_translation: Challenger: "Behold, it is upon me," "Behold, this is upon me" — prohibited, because it is a hand for the offering. The reason he said "upon me" — that is what is prohibited, but if he did not say "upon me" — not. Abaye's clever argument!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ אַבָּיֵי: טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר ״עָלַי״ — הוּא דְּאָסוּר. אֲבָל אָמַר ״הֲרֵי הוּא״, וְלָא אָמַר ״עָלַי״, ״הֲרֵי הוּא דְּהֶפְקֵר״ ״הֲרֵי הוּא דִּצְדָקָה״ קָאָמַר. וְהָא ״מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא יָד לְקׇרְבָּן״ קָתָנֵי!
human_translation: Abaye said to you the reason it is forbidden is said: Upon me. However, he said: It is hereby, and did not say: Upon me, saying: It is hereby ownerless It is hereby charity. But teaches because is an intimation an offering.
llm_translation: He said to you, Abaye: The reason he said "upon me" - it is that it is forbidden. But if he said "behold it is," and did not say "upon me," "behold it is" of hefker (ownerless) or "behold it is" of charity he is saying. And this, "because it is a hand for a sacrifice," it teaches!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אֵימָא: טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר ״עָלַי״ — הוּא אָסוּר וַחֲבֵירוֹ מוּתָּר, אֲבָל אָמַר ״הֲרֵי הוּא״ — שְׁנֵיהֶן אֲסוּרִין, דְּדִלְמָא ״הֲרֵי הוּא הֶקְדֵּשׁ״ קָאָמַר.
human_translation: Rather, say The reason is that he said: Upon me; he is prohibited but another is permitted However, he said: It is hereby, both of them are prohibited because perhaps he is saying: It is hereby consecrated
llm_translation: Rather say: The reason why when it says "עָלַי" — it is forbidden and his fellow is permitted, but when it says "הֲרֵי הוּא" — both are forbidden, perhaps because it is saying "הֲרֵי הוּא is consecrated."

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: ״הֲרֵי זוֹ חַטָּאת״ ״הֲרֵי זוֹ אָשָׁם״, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהוּא חַיָּיב חַטָּאת וְאָשָׁם — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם. ״הֲרֵי זוֹ חַטָּאתִי״ ״הֲרֵי זוֹ אֲשָׁמִי״, אִם הָיָה מְחוּיָּב — דְּבָרָיו קַיָּימִין. תְּיוּבְתָּא דְּאַבָּיֵי!
human_translation: raises an objection This is hereby a sin-offering, This is hereby a guilt-offering, even if he is liable a sin-offering or guilt-offering he has said nothing, This is hereby my sin-offering, This is hereby my guilt-offering, if he was liable his statement takes effect, a conclusive refutation of Abaye.
llm_translation: Challenger: "Here is a sin offering." "Here is a guilt offering." Even though he is liable for both a sin offering and a guilt offering - he did not say anything. "Here is my sin offering." "Here is my guilt offering." If he was obligated - his words stand. The conclusion of Abbaye!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ אַבָּיֵי: הָא מַנִּי — רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא. וְהָא אַבָּיֵי הוּא דְּאָמַר: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי — אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה! הֲדַר בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: Abaye said to you: whose is this It is Rabbi Yehuda, Wasn’t it Abaye who said: I say even according to He retracted
llm_translation: He said to you, Abaye: This is a dispute - it is Rabbi Yehuda. But Abaye is the one who said: I am the one who said - even to Rabbi Yehuda! He retracted.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לֵימָא, רָבָא דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה?
human_translation: But shall we say Rava, who said in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda
llm_translation: Rather, let us say, Rava who said like Rabbi Yehuda?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ רָבָא: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי — אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבָּנַן. עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמְרִי רַבָּנַן דְּלָא בָּעִינַן יָדַיִם מוֹכִיחוֹת אֶלָּא גַּבֵּי גֵּט, דְּאֵין אָדָם מְגָרֵשׁ אֶת אֵשֶׁת חֲבֵירוֹ. אֲבָל בְּעָלְמָא בָּעִינַן יָדַיִם מוֹכִיחוֹת.
human_translation: Rava said to you: I say even according to the Rabbis. The Rabbis say that we do not require obvious intimations only with regard to a bill of divorce, as a man does not divorce the wife of his fellow, However, generally we require obvious intimations.
llm_translation: Rava said to you: I, who said - even to the Rabbis. Until here, the Rabbis did not say that we require demonstrative hands except regarding a bill of divorce, for a person does not divorce his fellow's wife. But generally, we require demonstrative hands.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַב פָּפָּא: יֵשׁ יָד לְקִידּוּשִׁין, אוֹ לָא? הֵיכִי דָמֵי: אִילֵימָא דְּאָמַר לַהּ לְאִשָּׁה ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת לִי״, וְאָמַר לַחֲבֶירְתָּהּ ״וְאַתְּ נָמֵי״ — פְּשִׁיטָא הַיְינוּ קִידּוּשִׁין עַצְמָן! אֶלָּא כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר לַהּ לְאִשָּׁה ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת לִי״, וְאָמַר לַהּ לַחֲבֶירְתָּהּ ״וְאַתְּ״. מִי אָמְרִינַן ״וְאַתְּ נָמֵי״ אֲמַר לַהּ לַחֲבֶירְתָּהּ, וְתָפְסִי בַּהּ קִידּוּשִׁין לַחֲבֶירְתָּהּ, אוֹ דִּלְמָא: ״וְאַתְּ חֲזַאי״ אֲמַר לַהּ לַחֲבֶירְתַּהּ, וְלָא תָּפְסִי בָּהּ קִידּוּשִׁין בַּחֲבֶירְתַּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: Is there intimation for betrothal or not? What are the circumstances If we say where one said to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me, and he said to another And you too, isn’t obvious this is betrothal itself, Rather, where one said to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me, and he said to another And you. Do we say he said the other And you too and betrothal takes effect with regard to the other or perhaps he said to the other And you see and betrothal does not take effect with regard to the other
llm_translation: Inquiries of Rav Pappa: Is there a hand for betrothals, or not? How so? If you will say that he said to her, to a woman, "Behold, you are betrothed to me," and he said to her friend, "And you too" - it is obvious that these are betrothals themselves! Rather, for example, if he said to her, to a woman, "Behold, you are betrothed to me," and he said to her friend, "And you" - do we say that "And you too" he said to her friend, and she should grasp the betrothal for her friend, or perhaps, "And you see" he said to her friend, and she should not grasp the betrothal for her friend.

hebrew_text: וּמִי מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְרַב פָּפָּא? וְהָא מִדַּאֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְאַבָּיֵי: מִי סָבַר שְׁמוּאֵל יָדַיִם שֶׁאֵין מוֹכִיחוֹת הָוְיָין יָדַיִם, מִכְּלָל דִּסְבִירָא לֵיהּ לְרַב פָּפָּא דְּיֵשׁ יָד לְקִידּוּשִׁין! חֲדָא מִגּוֹ מַאי דִּסְבִירָא לֵיהּ לִשְׁמוּאֵל אֲמַר לֵיהּ לְאַבָּיֵי.
human_translation: Did Rav Pappa raise this dilemma? But from that Rav Pappa said to Abaye Does Shmuel hold that ambiguous intimations are intimations, by inference that Rav Pappa holds that there is intimation for betrothal. spoke to Abaye one of that Shmuel held.
llm_translation: And who asks for him to Rav Papa? And this that he said to him Rav Papa to Abbaye: Does Shmuel hold that hands that do not prove are considered hands, from the principle that he holds that there is a hand for sanctifications! One from there, what he holds for Shmuel, he said to him to Abbaye.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַב פָּפָּא: יֵשׁ יָד לְפֵאָה, אוֹ אֵין יָד לְפֵאָה? הֵיכִי דָמֵי: אִילֵימָא דְּאָמַר ״הָדֵין אוּגְיָא לֶיהֱוֵי פֵּאָה, וְהָדֵין נָמֵי״ — הָהִיא פֵּיאָה מְעַלַּיְיתָא הִיא. כִּי קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ, כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר ״וְהָדֵין״ וְלָא אָמַר ״נָמֵי״, מַאי?
human_translation: Rav Pappa raised dilemma: Is there intimation for pe’a , or is there no intimation for pe’a ? What are the circumstances If we say where one said: This furrow [ ugeya ] shall be pe’a and this too, this is full-fledged pe’a . He raises the dilemma where he said: And this, and he did not say: too, What
llm_translation: Inquiries of Rav Pappa: Is there a hand for Pe'ah, or is there no hand for Pe'ah? How so? If you say, "Thus should be Pe'ah, and thus also," that Pe'ah is excessive. When he asks him, for example, if he said "and thus" but did not say "also," what is the law?

hebrew_text: מִכְּלָל, דְּכִי אָמַר ״שָׂדֶה כּוּלָּהּ תֶּיהְוֵי פֵּאָה״, הָוְיָא פֵּאָה?
human_translation: by inference that where one said: The entire field shall be pe’a , pe’a ?
llm_translation: From the principle, that when it said "the entire field shall be for the corner," is it considered a corner?

hebrew_text: אִין, וְהָתַנְיָא: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאִם רוֹצֶה לַעֲשׂוֹת כׇּל שָׂדֵהוּ פֵּאָה — עוֹשֶׂה, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״פְּאַת שָׂדְךָ״.
human_translation: Yes, and it is taught From where that if one wants to render his entire field pe’a , do The verse states: the corner of your field”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Ein, vehatanya: minayin she'im rotzeh la'asot kol sadehu pe'ah - oseh, talmud lomar: 'pe'at sadekha'." English translation: "No, and it was taught: From where do we know that if one wants to make all of his field pe'ah - he may do so, as the Scripture states: 'The corner of your field'."

hebrew_text: מִי אָמְרִינַן: כֵּיוָן דְּאִיתַּקַּשׁ לְקׇרְבְּנוֹת; מָה קׇרְבָּנוֹת יֵשׁ לָהֶם יָד, אַף פֵּאָה יֵשׁ לָהּ יָד. אוֹ דִלְמָא: כִּי אִיתַּקַּשׁ — לְ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״ הוּא דְּאִיתַּקַּשׁ. וְהֵיכָא אִיתַּקַּשׁ? דְּתַנְיָא:
human_translation: Do we say since juxtaposed to offerings, just as offerings have intimation, so too, pe’a has intimation? Or perhaps when it is juxtaposed to You shall not delay? And where is it juxtaposed? As it is taught
llm_translation: We say: Since they are connected to sacrifices; just as sacrifices have a hand, so too Pe'ah has a hand. Or perhaps: when it is connected — it is connected to "do not delay." And where is it connected? As it was taught:

hebrew_text: ״מֵעִמָּךְ״, זֶה לֶקֶט שִׁכְחָה וּפֵאָה.
human_translation: “of you” This is gleanings, forgotten and pe’a .
llm_translation: "From you," this is gleanings, forgotten sheaves, and corner of the field.

hebrew_text: יֵשׁ יָד לִצְדָקָה, אוֹ אֵין יָד לִצְדָקָה? הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵימָא דְּאָמַר: ״הָדֵין זוּזָא לִצְדָקָה, וְהָדֵין נָמֵי״ — הָהוּא צְדָקָה עַצְמָהּ הִיא! אֶלָּא כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר ״הָדֵין״ וְלָא אָמַר ״נָמֵי״, מַאי? ״הָדֵין נָמֵי צְדָקָה״ קָאָמַר, אוֹ דִּלְמָא [מַאי] ״וְהָדֵין״ (נָמֵי) — לְנַפְקוּתָא בְּעָלְמָא קָאָמַר, וְדִבּוּרָא הוּא דְּלָא אַסְּקֵיהּ.
human_translation: Is there intimation for charity or is there no intimation for charity? What are the circumstances If we say that one said: This dinar is for charity and this also, that itself is charity. Rather, where he said: This, and did not say: Also. What saying: This is also charity, or perhaps what is the meaning of: And this? saying merely for general use, and he did not complete his statement.
llm_translation: There is a hand for righteousness, or is there no hand for righteousness? How so? If you say, "This coin is for righteousness, and this coin also," — that coin itself is righteousness! Rather, for example, if one said "this" and did not say "also," what is it? "This also is righteousness" he is saying, or perhaps "and this" (also) — he is speaking in general terms, and it is a matter that cannot be resolved.

hebrew_text: מִי אָמְרִינַן: כֵּיוָן דְּאִיתַּקַּשׁ לְקׇרְבָּנוֹת, דִּכְתִיב: ״בְּפִיךְ״ — זוֹ צְדָקָה. מָה קׇרְבָּנוֹת יֵשׁ לָהֶן יָד, אַף צְדָקָה יֵשׁ לָהּ יָד. אוֹ דִלְמָא לְ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״ הוּא דְּאִיתַּקַּשׁ?
human_translation: Do we say since juxtaposed to offerings, as it is written with your mouth” this is charity, just as there is intimation, with regard to offerings, so too, there is intimation with regard to charity? Or perhaps You shall not delay, that it is juxtaposed,
llm_translation: We say: Since it is connected to sacrifices, as it is written: "in your mouth" - this refers to charity. Just as sacrifices have hands, so too charity has hands. Or perhaps it is connected to "do not delay"?

hebrew_text: יֵשׁ יָד לְהֶפְקֵר, אוֹ דִלְמָא אֵין יָד לְהֶפְקֵר? הַיְינוּ צְדָקָה!
human_translation: Is there intimation for ownerless, or perhaps there is no intimation for ownerless. This is charity,
llm_translation: There is a hand to declare ownerless, or perhaps there is no hand to declare ownerless? That is charity!

hebrew_text: אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר קָאָמַר. אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר יֵשׁ יָד לִצְדָקָה, דְּאֵין הֶיקֵּשׁ לְמֶחֱצָה. הֶפְקֵר מִי אָמְרִינַן הַיְינוּ צְדָקָה, אוֹ דִּלְמָא שָׁאנֵי צְדָקָה, דִּצְדָקָה לָא חַזְיָא אֶלָּא לַעֲנִיִּים, אֲבָל הֶפְקֵר בֵּין לַעֲנִיִּים בֵּין לַעֲשִׁירִים?
human_translation: stated If you say, If you say there is intimation for charity, as there is no partial juxtaposition, do we say ownerless is charity; or perhaps charity is different, as charity is suitable only for the poor, but ownerless property both the poor and the wealthy,
llm_translation: If you find to say, he said. If you find to say, there is a hand for righteousness, for it is not difficult halfway. Who said it is hefker that we say this is righteousness, or perhaps it is different righteousness, for righteousness is only seen for the poor, but hefker, whether for the poor or for the rich?

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָבִינָא: יֵשׁ יָד לְבֵית הַכִּסֵּא, אוֹ לָא? הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵימָא דַּאֲמַר ״הָדֵין בֵּיתָא לֶיהֱוֵי בֵּית הַכִּסֵּא, וְהָדֵין נָמֵי״, הַהוּא בֵּית הַכִּסֵּא נָמֵי הָוֵה! אֶלָּא כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר ״וְהָדֵין״ וְלָא אָמַר ״נָמֵי״. מַאי ״הָדֵין״ דְּאָמַר — ״וְהָדֵין נָמֵי בֵּית הַכִּסֵּא״, אוֹ דִלְמָא מַאי ״וְהָדֵין״ — לְתַשְׁמִישָׁא בְּעָלְמָא קָאָמַר.
human_translation: Ravina raised dilemma: Is there intimation for a bathroom or not? What are the circumstances If we say that one said: Let this structure be a bathroom and this also, that is also a bathroom. Rather, where he said: And this, and he did not say: Also. What And this, that he said, And this also be a bathroom? Or perhaps what And this? He is saying for general use
llm_translation: Inquiries of Ravina: Is there a hand to the toilet, or not? How so? If you say, "So too should the house be a toilet, and so too," that toilet would also be a toilet! Rather, for example, if one says "and so," and does not say "also." What is "and so" that he said - "and so too should the toilet," or perhaps what is "and so" - he is speaking of regular use.

hebrew_text: מִכְּלָל דִּפְשִׁיטָא לֵיהּ לְרָבִינָא דְּיֵשׁ זִימּוּן לְבֵית הַכִּסֵּא? וְהָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ לְרָבִינָא: הִזְמִינוֹ לְבֵית הַכִּסֵּא מַהוּ? הִזְמִינוֹ לְבֵית הַמֶּרְחָץ מַהוּ? זִימּוּן מוֹעִיל, אוֹ אֵין זִימּוּן מוֹעִיל?
human_translation: by inference that it is obvious to Ravina that there is designation for a bathroom, Didn’t Ravina raise this as a dilemma? designated as a bathroom, what is designated it as a bathhouse, what is is designation effective or is designation not effective?
llm_translation: From the fact that it is obvious to Ravina that there is a designated time for the privy, and he asks: If one designated it for the privy, what is the law? If one designated it for the bathhouse, what is the law? Is designation effective, or is designation not effective?

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא חֲדָא מִגּוֹ חֲדָא קָמִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ: זִימּוּן מוֹעִיל אוֹ אֵין זִימּוּן מוֹעִיל. אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר יֵשׁ זִימּוּן: יֵשׁ יָד אוֹ אֵין יָד תִּיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Ravina raised one dilemma within another Is designation effective or is designation not effective? if you say there is designation, is there intimation or is there not intimation, The dilemma remains
llm_translation: Ravinah one from another from another asked him: invitation useful or not invitation useful. If you find to say there is invitation: there is hand or not hand ask him.

hebrew_text: מְנוּדֶּה אֲנִי לָךְ וְכוּ׳. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מוֹדֶה רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא לְעִנְיַן מַלְקוֹת שֶׁאֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה. דְּאִם כֵּן, נִיתְנֵי ״רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא מַחְמִיר״.
human_translation: I am ostracized from you, Abaye said: Rabbi Akiva concedes with regard to flogging that one is not flogged As, if so, let teach: Rabbi Akiva is stringent.
llm_translation: I am a m'nudeh for you, etc. Abaye said: Rabbi Akiva admits regarding lashes that he is not lashed. For if so, it should be said, "Rabbi Akiva is stringent."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: בִּ״נְדִינָא מִינָּךְ״ — דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּאָסוּר. ״מְשַׁמַּתְנָא מִינָּךְ״ — לְכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא שְׁרֵי. בְּמַאי פְּלִיגִי —
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: With I am distanced [ nadeina ] from you, everyone agrees that he is prohibited I am excommunicated [ meshamattena ] from you everyone agrees permitted With regard to what do they disagree?
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: "Bin'dina minach" - that which is universally accepted, there is no dispute that it is forbidden. "Meshammatna minach" - to all people it is permitted. In what do they dispute?

hebrew_text: בִּ״מְנוּדֶּה אֲנִי לָךְ״, דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר: לִישָּׁנָא דְנִידּוּיָא הוּא, וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי: לִישָּׁנָא דִמְשַׁמַּתְנָא הוּא.
human_translation: with regard to I am ostracized from you, as Rabbi Akiva holds it is a language of distancing and the Rabbis hold it is a language of excommunication,
llm_translation: "In 'I am committed to you,' Rabbi Akiva holds: it is a matter of a vow, and the Rabbis hold: it is a matter of a tradition."

hebrew_text: וּפְלִיגָא דְּרַב חִסְדָּא. דְּהָהוּא גַּבְרָא דְּאָמַר ״מְשַׁמַּתְנָא בְּנִכְסֵיהּ דִּבְרֵיהּ דְּרַב יִרְמְיָה בַּר אַבָּא״ אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב חִסְדָּא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לֵית דְּחָשׁ לַהּ לְהָא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא. קָסָבַר: בִּ״מְשַׁמַּתְנָא״ פְּלִיגִי.
human_translation: And disagrees with Rav Ḥisda, as a certain man who said: I am excommunicated the property of the son of Rav Yirmeya bar Abba. He came before Rav Ḥisda said to him: There is no one who, is concerned for that of Rabbi Akiva. holds they disagree with regard to I am excommunicated
llm_translation: Dispute of Rav Ḥisda. For that man who said, "He who appraises his property according to the words of Rav Yirmeya bar Abba," came before Rav Ḥisda. He said to him: There is no need for him to concern himself with the matter of Rabbi Akiva. He holds: In the case of "appraises," they disagree.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אִילָא אָמַר רַב: נִדָּהוּ בְּפָנָיו — אֵין מַתִּירִין לוֹ אֶלָּא בְּפָנָיו. נִדָּהוּ שֶׁלֹּא בְּפָנָיו — מַתִּירִין לוֹ בֵּין בְּפָנָיו בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא בְּפָנָיו.
human_translation: Rabbi Ila said Rav said: one ostracized in his presence, one dissolve for him only in his presence. one ostracized him not in his presence, one dissolve it for him in his presence or not in his presence.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Ila said Rav: His vow in his presence - they do not permit him except in his presence. His vow not in his presence - they permit him whether in his presence or not in his presence.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חָנִין אָמַר רַב: הַשּׁוֹמֵעַ הַזְכָּרַת הַשֵּׁם מִפִּי חֲבֵירוֹ צָרִיךְ לְנַדּוֹתוֹ, וְאִם לֹא נִידָּהוּ — הוּא עַצְמוֹ יְהֵא בְּנִידּוּי. שֶׁכׇּל מָקוֹם שֶׁהַזְכָּרַת הַשֵּׁם מְצוּיָה, שָׁם עֲנִיּוּת מְצוּיָה.
human_translation: Rav Ḥanin said Rav said: One who hears mention of the name by another must ostracize him And if he did not ostracize him, he himself, shall be ostracized, as wherever mention of God’s name is common, poverty is common there.
llm_translation: Rav Hanin said in the name of Rav: One who hears the mentioning of the Name from his fellow must excommunicate him, and if he does not excommunicate him, he himself shall be excommunicated. For in every place where the mentioning of the Name is found, poverty is found.

hebrew_text: וַעֲנִיּוּת, כְּמִיתָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי מֵתוּ כׇּל הָאֲנָשִׁים״, וְתַנְיָא: כׇּל מָקוֹם שֶׁ״נָּתְנוּ חֲכָמִים עֵינֵיהֶם״, אוֹ מִיתָה אוֹ עוֹנִי.
human_translation: And poverty is like death, as it is stated: “For all the men are dead And it is taught Wherever the Sages set their eyes either death or poverty.
llm_translation: Poverty, like death, as it is stated: "For all the men have died." And it was taught: In any place where "the sages have set their eyes," either death or poverty.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: הֲוָה קָאֵימְנָא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב הוּנָא, שַׁמְעַהּ לְהָךְ אִיתְּתָא דְּאַפִּקָה הַזְכָּרַת הַשֵּׁם לְבַטָּלָה, שַׁמְּתַהּ וּשְׁרָא לַהּ לְאַלְתַּר בְּאַפַּהּ. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ תְּלָת: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ הַשּׁוֹמֵעַ הַזְכָּרַת הַשֵּׁם מִפִּי חֲבֵירוֹ צָרִיךְ לְנַדּוֹתוֹ, וּשְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: נִידָּהוּ בְּפָנָיו, אֵין מַתִּירִין לוֹ אֶלָּא בְּפָנָיו, וּשְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: אֵין בֵּין נִידּוּי לַהֲפָרָה וְלֹא כְּלוּם.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba said: I was standing before Rav Huna, he heard a certain woman utter a mention of the name in vain. He excommunicated her and immediately dissolved for her in her presence. Learn three things from this. Learn from this one who hears mention of the name by another must ostracize him; and learn from this one ostracized in his presence, one dissolve for him only in his presence; and learn from this there is nothing, between ostracism and nullification
llm_translation: Rabbi Abba said: I was standing before Rav Huna, when I heard that a woman had pronounced the Name for the purpose of nullifying it. She placed it in a dough and threw it into the oven immediately. Learn from this three things: Learn from this that one who hears the Name pronounced by his fellow must excommunicate him; and learn from this: Excommunicate him in his presence, and we only permit him in his presence; and learn from this: There is no difference between excommunication for the purpose of purification and for the purpose of punishment.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב: תַּלְמִיד חָכָם מְנַדֶּה לְעַצְמוֹ, וּמֵיפֵר לְעַצְמוֹ. פְּשִׁיטָא? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: ״אֵין חָבוּשׁ מַתִּיר עַצְמוֹ מִבֵּית הָאֲסוּרִין״, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Rav Giddel said Rav said: A Torah scholar ostracize himself, and he nullify for himself. Isn’t obvious lest you say, A prisoner cannot free himself from prison, teaches us
llm_translation: Rav Giddel said in the name of Rav: A Torah scholar can declare himself a debtor and exempt himself. Is it not obvious? Lest you say, "A prisoner cannot release himself from prison," this teaches us otherwise.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָּמֵי: כִּי הָא דְּמָר זוּטְרָא חֲסִידָא, כִּי מִחַיַּיב בַּר בֵּי רַב שַׁמְתָּא — מְשַׁמֵּית נַפְשֵׁיהּ בְּרֵישָׁא, וַהֲדַר מְשַׁמֵּת בַּר בֵּי רַב. וְכִי עָיֵיל לְבֵיתֵיהּ, שָׁרֵי לְנַפְשֵׁיהּ וַהֲדַר שָׁרֵי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: What are the circumstances like that Mar Zutra Ḥasida. When a student the academy was liable to excommunication, first excommunicate himself and then he would excommunicate the student And when he would enter his home, he would dissolve for himself and then dissolve for
llm_translation: How are the circumstances? Like this case of Mar Zutra the pious, when Bar Bery Rav Shmata obligated him - he put himself to death at first, and then Bar Bery Rav obligated him again. And when he went home, he permitted himself, and then he permitted him.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב:
human_translation: And Rav Giddel said Rav said:
llm_translation: And Rav Giddel said, Rav said:

hebrew_text: מִנַּיִן שֶׁנִּשְׁבָּעִין לְקַיֵּים אֶת הַמִּצְוָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״נִשְׁבַּעְתִּי וָאֲקַיֵּמָה לִשְׁמֹר מִשְׁפְּטֵי צִדְקֶךָ״.
human_translation: From where that one may take an oath to fulfill a mitzva? as it is stated: “I have sworn and I have confirmed it, to observe Your righteous ordinances”
llm_translation: From where do we derive the obligation to swear in order to fulfill the commandment, as it is stated: "I have sworn and I will fulfill it, to observe Your righteous ordinances" (Psalms 119:106).

hebrew_text: וַהֲלֹא מוּשְׁבָּע וְעוֹמֵד מֵהַר סִינַי הוּא. אֶלָּא הָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּשָׁרֵי לֵיהּ לְאִינִישׁ לְזָרוֹזֵי נַפְשֵׁיהּ.
human_translation: Is he not already under oath from Mount Sinai Rather, teaches us this: It is permitted for a man to motivate himself
llm_translation: And isn't "sitting and standing from Mount Sinai" itself? Rather, here it is teaching us that it is permitted for a person to be diligent for themselves.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב: הָאוֹמֵר ״אַשְׁכִּים וְאֶשְׁנֶה פֶּרֶק זֶה״ ״אֶשְׁנֶה מַסֶּכְתָּא זוֹ״ — נֶדֶר גָּדוֹל נָדַר לֵאלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל. וַהֲלֹא מוּשְׁבָּע וְעוֹמֵד הוּא, וְאֵין שְׁבוּעָה חָלָה עַל שְׁבוּעָה! מַאי קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן, דַּאֲפִילּוּ זָרוֹזֵי בְּעָלְמָא — הַיְינוּ דְּרַב גִּידֵּל קַמַּיְיתָא!
human_translation: And Rav Giddel said Rav said: One who says: I will rise early and study this chapter, I will study this tractate, has taken a great vow to the God of Israel. Is he not already under oath And an oath does not take effect upon a oath. What is he teaching us? that even merely motivate oneself this is the first of Rav Giddel.
llm_translation: And Rav Giddel said in the name of Rav: One who says, "I will rise early and study this chapter," "I will study this tractate," has taken a great vow to the God of Israel. But is he not sitting and standing, and one oath does not override another oath! What does this teach us? Even though they are swift in the world — that is what Rav Giddel meant to say!

hebrew_text: הָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן: כֵּיוָן דְּאִי בָּעֵי פָּטַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ בִּקְרִיַּת שְׁמַע שַׁחֲרִית וְעַרְבִית, מִשּׁוּם הָכִי חָיֵיל שְׁבוּעָה עֲלֵיהּ.
human_translation: teaches us this: Since if he desires he can exempt himself with the recitation Shema morning and evening, due to that the oath takes effect upon him
llm_translation: This is what is implied: Since if one wants to exempt oneself with the recitation of the Shema in the morning and evening, therefore he is liable for an oath.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״נַשְׁכִּים וְנִשְׁנֶה פֶּרֶק זֶה״ — עָלָיו לְהַשְׁכִּים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֹּאמֶר אֵלַי (בֶּן אָדָם) קוּם צֵא אֶל הַבִּקְעָה וְשָׁם אֲדַבֵּר אוֹתָךְ וָאֵצֵא אֶל הַבִּקְעָה וְהִנֵּה שָׁם כְּבוֹד ה׳ עֹמֵד״.
human_translation: Rav Giddel said Rav said: one who says to another: Let us rise early and study this chapter, it is upon him to rise early as it is stated: “And He said to me: Arise, go forth into the plain, and there I will speak with you. and went forth into the plain; and behold, the glory of the Lord stood there”
llm_translation: Rav Giddel said in the name of Rav: One who says to his fellow, "Let us wake up early and learn this chapter," he should wake up early, as it is stated: "And He said to me (son of man), arise, go out to the valley, and there I will speak with you." So I arose and went out to the valley, and behold, the glory of the Lord was standing there.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: נִידּוּהוּ בַּחֲלוֹם, צָרִיךְ עֲשָׂרָה בְּנֵי אָדָם לְהַתִּיר לוֹ, וְהוּא דְּתָנוּ הִלְכְתָא, אֲבָל מַתְנוּ וְלָא תָּנוּ — לָא. וְאִי לֵיכָּא דְּתָנוּ הִלְכְתָא — אֲפִילּוּ מַתְנוּ וְלָא תָּנוּ.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: One was ostracized in a dream requires ten people to dissolve for him. And only who have studied halakha , However, recited Mishna and have not studied no, And if there are not who have studied halakha , even who have recited Mishna and have not studied
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: If he was excommunicated in a dream, ten people are needed to permit him, as it was taught as a tradition. But if it was taught and not as a tradition - no. And if there is a tradition - even if it was taught and not as a tradition.

hebrew_text: וְאִי לֵיכָּא — לֵיזִיל וְלִיתֵּב אַפָּרָשַׁת דְּרָכִים וְיָהֵיב שְׁלָמָא לְבֵי עַשְׂרָה, עַד דְּמִקַּלְעִי לֵיהּ עַשְׂרָה דְּגָמְרִי הִלְכְתָא.
human_translation: And if there are not let him go and sit at the crossroads and extend shalom , to ten people, until ten who have studied halakha happen to come to him.
llm_translation: If it is not so - let him go and sit in the study hall of Derech Eretz and give a greeting to ten people, until ten people greet him, he has completed the law.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: יָדַע מַאן שַׁמְתֵּיהּ, מַהוּ דְּלִישְׁרֵי לֵיהּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לְשַׁמּוֹתֵיהּ שַׁוְּיוּהּ שָׁלִיחַ, לְמִישְׁרֵי לֵיהּ לָא שַׁוְּיוּהּ שָׁלִיחַ.
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: he knows who excommunicated him what is dissolve for him? said to him: he was appointed as an agent to excommunicate him, he was not appointed as an agent to dissolve for him.
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: "If one knows who placed it, what is the law regarding returning it to him?" He said to him: "If it was placed with a messenger, returning it to him is not necessary."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַחָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: שַׁמְּתֻיהּ וּשְׁרוֹ לֵיהּ בְּחֶלְמֵיהּ, מַאי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאִי אֶפְשָׁר לַבָּר בְּלֹא תֶּבֶן,
human_translation: Rav Aḥa said to Rav Ashi: he was excommunicated and dissolved for him in his dream, what is said to him: Just as it is impossible for the grain without straw,
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Acha to Rav Ashe: "Appoint him and sing to him in his dreams, what? He said to him: Just as it is impossible for a son without straw,

hebrew_text: כָּךְ אִי אֶפְשָׁר לַחֲלוֹם בְּלֹא דְּבָרִים בְּטֵלִים.
human_translation: so too, it is impossible to dream without idle matter.
llm_translation: So it is impossible to dream without idle words.

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא הֲוָה לַהּ נִדְרָא לִדְבֵיתְהוּ. אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב אָשֵׁי, אָמַר לֵיהּ: בַּעַל מַהוּ שֶׁיֵּעָשֶׂה שָׁלִיחַ לַחֲרָטַת אִשְׁתּוֹ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִי מְכַנְּפִין — אִין, אִי לָא — לָא.
human_translation: Ravina’s wife had a vow came before Rav Ashi said to him: What is a husband can become an agent to his wife’s regret said to him: If were assembled, yes; if not no,
llm_translation: Ravina was to her vow to his house. He came before Rav Ashe, he said to him: "With what can a husband appoint a messenger to divorce his wife?" He said to him: "If they are not close - no, if they are close - yes."

hebrew_text: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ תְּלָת. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: בַּעַל נַעֲשֶׂה שָׁלִיחַ לַחֲרָטַת אִשְׁתּוֹ. וּשְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: לָא שְׁרֵי לְמִישְׁרֵי נִדְרָא בְּאַתְרָא דְרַבֵּיהּ. וּשְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: כִּי מְכַנְּפִין שַׁפִּיר דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Learn from this three Learn from this a husband can become an agent to his wife’s regret. And learn from this is not permitted to dissolve a vow in the location of his teacher, And learn from this when were assembled, seems well
llm_translation: Listen to this, learn three things. Listen to this: a husband can appoint a messenger to divorce his wife. And listen to this: it is not permitted to fulfill a vow in the place of one's teacher. And listen to this: for the wings of a bird resemble the wings of a bat.

hebrew_text: וְשַׁמְתָּא — אֲפִילּוּ בְּאַתְרָא דְרַבֵּיהּ, וְיָחִיד מוּמְחֶה שָׁרֵי שַׁמְתָּא.
human_translation: And excommunication even in the location of his teacher. And an individual expert dissolve excommunication
llm_translation: And Shemta - even in the place of his teacher, and an individual with a blemish is permitted Shemta.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בַּר זְבִיד, אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק בַּר טַבְלָא, אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא אֲרִיכָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי אַחָא, אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא, אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, אָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִינָא, אָמַר רַבִּי מְיָאשָׁה מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בַּר אִילְעַאי: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״וְזָרְחָה לָכֶם יִרְאֵי שְׁמִי (שֶׁמֶשׁ צְדָקָה וְגוֹ׳)״ אֵלּוּ בְּנֵי אָדָם שֶׁהֵן יְרֵאִין לְהוֹצִיא שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם לְבַטָּלָה. ״שֶׁמֶשׁ צְדָקָה וּמַרְפֵּא״. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ חִרְגָּא דְיוֹמָא מַסֵּי.
