human_translation: Rabbi Shimon bar Zevid said Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Tavla said Rabbi Ḥiyya Arikha, of the school of Rabbi Aḥa said Rabbi Zeira said Rabbi Elazar said Rabbi Ḥanina said Rabbi Meyasha said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda bar Elai: What is which is written: “But to you that fear My name shall the sun of righteousness arise these are people who are afraid to mention the name of Heaven in vain. a sun of righteousness with healing Abaye said: Learn from this the dust [ ḥirga ] the day heals,
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon bar Zevid said, Rabbi Yitzchak bar Tabla said, Rabbi Chiya the Elder of the house of Rabbi Acha said, Rabbi Zeira said, Rabbi Elazar said, Rabbi Chanina said, Rabbi Meirasha in the name of Rabbi Yehuda bar Ilai: What is the meaning of the verse, "But to you who fear My name, the sun of righteousness shall arise with healing in its wings"? These are people who are careful to mention the name of Heaven in order to sanctify it. "The sun of righteousness and healing." Abaye said: Learn from this the importance of the fear of the day.

hebrew_text: וּפְלִיגָא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ, דְּאָמַר: אֵין גֵּיהִנָּם לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, אֶלָּא הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא מוֹצִיא חַמָּה מִנַּרְתִּיקָהּ, צַדִּיקִים מִתְרַפְּאִין בָּהּ וּרְשָׁעִים נִידּוֹנִין בָּהּ. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְזָרְחָה לָכֶם יִרְאֵי שְׁמִי שֶׁמֶשׁ וְגוֹ׳״. וְלֹא עוֹד, אֶלָּא שֶׁמִּתְעַדְּנִין בָּהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וִיצָאתֶם וּפִשְׁתֶּם כְּעֶגְלֵי מַרְבֵּק״.
human_translation: disagrees with Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, said: There is no Gehenna in the World-to-Come. Rather, the Holy One, Blessed be He, remove the sun from its sheath [ minartika ], the righteous will be healed by it and the wicked will be punished by it. as it is stated: “But to you that fear My name shall the sun arise and moreover, but they will be rejuvenated by it, as it is stated: “And you shall go forth and leap as calves of the stall.”
llm_translation: Dispute of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, who said: Hell is not eternal in the World to Come, rather the Holy One, blessed be He, will take out the sun from its sheath, the righteous will be healed by it, and the wicked will be judged by it. As it is stated: "But for you who revere My name, the sun of righteousness will rise with healing in its rays." And not only that, but they will delight in it, as it is stated: "And you will go out and leap like calves released from the stall."

hebrew_text: וְהָרְשָׁעִים נִידּוֹנִין בָּהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הִנֵּה הַיּוֹם בָּא בֹּעֵר כַּתַּנּוּר וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: And the wicked will be punished by as it is stated: “For behold, the day is coming, it burns as a furnace;
llm_translation: The wicked are judged in it, as it is said: "Behold, the day is coming, burning like a furnace, and so on."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״כְּנִדְרֵי רְשָׁעִים״ — נָדַר בְּנָזִיר וּבְקׇרְבָּן וּבִשְׁבוּעָה. ״כְּנִדְרֵי כְשֵׁרִים״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם. ״כְּנִדְבוֹתָם״ — נָדַר בְּנָזִיר וּבְקׇרְבָּן.
human_translation: like the vows of the wicked, he has vowed with regard to a nazirite, or an offering, or an oath. Like the vows of the virtuous, he has not said anything, Like their gift offerings, he has vowed with regard to a nazirite or an offering.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "Like the vows of the wicked" — one may vow regarding a Nazirite, a sacrifice, and an oath. "Like the vows of the righteous" — he did not say anything. "Like their freewill offerings" — one may vow regarding a Nazirite and a sacrifice.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ וְדִלְמָא הָכִי קָאָמַר: כְּנִדְרֵי רְשָׁעִים לָא נָדַרְנָא? אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: בְּאוֹמֵר ״כְּנִדְרֵי רְשָׁעִים הֲרֵינִי עָלַי וְהֵימֶנּוּ״, ״הֲרֵינִי״ — בִּנְזִירוּת, ״עָלַי״ — בְּקׇרְבָּן, ״הֵימֶנּוּ״ — בִּשְׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: And perhaps this is what he is saying: I am not making a vow like the vows of the wicked, Shmuel said: one who said: Like the vows of the wicked I am hereby, upon myself, or: From it. I am hereby, of naziriteship. upon myself, to an offering. From it, through an oath.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Perhaps this is what he is saying: "We did not vow like the vows of the wicked?" Shmuel said: By saying, "Like the vows of the wicked, behold I am upon myself and I fulfill it," "behold I am" - with regard to Naziriteship, "upon myself" - with regard to offering, "and fulfill it" - with regard to an oath.

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵינִי״ נְזִירוּת. דִּלְמָא הֲרֵינִי בְּתַעֲנִית קָאָמַר? אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: כְּשֶׁהָיָה נָזִיר עוֹבֵר לְפָנָיו.
human_translation: I am hereby, naziriteship? Perhaps he is saying: I am hereby to fast. Shmuel said: where a nazirite was passing in front of him,
llm_translation: "Behold, I am a Nazirite." Perhaps he is saying, "Behold, I am on a fast"? Shmuel said: When he was a Nazirite, he would pass before him.

hebrew_text: (״עָלַי״ — בְּקׇרְבָּן) ״הֵימֶנּוּ״ — בִּשְׁבוּעָה. דִּלְמָא: ״הֵימֶנּוּ״ — דְּאָכֵילְנָא קָאָמַר! אָמַר רָבָא: דְּאָמַר ״הֵימֶנּוּ שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״.
human_translation: upon myself, to an offering, From it, through an oath? Perhaps he is saying: I will eat from Rava said: where he said: I will not eat from it.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "'Alai' - in the offering, 'heimenu' - in a week. Perhaps 'heimenu' means that we eat! Rava said: 'Heimenu' means that he does not eat." English translation: "'Alai' - in the offering, 'heimenu' - in a week. Perhaps 'heimenu' means that we eat! Rava said: 'Heimenu' means that he does not eat."

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי מַאי לְמֵימְרָא? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: הָא לָא מַפֵּיק שְׁבוּעָה מִפּוּמֵּיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן הָדֵין.
human_translation: If so, what of stating Lest you say he did not utter oath from his mouth this teaches us this
llm_translation: So what can be said? What might one say? Perhaps you will say: "This does not establish a week from itself, it is the same."

hebrew_text: ״כְּנִדְרֵי כְשֵׁרִים״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם, ״כְּנִדְבוֹתָם״ — נָדַר וְכוּ׳. מַאן תַּנָּא דְּשָׁאנֵי לֵיהּ בֵּין נֶדֶר לִנְדָבָה? לֵימָא לָא רַבִּי מֵאִיר וְלָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה!
human_translation: like the vows of the virtuous, he has not said anything. Like their gift offerings, he has vowed Who is the tanna according to whom difference between a vow and a gift Shall we say not Rabbi Meir and not Rabbi Yehuda
llm_translation: "Like vows of valid offerings" — he did not say anything, "like their freewill offerings" — he vowed, etc. Who is the Tanna that distinguishes between a vow and a freewill offering? Let us say it is neither Rabbi Meir nor Rabbi Yehuda!

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: ״טוֹב אֲשֶׁר לֹא תִדֹּר וְגוֹ׳״, טוֹב מִזֶּה וּמִזֶּה — שֶׁאֵינוֹ נוֹדֵר כׇּל עִיקָּר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: טוֹב מִזֶּה וּמִזֶּה נוֹדֵר וּמְשַׁלֵּם.
human_translation: as it is taught “Better that you should not vow, better than this and that who does not take a vow at all. the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: Better than this and that is one who vows and pays.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "It is good not to vow, etc." - Good from this and from this - that one does not vow at all, these are the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: Good from this and from this, one vows and pays.

hebrew_text: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי מֵאִיר,
human_translation: You even say Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: Even if you say "Rabbi Meir,"

hebrew_text: כִּי קָאָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר — בְּנֶדֶר, בִּנְדָבָה לָא קָאָמַר. וְהָא קָתָנֵי: ״כְּנִדְבוֹתָם״ — נָדַר בְּנָזִיר וּבְקׇרְבָּן! תְּנִי: נָדַב בְּנָזִיר וּבְקׇרְבָּן.
human_translation: When Rabbi Meir said to a vow; he did not say it with regard to a gift But it is taught Like the gift offerings he has vowed with regard to a nazirite or an offering; Teach He has volunteered with regard to a nazirite or an offering.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Ki ka'amar Rabbi Meir — b'nedar, b'nidavah lo ka'amar. V'ha katanei: 'k'nidvotam' — nadar b'nazir u'v'korban! Teni: nadav b'nazir u'v'korban." English translation: "For Rabbi Meir said — in a vow, not in a freewill offering did he say. And it teaches: 'like their freewill offerings' — he vowed in a nazirite vow and in a sacrifice! It was taught: he vowed in a nazirite vow and in a sacrifice."

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא נוֹדֵר דְּלָא — דִּלְמָא אָתֵי בָּהּ לִידֵי תַקָּלָה? נְדָבָה נָמֵי לָא — דִּלְמָא אָתֵי בָּהּ לִידֵי תַקָּלָה!
human_translation: What is different about one who vows, which is not perhaps he will encounter a stumbling block it also not gift perhaps he will encounter a stumbling block with it.
llm_translation: What is the difference between a vow that is not binding - perhaps it will lead to a stumbling block? A voluntary offering is also not binding - perhaps it will lead to a stumbling block!

hebrew_text: כְּהִלֵּל הַזָּקֵן. דְּתַנְיָא: אָמְרוּ עַל הִילֵּל הַזָּקֵן שֶׁלֹּא מָעַל אָדָם בְּעוֹלָתוֹ כׇּל יָמָיו. מְבִיאָהּ כְּשֶׁהִיא חוּלִּין לָעֲזָרָה, וּמַקְדִּישָׁהּ, וְסוֹמֵךְ עָלֶיהָ, וְשׁוֹחֲטָהּ.
human_translation: like Hillel the Elder. As it is taught They said about Hillel the Elder that no person misused his burnt-offering in his lifetime. he would bring it when it was unconsecrated to courtyard and consecrate it, and place his hand on its and slaughter it.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Like Hillel the Elder. As it was taught: They said of Hillel the Elder that he did not neglect his burnt offering all his days. He would bring it when it was weekday to the Temple courtyard, consecrate it, lean his hands on it, and slaughter it."

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא נְדָבָה דְקׇרְבָּנוֹת. נְדָבָה דִנְזִירוּת מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר? סָבַר לַהּ כְּשִׁמְעוֹן הַצַּדִּיק.
human_translation: This works out well gifts of offerings, voluntary of naziriteship, what is there to say? holds in accordance with Shimon HaTzaddik.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Hanicha nedavah dekorbanot. Nedavah dinzirut ma'ai ikka lemeimar? Savar la keshimon hatzadik." Translation: "He left a voluntary offering of sacrifices. What is the voluntary offering of nazirites? He thought like Shimon the Righteous."

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא, אָמַר (רַבִּי) שִׁמְעוֹן הַצַּדִּיק: מִיָּמַי לֹא אָכַלְתִּי אֲשַׁם נָזִיר טָמֵא אֶלָּא אֶחָד. פַּעַם אַחַת בָּא אָדָם אֶחָד נָזִיר מִן הַדָּרוֹם, וּרְאִיתִיו שֶׁהוּא יְפֵה עֵינַיִם וְטוֹב רוֹאִי וּקְווּצּוֹתָיו סְדוּרוֹת לוֹ תַּלְתַּלִּים. אָמַרְתִּי לוֹ: בְּנִי, מָה רָאִיתָ לְהַשְׁחִית אֶת שְׂעָרְךָ זֶה הַנָּאֶה?
human_translation: As it is taught Rabbi Shimon HaTzaddik said: In all my days I never ate the guilt-offering of a ritually impure nazirite except one One time, a particular man who was a nazirite came from the South and I saw that he had beautiful eyes and was good looking, and the fringes of his hair were arranged in curls. I said to him: My son, what did you see to destroy this beautiful hair of yours
llm_translation: It was taught: (Rabbi) Shimon the Righteous said: From the days of my youth, I have not eaten a Nazirite guilt-offering for impurity except one. Once, a certain man came, a Nazirite from the south, and I saw that he had beautiful eyes, was good-looking, and his locks were arranged in curls. I said to him: My son, what did you see to destroy this beautiful hair of yours?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לִי: רוֹעֶה הָיִיתִי לְאַבָּא בְּעִירִי, הָלַכְתִּי לְמַלּאוֹת מַיִם מִן הַמַּעְיָין וְנִסְתַּכַּלְתִּי בַּבָּבוּאָה שֶׁלִּי, וּפָחַז עָלַי יִצְרִי וּבִקֵּשׁ לְטוֹרְדֵנִי מִן הָעוֹלָם. אָמַרְתִּי לוֹ: רָשָׁע! לָמָה אַתָּה מִתְגָּאֶה בְּעוֹלָם שֶׁאֵינוֹ שֶׁלְּךָ, בְּמִי שֶׁהוּא עָתִיד לִהְיוֹת רִמָּה וְתוֹלֵעָה? הָעֲבוֹדָה, שֶׁאֲגַלֵּחֲךָ לַשָּׁמַיִם!
human_translation: He said to me: I was a shepherd for father in my city, I went to draw water from the spring, and I looked at my reflection [ babavua ] and my inclination quickly overcame me and sought to expel me from the world. I said to Wicked one! Why do you pride yourself in a world that is not yours? of someone who will eventually be for worms and maggots, by the service that I shall shave you for Heaven.
llm_translation: He said to me: I used to be a shepherd for my father in my city, I went to fill water from the spring and looked at my reflection in my flask, and my evil inclination rushed upon me and sought to destroy me from the world. I said to him: Wicked one! Why do you boast in a world that is not yours, in one who is destined to be decay and worm? The work that will shave you to the heavens!

hebrew_text: מִיָּד עָמַדְתִּי וּנְשַׁקְתִּיו עַל רֹאשׁוֹ, אָמַרְתִּי לוֹ: בְּנִי, כָּמוֹךָ יִרְבּוּ נוֹזְרֵי נְזִירוּת בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל. עָלֶיךָ הַכָּתוּב אוֹמֵר ״אִישׁ כִּי יַפְלִא לִנְדֹּר נֶדֶר נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר לַה׳״.
human_translation: I immediately arose and kissed him on his head. I said to him: My son, may there be more who take vows of naziriteship like you among the Jewish people. About you the verse states: “When a man shall clearly utter a vow, the vow of a nazirite, to consecrate himself to the Lord”
llm_translation: I immediately stood up and kissed him on his head, and said to him: "My son, may those who observe the vow of Naziriteship in Israel be as numerous as you. Upon you the verse says, 'If a man makes a special vow of Naziriteship to the Lord.'"

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַבִּי מָנִי: מַאי שְׁנָא אֲשַׁם נָזִיר טָמֵא דְּלָא אֲכַל — דְּאָתֵי עַל חֵטְא? כׇּל אֲשָׁמוֹת נָמֵי לָא לֵיכוֹל, דְּעַל חֵטְא אָתוּ!
human_translation: Rabbi Mani strongly objects to What is different about the guilt-offering of a ritually impure nazirite that did not eat, because it came as a result of sin Let him also not eat all guilt-offerings, as they come as a result of sin.
llm_translation: Rebbe Mani objects to her: What is the difference with the guilt-offering of a defiled Nazirite that he did not eat - that it comes for a sin? All guilt-offerings are not able to come, for they come for a sin!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹנָה, הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא: כְּשֶׁהֵן תּוֹהִין נוֹזְרִין. וּכְשֶׁהֵן מִטַּמְּאִין וְרָבִין עֲלֵיהֶן יְמֵי נְזִירוּת, מִתְחָרְטִין בָּהֶן, וְנִמְצְאוּ מְבִיאִין חוּלִּין לָעֲזָרָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yona said to him: This is the reason: When they regret they become nazirites, and when they become ritually impure and the days of naziriteship are increased, they regret They will then turn out to be bringing non-sacred into courtyard.
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Yonah, this is the reason: when they are beautifying, they are nazirites. And when they become impure and their days of naziriteship increase upon them, they regret it, and it is found that they bring mundane offerings to the Temple.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ נָזִיר טָהוֹר נָמֵי! נָזִיר טָהוֹר לָא, דְּאָמוֹדֵי אָמֵיד נַפְשֵׁיהּ דְּיָכוֹל לִנְדּוֹר.
human_translation: If so, even a ritually pure nazirite as well a pure nazirite no because he assessed himself that able to vow
llm_translation: If so, even a pure Nazirite is considered impure! A pure Nazirite is not considered impure, for he establishes for himself that he is able to take a vow.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא:
human_translation: And if you wish, say:
llm_translation: And if you will say:

hebrew_text: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, כִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה — בִּנְדָבָה, בְּנֶדֶר לָא אָמַר.
human_translation: Even you say Rabbi Yehuda, when Rabbi Yehuda said with regard to a gift he did not say with regard to vows.
llm_translation: Even if you say Rabbi Yehuda, when Rabbi Yehuda said - with a voluntary offering, he did not say with a vow.

hebrew_text: וְהָקָתָנֵי: ״טוֹב מִזֶּה וּמִזֶּה נוֹדֵר וּמְקַיֵּים״! תְּנִי: ״נוֹדֵב וּמְקַיֵּים״.
human_translation: But isn’t the mishna teaching better than this and that is one who vows [ noder ] and pays, Teach one who volunteers [ nodev ] and pays
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And the Tannaim: 'Better from this and from this vows and fulfills'! It was taught: 'Vows and fulfills'." English translation: "And the Tannaim taught: 'It is better to vow and fulfill than to vow and not fulfill'! It was taught: 'Vows and fulfills'."

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא נוֹדֵר דְּלָא, דִילְמָא אָתֵי בָּהּ לִידֵי תַקָּלָה? נְדָבָה נָמֵי, דִּילְמָא אָתֵי בָּהּ לִידֵי תַקָּלָה!
human_translation: What is different about one who vows, which is not perhaps he will encounter a stumbling block it also not a gift perhaps he will encounter a stumbling block with it.
llm_translation: What is different about a vow that is not binding, perhaps it will lead to a stumbling block? A freewill offering as well, perhaps it will lead to a stumbling block!

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר: אָדָם מֵבִיא כִּבְשָׂתוֹ לָעֲזָרָה, וּמַקְדִּישָׁה, וְסוֹמֵךְ עָלֶיהָ, וְשׁוֹחֲטָהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda to his reasoning, as he said A person brings his lamb to courtyard and consecrates it and leans on it and slaughters it.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda according to his reasoning, as he said: A person brings his sheep to the Temple courtyard, consecrates it, leans on it, and slaughters it.

hebrew_text: תִּינַח נְדָבָה דְקׇרְבָּנוֹת, נְדָבָה דִנְזִירוּת מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: works out well gifts of offerings, voluntary of naziriteship, what is there to say?
llm_translation: "Let's analyze the voluntary offering of sacrifices, what is the nature of the voluntary offering of vows?"

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה לְטַעְמֵיהּ. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: חֲסִידִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים הָיוּ מִתְאַוִּין לְהָבִיא קׇרְבַּן חַטָּאת. לְפִי שֶׁאֵין הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא מֵבִיא תַּקָּלָה עַל יְדֵיהֶם, מָה הָיוּ עוֹשִׂין? עוֹמְדִים וּמִתְנַדְּבִין נְזִירוּת לַמָּקוֹם, כְּדֵי שֶׁיִּתְחַיֵּיב קׇרְבַּן חַטָּאת לַמָּקוֹם.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda to his reasoning, as it is taught Rabbi Yehuda says: The early pious would desire to bring a sin-offering because the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not bring about a stumbling block through them, What would they do? They would rise and volunteer naziriteship to the Omnipresent in order to be liable sin-offering to the Omnipresent.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda according to his reasoning. As it was taught: Rabbi Yehuda says, "The early pious ones used to desire to bring a sin offering. Since the Holy One, blessed be He, does not bring a stumbling block upon them, what would they do? They would stand and volunteer vows to the place, so that they would become obligated to bring a sin offering to the place."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: לֹא נָדְרוּ בְּנָזִיר, אֶלָּא: הָרוֹצֶה לְהָבִיא עוֹלָה — מִתְנַדֵּב וּמֵבִיא, שְׁלָמִים — מִתְנַדֵּב וּמֵבִיא, תּוֹדָה וְאַרְבָּעָה מִינֵי לַחְמָהּ — מִתְנַדֵּב וּמֵבִיא. אֲבָל בִּנְזִירוּת לֹא הִתְנַדְּבוּ, כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יִקָּרְאוּ חוֹטְאִין. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״וְכִפֶּר עָלָיו מֵאֲשֶׁר חָטָא עַל הַנָּפֶשׁ״.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: They did not take a vow of naziriteship. Rather, one who want to bring a burnt-offering volunteer and bring a peace-offering volunteer and bring a thanks-offering and its four types of bread volunteer and bring However, they did not volunteer naziriteship in order that they not be called sinners. as it is stated: “And he shall make atonement for him, for that he sinned against the soul”
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: They did not vow Naziriteship, rather: one who wishes to bring a burnt offering—volunteers and brings; peace offerings—volunteers and brings; thanksgiving and the four types of loaves—volunteers and brings. But for Naziriteship, they did not volunteer, so that they would not be called sinners. As it is stated, "and he shall make atonement for him for the sin that he committed against the soul."

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: שִׁמְעוֹן הַצַּדִּיק וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הַקַּפָּר כּוּלָּן שִׁיטָה אַחַת הֵן, דְּנָזִיר חוֹטֵא הָוֵי: שִׁמְעוֹן הַצַּדִּיק וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הָא דַּאֲמַרַן.
human_translation: Abaye said: Shimon HaTzaddik, Rabbi Shimon, and Rabbi Elazar HaKappar are all of the same opinion, that a nazirite is a sinner. Shimon HaTzaddik and Rabbi Shimon that which we said.
llm_translation: Abaye said: Shimon HaTzaddik, and Rabbi Shimon, and Rabbi Elazar HaKappar, all of them are of the same opinion, that a Nazirite is considered a sinner. This is the statement of Shimon HaTzaddik and Rabbi Shimon, as we have said.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הַקַּפָּר בְּרַבִּי, דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הַקַּפָּר בְּרַבִּי אוֹמֵר: ״וְכִפֶּר עָלָיו מֵאֲשֶׁר חָטָא עַל הַנָּפֶשׁ״. וְכִי בְּאֵיזוֹ נֶפֶשׁ חָטָא זֶה? אֶלָּא: שֶׁצִּיעֵר עַצְמוֹ מִן הַיַּיִן. וַהֲלֹא דְּבָרִים קַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה זֶה שֶׁלֹּא צִיעֵר עַצְמוֹ אֶלָּא מִן הַיַּיִן נִקְרָא חוֹטֵא, הַמְצַעֵר עַצְמוֹ מִכׇּל דָּבָר עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה. מִכָּאן כׇּל הַיּוֹשֵׁב בְּתַעֲנִית נִקְרָא חוֹטֵא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Elazar HaKappar the Distinguished as it is taught Rabbi Elazar HaKappar the Distinguished says: “And he shall make atonement for him, for that he sinned against the soul.” Against which soul did sin? Rather, that he caused himself suffering from wine. Are matters not a fortiori : Just as this who causes himself suffering only from wine, is called a sinner, one who causes himself suffering from everything all the more so From here whoever fasts is called a sinner.
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar HaKappar, son of Rabbi, as it was taught: Rabbi Elazar HaKappar, son of Rabbi, says: "And he shall make atonement for him who sinned against the soul." But in what way did he sin against the soul? Rather, that he refrained himself from wine. And are these not logical arguments: If one who refrains himself only from wine is called a sinner, how much more so one who refrains himself from everything. From here, anyone who sits in a fast is called a sinner.

hebrew_text: וְהָדֵין קְרָא בְּנָזִיר טָמֵא כְּתִיב! מִשּׁוּם דְּשָׁנָה בְּחֵטְא הוּא.
human_translation: Isn’t this verse written with regard to a ritually impure nazirite? because he repeated his sin.
llm_translation: And similarly, it is written in the case of a Nazirite becoming impure! Because he deviated in a sin.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הָאוֹמֵר (לַחֲבֵירוֹ) ״קֻוֽנָּם״ ״קוּנָּח״ ״קוּנָּס״ — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ כִּינּוּיִין לַקׇּרְבָּן. ״חֶרֶק״ ״חֶרֶךְ״ ״חֶרֶף״ — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ כִּינּוּיִין לַחֵרֶם. ״נָזִיק״ ״נָזִיחַ״ ״פָּזִיחַ״ — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ כִּינּוּיִין לִנְזִירוּת. ״שְׁבוּתָה״ ״שְׁקוּקָה״, נוֹדֵר בְּ״מוֹהִי״ — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ כִּינּוּיִין לַשְּׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: one who says to another konam , konaḥ , konas , these are substitutes offering [ korban ], Ḥerek , ḥerekh ḥeref ; these are substitutes dedication [ ḥerem ] Nazik , naziaḥ , paziaḥ ; these are substitutes naziriteship [ nazir ]. Shevuta , shekuka , vows with mohi , these are substitutes oath [ shevua ].
llm_translation: The one who says (to his fellow), "Qunnam," "Qunnach," "Qunnas" — these are designations for sacrifices. "Chereq," "Cherech," "Cheref" — these are designations for a ban. "Nazik," "Nazicha," "Pazicha" — these are designations for Naziriteship. "Shevutah," "Shequqah," he vows with "Mohi" — these are designations for an oath.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיתְּמַר כִּינּוּיִין, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: לְשׁוֹן אוּמּוֹת הֵן. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ אָמַר: לָשׁוֹן שֶׁבָּדוּ לָהֶם חֲכָמִים לִהְיוֹת נוֹדֵר בּוֹ. וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״בַּחֹדֶשׁ אֲשֶׁר בָּדָא מִלִּבּוֹ״.
human_translation: It was stated substitutes Rabbi Yoḥanan said: They are a language of nations Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: language that the Sages devised [ badu ] with which take a vow. And so it states “In the month that he had devised [ bada ] in his own heart”
llm_translation: Gemara: It was stated: "Kinnuyin." Rabbi Yochanan said: They are the language of the nations. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: It is a language that the sages designated for them to make vows with. And so it says: "In the month that is in the heart of his heart."

hebrew_text: וְטַעְמָא מַאי תַּקִּינוּ רַבָּנַן כִּינּוּיִין? דְּלָא לֵימָא ״קׇרְבָּן״. וְלֵימָא ״קׇרְבָּן״? דִּילְמָא אָמַר ״קׇרְבָּן לַה׳״. וְלֵימָא ״קׇרְבָּן לַה׳״? דִּילְמָא אָמַר ״לַה׳״ וְלָא אָמַר ״קׇרְבָּן״, וְקָא מַפֵּיק שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם לְבַטָּלָה.
human_translation: And what is the reason the Sages established substitutes so that one not say offering. And let him say offering; Perhaps he will say: An offering to the Lord. And let him say: An offering to the Lord. Perhaps he will say: To the Lord, and not say: An offering, and he will express the name of Heaven in vain.
llm_translation: The reason why the Rabbis instituted Kinuyim (substitute terms) is so that one should not say "korban." And why not say "korban"? Perhaps one might say "korban to the Lord." And why not say "korban to the Lord"? Perhaps one might say "to the Lord" without saying "korban," thus invoking the name of Heaven in vain.

hebrew_text: וְתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר:
human_translation: And it is taught Rabbi Shimon says:
llm_translation: "And it was taught: Rabbi Shimon says:"

hebrew_text: מִנַּיִן שֶׁלֹּא יֹאמַר אָדָם ״לַה׳ עוֹלָה״, ״לַה׳ מִנְחָה״, ״לַה׳ תּוֹדָה״, ״לַה׳ שְׁלָמִים״ — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״קׇרְבָּן לַה׳״.
human_translation: From where that a person should not say: To the Lord a burnt-offering, To the Lord a meal-offering, To the Lord a thanks-offering, To the Lord a peace-offering, The verse states: “An offering to the Lord”
llm_translation: From where do we derive that a person should not say "an offering to the Lord," "a meal offering to the Lord," "a thanksgiving offering to the Lord," "a peace offering to the Lord"? The Talmud teaches: "An offering to the Lord."

hebrew_text: וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה זֶה שֶׁלֹּא נִתְכַּוֵּון אֶלָּא לְהַזְכִּיר שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם עַל הַקׇּרְבָּן — אָמְרָה תּוֹרָה ״קׇרְבָּן לַה׳״, לְבַטָּלָה — עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה.
human_translation: And an a fortiori Just as this who intended to mention the name of Heaven only upon an offering, the Torah said An offering to the Lord, in vain, all the more so
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And a fortiori: And what is this that it was not intended except to mention the name of Heaven over the sacrifice - the Torah said 'a sacrifice to the Lord,' to nullify it - how much more so." English translation: "And a fortiori: And what is this that it was not intended except to mention the name of Heaven over the sacrifice - the Torah said 'a sacrifice to the Lord,' to nullify it - how much more so."

hebrew_text: לֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: כִּינּוּיֵי כִינּוּיִין — אֲסוּרִין. וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: כִּינּוּיֵי כִינּוּיִין — מוּתָּרִין.
human_translation: Let us say parallel to tanna’im , Beit Shammai say: substitutes for substitute terms forbidden. And Beit Hillel say: substitutes for substitute terms permitted.
llm_translation: Let us say according to the opinion of the Tannaim, Beit Shammai say: nicknames, nicknames - prohibited. And Beit Hillel say: nicknames, nicknames - permitted.

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו: מַאן דְּאָמַר כִּינּוּיֵי כִינּוּיִין אֲסוּרִין, קָסָבַר (כִּינּוּיֵי) כִינּוּיִין לְשׁוֹן אוּמּוֹת הֵן. וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר מוּתָּרִים, קָסָבַר לָשׁוֹן שֶׁבָּדוּ לָהֶן חֲכָמִים?
human_translation: What, is it not the one who says substitutes for substitute terms forbidden holds that substitutes language of nations, And according to the one who says permitted, he holds that language that the Sages devised.
llm_translation: What is the reason why some say that symbolic designations are forbidden? He holds that symbolic designations are considered the language of idolaters. And according to the one who says they are permitted, he holds that the Sages have appropriated their language for themselves.

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא כִּינּוּיִין לְשׁוֹן אוּמּוֹת הֵן, וּבֵית שַׁמַּאי סָבְרִי: בְּהָנֵי נָמֵי מִשְׁתַּעִי אוּמּוֹת, וּבֵית הִלֵּל סָבְרִי: בְּהָנֵי לָא מִשְׁתַּעִי אוּמּוֹת.
human_translation: No, that everyone substitutes are the language of nations, and Beit Shammai hold the nations speak these also, and Beit Hillel hold the nations do not speak these
llm_translation: Not, all of the world, designations, language, nations, they are, and Beit Shammai hold: with them, should learn nations, and Beit Hillel hold: with them, should not learn nations.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי סָבְרִי: גָּזְרִינַן כִּינּוּיֵי כִינּוּיִין מִשּׁוּם כִּינּוּיִין, וּבֵית הִלֵּל סָבְרִי: לָא גָּזְרִינַן כִּינּוּיֵי כִינּוּיִין מִשּׁוּם כִּינּוּיִין.
human_translation: And if you wish, say Beit Shammai hold we a decree substitutes for substitute terms due to substitute terms And Beit Hillel hold: We do not a decree substitutes for substitute terms due to substitute terms
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: Beit Shammai hold: we decree the prohibitions of prohibitions due to prohibitions, and Beit Hillel hold: we do not decree the prohibitions of prohibitions due to prohibitions.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָּמֵי כִּינּוּיֵי כִינּוּיִין דִּנְדָרִים? תָּנֵי רַב יוֹסֵף: ״מַקְנֵמְנָא״ ״מַקְנַחְנָא״ ״מַקְנֵסְנָא״. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי כִּינּוּיֵי כִינּוּיִין דְּחֵרֶם? תָּנֵי מַפְשָׁאָה: ״חֲרָקִים״ ״חֲרָכִים״ ״חֲרָפִים״. כִּינּוּיֵי כִינּוּיִין דִּנְזִירוּת? תָּנֵי רַב יוֹסֵף: ״מַחְזֵקְנָא״ ״מַנְזַחְנָא״ ״מַפִּיחְנָא״.
human_translation: What are the circumstances of substitutes for substitute terms for vows? Rav Yosef teaches Mekanamna , mekanaḥna , mekanasna . What are the circumstances of substitutes for substitute terms for dedication [ ḥerem ]? Mafsha’a teaches: Ḥarakim , ḥarakhim , ḥarafim . substitutes for substitute terms for naziriteship [ nezirut ]? Rav Yosef teaches: Meḥazakna , menazaḥna , mafiḥna .
llm_translation: How are the names of vows designated? Rav Yosef taught: "maknemna," "maknachna," "maknesna." How are the names of cherem designated? Mapsha taught: "charakim," "charakhim," "charafim." What are the designations of nazir vows? Rav Yosef taught: "machzekna," "manzakhna," "mappikhna."

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: ״מִיפְּחַזְנָא״ מַאי? ״מִיתְּחַזְנָא״ מַאי? ״מִיתְּעַזְנָא״ מַאי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: ״קִינְּמָא״ (קינמא) מַאי? ״קֻוֽנָּם״ קָאָמַר, אוֹ דִלְמָא ״קִנְּמָן בֶּשֶׂם״ קָאָמַר?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before mifḥazna , what mitḥazna , what mitazna , what Ravina said to Rav Ashi: kinma , what saying konam , or perhaps saying sweet cinnamon [ kineman besem ]
llm_translation: He asked them: "What is 'mipchazna'? What is 'mitchazna'? What is 'mitazna'?" Ravina said to Rav Ashi: "What is 'kinma'? Is he saying 'kunnam,' or perhaps he is saying 'kinman besem'?"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב חִיָּיא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: ״קִינָּה״ מַאי? קִינָּה שֶׁל תַּרְנְגוֹלִין קָאָמַר, אוֹ דִילְמָא לָשׁוֹן דְּקֻוֽנָּם? תִּיבְּעֵי.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ḥiyya, said to Rav Ashi: kina , saying chicken coop, or perhaps it is a term for konam The dilemma remains
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Ahah son of Rav Chiya said to Rav Ashi: "What is 'kinna'?" What is meant by 'kinna' of roosters, or perhaps it is the language of their Creator? Let it remain unresolved.

hebrew_text: כִּינּוּיֵי כִינּוּיִין דִּשְׁבוּעָה הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? ״שְׁבוּאֵל״ ״שְׁבוּתִיאֵל״ ״שְׁקוּקָאֵל״. שְׁבוּאֵל? שְׁבוּאֵל בֶּן גֵּרְשׁוֹם מַשְׁמַע! אֶלָּא: ״שְׁבוּבָאֵל״ ״שְׁבוּתִיאֵל״ ״שְׁקוּקָאֵל״ מַהוּ? אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: אָמַר ״אַשִּׁיבְתָּא״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם, ״אַשְׁקִיקָא״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם, ״קָרִינְשָׂא״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם.
human_translation: What are the circumstances of substitutes for substitute terms of oaths [ shevua ]? shevuel , shevutiel , shekukael . shevuel indicates Shevuel, son of Gershom, Rather, shevuvael , shevutiel , shekukael . What is Shmuel said: he said ashivta he has not said anything, ashkika he has not said anything. karinsha he has not said anything,
llm_translation: The designations of the designations of the oath, how are they valued? "Shevu'el," "Shevutiel," "Shekukael." Shevu'el? Shevu'el son of Gershom is heard! Rather: "Shevuba'el," "Shevutiel," "Shekukael," what are they? Shmuel said: He said "Ashivta" - he did not say anything, "Ashkika" - he did not say anything, "Karinsha" - he did not say anything.

hebrew_text: ״נָדַר בְּמוֹהִי הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ כִינּוּיִין״. תַּנְיָא, רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: הָאוֹמֵר ״בְּמוֹהִי״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם, ״בְּמוֹמָתָא דַּאֲמַר מוֹהִי״ — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ כִּינּוּיִין לַשְּׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: took a vow with mohi , these are substitute terms It is taught Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: One who says by mohi has not said anything. By an oath [ bemomata ] that Mohi said, these are substitute terms for an oath.
llm_translation: "Talmudic text: 'He vowed by my hair, these are nicknames.' It was taught: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: One who says 'by my hair' - he said nothing; 'by the blemish of the one who said "my hair"' - these are nicknames for an oath."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הָאוֹמֵר ״לַחוּלִּין שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״, ״לָא כָּשַׁר״ וְ״לָא דְּכֵי״, ״טָהוֹר״ וְ״טָמֵא״, ״נוֹתָר״ וּ״פִיגּוּל״ — אָסוּר.
human_translation: If one says That which I eat of yours laḥullin , not valid not dekhi , ritually pure, or ritually impure, left over [ notar ], or piggul , it is forbidden.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who says, "To the profane that I will eat you," "Not kosher," and "Not fitting," "Pure" and "Impure," "Leftover" and "Pigul" — it is prohibited.

hebrew_text: כְּאִימְּרָא, כְּדִירִים, כָּעֵצִים, כָּאִשִּׁים, כַּמִּזְבֵּחַ, כַּהֵיכָל, כִּירוּשָׁלַיִם. נָדַר בְּאֶחָד מִכׇּל מְשַׁמְּשֵׁי הַמִּזְבֵּחַ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הִזְכִּיר קׇרְבָּן — הֲרֵי זֶה נָדַר בְּקׇרְבָּן. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: הָאוֹמֵר ״יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם.
human_translation: like the lamb like the enclosures, like the wood like the fires like the altar, like the Sanctuary, like Jerusalem, he took a vow with any of the accessories of the altar, although he did not mention an offering, it is a vow an offering. Rabbi Yehuda says: One who says Jerusalem, has not said anything.
llm_translation: As the saying goes, like chambers, like trees, like fires, like the altar, like the temple, like Jerusalem. One who vows by any of the utensils of the altar, even though he did not mention a sacrifice - behold, he has vowed regarding a sacrifice. Rabbi Yehuda says: One who says "Jerusalem" - he has said nothing.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ סַבְרוּהָ: מַאי ״לַחוּלִּין״ — לָא לְחוּלִּין לֶיהֱוֵי, אֶלָּא קׇרְבָּן.
human_translation: They assumed: What is laḥullin ? It shall not [ la ] be non-sacred [ ḥullin ] rather offering.
llm_translation: Gemara: They thought: What is "lachulin" - not for lachulin should it be, but rather korban.

hebrew_text: מַנִּי מַתְנִיתִין? אִי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — לֵית לֵיהּ מִכְּלָל לָאו אַתָּה שׁוֹמֵעַ הֵן. דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: כׇּל תְּנַאי שֶׁאֵינוֹ כִּתְנַאי בְּנֵי גָד וּבְנֵי רְאוּבֵן — אֵינוֹ תְּנַאי.
human_translation: Whose the mishna? If Rabbi Meir, he does not hold from a negative you infer a positive As we learned Rabbi Meir says any condition that is not like the condition of the sons of Gad and the sons of Reuben, is not condition.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Mani matnitin? I Rabbi Meir - leit lei miklal la'av attah shomea hen. Ditanan, Rabbi Meir omer: Kol tenai she'eino kitnai bnei Gad u'bnei Reuven - einu tenai." English translation: "What is the law of the Mishnah? If it is Rabbi Meir - you do not hear from it a general principle. For we learned: Rabbi Meir says: Any stipulation that is not like the stipulation of the sons of Gad and the sons of Reuben - is not a stipulation."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא. אֵימָא סֵיפָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: הָאוֹמֵר ״יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם. מִדְּסֵיפָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה — רֵישָׁא לָאו רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא!
human_translation: Rather, is Rabbi Yehuda. Say the latter clause Rabbi Yehuda says: One who says Jerusalem has not said anything. From latter clause is Rabbi Yehuda, first clause is not Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Rather, it is Rabbi Yehuda. Say the latter part, Rabbi Yehuda says: One who says "Jerusalem" - he said nothing. From the latter part, Rabbi Yehuda - the beginning is not Rabbi Yehuda!

hebrew_text: כּוּלֵּהּ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: שֶׁרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: הָאוֹמֵר ״יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם.
human_translation: The entire Rabbi Yehuda, and this is what is teaching: as Rabbi Yehuda says, one who says Jerusalem has not said anything,
llm_translation: The entirety of it is Rabbi Yehuda, and thus it was taught: Rabbi Yehuda says: One who says "Jerusalem" - he said nothing.

hebrew_text: וְכִי אָמַר ״כִּירוּשָׁלַיִם״, לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מִי מִיתְּסַר? וְהָתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: הָאוֹמֵר ״כִּירוּשָׁלַיִם״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם, עַד שֶׁיִּדּוֹר בְּדָבָר הַקָּרֵב בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם!
human_translation: When says like Jerusalem, is it prohibited according to Rabbi Yehuda? Isn’t it taught Rabbi Yehuda says: One who says like Jerusalem has not said anything unless he vows by means of an item that is sacrificed in Jerusalem.
llm_translation: And when he said "Jerusalem," to Rabbi Yehuda who is being excluded? And it was taught: Rabbi Yehuda says: One who says "Jerusalem" — he said nothing until he dwells in the matter that is close in Jerusalem!

hebrew_text: כּוּלַּהּ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, וּתְרֵי תַּנָּאֵי אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: The entire Rabbi Yehuda, and two tanna’im in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: The entirety is Rabbi Yehuda, and two Tannaim dispute in the school of Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא: ״חוּלִּין״ ״הַחוּלִּין״ ״כְּחוּלִּין״, בֵּין ״שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״ וּבֵין ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל לָךְ״, — מוּתָּר. ״לַחוּלִּין שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״ — אָסוּר. ״לַחוּלִּין לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ — מוּתָּר.
human_translation: It is taught Non-sacred, The non-sacred, Like the non-sacred, whether That which I eat of yours, or: That which I do not eat of yours, permitted. That which I eat of yours laḥullin , forbidden. That which I do not eat of yours laḥullin , permitted
llm_translation: It was taught: "Chulin," "HaChulin," "KeChulin," whether "she'ochal lach" or "shelo ochal lach," - permissible. "LaChulin she'ochal lach" - forbidden. "LaChulin lo ochal lach" - permissible.

hebrew_text: רֵישָׁא מַנִּי — רַבִּי מֵאִיר הִיא, דְּלֵית לֵיהּ מִכְּלָל לָאו אַתָּה שׁוֹמֵעַ הֵין.
human_translation: Who is the first clause It is Rabbi Meir, who does not hold from a negative you infer a positive
llm_translation: The beginning is attributed to Rabbi Meir, for he does not have anything in the category of "you shall surely hear."

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: ״לַחוּלִּין לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ — מוּתָּר. וְהָתְנַן: ״לַקׇּרְבָּן לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ — רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹסֵר. וְקַשְׁיָא לַן: הָא לֵית לֵיהּ מִכְּלָל לָאו אַתָּה שׁוֹמֵעַ הֵין?
human_translation: say the latter clause That which I will not eat of yours laḥullin , permitted But didn’t we learn I will not eat of yours lakorban , Rabbi Meir prohibits poses a difficulty for us not from a negative you infer a positive
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: 'Lachulin lo ochal lach' — mutar. Ve'hatnan: 'Lakorban lo ochal lach' — Rabbi Meir oser. V'kashya lan: Ha leit lei miklal la'av attah shomea hein?" English translation: "Say the latter clause: 'For secular purposes, I may not eat you' — permitted. And we learned in a Mishnah: 'For sacrificial purposes, I may not eat you' — Rabbi Meir prohibits. And our difficulty is: Does it not lack a generalization from which you can infer a negative?"

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא, נַעֲשָׂה כְּאוֹמֵר: לְקׇרְבָּן יְהֵא, לְפִיכָךְ לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ. הָכָא נָמֵי הָכִי קָאָמַר לֵיהּ: לָא חוּלִּין לֶיהֱוֵי, לְפִיכָךְ לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ!
human_translation: And Rabbi Abba said: It is as though he said: It shall be for an offering [ lekorban ], therefore I will not eat yours. Here too, this is what he said to him: It shall not be non-sacred, therefore I will not eat yours.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Abba said, it was done as it says: "For a sacrifice it shall be," therefore I cannot eat for you. Here too, he said to him likewise: It should not be profane, therefore I cannot eat for you!

hebrew_text: הַאי תַּנָּא סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר בַּחֲדָא וּפְלִיג עֲלֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא? סָבַר לַהּ כְּוָתֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא — דְּלֵית לֵיהּ מִכְּלָל לָאו אַתָּה שׁוֹמֵעַ הֵין, וּפְלִיג עֲלֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא — בְּקׇרְבָּן.
human_translation: This tanna holds in accordance with Rabbi Meir in one and disagrees with his in another. He holds in accordance with his in one that he does not hold that from a negative you infer a positive And he disagrees with his in another in an offering.
llm_translation: This Tanna holds according to Rabbi Meir in one aspect and disagrees with him in another aspect? He holds according to him in one aspect - that he does not include it in the general category, and he disagrees with him in another aspect - regarding the offering.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: הָא דְאָמַר ״לַחוּלִּין״, וְהָא דְּאָמַר ״לָא לְחוּלִּין״, דְּמַשְׁמַע: לָא לֶיהֱוֵי חוּלִּין אֶלָּא כְּקׇרְבָּן.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: This where he said: as non-sacred, and that where he said: not as non-sacred, which indicates: It shall not be non-sacred rather like an offering,
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: This that it says "lachulin," and this that it says "la lachulin," implies: it should not be lachulin except as a korban.

hebrew_text: ״טָהוֹר״ וְ״טָמֵא״, ״נוֹתָר״ וּ״פִיגּוּל״ — אָסוּר. בָּעֵי רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: ״הֲרֵי עָלַי כִּבְשַׂר זִבְחֵי שְׁלָמִים לְאַחַר זְרִיקַת דָּמִים״, מַהוּ?
human_translation: ritually pure, or ritually impure, left over [ notar ], or piggul , it is forbidden. Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma: This to me the meat of peace-offerings after the sprinkling of blood, what is
llm_translation: "Tahor" and "tamei," "notar" and "pigul" — prohibited. Rami bar Hama inquired: "If upon me is like the flesh of peace-offerings after the sprinkling of the blood," what is it?

hebrew_text: אִי דְּקָאָמַר בְּהָדֵין לִישָּׁנָא — בְּהֶיתֵּרָא קָא מַתְפֵּיס! אֶלָּא: כְּגוֹן דְּמַחֵית בְּשַׂר זִבְחֵי שְׁלָמִים, וּמַחֵית דְּהֶיתֵּרָא גַּבֵּיהּ, וְאָמַר: ״זֶה כָּזֶה״, מַאי: בְּעִיקָּרוֹ קָא מַתְפֵּיס, אוֹ בְּהֶיתֵּרָא קָא מַתְפֵּיס?
human_translation: If he said with this formulation, he is associating with a permitted Rather, where he places the meat of peace-offerings and he places that is permitted next to it. And he says: This is like that. what Is he associating with the original or is he associating with the permitted
llm_translation: The text is saying: "If he said it in that case - he is grasping at straws! Rather, for example, if one destroys the meat of peace offerings, and he destroys the fat of it, and says: 'This is like this,' what is it: is he grasping at the essence, or is he grasping at the excess?"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא, תָּא שְׁמַע: נוֹתָר וּפִיגּוּל.
human_translation: Rava said: Come hear notar or piggul ,
llm_translation: Rava said, come and hear: "Leftover" and "Pigul."

hebrew_text: וְהָא נוֹתָר וּפִיגּוּל לְאַחַר זְרִיקַת דָּמִים הוּא.
human_translation: But notar and piggul are after the sprinkling of the blood,
llm_translation: And the ha notar and pigul to after zrikat damim he.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב נָתָן: בְּנוֹתָר שֶׁל עוֹלָה. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִם כֵּן, לִיתְנֵי בִּבְשַׂר עוֹלָה!
human_translation: Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said to him: notar of a burnt-offering. said to If so, let it teach to the meat of a burnt-offering.
llm_translation: He said to him Rav Huna son of Rav Natan: "With the leftover of the burnt offering." He said to him: "If so, let it be given with the flesh of the burnt offering!"

hebrew_text: לָא מִיבַּעְיָא קָאָמַר: לָא מִיבַּעְיָא ״בְּשַׂר עוֹלָה״ דְּאָסוּר, דְּהָא בְּקׇרְבָּן קָא מַתְפֵּיס, נוֹתָר וּפִיגּוּל דְּעוֹלָה אִיצְטְרִיכָא,
human_translation: is speaking It is not necessary. It is not necessary associates meat of a burnt-offering, forbidden, as he extends an offering notar and piggul of a burnt-offering, it is necessary to say
llm_translation: He is not asking a question: He is not asking, "The meat of a burnt offering" is prohibited, for in the case of a sacrifice it is effective, and the leftover and disqualified offering of a burnt offering are necessary.

hebrew_text: סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא כְּאִיסּוּר נוֹתָר, כְּאִיסּוּר פִּיגּוּל, וְהָוֵה לֵיהּ כְּמַתְפֵּיס בְּדָבָר הָאָסוּר, וְלָא מִיתְּסַר, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: enter your mind to say like the prohibition of notar like the prohibition of piggul , and this would be like one who associates an item that is forbidden is not forbidden, teaches us
llm_translation: I would say, according to the prohibition of what remains, like the prohibition of pigul, and it is considered as if he is grasping onto a forbidden matter, and not withdrawing, this is what he is teaching us.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: אֵיזֶהוּ אִיסָּר הָאָמוּר בְּתוֹרָה? אָמַר: ״הֲרֵינִי שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל בָּשָׂר וְשֶׁלֹּא אֶשְׁתֶּה יַיִן כַּיּוֹם שֶׁמֵּת בּוֹ אָבִיו״, ״כַּיּוֹם שֶׁמֵּת בּוֹ רַבּוֹ״, ״כַּיּוֹם שֶׁנֶּהֱרַג בּוֹ גְּדַלְיָה בֶּן אֲחִיקָם״, ״כַּיּוֹם שֶׁרָאִיתִי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם בְּחוּרְבָּנָהּ״, וְאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: וְהוּא שֶׁנָּדוּר בְּאוֹתוֹ הַיּוֹם.
human_translation: raises an objection Which is the prohibition [ issar ] mentioned in the Torah? one said: I hereby that I will not eat meat and I will not drink wine like the day his father died, Like the day his teacher died, Like the day Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, was killed Like the day I saw Jerusalem in its destruction. And Shmuel said: And this is if he was obligated by vow on that day
llm_translation: The question was raised: What is the vow of abstention mentioned in the Torah? He said: "Behold, I will not eat meat or drink wine on the day my father dies," "on the day my teacher dies," "on the day Gedaliah son of Ahikam was killed," "on the day I saw Jerusalem in its destruction," and Samuel said: And this is what was vowed on that day.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? לָאו כְּגוֹן דְּקָאֵי בְּחַד בְּשַׁבָּא דְּמִית בֵּיהּ אֲבוּהּ, וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּאִיכָּא טוּבָא חַד בְּשַׁבָּא דְּהֶיתֵּרָא, וְקָתָנֵי אָסוּר. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ בְּעִיקָּר הוּא מַתְפֵּיס.
human_translation: What are the circumstances? Is it not for example, it was Sunday, on which his father died? And although there were many permitted Sundays and the tanna teaches prohibited. Learn from this that he associates the original
llm_translation: "How are the circumstances? Not like a case where one stands in a marketplace and his father dies, and even though there is another good thing that happened to him in the marketplace, and the Mishnah teaches it is forbidden. Learn from this that fundamentally he is apprehended."

hebrew_text: דִּשְׁמוּאֵל, הָכִי אִיתְּמַר, אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: וְהוּא שֶׁנָּדוּר וּבָא מֵאוֹתוֹ הַיּוֹם וְאֵילָךְ.
human_translation: this is how of Shmuel was stated: Shmuel said: And this is if he was continuously obligated by a vow from that day forward
llm_translation: Samuel the Babylonian said, Samuel said: "And he who is pledged and comes from that day and onward."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבִינָא, תָּא שְׁמַע: ״כְּחַלַּת אַהֲרֹן״, ״וְכִתְרוּמָתוֹ״ — מוּתָּר. הָא ״כִּתְרוּמַת לַחְמֵי תוֹדָה״ — אָסוּר.
human_translation: Ravina said: Come hear like the ḥalla of Aaron, or like his teruma , permitted. But like the teruma of the loaves of the thanks-offering, forbidden.
llm_translation: Ravina said, come and hear: "Like the offering of Aaron," "and his contribution" - permissible. But "the contribution of the bread of thanksgiving" - prohibited.

hebrew_text: וְהָא תְּרוּמַת לַחְמֵי תוֹדָה — לְאַחַר זְרִיקַת דָּמִים הִיא.
human_translation: But the teruma of the loaves of the thanks-offering is after the sprinkling of the blood.
llm_translation: And this, the offering of the bread of thanksgiving - after the sprinkling of the blood it is.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא: ״כִּתְרוּמַת הַלִּשְׁכָּה״ — אָסוּר.
human_translation: Say like the collection of the chamber, forbidden.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Eima: "Kitrumat haLiksha" - asur. English translation: Say: "The offering of the chamber" - forbidden.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל תְּרוּמַת לַחְמֵי תוֹדָה מַאי — מוּתָּר? לִיתְנֵי לַחְמֵי תוֹדָה, וְכׇל שֶׁכֵּן תְּרוּמָתוֹ! הָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן תְּרוּמַת לַחְמֵי תוֹדָה — תְּרוּמָתוֹ הִיא.
human_translation: But the teruma of the loaves of the thanks-offering, what, permitted? let it teach the loaves of the thanks-offering and teruma of all the more so teaches us this: Teruma of the loaves of the thanks-offering his teruma
llm_translation: But the heave offering of the bread of thanksgiving what — permitted? Let it teach the bread of thanksgiving, and all the more so his heave offering! This teaches us that the heave offering of the bread of thanksgiving is indeed his heave offering.

hebrew_text: וְאִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא: תְּרוּמַת לַחְמֵי תוֹדָה נָמֵי קוֹדֶם זְרִיקַת דָּמִים הוּא. כְּגוֹן דְּאַפְרְשִׁינְהוּ בְּלֵישָׁה.
human_translation: And if you wish, say teruma of the loaves of the thanks-offering also before the sprinkling of the blood, for example, when he separated during the kneading
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: The heave offering of the bread of thanksgiving is considered primary before the sprinkling of the blood. For example, as we explained in Lisha.

hebrew_text: וְכִי הָא דְּאָמַר רַב טוֹבִי בַּר קִיסְנָא אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: לַחְמֵי תוֹדָה שֶׁאֲפָאָן בְּאַרְבַּע חַלּוֹת — יָצָא. וְהָכְתִיב אַרְבָּעִים! לְמִצְוָה.
human_translation: And in accordance with that which Rav Tovi bar Kisna said Shmuel said: one baked the loaves of the thanks-offering as four loaves he has fulfilled Isn’t it written forty to mitzva
llm_translation: And when Rav Tovi bar Kisna said in the name of Shmuel: "Loaves of thanksgiving that are made with four loaves - one has fulfilled the obligation." But it is written forty! For the commandment.

hebrew_text: וְהָא בָּעֵי לְמִשְׁקַל תְּרוּמָה! וְכִי תֵּימָא דְּשָׁקֵיל חֲדָא רִיפְתָּא עַל כּוּלַּהּ — וְהָתְנַן: אֶחָד מִכׇּל קׇרְבָּן. שֶׁלֹּא יִטּוֹל מִקׇּרְבָּן עַל חֲבֵירוֹ! וְכִי תֵּימָא דְּשָׁקֵיל פְּרוּסָה מִכׇּל חַד וְחַד, וְהָתְנַן: ״אֶחָד״, שֶׁלֹּא יִטּוֹל פְּרוּסָה!
human_translation: But he is required to take teruma , And if you would say that he takes one bread for all but didn’t we learn one out of each offering that he should not take from one offering, for another? And if you would say that he takes a slice from each one but didn’t we learn one that he may not take a slice
llm_translation: And this requires weighing the terumah! And if you say that one should weigh one handful for all of it — but we learned: "One" from every offering. He should not take from one offering for his fellow! And if you say that one should weigh a portion from each and every one, but we learned: "One," he should not take a portion!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא דְּאַפְרְשִׁינְהוּ בְּלֵישָׁה. דְּשָׁקֵיל חֲדָא מֵחָמֵץ, וַחֲדָא מִן חַלּוֹת, וַחֲדָא מִן רְקִיקִים, וַחֲדָא מִן רְבוּכָה.
human_translation: Rather, that he separated during kneading. He took one from the leavened bread, one from the loaves, one from the wafers, and one from the flour mixed with water and oil.
llm_translation: Rather, that I may explain it in the language of the Mishnah. He takes one from vinegar, and one from loaves, and one from crackers, and one from porridge.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי: ״הֲרֵי עָלַי כִּבְכוֹר״, רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב אוֹסֵר, וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַתִּיר.
human_translation: Let us say parallel to tanna’im . This to me a firstborn, Rabbi Ya’akov renders forbidden and Rabbi Yehuda renders permitted.
llm_translation: Let us say like the Tannaim: "Behold, upon me is the status of a firstborn," Rabbi Yaakov prohibits, and Rabbi Yehuda permits.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִי נֵימָא לִפְנֵי זְרִיקַת דָּמִים, מַאי טַעְמָא דְמַאן דְּשָׁרֵי. וְאִי לְאַחַר זְרִיקַת דָּמִים, מַאי טַעְמָא דְּמַאן דְּאָסַר? אֶלָּא לָאו,
human_translation: What are the circumstances If we say before the sprinkling of the blood, what is the rationale of the one who renders permitted? And if after the sprinkling of the blood, what is the rationale of the one who renders forbidden? Rather, is it not
llm_translation: "How are the laws of blood similar? If it is said before the sprinkling of blood, what is the reason that one is permitted? And if it is said after the sprinkling of blood, what is the reason that one is forbidden? Rather, it is not so,"

hebrew_text: דְּמַחֵית בְּשַׂר בְּכוֹר וּמַחֵית בָּשָׂר דְּהַאיְךְ גַּבֵּיהּ, וְאָמַר ״זֶה כָּזֶה״. וְתַנָּאֵי הִיא.
human_translation: that he places the meat of a firstborn and he places another meat next to it, and he said: This like that and it is tanna’im
llm_translation: The text reads: "If one destroys the flesh of a firstborn animal and destroys the flesh of this one, how can he redeem it, and he says, 'This one is like that one.' And it is a teaching of the Tannaim."

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לִפְנֵי זְרִיקַת דָּמִים, וּמַאי טַעְמָא דְמַאן דְּשָׁרֵי — אָמַר קְרָא: ״כִּי יִדֹּר״, עַד שֶׁיִּדּוֹר בְּדָבָר הַנָּדוּר, לְאַפּוֹקֵי בְּכוֹר, דְּדָבָר הָאָסוּר הוּא.
human_translation: No, everyone before the sprinkling of the blood, and what is the reason of the one who renders permitted? The verse states: “When takes a vow” until he takes a vow with an item forbidden by means of a vow, to exclude a firstborn, which is an item that is forbidden
llm_translation: Not, all the world, before sprinkling of blood, and what reason that who permits — said scripture: "When he vows," until he fulfills in the matter vowed, to exempt the firstborn, for it is a prohibited matter.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּאָסַר, אָמַר קְרָא: ״לַה׳״, לְרַבּוֹת דָּבָר הָאָסוּר.
human_translation: And the one who renders forbidden the verse states: “To the Lord” to include item that is forbidden
llm_translation: And one who prohibited, said the verse: "to the Lord," to include a matter that is prohibited.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּשָׁרֵי, ״לַה׳״ מַאי עָבֵיד לֵיהּ? מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְמַתְפִּיס בְּחַטָּאת וְאָשָׁם.
human_translation: And the one who renders permitted what does he do with “to the Lord”? He requires to one who associates a sin-offering and a guilt-offering.
llm_translation: The one who permits, "to the Lord," what does he do with it? He needs it for the purpose of acquiring a sin-offering and a guilt-offering.

hebrew_text: וּמָה רָאִיתָ לְרַבּוֹת חַטָּאת וְאָשָׁם וּלְהוֹצִיא אֶת הַבְּכוֹר? מְרַבֶּה אֲנִי חַטָּאת וְאָשָׁם שֶׁהוּא מַתְפִּיס בְּנֶדֶר, וּמוֹצִיא אֲנִי אֶת הַבְּכוֹר שֶׁהוּא קָדוֹשׁ מִמְּעֵי אִמּוֹ.
human_translation: And what did you see to include a sin-offering and a guilt-offering and to exclude the firstborn? I include the sin-offering and guilt-offering that he associates by means of a vow, And I remove the firstborn, because it is sacred from its mother’s womb.
llm_translation: And what did you see to include a sin offering, a guilt offering, and to bring out the firstborn? I include a sin offering and a guilt offering that are subject to a vow, and I bring out the firstborn that is holy from its mother's womb.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּאָסַר, בְּכוֹר נָמֵי מַתְפִּיסוֹ בְּנֶדֶר הוּא. דְּתַנְיָא, מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אָמְרוּ: מִנַּיִן לְנוֹלַד בְּכוֹר בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתוֹ, שֶׁמִּצְוָה לְהַקְדִּישׁוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הַזָּכָר תַּקְדִּישׁ״.
human_translation: And the one who renders forbidden firstborn also associates by a vow, as it is taught They said in the name of Rabbi From where that one has a firstborn born in his home a mitzva to consecrate it? As it is stated: “The males you shall consecrate”
llm_translation: And one who prohibits, the firstborn of his animals he is taking hold of with a vow. As it was taught, in the name of Rabbi they said: From where do we know to sanctify a firstborn born within his house, as it is a commandment to sanctify him, as it is said: "The male you shall sanctify."

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּשָׁרֵי, כִּי לָא מַקְדֵּישׁ לֵיהּ מִי לָא מִיקַּדֵּישׁ?
human_translation: And the one who renders permitted if he does not consecrate it, is it not consecrated?
llm_translation: And who permits, for if one does not sanctify it, who does sanctify it?

hebrew_text: ״כְּאִימְּרָא״, ״כַּדִּירִים״.
human_translation: like the lamb [ imra ] like the enclosures,
llm_translation: "As it was said," "like the deer."

hebrew_text: תָּנָא: ״אִימְּרָא״, ״לְאִימְּרָא״, ״כְּאִימְּרָא״, ״דִּירִים״, ״לַדִּירִים״ ״כַּדִּירִים״, ״עֵצִים״, ״לָעֵצִים״, ״כָּעֵצִים״, ״אִישִּׁים״, ״לָאִישִּׁים״, ״כָּאִישִּׁים״, ״מִזְבֵּחַ״, ״לַמִּזְבֵּחַ״, ״כַּמִּזְבֵּחַ״, ״הֵיכָל״, ״לַהֵיכָל״, ״כַּהֵיכָל״, ״יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״, ״לִירוּשָׁלַיִם״, ״כִּירוּשָׁלַיִם״, כּוּלָּן: ״שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״ — אָסוּר. ״לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ — מוּתָּר.
human_translation: taught a lamb, for a lamb, like a lamb; enclosures, for enclosures, like enclosures; wood, for wood, like wood; fires, for fires, like fires; the altar, for the altar, like the altar; the Sanctuary, for the Sanctuary, like the Sanctuary; Jerusalem, for Jerusalem, like Jerusalem; all of them, That which I will eat of yours, it is forbidden. I will not eat of yours, permitted,
llm_translation: Mishna: "Imra," "le'imra," "ke'imra," "dirim," "ladirim," "kadirim," "etzim," "la'etzim," "ka'etzim," "ishim," "la'ishim," "ka'ishim," "mizbeach," "lamizbeach," "kamizbeach," "heichal," "laheichal," "kaheichal," "Yerushalayim," "liYerushalayim," "kiYerushalayim," all of them: "she'ochal lach" — forbidden. "lo ochal lach" — permitted.

hebrew_text: מַאן שָׁמְעִינַן לֵיהּ דְּלָא שָׁנֵי לֵיהּ ״אִימְּרָא״ ״לְאִימְּרָא״ ״כְּאִימְּרָא״ — רַבִּי מֵאִיר הִיא.
human_translation: Who is we have heard, for whom there is no difference a lamb, for a lamb, like a lamb, It is Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: One who we hear of him that not changes him "Imra" "Le'Imra" "Ke'Imra" - Rabbi Meir it is.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: וְכוּלָּן ״לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ — מוּתָּר. וְהָתְנַן: ״לַקָּרְבָּן לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ — רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹסֵר, וְאָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: נַעֲשָׂה כְּאוֹמֵר ״לְקָרְבָּן יְהֵא, לְפִיכָךְ לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״.
human_translation: say the latter clause all of them, I will not eat of yours, permitted. But didn’t we learn I will not eat of yours for an offering [ lekorban ], Rabbi Meir prohibits And Rabbi Abba said it is as though he said: It shall be for an offering [ lekorban ], therefore I will not eat yours.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: v'chulan 'lo ochal lakh' — mutar. V'hatnan: 'la'karban lo ochal lakh' — Rabbi Meir oser, v'amar Rabbi Abba: na'aseh ke'omer 'le'karban yehai, lefichach lo ochal lakh." English translation: "The Gemara asks: And all of them 'not eaten by you' — permissible. And we learned in a Mishnah: 'Not eaten as a sacrifice by you' — Rabbi Meir prohibits, and Rabbi Abba said: It should be done as it says 'for a sacrifice it shall be, therefore not eaten by you.'"

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא דְּאָמַר ״לָא לְאִימְּרָא״, הָא דְּאָמַר ״לְאִימְּרָא״.
human_translation: This not difficult: This where one said: not [ la ] for a lamb [ le’imra ]. that where he said: For a lamb [ le’imra ].
llm_translation: Not difficult: this that it says "not to say," this that it says "to say."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הָאוֹמֵר ״קׇרְבָּן״, ״עוֹלָה״, ״מִנְחָה״, ״חַטָּאת״, ״תּוֹדָה״, ״שְׁלָמִים״, ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל לָךְ״ — אָסוּר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַתִּיר. ״הַקׇּרְבָּן״, ״כַּקׇּרְבָּן״, ״קׇרְבָּן שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״ — אָסוּר. ״לַקׇּרְבָּן לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ — רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: one who says: An offering, a burnt-offering, a meal-offering, a sin-offering, a thanks-offering, a peace-offering, That which I eat of yours, is forbidden. Rabbi Yehuda renders permitted The offering, like an offering, an offering, That which I will eat of yours, is forbidden. I will not eat of yours for an offering, Rabbi Meir renders forbidden.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who says, "Korban," "Olah," "Mincha," "Chatat," "Todah," "Shelamim," "that I will eat for you" — it is prohibited. Rabbi Yehuda permits it. "HaKorban," "KaKorban," "Korban she'ochel lach" — it is prohibited. "Lakorban lo ochel lach" — Rabbi Meir prohibits it.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ קָתָנֵי ״קׇרְבָּן״, ״הַקׇּרְבָּן״, ״כַּקׇּרְבָּן שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״ — אָסוּר. סְתָמָא תְּנָא כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, דְּלָא שָׁנֵי לֵיהּ בֵּין ״אִימְּרָא״ ״לְאִימְּרָא״.
human_translation: It teaches An offering, the offering, like an offering, That which I will eat of yours, it is forbidden. this unattributed mishna taught in accordance with Rabbi Meir, for whom there is no difference whether a lamb [ imra ] as a lamb [ le’imra ].
llm_translation: The text states: "When it says 'korban,' 'hakorban,' 'like the korban that you eat' - it is forbidden." It is assumed that the anonymous Mishnaic teacher follows the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who does not differentiate between 'imra' and 'le'imra.'

hebrew_text: [אִי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — הָא] דְּקָתָנֵי: ״הַקׇּרְבָּן שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״ — אָסוּר, וְהָתַנְיָא: מוֹדִים חֲכָמִים לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּאוֹמֵר ״הָא קׇרְבָּן״, וְ״הָא עוֹלָה״ וְ״הָא מִנְחָה״ וְ״הָא חַטָּאת שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״ — שֶׁמּוּתָּר? שֶׁלֹּא נָדַר זֶה אֶלָּא בְּחַיֵּי קׇרְבָּן!
human_translation: if it is Rabbi Meir, that which it teaches The offering [ hakorban ], That which I will eat of yours, is forbidden. isn’t it taught the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Yehuda with one who says: This offering [ ha korban ], or this burnt-offering [ ha ola ], or this meal-offering [ ha minḥa ], or this sin-offering [ ha ḥatat ], That I will eat of yours, is permitted? that did not take a vow rather, by the life of the offering,
llm_translation: If Rabbi Meir — this as it is taught: "The offering that you eat" — forbidden, and it was taught: The sages agree with Rabbi Yehuda in saying "this offering," and "this burnt offering," and "this meal offering," and "this sin offering that you eat" — is it permitted? This was not vowed except during the life of the offering!

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא דְּאָמַר ״הָא קׇרְבָּן״, וְהָא דְּאָמַר ״הַקׇּרְבָּן״. מַאי טַעְמָא? חַיֵּי קׇרְבָּן קָאָמַר.
human_translation: This not difficult. This where one said: This offering [ ha korban ], that where one said: The offering [ hakorban ]. What is the reason he is saying the life of offering,
llm_translation: Not difficult: this that said "ha korban," and this that said "ha korban." What is the reason? The lives of the korban he is saying.

hebrew_text: קָתָנֵי: ״לַקׇּרְבָּן לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹסֵר. וְהָא לֵית לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר מִכְּלָל לָאו אַתָּה שׁוֹמֵעַ הֵן! אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: נַעֲשָׂה כְּאוֹמֵר: לְקׇרְבָּן יְהֵא, לְפִיכָךְ לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ.
human_translation: teaches I will not eat of yours is lakorban , Rabbi Meir prohibits Isn’t Rabbi Meir does not hold that from a negative you infer a positive Rabbi Abba said: It is as though he said: It shall be for an offering [ lekorban ], therefore I will not eat yours.
llm_translation: The text states: "For the sacrifice, you shall not eat it," Rabbi Meir prohibits. But does Rabbi Meir not have it from the inclusive statement? Do you not hear "yes"! Rabbi Abba said: It should be done as it says: "For the sacrifice it shall be," therefore you shall not eat it.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״קֻוֽנָּם פִּי מְדַבֵּר עִמָּךְ״, ״יָדִי עוֹשָׂה עִמָּךְ״, ״רַגְלִי מְהַלֶּכֶת עִמָּךְ״ — אָסוּר.
human_translation: One who says to another: konam my mouth speak with you, my hand work with you, my foot walk with you, it is prohibited
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who says to his fellow, "Your mouth is speaking with me," "My hand is doing with you," "My foot is walking with you" — is forbidden.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ וּרְמִינְהוּ: חוֹמֶר בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת מִבַּנְּדָרִים וּבַנְּדָרִים מִבַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת. חוֹמֶר בַּנְּדָרִים, שֶׁהַנְּדָרִים חָלִים עַל הַמִּצְוָה כְּבָרְשׁוּת, מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת. וְחוֹמֶר בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת, שֶׁהַשְּׁבוּעוֹת חָלוֹת עַל דָּבָר שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מַמָּשׁ וְשֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַמָּשׁ, מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בַּנְּדָרִים.
human_translation: raises a contradiction stricture to oaths beyond to vows, and to vows beyond to oaths. The stricture to vows is that vows take effect with regard to a mitzva as with regard to optional which is not the case with regard to oaths, And the stricture to oaths is that oaths take effect upon a matter that has substance and a matter that does not have substance, which is not the case with regard to vows,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara and it was asked: A stringency in oaths over vows, and in vows over oaths. A stringency in vows, for vows take effect on a mitzvah as on a reshus, which is not the case with oaths. And a stringency in oaths, for oaths take effect on something tangible and intangible, which is not the case with vows." English translation:

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: בְּאוֹמֵר ״יֵאָסֵר פִּי לְדִיבּוּרִי״, ״יָדַי לְמַעֲשֵׂיהֶם״, ״רַגְלַי לְהִילּוּכָן״. דַּיְקָא נָמֵי, דְּקָתָנֵי ״פִּי מְדַבֵּר עִמָּךְ״, וְלָא קָתָנֵי ״שֶׁאֲנִי מְדַבֵּר עִמָּךְ״.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said: to one who says: My mouth shall be forbidden to my speech, My hands to their work, My feet to their walking. is also precise as it teaches: my mouth speak with you, and it does not teach: That which I speak with you.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said: When it says, "Let my mouth be silenced from speaking," "Let my hands be still from their actions," "Let my feet not walk in their ways." It is precisely stated, as it was taught: "My mouth speaks with you," and it does not teach, "that I speak with you."

hebrew_text: הַדְרָן עֲלָךְ כׇּל כִּנּוּיֵי
llm_translation: We will return to you, all the designations.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ וְאֵלּוּ מוּתָּרִין: ״חוּלִּין שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״, ״כִּבְשַׂר חֲזִיר״, ״כַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה״, ״כְּעוֹרוֹת לְבוּבִין״, ״כִּנְבֵילוֹת וּטְרֵיפוֹת״, ״כִּשְׁקָצִים וּרְמָשִׂים״, ״כְּחַלַּת אַהֲרֹן וְכִתְרוּמָתוֹ״ — מוּתָּר.
human_translation: And these are permitted: That which I will eat of yours non-sacred [ ḥullin ]; like pig meat; Like idol worship; Like hides whose hearts were removed Like animal carcasses and animals with a wound that will cause them to die within twelve months [ tereifot ]; Like repugnant creatures and creeping animals; Like the ḥalla of Aaron, or like his teruma ; permitted.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "And these are permitted: 'Non-sacred items that someone else eats for you,' 'pork meat,' 'foreign worship,' 'the fat-tails,' 'nevelot and treifot,' 'creeping things and rodents,' 'the worm of Aaron's staff and its tithe' — are permitted."

hebrew_text: הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשְׁתּוֹ ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ עָלַי כְּאִימָּא״ — פּוֹתְחִין לוֹ פֶּתַח מִמָּקוֹם אַחֵר. שֶׁלֹּא יָקֵל רֹאשׁוֹ לְכָךְ.
human_translation: who says to his wife: You are hereby to me like mother, is broached with him by a different extenuation, that he will not lightly.
llm_translation: One who says to his wife, "Behold, you are upon me like my mother," we open for him a different path, so that his head should not become light because of this.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר ״חוּלִּין שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״ הָא אָמַר ״לַחוּלִּין שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ״, מַשְׁמַע: לָא לְחוּלִּין לֶיהֱוֵי אֶלָּא קׇרְבָּן.
human_translation: the reason that he said: That which I will eat of yours ḥullin ; but he said: That which I will eat of yours laḥullin , indicates will not [ la ] be non-sacred [ ḥullin ], rather an offering,
llm_translation: Gemara: The reason for what he said, "Chulin that you may eat," is this: he said, "for the Chulin that you may eat," implying: not for Chulin should it be, but rather a Korban.

hebrew_text: מַנִּי מַתְנִיתִין? אִי רַבִּי מֵאִיר — הָא לֵית לֵיהּ מִכְּלָל
human_translation: Whose the mishna? If Rabbi Meir, isn’t he of not From
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna of this Mishnah? If it is Rabbi Meir - this does not include him in the general category.

hebrew_text: לָאו אַתָּה שׁוֹמֵעַ הֵן! וְאֶלָּא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, הַיְינוּ רֵישָׁא!
human_translation: a negative you infer a positive And rather Rabbi Yehuda, this is the first clause.
llm_translation: Not you hear yes! But Rabbi Yehuda, that is the beginning!

hebrew_text: אַיְּידֵי דְּקָתָנֵי ״כִּבְשַׂר חֲזִיר״, ״כַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה״, לְהָכִי קָתָנֵי ״חוּלִּין״.
human_translation: since teaches like pig meat like idol worship, it therefore teaches non-sacred.
llm_translation: Through what means does it teach the Mishnah "like pig meat," "like foreign worship"? Therefore it teaches in "Hullin."

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא אָמַר: הָכִי קָתָנֵי, וְאֵלּוּ מוּתָּרִין: ״כְּחוּלִּין״, ״כִּבְשַׂר חֲזִיר״, ״כַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה״. וְאִי לָא תְּנָא חוּלִּין, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא בָּעֵי שְׁאֵלָה.
human_translation: Ravina said this is is teaching: And these are permitted: like non-sacred like pig meat, like idol worship. And if it did not teach non-sacred I would say requires, a request
llm_translation: Ravina said: Thus it was taught, and these are permitted: "like sand," "like pig meat," "like foreign worship." And if the Mishnah did not teach "like sand," I would have said it requires inquiry.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אִיכָּא לְאַסּוֹקֵי עַל דַּעְתָּא הָכִי? הָא מִדְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשְׁתּוֹ ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ עָלַי כְּאִימָּא״ — פּוֹתְחִין לוֹ פֶּתַח מִמָּקוֹם אַחֵר, מִכְּלָל דְּרֵישָׁא לָא בָּעֲיָא שְׁאֵלָה! אֶלָּא מְחַוַּורְתָּא, חוּלִּין מִמֵּילָא נַסְבַהּ.
human_translation: But is there to consider this But from that the latter clause teaches who says to his wife: You are hereby to me like mother, broached with him by a different extenuation, it may be inferred that the first clause does not necessitate a request Rather, it is clear non-sacred was cited tangentially
llm_translation: And who is fit to engage in matters of knowledge like this? This is learned in the latter part: One who says to his wife, "Behold, you are to me like my mother" — we open for him another door, as it is not necessary to ask a question from the general principle! Rather, from the pit of the stomach, the mundane is drawn from the extraordinary.

hebrew_text: מְנָהָנֵי מִילֵּי? אָמַר קְרָא: ״אִישׁ כִּי יִדֹּר נֶדֶר לַה׳״ — עַד שֶׁיִּדּוֹר בְּדָבָר הַנָּדוּר.
human_translation: From where is this matter the verse states: “When a man takes a vow to the Lord” until one takes a vow of an item that is a vow
llm_translation: Benefit of words? Scripture says: "When a man makes a vow to the Lord" - until he vows in the matter of the vow.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ בְּדָבָר הָאָסוּר נָמֵי, דְּהָא כְּתִיב ״לֶאְסֹר אִסָּר עַל נַפְשׁוֹ״! ״לֶאְסֹר אִסָּר״ מִבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא: אֵיזֶהוּ אִיסָּר הָאָמוּר בַּתּוֹרָה כּוּ׳.
human_translation: If so, even with an item forbidden also as it is written: “To bind his soul with a bond [ issar ],” “To bind his soul with a bond” is necessary for that which is taught What is the bond mentioned in the Torah.
llm_translation: If so, even in a matter that is forbidden indeed, for it is written "to forbid a prohibition upon himself"! "To forbid a prohibition" - the Tanna requires it as taught: What is the prohibition mentioned in the Torah?

hebrew_text: הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשְׁתּוֹ הֲרֵי אַתְּ כְּאִימָּא כּוּ׳. וּרְמִינְהוּ: הֲרֵי אַתְּ עָלַי כִּבְשַׂר אִימָּא, כִּבְשַׂר אֲחוֹתִי, כְּעׇרְלָה, וּכְכִלְאֵי הַכֶּרֶם — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם!
human_translation: who says to his wife: You are hereby like mother, raises a contradiction You are hereby to me like the flesh of mother, like the flesh of my sister, like the fruit of a tree during the first three years after its planting [ orla ], or like diverse kinds in a vineyard, he has said nothing.
llm_translation: One who says to his wife, "Behold, you are like my mother," and they asked: "Behold, you are upon me like the flesh of my mother, the flesh of my sister, like uncircumcision, and like the forbidden parts of the vineyard" — he did not say anything!

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, וְצָרִיךְ שְׁאֵלָה מִדְּרַבָּנַן. רָבָא אָמַר: הָא בְּתַלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים, הָא בְּעַם הָאָרֶץ.
human_translation: Abaye said: He has said nothing by Torah law, However, he needs a request by rabbinic law. Rava said: That to Torah scholars, This to an ignoramus,
llm_translation: Abaye said: He did not say anything from the Torah, and one needs to ask a question from the Rabbis. Rava said: This is with the disciples of the sages, this is with the common people.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: הַנּוֹדֵר בַּתּוֹרָה — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם. וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: וְצָרִיךְ שְׁאֵלָה לְחָכָם. וְאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: וְתַלְמִיד חָכָם אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ שְׁאֵלָה.
human_translation: And it is taught One who takes a vow with a Torah has not said anything, And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: But he needs a request to a halakhic authority And Rav Naḥman said: And a Torah scholar does not need a request.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught: One who vows regarding the Torah - he said nothing. And Rabbi Yochanan said: And one needs to ask a sage. And Rav Nachman said: And a Torah scholar does not need to ask.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא: הַנּוֹדֵר בַּתּוֹרָה — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם. בְּמַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בָּהּ — דְּבָרָיו קַיָּימִין. בָּהּ וּבְמַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בָּהּ — דְּבָרָיו קַיָּימִין.
human_translation: It is taught One who takes a vow with a Torah has not said anything, with what is written in his statement is upheld. with it and with what is written in it, his statement is upheld.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: One who vows regarding the Torah - he has not said anything. With what is written in it - his words are established. In it and with what is written in it - his words are established.

hebrew_text: קָתָנֵי ״בְּמַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בָּהּ״ — דְּבָרָיו קַיָּימִין, ״בָּהּ וּבְמַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בָּהּ״ — צְרִיךְ לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: It is taught with what is written in his statement is upheld. Need it be said with it and with what is written in it?
llm_translation: It was taught: "In what is written in it" - his words stand; "In it and in what is written in it" - is it necessary to say?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן, לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — דְּמַחֲתָא אוֹרָיְיתָא אַאַרְעָא, הָא — דְּנָקֵיט לַהּ בִּידֵיהּ. מַחֲתָא עַל אַרְעָא — דַּעְתֵּיהּ אַגְּוִילֵי. נָקֵט לַהּ בִּידֵיהּ — דַּעְתֵּיהּ עַל הָאַזְכָּרוֹת שֶׁבָּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman said: not difficult. This where the Torah is placed on the ground, that where he is holding it in his hands. it is placed on the ground, his thoughts are concerning the parchment, he is holding it in his hands his thoughts are concerning the mentions [ azkarot ] that are in it,
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said, it is not difficult: this - that he extinguished the Torah light in the land, this - that he took it in his hands. Extinguished on the land - his thoughts will be confused. Took it in his hands - his thoughts will be on the memories within it.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: דְּמַחֲתָא עַל אַרְעָא. וְהָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן, דְּאַף עַל גַּב דְּמַחֲתָא עַל אַרְעָא — כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר ״בְּמַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בָּהּ״ מַהֲנֵי. וְזוֹ וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר זוֹ קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: And if you wish, say where it is placed on the ground, and this teaches us that even though it is placed on the ground, since he said: With what is written in it, it is effective And teaches This, and it is unnecessary to say that.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: that it is crushed on the ground. And this is what is implied to us, that even though it is crushed on the ground - since it says "with what is written in it," it is effective. And this, and there is no need to say this, it is taught.

hebrew_text: וְאִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא: כּוּלָּהּ מְצִיעֲתָא נָמֵי דְּנָקֵיט לֵיהּ בִּידֵיהּ. וְהָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן: כֵּיוָן דְּנָקֵיט לֵיהּ בִּידֵיהּ, אַף עַל גַּב דְּלָא אָמַר אֶלָּא ״בָּהּ״ — כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר ״בְּמַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בָּהּ״ דָּמֵי.
human_translation: And if you wish, say the entire middle clause, where he is holding in his hands. And teaches us this: Since he is holding it in his hands, even though he said only: With considered like one who said: With what is written in it.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: The whole offering she also brings with her own hands. And this is what we hear: Once she brings it with her own hands, even though he did not say except "with it" - it is similar to one who says "with what is written in it."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֲנִי יָשֵׁן״, ״שֶׁאֲנִי מְדַבֵּר״, ״שֶׁאֲנִי מְהַלֵּךְ״, הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשָּׁה ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֲנִי מְשַׁמְּשֵׁךְ״ — הֲרֵי זֶה בְּ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: Sleeping is for me as if an offering [ konam ], Speaking is for me; Walking is for me; one who says to his wife: Engaging in sexual intercourse with you is konam for me, he is in “He shall not profane his word”
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "If one says, 'I am asleep,' 'I am speaking,' 'I am walking,' or says to a woman, 'I am engaging with you,' — this is considered as if he did not begin his statement."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיתְּמַר: ״קֻוֽנָּם עֵינַי בְּשֵׁינָה הַיּוֹם אִם אִישַׁן לְמָחָר״, אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: אַל יִשַׁן הַיּוֹם, שֶׁמָּא יִשַׁן לְמָחָר. וְרַב נַחְמָן אָמַר: יִשַׁן הַיּוֹם, וְלָא חָיְישִׁינַן שֶׁמָּא יִשַׁן לְמָחָר. וּמוֹדֶה רַב יְהוּדָה בְּאוֹמֵר ״קֻוֽנָּם עֵינַי בְּשֵׁינָה לְמָחָר אִם אִישַׁן הַיּוֹם״, שֶׁיִּשַׁן הַיּוֹם.
human_translation: It was stated Sleeping is konam for my eyes today if I will sleep tomorrow, Rav Yehuda said Rav said: He may not sleep today, lest he sleep tomorrow And Rav Naḥman said: He may sleep today, and we are not concerned that he will perhaps sleep tomorrow, And Rav Yehuda concedes in he says: Sleeping is konam for my eyes tomorrow if I sleep today, he may sleep today.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara: 'Kunnam einai b'sheinah hayom im ishan lemachar,' Amar Rav Yehudah Amar Rav: Al yishan hayom, shema yishan lemachar. VeRav Nachman Amar: Yishan hayom, v'lo chayeshinan shema yishan lemachar. Umodeh Rav Yehudah b'omer 'Kunnam einai b'sheinah lemachar im ishan hayom,' sheyishan hayom." English translation: Gemara: "It was stated: 'Seal my eyes in sleep today if I sleep tomorrow.' Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: One should not sleep during the day, lest he sleep tomorrow. And Rav Nachman said: One should sleep during the day, and we are not concerned lest he sleep tomorrow. And Rav Yehudah agrees when he says, 'Seal my eyes in sleep tomorrow if I sleep today,' that one should sleep today."

hebrew_text: כִּי לָא מִזְדְּהַיר — בִּתְנָאָה, אֲבָל בְּאִיסּוּרָא — מִזְדְּהַר.
human_translation: when is not careful, with regard to a condition. However, is careful with regard to a prohibition.
llm_translation: For not cautious - with permission, but with prohibition - cautious.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֲנִי יָשֵׁן, שֶׁאֲנִי מְהַלֵּךְ, שֶׁאֲנִי מְדַבֵּר וְכוּ׳. הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא כִּדְקָתָנֵי, ״שֶׁאֲנִי יָשֵׁן״ מִי הָוֵי נִדְרָא? וְהָתְנַן: חוֹמֶר בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת, שֶׁהַשְּׁבוּעוֹת חָלוֹת עַל דָּבָר שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מַמָּשׁ וְעַל דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַמָּשׁ, מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בַּנְּדָרִים. וְשֵׁינָה דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַמָּשׁ הוּא! אֶלָּא דְּאָמַר: ״קֻוֽנָּם עֵינַי בְּשֵׁינָה״.
human_translation: We learned Sleeping is konam for me, Walking is for me, Speaking is for me, What are the circumstances? If we say as teaches, is Sleeping is for me, vow? But didn’t we learn stringency with regard to oaths that oaths apply to something that has actual and to something that does not have actual which is not the case with regard to vows. And sleep is something that does not have actual Rather, where he said: Sleeping is konam for my eyes.
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: "Their measure when I am asleep, when I am walking, when I am speaking, etc." How is it similar? If you say it is as we learned, "When I am asleep," who is being referred to? But we learned in a Mishnah: There is a stringency with oaths, as oaths can be taken regarding something tangible and regarding something intangible, which is not the case with vows. And sleep is something intangible! Rather, it means: "Their measure is upon me in my sleep."

hebrew_text: וְאִי דְּלָא יָהֵיב שִׁיעוּרָא, מִי שָׁבְקִינַן לֵיהּ עַד דְּעָבַר אִיסּוּר ״בַּל יַחֵל״? וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אִישַׁן שְׁלֹשָׁה יָמִים״ — מַלְקִין אוֹתוֹ וְיָשֵׁן לְאַלְתַּר!
