human_translation: And if he did not give a measurement do we let him until he transgresses the prohibition: He shall not profane, But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say an oath that I will not sleep for three days, flogs him and he may sleep immediately,
llm_translation: And if he did not give a measure, do we leave it for him until he transgresses the prohibition of "do not delay"? But didn't Rabbi Yochanan say: "An oath that one does not fulfill within three days" — he is lashed and must fulfill it immediately!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא דַּאֲמַר ״קֻוֽנָּם עֵינַי בְּשֵׁינָה לְמָחָר אִם אִישַׁן הַיּוֹם״. הָא אָמְרַתְּ כׇּל בְּאִסּוּרֵיהּ, מִזְדְּהַר?
human_translation: Rather, where said: Sleeping is konam to my eyes tomorrow if I sleep today. didn’t you say is careful with regard to any prohibition
llm_translation: Rather, it was said, "I will guard my eyes with sleep for tomorrow if a man sleeps today." Is it not that you said all its prohibitions, is one cautious?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא דְּאָמַר ״קֻוֽנָּם עֵינַי בְּשֵׁינָה הַיּוֹם אִם אִישַׁן לְמָחָר״. וְאִי לָא נָיֵים הַיּוֹם, כִּי נָיֵים לְמָחָר מַאי ״בַּל יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״ אִיכָּא? אֶלָּא לָאו בִּדְנָיֵים. אַלְמָא אִיתֵיהּ דְּנָיֵים. וּתְיוּבְתָּא דְרַב יְהוּדָה!
human_translation: Rather, is obvious where said: Sleeping is konam to my eyes today if I sleep tomorrow. And if he does not sleep today, when he sleeps tomorrow, what He shall not profane his word, is there? Rather, is it not with regard to where he slept Apparently, there is in which he sleeps And a refutation of Rav Yehuda
llm_translation: Rather, it is obvious that he said, "Establish their eyes in sleep today, if one sleeps tomorrow." And if today is not suitable, for sleeping tomorrow, what is the meaning of "he should not delay his word"? Rather, it is not in the context of sleeping. It is evident that there is a suitable time for sleeping. And the excellence of Rav Yehuda!

hebrew_text: כִּי קָתָנֵי, דְּאִי נָיֵים.
human_translation: When teaches that if he did sleep
llm_translation: It is taught, for if it were pleasant.

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם כִּדְקָתָנֵי וּמַאי ״בַּל יַחֵל״ — מִדְּרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Ravina said Actually, as it teaches, And what He shall not profane? by rabbinic law.
llm_translation: Ravina said: Always follow the opinion of the Tanna, and what is "Bal Yachel" - from the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אִיכָּא ״בַּל יַחֵל״ מִדְּרַבָּנַן? אִין, וְהָתַנְיָא: דְּבָרִים הַמּוּתָּרִין וַאֲחֵרִים נָהֲגוּ בָּהֶן אִיסּוּר — אִי אַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לְהַתִּירָן בִּפְנֵיהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: But is there a He shall not profane, by rabbinic law? Yes, and it is taught matters that are permitted, but others are accustomed to observe a prohibition with regard to them, you may not permit before as it is stated: “He shall not profane his word”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And is there "Bal Yachel" from the Rabbis? No, and it was taught: Things that are permitted and others have made them forbidden - if you are not authorized to permit them in their presence, as it is stated: "He shall not profane his word."

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: ״שֶׁאַתְּ נֶהֱנֵית לִי עַד הַפֶּסַח אִם תֵּלְכִי לְבֵית אָבִיךְ עַד הֶחָג״, הָלְכָה לִפְנֵי הַפֶּסַח — אֲסוּרָה בַּהֲנָאָתוֹ עַד הַפֶּסַח.
human_translation: We learned Deriving benefit from me until Passover for you if you go to your father’s house until the festival she went before Passover, she is prohibited from deriving benefit from him until Passover,
llm_translation: We learned: "If 'you will enjoy me until Passover, if you go to your father's house until the holiday,'" the halacha before Passover - it is forbidden to benefit from it until Passover.

hebrew_text: הָלְכָה לִפְנֵי הַפֶּסַח — אֲסוּרָה, לֹא הָלְכָה — לָא!
human_translation: she went before Passover prohibited for her she did not go, not
llm_translation: Halacha before Pesach - forbidden, not Halacha - no!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: הָלְכָה לִפְנֵי הַפֶּסַח — אֲסוּרָה, וְלוֹקָה. לֹא הָלְכָה — אֲסוּרָה בְּעָלְמָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba said she went before Passover, she prohibited from and she is flogged. she did not go merely prohibited for her
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Abba: Halacha before Pesach - forbidden, and one is liable. If not Halacha - forbidden in general.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: אַחַר הַפֶּסַח בְּ״בַל יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״. וְאִי דְּלָא אִיתְהֲנִי לִפְנֵי הַפֶּסַח, מִי אִיכָּא ״בַּל יַחֵל״? אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא דְּאִיתְהֲנִי. אַלְמָא מִיתְהֲנֵי,
human_translation: Say the latter clause after Passover in He shall not profane his word. And if where she did not derive benefit before Passover, is there He shall not profane? Rather, is obvious that she derived benefit Apparently, she may derive benefit
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: Achar haPesach b'bal yachel devaro. V'ei d'lo itehani lifnei haPesach, mi ikka 'bal yachel'? Ella peshita d'itehani. Alma mitehanei." English translation: "Say the latter clause: After the Passover, 'he shall not delay to fulfill his vow.' And if it does not apply before the Passover, where is 'he shall not delay'? Rather, it is obvious that it applies before the Passover. Therefore, it is applicable."

hebrew_text: וּתְיוּבְתָּא דְרַב יְהוּדָה!
human_translation: And a conclusive refutation of Rav Yehuda.
llm_translation: And the response of Rav Yehuda!

hebrew_text: כִּי קָתָנֵי, דְּאִי אִיתְהֲנִי הֲרֵי זֶה בְּ״בַל יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: When teaches that if she derived benefit she is in He shall not profane his word.
llm_translation: For it was taught, for if it is possible, behold this is in "Bavel shall begin his word."

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: ״שֶׁאַתְּ נֶהֱנֵית לִי עַד הֶחָג אִם תֵּלְכִי לְבֵית אָבִיךְ עַד הַפֶּסַח״, הָלְכָה לִפְנֵי הַפֶּסַח — אֲסוּרָה בַּהֲנָאָתוֹ עַד הֶחָג, וּמוּתֶּרֶת לֵילֵךְ אַחַר הַפֶּסַח.
human_translation: We learn Deriving benefit from me until the festival for you if you go to your father’s house until Passover, she went before Passover, she prohibited from deriving benefit from him until the festival and she is permitted to go after Passover.
llm_translation: We learned: "If 'you will enjoy me until the holiday, if you go to your father's house until the Passover,'" the halacha before the Passover - it is forbidden to benefit from it until the holiday, and it is permitted to go after the Passover.

hebrew_text: הָלְכָה — אֲסוּרָה, לֹא הָלְכָה — לָא.
human_translation: she went prohibited for her she did not go not
llm_translation: Halacha - asurah, lo halacha - la.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: הוּא הַדִּין דַּאֲפִילּוּ לֹא הָלְכָה אֲסוּרָה. הָלְכָה — אֲסוּרָה וְלוֹקָה, לֹא הָלְכָה — אֲסוּרָה בְּעָלְמָא.
human_translation: Rava said: The same is true, that even if she did not go, she prohibited from she went prohibited for her but she is flogged; she did not go, merely prohibited for her
llm_translation: Rava said: It is the same whether it went as a prohibited halakha. Halakha - prohibited and receives lashes, did not go as a halakha - prohibited in general.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: ״כִּכָּר זוֹ עָלַי הַיּוֹם אִם אֵלֵךְ לְמָקוֹם פְּלוֹנִי לְמָחָר״, אָכַל — הֲרֵי זֶה בְּ״בַל יֵלֵךְ״!
human_translation: raises an objection This loaf is to me today if I go to such and such a place tomorrow, he ate he is subject to he shall not go
llm_translation: Challenger: "If this loaf is upon me today, if I go to such and such a place tomorrow," and he eats - this is considered as "he shall not go"!

hebrew_text: מִי קָתָנֵי ״אוֹכֵל״? ״אָכַל״ קָתָנֵי, דְּכִי אֲכַל הֲרֵי זֶה בְּ״בַל יֵלֵךְ״.
human_translation: Does teach he may eat It teaches he ate, that once he ate, he is subject to he shall not go.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Who teaches "eating"? "He ate" teaches, for when one ate, behold, this is in "he shall not go."

hebrew_text: הָלַךְ — הֲרֵי זֶה בְּ״בַל יַחֵל״ דְּבָרוֹ. מְהַלֵּךְ — לָא. וְקַשְׁיָא לְרַב יְהוּדָה!
human_translation: he went he is in He shall not profane his word. he may not go and a difficulty to Rav Yehuda.
llm_translation: He went - behold this is in "Bavel Yachel" his statement. He is walking - no. And a difficulty for Rav Yehuda!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ רַב יְהוּדָה: הוּא הַדִּין דְּלִיתְנֵי ״מְהַלֵּךְ״. אַיְּידֵי דְּקָתָנֵי רֵישָׁא ״אָכַל״, דְּלָא מִיתְנֵי לֵיהּ ״אוֹכֵל״ — תָּנֵי סֵיפָא ״הָלַךְ״.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said to you the same is true, that could have taught he may go. since the first clause teaches he ate as it cannot teach he may eat the latter clause teaches he went,
llm_translation: He said to you, Rav Yehudah: It is the same as not stating "walking." Since it teaches at the beginning "ate," as it does not teach him "eating" - it teaches at the end "went."

hebrew_text: הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשָּׁה ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֲנִי מְשַׁמְּשֵׁךְ״, הֲרֵי זֶה בְּ״בַל יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״. וְהָא מִשְׁתַּעְבַּד לָהּ מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, דִּכְתִיב: ״שְׁאֵרָהּ כְּסוּתָהּ וְעֹנָתָהּ לֹא יִגְרָע״!
human_translation: one who says to his wife: Engaging in sexual intercourse with you is konam for me, he is in He shall not profane his word. But isn’t he duty bound by Torah law to her, as it is written: “Her food, her clothing, and her conjugal rights he may not diminish”
llm_translation: One who says to a woman, "I am using you as a vessel," this is considered as if he has violated his word. And he is liable to her biblically, as it is written: "Her food, her clothing, and her marital rights, he shall not diminish!"

hebrew_text: בְּאוֹמֵר ״הֲנָאַת תַּשְׁמִישֵׁךְ עָלַי״, וְהָא לָא קָא נִיחָא לֵיהּ בְּתַשְׁמִישׁ.
human_translation: where he says: The pleasure from sexual intercourse with you is to me, and sexual intercourse is not amenable to him.
llm_translation: He says, "The benefit of your use is upon me," but isn't it pleasing to him in the use.

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: ״תַּשְׁמִישִׁי עָלֶיךָ״ — כּוֹפִין אוֹתָהּ וּמְשַׁמַּשְׁתּוֹ, דְּשַׁעְבּוֹדֵי מְשׁוּעְבֶּדֶת לֵיהּ. ״הֲנָאַת תַּשְׁמִישְׁךָ עָלַי״ — אָסוּר, שֶׁאֵין מַאֲכִילִין לוֹ לְאָדָם דָּבָר הָאָסוּר לוֹ.
human_translation: As Rav Kahana said: Sexual intercourse with me is to you, coerces her to engage in sexual intercourse with him, as she is duty bound to him The pleasure from sexual intercourse with you is to me, it is prohibited as one may not feed a person that which is forbidden to him.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rabbi Kahana said: "Your service upon you" - they force her and make him serve, for the service of a maidservant is incumbent upon him. "The pleasure of your service upon me" - it is forbidden, for one may not feed a person something that is forbidden to him.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאֵינִי יָשֵׁן, שֶׁאֵינִי מְדַבֵּר, שֶׁאֵינִי מְהַלֵּךְ — אָסוּר. קׇרְבָּן לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ, הָא קׇרְבָּן שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ, לֹא קׇרְבָּן לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ — מוּתָּר.
human_translation: an oath that I will not sleep, That I will not speak, That I will not walk, prohibited An offering [ korban ] that I will not eat of yours, This offering [ ha korban ] that I will eat of yours, I will not eat of yours not an offering [ la korban ], permitted.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: A vow that I will not sleep, that I will not speak, that I will not walk - is forbidden. "A sacrifice you may not eat" - this refers to a sacrifice that you may not eat. "A sacrifice you may not eat" - this is permitted.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַנִּי מַתְנִיתִין — רַבִּי מֵאִיר הִיא, דְּאִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה — לָא שָׁנֵי לֵיהּ ״קׇרְבָּן״ וְלָא שָׁנֵי לֵיהּ ״הַקׇּרְבָּן״.
human_translation: Whose the mishna? It is Rabbi Meir. As, if Rabbi Yehuda, he does not differentiate An offering, and he does not differentiate This offering.
llm_translation: Gemara: "Gemara, who is the Tanna of the Mishnah? It is Rabbi Meir, for if it were Rabbi Yehuda, he would not change it to 'korban' and he would not change it to 'hakorban'."

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: ״לַקׇּרְבָּן לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ — מוּתָּר. וְהָתְנַן: ״לַקׇּרְבָּן לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״ — רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹסֵר, וְאָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: נַעֲשָׂה כְּאוֹמֵר: ״לַקׇּרְבָּן יְהֵא, לְפִיכָךְ לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ״.
human_translation: Say the latter clause I will not eat of yours not an offering, permitted. But didn’t we learn I will not eat of yours for an offering [ lekorban ], Rabbi Meir forbids And Rabbi Abba said it is rendered as one who says: will be for an offering; therefore, I will not eat of yours.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: 'Laqorban lo okhal lakh' — mutar. Ve'hatnan: 'Laqorban lo okhal lakh' — Rabbi Meir oser, ve'amar Rabbi Abba: Na'asah ke'omer: 'Laqorban yehe, lefikhakh lo okhal lakh'." English translation: "The reason for the latter statement: 'For the sacrifice, I do not eat for you' — is permitted. And we learned in a Mishnah: 'For the sacrifice, I do not eat for you' — Rabbi Meir prohibits, and Rabbi Abba said: It was done as he said: 'For the sacrifice it shall be, therefore I do not eat for you'."

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא דְּאָמַר ״לַקׇּרְבָּן״, הָא דְּאָמַר ״לָא לְקׇרְבָּן״ — דְּלָא הָוֵי קׇרְבָּן קָאָמַר.
human_translation: not difficult. That who said: For an offering [ lekorban ], This who said: Not for an offering [ la lekorban ], he is saying that it should not be an offering,
llm_translation: Not difficult: this that it says "for the sacrifice," this that it says "not for the sacrifice" — it is not a sacrifice that he is referring to.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ שְׁבוּעָה לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ, הָא שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ, לָא שְׁבוּעָה לֹא אוֹכַל לָךְ — אָסוּר.
human_translation: An oath I will not eat of yours, This an oath that I will eat of yours [ she’okhal lekha ], Not an oath that I will not eat of yours, is forbidden.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "A week that does not eat for you, the week that eats for you, not a week that does not eat for you - is forbidden."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מִכְּלָל דְּהָא שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ — דְּלָא אָכֵילְנָא מַשְׁמַע. וּרְמִינְהוּ: שְׁבוּעוֹת שְׁתַּיִם שֶׁהֵן אַרְבַּע. שֶׁאוֹכַל וְשֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל, שֶׁאָכַלְתִּי וְשֶׁלֹּא אָכַלְתִּי. מִדְּקָאָמַר שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל, שֶׁאָכַלְתִּי וְשֶׁלֹּא אָכַלְתִּי, מִכְּלָל דְּשֶׁאוֹכַל לָךְ — דְּאָכֵילְנָא מַשְׁמַע!
human_translation: By inference that This is an oath that I will eat of yours, indicates that I will not eat. And raises a contradiction two oaths that are four: that I will eat, and: That I will not eat; that I ate, and: That I did not eat. From that states: That I will not eat; that I ate, and That I did not eat, by inference that that I will eat of yours [ she’okhal lekha ] indicates: that I will eat.
llm_translation: Gemara: From the fact that the oath "that he shall eat for you" does not imply that I will eat, and we raised a dilemma: Two oaths are four, whether he eats or does not eat, whether I have eaten or have not eaten. From the fact that "he does not eat" means that I have eaten and have not eaten, it is inferred that "that he shall eat for you" implies that I will eat!

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: ״שֶׁאוֹכַל״ שְׁתֵּי לְשׁוֹנוֹת מַשְׁמַע. הָיוּ מְסָרְבִין בּוֹ לֶאֱכוֹל, וְאָמַר: ״אָכֵילְנָא אָכֵילְנָא״, וְתוּ: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאוֹכַל״ — דְּאָכֵילְנָא מַשְׁמַע. אֲבָל אָמַר: ״לָא אָכֵילְנָא לָא אָכֵילְנָא״, וְתוּ אָמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאוֹכַל״ — ״דְּלָא אָכֵילְנָא״ קָאָמַר.
human_translation: Abaye said: That I will eat [ she’okhal ], indicates two expressions, they were importuning [ mesarevin ] him to eat, and he said: I will eat, I will eat, and furthermore An oath that I will eat [ she’okhal ], it indicates: That I will eat. However, he said: I will not eat, I will not eat, and he furthermore said: An oath that I will eat [ she’okhal ], he is saying: That I will not eat.
llm_translation: Abaye said: "When one says 'I will eat,' it implies two tongues. If they were coaxing him to eat, and he said, 'I will eat, I will eat,' and then he said, 'I will eat a week from now' — it implies that he will eat. But if he said, 'I will not eat, I will not eat,' and then he said, 'I will eat a week from now' — he is saying that he will not eat."

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: ״שֶׁאוֹכַל״ דִּשְׁבוּעָה — ״שֶׁאִי אוֹכַל״ קָאָמַר. אִם כֵּן, פְּשִׁיטָא! מַאי לְמֵימְרָא? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: מֵיקַם לִישָּׁנָא הִיא דְּאִיתְּקִיל לֵיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said That I will eat [ she’okhal ], with regard to an oath, is saying he said: That I will not eat [ she’i okhal ]. If so, is obvious, What of stating Lest you say he blundered upholding the wording, teaches us
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: "That he eats" - he means "that he does not eat." If so, it is obvious! What is there to say? Perhaps you might say: It is a case where he has resolved to change his mind, which is why he is hinting to us.

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי לָא אָמַר טַעַם כְּרַב אָשֵׁי — דְּלָא קָתָנֵי ״שֶׁאִי אוֹכַל״.
human_translation: Abaye did not state reason by Rav Ashi, as does not teach That I will not eat [ she’i okhal ].
llm_translation: Abaye did not say the reason like Rav Ashi - because it does not teach "that he may eat."

hebrew_text: וְרַב אָשֵׁי נָאדֵי מִן טַעַם דְּאַבָּיֵי. קָסָבַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ נָמֵי, מַשְׁמַע שְׁתֵּי לְשׁוֹנוֹת. הָיוּ מְסָרְבִין בּוֹ לֶאֱכוֹל וְאָמַר: ״לָא אָכֵילְנָא לָא אָכֵילְנָא״, וְאָמַר נָמֵי: ״שְׁבוּעָה״, בֵּין ״שֶׁאוֹכַל״ בֵּין ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ — הָדֵין ״אָכֵילְנָא״ מַשְׁמַע דְּאָמַר.
human_translation: And Rav Ashi turned away [ nadei ] from the reason that Abaye he held That I will not eat, also indicates two expressions, they were importuning him to eat and he said: I will not eat, I will not eat, and he said: An oath, whether That I will eat, or: That I will not eat, this indicates that he is saying: I will eat.
llm_translation: Rav Ashei from the reasoning of Abbaye. He holds "that he does not eat" also, implies two languages. They were offering him food to eat, and he said: "I will not eat, I will not eat," and he said also: "an oath," whether "that he eats" or "that he does not eat" — similarly, "I will eat" implies that he said.

hebrew_text: וְאִיכָּא לְתָרוֹצַהּ נָמֵי לִישָּׁנָא ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ — ״שְׁבוּעָה דְּלָא אָכֵילְנָא״ קָאָמַר. אֶלָּא תַּנָּא פַּסְקַהּ: ״שֶׁאוֹכַל״ — ״דְּאָכֵילְנָא״ מַשְׁמַע, וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״ — ״לֹא אוֹכַל״ מַשְׁמַע.
human_translation: And there is also to interpret the expression: An oath that I will not eat, indicating saying: An oath that I will not eat. Rather, the tanna established a principle: That I will eat, indicates that I will eat, and: That I will not eat, indicates I will not eat.
llm_translation: And there is room for reconciliation also for the other statement, "a week that I do not eat" - he is saying "a week that I do not eat." Rather, a Tanna has resolved it: "that I eat" - implies that I eat, and "that I do not eat" - implies that I do not eat.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ זֶה חוֹמֶר בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת מִבַּנְּדָרִים, וְחוֹמֶר בַּנְּדָרִים מִבַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת. כֵּיצַד? אָמַר: ״קֻוֽנָּם סוּכָּה שֶׁאֲנִי עוֹשֶׂה״, ״לוּלָב שֶׁאֲנִי נוֹטֵל״, ״תְּפִילִּין שֶׁאֲנִי מַנִּיחַ״ — בַּנְּדָרִים אָסוּר, בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת מוּתָּר, שֶׁאֵין נִשְׁבָּעִין לַעֲבוֹר עַל הַמִּצְוֹת.
human_translation: This is a stringency of oaths vis-à-vis vows, And a stringency of vows vis-à-vis oaths. How so? said: Making a sukka is konam for me, Taking a lulav is for me, Donning phylacteries is for me, in vows, forbidden, in oaths, permitted, as one cannot take an oath to transgress the mitzvot.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: This is the stringency of oaths over vows, and the stringency of vows over oaths. How so? It says: "I am bound by a vow to make a sukkah," "I am taking a lulav," "I am putting on tefillin" — in vows, it is prohibited; in oaths, it is permitted, because one does not swear to transgress the commandments.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ ״חוֹמֶר״, מִכְּלָל דְּנֶדֶר הוּא. וְהָא ״מוּתָּר״ קָתָנֵי!
human_translation: a stringency by inference that is vow But doesn’t teach permitted
llm_translation: The word "chomer" is from the category of a vow. And the word "mutar" is taught!

hebrew_text: אַסֵּיפָא דְּאִידַּךְ בָּבָא קָתָנֵי. ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאֵינִי יָשֵׁן״, ״שֶׁאֵינִי מְדַבֵּר״, ״שֶׁאֵינִי מְהַלֵּךְ״ — אָסוּר. זֶה חוֹמֶר בַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת מִבַּנְּדָרִים.
human_translation: is taught with regard to the latter clause of the other section. An oath that I will not sleep, That I will not speak, That I will not walk, forbidden This is a stringency of oaths vis-à-vis vows.
llm_translation: The latter clause in the Bava Kama states: "An oath that I do not sleep," "An oath that I do not speak," "An oath that I do not walk" — is prohibited. This is a stringency in oaths compared to vows.

hebrew_text: חוֹמֶר בַּנְּדָרִים מִבַּשְּׁבוּעוֹת כֵּיצַד כּוּ׳. רַב כָּהֲנָא מַתְנֵי: אָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב. וְרַב טָבְיוֹמֵי מַתְנֵי: אָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל. מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֵין נִשְׁבָּעִין לַעֲבוֹר עַל הַמִּצְוֹת? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״, ״דְּבָרוֹ לֹא יַחֵל״ — אֲבָל מֵיחֵל הוּא לְחֶפְצֵי שָׁמַיִם.
human_translation: a stringency of vows vis-à-vis oaths. How so? Rav Kahana teaches Rav Giddel said Rav said, and Rav Tavyumei teaches Rav Giddel said Shmuel From where that one cannot take an oath to transgress the mitzvot? The verse states: “He shall not profane his word” his word, he shall not profane. However, he may profane for the desires of Heaven.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: The stringency of vows compared to oaths, how so? Rav Kahana teaches: Rav Giddel said in the name of Rav. And Rav Tavyumei teaches: Rav Giddel said in the name of Shmuel. From where do we derive that one may not swear to transgress the commandments? The verse teaches: "He shall not profane his word," "His word he shall not profane" — but he may profane it for the sake of Heaven.

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא נֶדֶר — דִּכְתִיב: ״אִישׁ כִּי יִדֹּר נֶדֶר לַה׳ ... לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״. שְׁבוּעָה נָמֵי, הָא כְּתִיב: ״אוֹ הִשָּׁבַע שְׁבֻעָה לַה׳ לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״!
human_translation: What is different a vow as it is written “When a man takes a vow to the Lord…he shall not profane his word” an oath it is also written “Or swears an oath” to God, “he shall not profane his word.”
llm_translation: What is the difference with a vow? — As it is written: "When a man makes a vow to the Lord... he shall not break his word." Likewise, an oath, as it is written: "Or if a man swears an oath to the Lord, he shall not break his word!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הָא דְּאָמַר ״הֲנָאַת סוּכָּה עָלַי״, הָא דְּאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶהֱנֶה מִן הַסּוּכָּה״.
human_translation: Abaye said: This who said: The benefit from a sukka to me. that who said: an oath that I will not derive benefit from the sukka .
llm_translation: Abaye said: This that it says, "Benefit of a sukkah upon me," this that it says, "An oath that I will not benefit from the sukkah."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: וְכִי מִצְוֹת לֵיהָנוֹת נִיתְּנוּ? אֶלָּא, אָמַר רָבָא: הָא דְּאָמַר ״יְשִׁיבַת סוּכָּה עָלַי״, וְהָא דְּאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֵשֵׁב בַּסּוּכָּה״.
human_translation: Rava said But were mitzvot given for deriving benefit? Rather, Rava said This who said: Dwelling in a sukka to me, and that who said: an oath that I will not dwell in a sukka .
llm_translation: Rava said: And were the mitzvot given for her enjoyment? Rather, Rava said: This is like what is said, "Dwelling in a sukkah is upon me," and like what is said, "A vow not to sit in a sukkah."

hebrew_text: וְשֶׁאֵין נִשְׁבָּעִין לַעֲבוֹר עַל הַמִּצְוֹת מֵהָכָא נָפְקָא לֵיהּ? מֵהָתָם נָפְקָא לֵיהּ, דְּתַנְיָא: יָכוֹל נִשְׁבַּע לְבַטֵּל אֶת הַמִּצְוָה וְלֹא בִּיטֵּל, יָכוֹל יְהֵא חַיָּיב —
human_translation: And that one cannot take an oath to transgress the mitzvot derived from here, It is derived from there, as it is taught might takes an oath to nullify a mitzva and does not nullify it, might he will be liable
llm_translation: And that they are not sworn to transgress the commandments, from where is it derived? It is derived from there, as it is taught: One might have thought that one can swear to annul the commandment but not annul it. One might have thought that one should be liable —

hebrew_text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְהָרַע אוֹ לְהֵיטִיב״. מָה הֲטָבָה רְשׁוּת, אַף הֲרָעָה רְשׁוּת. יָצָא נִשְׁבַּע לְבַטֵּל אֶת הַמִּצְוָה וְלֹא בִּיטֵּל — שֶׁאֵין הָרְשׁוּת בְּיָדוֹ!
human_translation: the verse states: to do evil, or to do good” just as the doing of good, permitted so too, the doing of evil, permitted, excludes takes an oath to nullify a mitzva and does not nullify it; as the permission is not in his power.
llm_translation: The Talmud teaches: "To do evil or to do good." Just as doing good is optional, so too doing evil is optional. If one took an oath to nullify a commandment and did not nullify it - he has no authority!

hebrew_text: חַד קְרָא לְמִיפְטְרֵיהּ מִקׇּרְבַּן שְׁבוּעָה, וְחַד לְמִיפְטְרֵיהּ מִן לָאו דִּשְׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: One verse: to exempt him from an offering for an oath, and one to exempt him from the prohibition for an oath.
llm_translation: One Scripture releases him from the obligation of an oath offering, and one Scripture releases him from the prohibition of an oath.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ יֵשׁ נֶדֶר בְּתוֹךְ נֶדֶר, וְאֵין שְׁבוּעָה בְּתוֹךְ שְׁבוּעָה. כֵּיצַד? אָמַר: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר אִם אוֹכַל״, ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר אִם אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל — חַיָּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת. ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת.
human_translation: There is a vow within a vow. But there is no oath within an oath. How so? said: I am hereby a nazirite if I eat, I am hereby a nazirite if I eat, and he ate, he is obligated for each and every one an oath that I will not eat, an oath that I will not eat, and he ate, he is liable for only one
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: There is a vow within a vow, but there is no oath within an oath. How so? One says, "Behold, I am a Nazirite if I eat," "Behold, I am a Nazirite if I eat," and he eats - he is liable for each one separately. "An oath that I will not eat," "An oath that I will not eat," and he eats - he is only liable for one.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״ ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לְמָחָר״, דְּמִיגּוֹ דְּקָא מִיתּוֹסַף יוֹמָא יַתִּירָא — חָיְילָא נְזִירוּת עַל נְזִירוּת. אֲבָל אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״, ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״ — אֵין חָלָה נְזִירוּת עַל נְזִירוּת. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ אָמַר: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״, ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״ — חָלָה נְזִירוּת עֲלֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rav Huna said: They taught only where he said: I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby a nazirite tomorrow. As since an additional day is added naziriteship takes effect upon naziriteship. However, he said: I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby a nazirite today, naziriteship does not take effect upon naziriteship, And Shmuel said even he said: I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby a nazirite today, naziriteship takes effect with regard to him,
llm_translation: Gemara said Rav Huna: They only taught a case where he said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite today," "Behold, I am a Nazirite for tomorrow," because since the additional day is added, it is a matter of one Nazirite vow upon another Nazirite vow. But if he said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite today," "Behold, I am a Nazirite today," there is no Nazirite vow upon another Nazirite vow. And Samuel said: Even if he said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite today," "Behold, I am a Nazirite today," a Nazirite vow is imposed upon him.

hebrew_text: וּלְרַב הוּנָא, אַדִּתְנָא אֵין שְׁבוּעָה בְּתוֹךְ שְׁבוּעָה, לִיתְנֵי: יֵשׁ נֶדֶר בְּתוֹךְ נֶדֶר, וְאֵין נֶדֶר בְּתוֹךְ נֶדֶר. ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם, הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לְמָחָר״ — יֵשׁ נֶדֶר בְּתוֹךְ נֶדֶר, ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״ ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״ —
human_translation: And according to Rav Huna, instead of teaching there is no oath within an oath, let teach there is a vow within a vow, and there is not a vow within a vow. I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby a nazirite tomorrow, there is a vow within a vow. I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby a nazirite today,
llm_translation: To Rav Huna, it was taught: A vow within a vow does not incur an oath, let it teach: There is a vow within a vow, and there is no vow within a vow. "Behold, I am a Nazirite today, behold, I am a Nazirite for tomorrow" — there is a vow within a vow, "Behold, I am a Nazirite today" "Behold, I am a Nazirite today" —

hebrew_text: אֵין נֶדֶר בְּתוֹךְ נֶדֶר! קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: there is no vow within a vow. difficult,
llm_translation: There is no vow within a vow! It is a difficulty.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: יֵשׁ נֶדֶר בְּתוֹךְ נֶדֶר, וְאֵין שְׁבוּעָה בְּתוֹךְ שְׁבוּעָה. הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵימָא דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם, הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לְמָחָר״, דִּכְווֹתַהּ גַּבֵּי שְׁבוּעָה: ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים״, וְחָזַר וְאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל עֲנָבִים״ — אַמַּאי לָא חָלָה שְׁבוּעָה עַל שְׁבוּעָה?
human_translation: We learned There is a vow within a vow, but there is no oath within an oath. What are the circumstances? If we say where said: I am hereby a nazirite today, I am a hereby a nazirite tomorrow, in the corresponding with regard to an oath that I will not eat figs, and he then said: an oath that I will not eat grapes, why does an oath not take effect an oath
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: There is a vow within a vow, but there is no oath within an oath. How so? If you say, "Behold, I am a Nazirite today, I am a Nazirite for tomorrow," since the second statement is dependent on the first: "I will not eat figs," and then he retracts and says, "I will not eat grapes," why does the oath not take effect on top of the previous oath?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הֵיכִי דָּמֵי דְּלָא חָלָה שְׁבוּעָה עַל שְׁבוּעָה, כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים״, וְחָזַר וְאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים״, דִּכְווֹתַהּ גַּבֵּי נְזִירוּת הֵיכִי דָּמֵי — דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם, הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״, וְקָתָנֵי יֵשׁ נֶדֶר בְּתוֹךְ נֶדֶר. קַשְׁיָא לְרַב הוּנָא!
human_translation: Rather, what are the circumstances in which oath does not take effect an oath For example, where said: an oath that I will not eat figs, and he again said: an oath that I will not eat figs. In the corresponding with regard to naziriteship, what are the circumstances? where said: I am hereby a nazirite today, I am a hereby a nazirite today; and teaches there is a vow within a vow. a difficulty to Rav Huna,
llm_translation: Rather, how is it that the value is not a week upon a week, such as when one says, "A week that I will not eat figs," and then repeats and says, "A week that I will not eat figs," how is it similar to the case of a Nazirite vow — as when one says, "Behold, I am a Nazirite today, behold, I am a Nazirite today," and it is taught that there is a vow within a vow. This is a difficulty for Rav Huna!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לְךָ רַב הוּנָא: מַתְנִיתִין דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם, הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לְמָחָר״. דִּכְווֹתַהּ גַּבֵּי שְׁבוּעָה, דְּאָמַר: ״שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים״, וְחָזַר וְאָמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים וַעֲנָבִים״, דְּלָא חָיְילָא.
human_translation: Rav Huna said to you the mishna where said: I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby a nazirite tomorrow; in the corresponding with regard to an oath where said: that I will not eat figs, and then said: an oath that I will not eat figs and grapes, does not take effect,
llm_translation: He said to you, Rav Huna: Mishna that says, "Behold, I am a Nazirite today, behold, I am a Nazirite for tomorrow." As it is related to the oath of a week, he said, "I will not eat figs," and then he retracted and said, "I will not eat figs and grapes for a week," which is not valid.

hebrew_text: וְהָאָמַר רַבָּה: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים״, וְחָזַר וְאָמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים וַעֲנָבִים״, וְאָכַל תְּאֵנִים, וְהִפְרִישׁ קׇרְבָּן, וְחָזַר וְאָכַל עֲנָבִים — הָוְיָא לְהוּ עֲנָבִים חֲצִי שִׁיעוּר, וְאֵין מְבִיאִים קׇרְבָּן עַל חֲצִי שִׁיעוּר.
human_translation: But didn’t Rabba say an oath that I will not eat figs, and then said: an oath that I will not eat figs and grapes, and he ate figs, and he set aside an offering and he then ate grapes, grapes are a half-measure And one does not bring an offering for a half-measure.
llm_translation: The Gemara said: "A vow not to eat figs," and then he came back and said: "A vow not to eat figs and grapes." He ate figs, separated an offering, then came back and ate grapes - he is liable for eating grapes in half the required amount, and one does not bring an offering for eating in half the required amount.

hebrew_text: אַלְמָא הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים״, וְחָזַר וְאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל תְּאֵנִים וַעֲנָבִים״, מִיגּוֹ דְּחָל שְׁבוּעָה עַל עֲנָבִים — חָיְילָא נָמֵי עַל תְּאֵנִים! רַב הוּנָא לָא סְבִירָא לֵיהּ כְּרַבָּה.
human_translation: Apparently, where said: an oath that I will not eat figs, and then said: an oath that I will not eat figs and grapes, since the oath take effect with regard to grapes, it takes effect with regard to figs as well. Rav Huna does not hold in accordance with Rabba,
llm_translation: The Gemara asks: Here, where it says, "A vow not to eat figs," and then he came back and said, "A vow not to eat figs and grapes," since he included grapes in the vow — it is logical to say that he also included figs! Rav Huna does not agree with this reasoning like Rabbah.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: מִי שֶׁנָּזַר שְׁתֵּי נְזִירוֹת, מָנָה אֶת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה וְהִפְרִישׁ קׇרְבָּן, וְנִשְׁאַל עָלֶיהָ, עָלְתָה לוֹ שְׁנִיָּה בָּרִאשׁוֹנָה.
human_translation: raises an objection one who took two naziriteship, counted the first and set aside an offering and requested for the second is counted for him instead of the first.
llm_translation: Challenger: One who vowed two Nazirites, counted the first one and separated a sacrifice, and was asked about it, the second one ascends for him in place of the first one.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִילֵימָא דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם, הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לְמָחָר״ — אַמַּאי עָלְתָה לוֹ שְׁנִיָּה בָּרִאשׁוֹנָה, הָא אִיכָּא יוֹמָא יַתִּירָא? אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם, הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״.
human_translation: What are the circumstances? If we say that he said: I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby a nazirite tomorrow, why is the second naziriteship counted for him instead of the first? Isn’t there an additional day Rather, is obvious that he said: I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby a nazirite today,
llm_translation: How are the cases similar? If you say that one who says, "I am a Nazirite today, I am a Nazirite tomorrow" - why did he have a second thought the first time? If there was an extra day, it would be permissible? Rather, it is obvious that he said, "I am a Nazirite today, I am a Nazirite today."

hebrew_text: וּתְיוּבְתָּא דְרַב הוּנָא!
human_translation: and a conclusive refutation of Rav Huna.
llm_translation: And the response of Rav Huna!

hebrew_text: לָא, לְעוֹלָם ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם, הֲרֵינִי לְמָחָר״, וּמַאי ״עָלְתָה לוֹ״ — לְבַר מֵהָהוּא יוֹמָא יַתִּירָא. אִי נָמֵי, כְּגוֹן שֶׁקִּיבֵּל שְׁתֵּי נְזִירוּת בְּבַת אַחַת.
human_translation: No, actually I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby tomorrow. And what is counted for him except for that additional day, Alternatively, where he accepted two naziriteship simultaneously,
llm_translation: Not, forever "Behold I am a Nazirite today, behold I am for tomorrow," and what "has risen to him" - on the following day it is permitted. Alternatively, for example, if he accepted two Naziriteships at once.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב הַמְנוּנָא: ״נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר״ — מִכָּאן שֶׁהַנְּזִירוּת חָל עַל הַנְּזִירוּת. שֶׁיָּכוֹל, וַהֲלֹא דִּין הוּא: וּמָה שְׁבוּעָה חֲמוּרָה — אֵין שְׁבוּעָה חָלָה עַל שְׁבוּעָה, נְזִירוּת קַלָּה לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: נָזִיר לְהַזִּיר, מִכָּאן שֶׁהַנְּזִירוּת חָלָה עַל הַנְּזִירוּת.
human_translation: Rav Hamnuna raised objection “A nazirite, to consecrate [ nazir lehazzir ]” From here that naziriteship takes effect upon naziriteship. As might inference And just as an oath, stringent, an oath does not take effect upon oath, naziriteship, lenient, all the more so not the verse states: “ Nazir lehazzir .” From here that naziriteship takes effect upon naziriteship.
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: "A Nazir to become a Nazir" - from here we learn that the laws of Naziriteship apply to another Nazirite. This is reasonable, is it not? And what is the stringency of an oath? An oath does not apply to another oath, so certainly a light Naziriteship should apply to another Naziriteship. The Gemara explains: "A Nazir to become a Nazir" - from here we learn that the laws of Naziriteship apply to another Naziriteship.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵימָא דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם, הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לְמָחָר״, הָא קְרָא בָּעֲיָא?! אֶלָּא לָאו: דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם, הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר הַיּוֹם״ — וְקָתָנֵי נְזִירוּת חָל עַל נְזִירוּת!
human_translation: What are the circumstances? If we say where said: I am hereby a nazirite today, I am hereby a nazirite tomorrow, does that require a verse Rather, is it not where said: I am a nazirite today, I am a nazirite today? And teaches naziriteship takes effect upon naziriteship,
llm_translation: "How are they similar? If you say, 'Behold, I am a Nazirite today, I am a Nazirite tomorrow,' does the verse require this? Rather, is it not that he says, 'Behold, I am a Nazirite today, I am a Nazirite today' — and the Mishnah teaches that one vow of Naziriteship takes effect upon another vow of Naziriteship!"

hebrew_text: לָא, הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — כְּגוֹן שֶׁקִּיבֵּל עָלָיו שְׁתֵּי נְזִירוּת בְּבַת אַחַת.
human_translation: not with what are we dealing here? where he accepted upon himself two naziriteship simultaneously.
llm_translation: Not here, what are we dealing with? - For example, if he accepted upon himself two nazirites in one daughter.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי חוּמְרָא דִּשְׁבוּעָה מִנֶּדֶר? אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דְּחָיְילָא אֲפִילּוּ עַל דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַמָּשׁ, נֶדֶר נָמֵי חָמוּר, שֶׁכֵּן חָל עַל הַמִּצְוָה כִּרְשׁוּת. אֶלָּא — מִשּׁוּם דִּכְתִיב בָּהּ בִּשְׁבוּעָה: ״לֹא יְנַקֶּה״.
human_translation: And what is the stringency of an oath vis-à-vis a vow, If we say because takes effect even with regard to a matter that has no actual a vow also has stringency in that it, takes effect with regard to a mitzva just as permitted. Rather, because it is written with regard to an oath: “The Lord will not hold guiltless
llm_translation: And what is the stringency of an oath over a vow? Perhaps because it is stringent even regarding a matter that has no substance, a vow is also stringent, as it is incumbent upon fulfilling a commandment like an oath. Rather - because it is written in it regarding an oath: "He shall not be cleared."

hebrew_text: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל, שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל״, וְאָכַל — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. אָמַר רָבָא: אִם נִשְׁאַל עַל הָרִאשׁוֹנָה — שְׁנִיָּה חָלָה עָלָיו. מִמַּאי — מִדְּלָא קָתָנֵי ״אֵינוֹ אֶלָּא אַחַת״, וְקָתָנֵי ״אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת״, רַוְוחָא הוּא דְּלֵית לַהּ. כִּי מִיתְּשִׁיל עַל חֲבֶירְתַּהּ — חָיְילָא.
human_translation: an oath that I will not eat, an oath that I will not eat, and he ate, he is liable only one Rava said: If he requested for the first the second takes effect upon him. From where From that it is not taught there is only one, Rather, it is taught he is liable for only one. does not have a span when he requests the other takes effect.
llm_translation: "An oath not to eat, an oath not to eat," and he ate - he is only liable for one. Rava said: If he was asked about the first one, the second one takes effect on him. From where - since it does not teach "he is only liable for one," and it teaches "he is only liable for one," it is a void space. When one relies on his fellow - it is a mistake.

hebrew_text: לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא: חִיּוּבָא הוּא דְּלֵיכָּא, הָא שְׁבוּעָה אִיכָּא. לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא? לְכִדְרָבָא. דְּאָמַר רָבָא: נִשְׁאַל עַל הָרִאשׁוֹנָה — עָלְתָה לוֹ שְׁנִיָּה תַּחְתֶּיהָ.
human_translation: Another version there is no liability there is oath. with regard to what halakha with regard to of Rava, as Rava said: If he requested for the first the second is counted for him in its place.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Another answer: It is a matter of obligation, there is no need for an oath, but there is a week. What is the halakha? According to Rava. For Rava said: If one was asked about the first matter — he should answer about the second matter beneath it.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ: מִי שֶׁנָּדַר שְׁתֵּי נְזִירוֹת וּמָנָה אֶת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, וְהִפְרִישׁ קׇרְבָּן וְנִשְׁאַל עָלֶיהָ — עָלְתָה לוֹ שְׁנִיָּה בָּרִאשׁוֹנָה.
human_translation: Let us say supports his one who took two naziriteship, and counted the first and set aside an offering, and requested for the second counts for him instead of the first.
llm_translation: Let us say it assists him: One who vowed two Nazirites and counted the first one, and separated a sacrifice and was asked about it - a second one has arisen for him in the first one.

hebrew_text: כְּגוֹן שֶׁקִּיבֵּל עָלָיו שְׁתֵּי נְזִירוֹת בְּבַת אַחַת.
human_translation: where he accepted upon himself two naziriteship simultaneously.
llm_translation: For example, if he accepted upon himself two Nazirites in one day.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ סְתַם נְדָרִים לְהַחֲמִיר, וּפֵירוּשָׁם לְהָקֵל. כֵּיצַד? אָמַר ״הֲרֵי עָלַי כְּבָשָׂר מָלִיחַ״ ״כְּיֵין נֶסֶךְ״, אִם בְּשֶׁל שְׁלָמִים נָדַר — אָסוּר.
human_translation: Unspecified vows stringently, but their specification, leniently. How so? said: This to me like salted meat, like wine libations, if he vowed in reference to of a peace-offering, forbidden,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: General vows are to be stringent, while their explanations are to be lenient. How so? If one says, "Behold, upon me is a salty meat," "like wine libation," if he vowed regarding the peace offerings, it is prohibited.

hebrew_text: אִם בְּשֶׁל עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה נָדַר — מוּתָּר. וְאִם סְתָם — אָסוּר.
human_translation: If he vowed in reference to of idol worship, permitted, And if without specification, forbidden.
llm_translation: If in the context of foreign worship one vowed — permitted. But if unspecified — forbidden.

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵי עָלַי כְּחֵרֶם״, אִם כְּחֵרֶם שֶׁל שָׁמַיִם — אָסוּר, וְאִם כְּחֵרֶם שֶׁל כֹּהֲנִים — מוּתָּר. וְאִם סְתָם — אָסוּר.
human_translation: This hereby to me if like a dedication to Heaven, it is forbidden. And if like a dedication to priests, it is permitted, And if without specification, forbidden.
llm_translation: "Behold upon me as a cherem," if as a cherem of heaven - forbidden, and if as a cherem of the Kohanim - permitted. And if unspecified - forbidden.

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵי עָלַי כְּמַעֲשֵׂר״, אִם כְּמַעְשַׂר בְּהֵמָה נָדַר — אָסוּר. וְאִם שֶׁל גּוֹרֶן, — מוּתָּר. וְאִם סְתָם — אָסוּר.
human_translation: This is hereby to me like tithes, if he took a vow like the animal tithe, forbidden, And if of the granary, permitted. And if without specification, forbidden.
llm_translation: "Behold upon me as a tithe," if as a tithe of an animal vowed - forbidden. And if of a granary - permitted. And if unspecified - forbidden.

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵי עָלַי כִּתְרוּמָה״, אִם כִּתְרוּמַת הַלִּשְׁכָּה נָדַר — אָסוּר. וְאִם שֶׁל גּוֹרֶן — מוּתָּר. וְאִם סְתָם — אָסוּר. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: This is hereby to me like teruma , if he took a vow like the collection of the chamber [ terumat halishka ], forbidden, And if of the granary permitted, And if without specification, forbidden. the statement of Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: "Behold, upon me is a donation," if one vows like the donation of the Temple treasury - forbidden. And if it is like the donation of the threshing floor - permitted. And if it is unspecified - forbidden. These are the words of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: סְתַם תְּרוּמָה, בִּיהוּדָה — אֲסוּרָה, בַּגָּלִיל — מוּתֶּרֶת, שֶׁאֵין אַנְשֵׁי גָלִיל מַכִּירִין אֶת תְּרוּמַת הַלִּשְׁכָּה. סְתַם חֲרָמִים, בִּיהוּדָה — מוּתָּרִין, בַּגָּלִיל — אֲסוּרִין, שֶׁאֵין אַנְשֵׁי גָלִיל מַכִּירִין אֶת חֶרְמֵי הַכֹּהֲנִים.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: Unspecified teruma in Judea is forbidden. in the Galilee it is permitted, as the people of the Galilee are unfamiliar with the collection of the chamber. unspecified dedications in Judea are permitted, in the Galilee they are forbidden, as the people of the Galilee are unfamiliar with dedications to the priests,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehudah says: A regular Terumah, in Judea — forbidden, in the Galilee — permitted, because the people of the Galilee are not familiar with the Terumah of the Temple storeroom. Regular Cherem, in Judea — permitted, in the Galilee — forbidden, because the people of the Galilee are not familiar with the priestly Cherem.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ וְהָתְנַן: סְפֵק נְזִירוּת לְהָקֵל?
human_translation: But didn’t we learn Uncertainty naziriteship leniently?
llm_translation: Gemara: And we learned in a Mishnah: A doubt regarding Naziriteship to be lenient?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא, לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, הָא רַבָּנַן. דְּתַנְיָא: הַמַּקְדִּישׁ חַיָּיתוֹ וּבְהֶמְתּוֹ — הִקְדִּישׁ אֶת הַכּוֹי. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: לֹא הִקְדִּישׁ אֶת הַכּוֹי.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: not difficult. That Rabbi Eliezer, this the Rabbis, As it is taught One who consecrates his undomesticated animal and his domesticated animal has consecrated the koy Rabbi Eliezer says: He has not consecrated the koy .
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said, it is not difficult: this is Rabbi Eliezer, and this is the Rabbis. As it was taught: one who consecrates his life and his animal - he has consecrated the animal. Rabbi Eliezer says: he did not consecrate the animal.

hebrew_text: מַאן דְּאָמַר מָמוֹנוֹ מְעַיֵּיל לִסְפֵיקָא, גּוּפֵיהּ נָמֵי מְעַיֵּיל. וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מָמוֹנוֹ לָא מְעַיֵּיל לִסְפֵיקָא, גּוּפֵיהּ (נָמֵי)
human_translation: The who said puts his possessions into uncertainty, enters himself into as well. And who said does not put his possessions into uncertainty,
llm_translation: The one who says his money brings about doubt, his body also brings about doubt. And the one who says his money does not bring about doubt, his body also (brings about doubt).

hebrew_text: כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן דְּלָא מְעַיֵּיל לִסְפֵיקָא.
human_translation: all the more so, does not enter himself into uncertainty either.
llm_translation: All the more so that he does not bring up a doubt.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: בְּמַאי אוֹקֵימְתָּא לִסְפֵק נְזִירוּת לְהָקֵל — כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, אֵימָא סֵיפָא: סְפֵק בְּכוֹרוֹת, אֶחָד בְּכוֹרֵי אָדָם וְאֶחָד בְּכוֹרֵי בְהֵמָה, בֵּין טְמֵאָה בֵּין טְהוֹרָה — הַמּוֹצִיא מֵחֲבֵירוֹ עָלָיו הָרְאָיָה.
human_translation: Abaye said to In what did you establish that uncertainty naziriteship leniently? in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer. Say the latter clause uncertainty firstborns, whether human firstborns, or animal firstborns, whether non-kosher or kosher the burden of proof rests upon the claimant.
llm_translation: He said to him, Abaye: With what do you establish the leniency of doubt regarding Naziriteship? - Like Rabbi Eliezer. Let us say the latter part: Doubt regarding firstborns, whether of humans or of animals, whether impure or pure - the burden of proof rests upon the one who seeks to exempt his fellow.

hebrew_text: וְתָנֵי עֲלַהּ: וַאֲסוּרִים בְּגִיזָּה וַעֲבוֹדָה!
human_translation: And it is taught in that regard: But with regard to shearing and working forbidden,
llm_translation: And he taught about it: "And forbidden are with a shearing and labor!"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אַמַּאי קָא מְדַמֵּית קְדוּשָּׁה הַבָּאָה מֵאֵלֶיהָ, לִקְדוּשָּׁה הַבָּאָה בִּידֵי אָדָם?
human_translation: said to Why do you compare sanctity that emerges by itself, to sanctity that emerges by a person
llm_translation: He said to him: Why do you think that the sanctity that comes from itself is comparable to the sanctity that comes through the hands of man?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אִי קַשְׁיָא, הָא קַשְׁיָא: סְפֵק מַשְׁקִין, לִיטָּמֵא — טָמֵא, לְטַמֵּא אֲחֵרִים — טָהוֹר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר, וְכֵן הָיָה רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר כִּדְבָרָיו.
human_translation: Rather, if is difficult, this is difficult. liquid uncertainty impure being impure pure to render other impure. the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Elazar would also say in accordance with the statements of
llm_translation: Rather, if it is difficult, here is the difficulty: In the case of doubtful liquids, if it is impure — it remains impure; to render others impure — it is pure. These are the words of Rabbi Meir, and so too Rabbi Eliezer used to say in accordance with his words.

hebrew_text: וּמִי סְבִירָא לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר לִיטָּמֵא טָמֵא?
human_translation: But does Rabbi Eliezer hold being impure, it is impure?
llm_translation: And who holds according to Rabbi Eliezer to become impure impure?

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אֵין טוּמְאָה לְמַשְׁקִין כׇּל עִיקָּר. תֵּדַע: שֶׁהֲרֵי הֵעִיד יוֹסֵי בֶּן יוֹעֶזֶר אִישׁ צְרֵידָה עַל אַיָּל קַמְצָא דְּכַן, וְעַל מַשְׁקִין בֵּית מִטְבְּחַיָּא דְּכַן?
human_translation: But isn’t it taught Rabbi Eliezer says: impurity does not apply to liquids at all? Know as Yosei ben Yo’ezer of Tzereida testified concerning eil kamtza kosher, and concerning the liquids of the slaughterhouse they are pure.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says: There is no impurity for liquids at all fundamentally. You should know: for Yosei ben Yo'ezer, a man of Tzreida, testified concerning the kneading trough of such, and concerning the liquids of the slaughterhouse of such?

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לִשְׁמוּאֵל, דְּאָמַר: דְּכַן מִלְּטַמֵּא אֲחֵרִים, אֲבָל טוּמְאַת עַצְמָן יֵשׁ בָּהֶן, שַׁפִּיר.
human_translation: This works out well according to Shmuel, who said pure render other but they themselves are impurity. well.
llm_translation: The text reads: "Hanicha to Shmuel, who said: Indeed, it is possible to transmit impurity to others, but their own impurity is effective, that is fine."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְרַב דְּאָמַר דְּכַן מַמָּשׁ, מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: However, according to Rav, who said actually pure, what is there to say?
llm_translation: Rather, according to Rav who says it is indeed so, what can be said in response?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: הָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, וְהָא רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן.
human_translation: Rather, That Rabbi Yehuda, and this Rabbi Shimon.
llm_translation: Rather: this is Rabbi Yehuda, and this is Rabbi Shimon.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר אִם יֵשׁ בִּכְרִי הַזֶּה מֵאָה כּוֹר״, וְהָלַךְ וּמְצָאוֹ שֶׁנִּגְנַב אוֹ שֶׁאָבַד — רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַתִּיר, וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: As it is taught I am hereby a nazirite if there are in this heap one hundred kor , and he went and found that it was stolen or that it was lost Rabbi Yehuda permits And Rabbi Shimon prohibits
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "Behold, I am a Nazirite if there are one hundred kor in this pile," and he went and found that it was stolen or lost - Rabbi Yehuda permits, and Rabbi Shimon prohibits.

hebrew_text: וְרָמֵי דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אַדְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה: מִי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה לָא מְעַיֵּיל אִינִישׁ נַפְשֵׁיהּ לִסְפֵיקָא? וּרְמִינְהִי, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: סְתַם תְּרוּמָה בִּיהוּדָה — אֲסוּרָה, וּבַגָּלִיל — מוּתֶּרֶת, שֶׁאֵין אַנְשֵׁי הַגָּלִיל מַכִּירִין אֶת תְּרוּמַת הַלִּשְׁכָּה. טַעְמָא דְּאֵין מַכִּירִין,
human_translation: raises a contradiction of Rabbi Yehuda and of Rabbi Yehuda. Did Rabbi Yehuda say a person does not enter himself into uncertainty, And raises a contradiction Rabbi Yehuda says: Unspecified teruma in Judea is forbidden but in the Galilee it is permitted, as the people of the Galilee are not familiar with the collection of the chamber. The reason that they are not familiar;
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda: Did Rabbi Yehuda really say that a person should not endanger himself due to doubt? And it was raised: Rabbi Yehuda says: A sealed Terumah in Judea is forbidden, but in the Galilee it is permitted, because the people of the Galilee are not familiar with the Terumah of the Temple chamber. The reason is that they are not familiar.

hebrew_text: הָא מַכִּירִין — אֲסוּרִין!
human_translation: but they are familiar, forbidden,
llm_translation: These are the words: "Ha makirin - asurin!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: גַּבֵּי כְּרִי קָסָבַר כׇּל שֶׁסְּפֵיקוֹ חָמוּר מִוַּדַּאי — לָא מְעַיֵּיל נַפְשֵׁיהּ לִסְפֵיקָא, דְּאִילּוּ גַּבֵּי נָזִיר וַדַּאי, מְגַלֵּחַ וּמֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן וְנֶאֱכָל. עַל סְפֵיקוֹ, לָא מָצֵי מְגַלַּח.
human_translation: Rava said With regard to a heap, holds wherever uncertainty is more stringent than certainty, one does not enter himself into uncertainty. as while a definite nazirite shaves and brings an offering and it is eaten, one cannot shave for uncertain
llm_translation: Rava said: Regarding a doubtful case of a nazirite, if his doubt is more stringent than certain, he does not bring himself into doubt, for even in the case of a definite nazirite, he shaves, brings a sacrifice, and eats. But in a doubtful case, he does not shave.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב הוּנָא בַּר יְהוּדָה לְרָבָא: אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִיר עוֹלָם״, מַאי?
human_translation: Rav Huna bar Yehuda said to Rava: said: I am hereby a permanent nazirite, what
llm_translation: He said to him Rav Huna the son of Yehuda to Rava: He said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite forever," what?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נְזִיר עוֹלָם נָמֵי סְפֵיקוֹ חָמוּר מִוַּדַּאי, דְּאִילּוּ וַדַּאי הִכְבִּיד שְׂעָרוֹ — מֵיקֵל בְּתַעַר, וּמֵבִיא שָׁלוֹשׁ בְּהֵמוֹת. וְאִילּוּ סְפֵיקוֹ — לֹא.
human_translation: said to him: Even a permanent nazirite, his uncertainty is more stringent than certainty As the hair of a definite is heavy he may lighten with a razor and bring three animal whereas uncertainty cannot
llm_translation: He said to him: A nazirite for life, his doubt is more stringent than his certainty, for if he certainly made his hair heavy - he shaves with a razor and brings three animals. But if it is a doubt - he does not.

hebrew_text: אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִיר שִׁמְשׁוֹן״ מַאי?
human_translation: said: I am hereby a nazirite like Samson what
llm_translation: He said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite like Samson." What is the law?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נְזִיר שִׁמְשׁוֹן לָא תַּנְיָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וְהָאָמַר רַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה: תַּנְיָא נְזִיר שִׁמְשׁוֹן! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִי תַּנְיָא — תַּנְיָא.
human_translation: said to him: a nazirite Samson is not taught. said to him: But didn’t Rav Adda bar Ahava say a nazirite Samson is taught said to him: If is taught, is taught,
llm_translation: He said to him: The Nazirite of Samson is not taught. He said to him: But didn't Rav Adda bar Ahava say: It is taught, the Nazirite of Samson! He said to him: If it is taught - it is taught.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: הָהִיא — רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן אוֹמֵר: אֵין אֶחָד מֵהֶם נָזִיר — לְפִי שֶׁלֹּא נִיתְּנָה נְזִירוּת אֶלָּא לְהַפְלָאָה.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said That is Rabbi Yehuda in the name of Rabbi Tarfon. As it is taught Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Tarfon: None of them is a nazirite because naziriteship was given only through explicitness
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: That one—Rabbi Yehudah in the name of Rabbi Tarfon it is. As it was taught, Rabbi Yehudah in the name of Rabbi Tarfon says: None of them is a Nazir, for the vow of Naziriteship was only given for wonderment.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי מַאי אִירְיָא שֶׁנִּגְנַב אוֹ שֶׁאָבַד? אֶלָּא, לְהוֹדִיעֲךָ כֹּחוֹ דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, דְּאַף עַל גַּב דְּנִגְנַב אוֹ שֶׁאָבַד, קָסָבַר מְעַיֵּיל אִינִישׁ נַפְשֵׁיהּ לִסְפֵיקָא.
human_translation: If so, why specifically that was stolen or that it was lost? Rather, to convey the far-reaching nature of Rabbi Shimon, that even that it was stolen or that it was lost he holds a person enters himself into uncertainty,
llm_translation: So what is it called, stolen or lost? Rather, to inform you of the strength of Rabbi Shimon, for even though it was stolen or lost, he holds that a person brings upon himself doubt.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: סְתָם תְּרוּמָה בִּיהוּדָה כּוּ׳. הָא מַכִּירִין — אֲסוּרִין, אַלְמָא סְפֵיקָא לְחוּמְרָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: Unspecified teruma in Judea they are familiar forbidden. Apparently, uncertainty is stringently.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: A sealed Terumah in Judea is like open Terumah. Those who recognize the seal - forbidden. This implies uncertainty which leads to a stricter ruling.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: סְתָם חֲרָמִים בִּיהוּדָה — מוּתָּרִין, וּבַגָּלִיל — אֲסוּרִין, שֶׁאֵין אַנְשֵׁי הַגָּלִיל מַכִּירִין אֶת חֶרְמֵי הַכֹּהֲנִים. הָא מַכִּירִין — מוּתָּרִין. אַלְמָא סְפֵיקָא לְקוּלָּא!
human_translation: say the latter clause Unspecified dedications in Judea are permitted, but in the Galilee they are forbidden, because the people of the Galilee are unfamiliar with dedications allotted to the priests. they are familiar they are permitted, Apparently, uncertainty is leniently.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: Setam charamim biYehudah - mutarin, uvaGalil - asurin, she'ein anshei hagalil makirin et chermey hakohanim. Ha makirin - mutarin. Alma sefeika lekula!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: סֵיפָא רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי צָדוֹק הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: סְתַם תְּרוּמָה בִּיהוּדָה — אֲסוּרָה, רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי צָדוֹק אוֹמֵר: סְתַם חֲרָמִים בַּגָּלִיל — אֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: Abaye said: The latter clause is Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, as it is taught Rabbi Yehuda says unspecified teruma in Judea is forbidden. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says unspecified dedications in the Galilee are forbidden.
llm_translation: Abaye said: The latter part is according to Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok. As it was taught: Rabbi Yehuda says: A sealed offering in Judea is forbidden, Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok says: Sealed cherem offerings in the Galilee are forbidden.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ נָדַר בְּחֵרֶם, וְאָמַר: לֹא נָדַרְתִּי אֶלָּא בְּחֶרְמוֹ שֶׁל יָם. בְּקׇרְבָּן, וְאָמַר: לֹא נָדַרְתִּי אֶלָּא בְּקׇרְבָּנוֹת שֶׁל מְלָכִים.
human_translation: took a vow with a dedication [ ḥerem ], and said: I took a vow only with a sea net [ ḥermo shel yam ] with an offering, and said: I took a vow only with offerings to kings,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who vows with cherem, and says: "I only vowed with the cherem of the sea." With korban, and says: "I only vowed with the sacrifices of kings."

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵי עַצְמִי קׇרְבָּן״, וְאָמַר: לֹא נָדַרְתִּי אֶלָּא בְּעֶצֶם שֶׁהִנַּחְתִּי לִי לִהְיוֹת נוֹדֵר בּוֹ, ״קֻוֽנָּם אִשְׁתִּי נֶהֱנֵית לִי״, וְאָמַר: לֹא נָדַרְתִּי אֶלָּא בְּאִשְׁתִּי הָרִאשׁוֹנָה שֶׁגֵּירַשְׁתִּי —
human_translation: I am hereby an offering myself [ atzmi ], and said: I took a vow only with a bone [ etzem ] that I set aside for myself to vow with, Deriving benefit from me is konam for my wife, and said: I took a vow only with regard to my first wife whom I divorced,
llm_translation: "Behold, my bone is a sacrifice," and he said: "I did not vow except with the bone that I designated for myself to be vowed upon it," "Their wives are a delight to me," and he said: "I did not vow except with my first wife whom I divorced —"

hebrew_text: עַל כּוּלָּן אֵין נִשְׁאָלִין לָהֶם. וְאִם נִשְׁאֲלוּ — עוֹנְשִׁין אוֹתָן וּמַחְמִירִין עֲלֵיהֶן. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: For all do not request them, However, if they requested punishes them and treats them stringently the statement of Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: Regarding all of them, they are not asked. And if they were asked - they are punished and strict with them. The words of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: פּוֹתְחִין לָהֶן פֶּתַח מִמָּקוֹם אַחֵר, וּמְלַמְּדִין אוֹתָן — כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יִנְהֲגוּ קַלּוּת רֹאשׁ בִּנְדָרִים.
human_translation: And the Rabbis say: is broached with them by a different extenuation, And we teach them in order that they will not take vows lightly.
llm_translation: The Sages say: We open for them a different opening, and we teach them—so that they will not act frivolously with vows.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ הָא גּוּפָא קַשְׁיָא, אָמְרַתְּ: אֵין נִשְׁאָלִין לָהֶן, וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי: אִם נִשְׁאֲלוּ עוֹנְשִׁין אוֹתָן וּמַחְמִירִין עֲלֵיהֶן?
human_translation: This is itself difficult. you said they do not request them, and then it is taught if they requested punishes them and treats them stringently,
llm_translation: The text reads: "Gemara: This body is difficult. You said: They are not asked, and then it teaches: If they were asked, do they punish them and are strict with them?"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה, הָכִי קָתָנֵי: וְכוּלָּן אֵין צְרִיכִין שְׁאֵלָה, בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּתַלְמִיד חָכָם, אֲבָל בְּעַם הָאָרֶץ שֶׁבָּא לִישָּׁאֵל — עוֹנְשִׁין אוֹתוֹ וּמַחְמִירִין עָלָיו.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said this is what is teaching: All of these do not need a request. in what is this statement said? In a Torah scholar, However, an ignoramus who comes to request punishes him and treats him stringently.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said, thus it was taught: And all of them do not require a question, in what case are these words said - in a Torah scholar, but in an ignorant person who comes to inquire - they punish him and are strict with him.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא מַחְמִירִין — דְּלָא פָּתְחִינַן לֵיהּ בַּחֲרָטָה, אֶלָּא עוֹנְשִׁין הֵיכִי דָּמֵי?
human_translation: Granted, treats stringently that do not broach with him by means of regret; However, what are the circumstances punishes
llm_translation: In truth, we are stringent - for we did not open for him with a chisel, rather, how are the penalties similar?

hebrew_text: כִּדְתַנְיָא: מִי שֶׁנָּזַר וְעָבַר עַל נְזִירוּתוֹ — אֵין נִזְקָקִין לוֹ עַד שֶׁיִּנְהוֹג בּוֹ אִיסּוּר כַּיָּמִים שֶׁנָּהַג בָּהֶן הֶיתֵּר. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בִּנְזִירוּת מוּעֶטֶת. אֲבָל בִּנְזִירוּת מְרוּבָּה — דַּיּוֹ שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם.
human_translation: as it is taught one who vowed to be a nazirite and violated his naziriteship, does not attend to him until he observes prohibitions for the same days in which he behaved with permissiveness the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei said: In what is this statement, said? in a short naziriteship, However, in long naziriteship it is enough for him thirty days,
llm_translation: As it was taught: One who takes a Nazirite vow and violates his Naziriteship - we do not require him to bring offerings until he becomes accustomed to forbidden things as he was accustomed to permissible things. These are the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei said: In what case are these words said? In the case of a minor Nazirite vow. But in the case of a major Nazirite vow - thirty days are sufficient.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: הוֹאִיל וְאָמְרִי רַבָּנַן אֵין נִזְקָקִים לוֹ, בֵּי דִינָא דְּמִזְדַּקְקִי לָא עָבֵיד שַׁפִּיר. רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: מְשַׁמְּתִינַן לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: Since the Sages say does not attend to him, a court that does attend is not acting properly. Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov says: is excommunicated.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: Since the Rabbis have said they do not require him, the court that investigates does not act properly. Rav Acha bar Yaakov says: We appoint him.

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים פּוֹתְחִין לוֹ פֶּתַח כּוּ׳. תָּנָא: לְעוֹלָם אַל תְּהִי רָגִיל בַּנְּדָרִים, שֶׁסּוֹפְךָ לִמְעוֹל בִּשְׁבוּעוֹת. וְאַל תְּהִי רָגִיל אֵצֶל עַם הָאָרֶץ, שֶׁסּוֹפְךָ לְהַאֲכִילְךָ טְבָלִים. אַל תְּהִי רָגִיל אֵצֶל כֹּהֵן עַם הָאָרֶץ, שֶׁסּוֹפְךָ לְהַאֲכִילְךָ תְּרוּמָה. וְאַל תַּרְבֶּה שִׂיחָה עִם הָאִשָּׁה, שֶׁסּוֹפְךָ לָבוֹא לִידֵי נִיאוּף.
human_translation: the Rabbis say: is broached with him extenuation, taught Never be accustomed to vows, because ultimately you will abuse oaths, And do not regularly be around an ignoramus, because ultimately he will feed you untithed produce, Do not regularly be by an ignorant priest, because ultimately he will feed you teruma And do not talk extensively with a woman, because ultimately you will come to adultery.
llm_translation: The sages say, "One should open for him a door like this." It was taught: Always be not accustomed to making vows, for you may end up transgressing by swearing falsely. And do not be accustomed to being with the common people, for you may end up being fed untithed produce. Do not be accustomed to being with an ignorant priest, for you may end up being fed terumah. And do not engage in excessive conversation with a woman, for you may end up coming to the sin of adultery.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אַחָא בְּרַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה אוֹמֵר: כׇּל הַצּוֹפֶה בְּנָשִׁים, סוֹפוֹ בָּא לִידֵי עֲבֵירָה. וְכׇל הַמִּסְתַּכֵּל בַּעֲקֵבָהּ שֶׁל אִשָּׁה, הָוְיִין לוֹ בָּנִים שֶׁאֵינָן מְהוּגָּנִין. אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: וּבְאִשְׁתּוֹ נִדָּה. אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ: עֲקֵבָהּ דְּקָתָנֵי, בִּמְקוֹם הַטִּנּוֹפֶת, שֶׁהוּא מְכֻוּוֹן כְּנֶגֶד הֶעָקֵב.
human_translation: Rabbi Aḥa, son of Rabbi Yoshiya, says: Anyone who watches women will ultimately come to sin, and anyone who looks at the heel of a woman will have indecent children Rav Yosef said: And relates to his wife a menstruating woman. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: The heel that is mentioned the place of uncleanliness, as it is situated opposite the heel.
llm_translation: Rabbi Ahah, son of Rabbi Yoshiyah, says: Anyone who gazes at women, his end is to come to sin. And anyone who stares at a woman's heel, will have unworthy children. Rav Yosef said: And with his wife being a menstruant. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Her heel that is mentioned, in the place of the heel, which is directly opposite the heel.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא: ״בַּעֲבוּר תִּהְיֶה יִרְאָתוֹ עַל פְּנֵיכֶם״ — זוֹ בּוּשָׁה. ״לְבִלְתִּי תֶחֱטָאוּ״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהַבּוּשָׁה מְבִיאָה לִידֵי יִרְאַת חֵטְא. מִיכָּן אָמְרוּ: סִימָן יָפֶה בְּאָדָם שֶׁהוּא בַּיְישָׁן. אֲחֵרִים אוֹמְרִים: כׇּל אָדָם הַמִּתְבַּיֵּישׁ, לֹא בִּמְהֵרָה הוּא חוֹטֵא. וּמִי שֶׁאֵין לוֹ בּוֹשֶׁת פָּנִים — בְּיָדוּעַ שֶׁלֹּא עָמְדוּ אֲבוֹתָיו עַל הַר סִינַי.
human_translation: It is taught “That His fear may be upon your faces” this shame, “That you not sin” teaches that shame leads to fear of sin. From here said: It is a good sign in a person that he is one who experiences shame. Others say: Any person who experiences shame will not quickly sin, and one who does not have shamefaced, it is known that his forefathers did not stand at Mount Sinai.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: It was taught: "‘So that his fear may be before your faces’ — this is shame. ‘So that you may not sin’ — this teaches that shame leads to fear of sin. From here they said: It is a good sign for a person to be bashful. Others say: Any person who is bashful, will not quickly sin. And one who has no shame on his face — it is known that his ancestors did not stand at Mount Sinai." English translation:

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן דַּהֲבַאי, אַרְבָּעָה דְּבָרִים סָחוּ לִי מַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת: חִיגְּרִין מִפְּנֵי מָה הָוְיִין — מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוֹפְכִים אֶת שׁוּלְחָנָם. אִילְּמִים מִפְּנֵי מָה הָוְיִין — מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמְּנַשְּׁקִים עַל אוֹתוֹ מָקוֹם. חֵרְשִׁים מִפְּנֵי מָה הָוְיִין — מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמְסַפְּרִים בִּשְׁעַת תַּשְׁמִישׁ. סוֹמִין מִפְּנֵי מָה הָוְיִין — מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמִּסְתַּכְּלִים בְּאוֹתוֹ מָקוֹם.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Dehavai said: The ministering angels told me four matters: For what do lame people come into existence? because overturn their tables, For what do mute people come into existence? because kiss that place For what do deaf people come into existence? because converse while engaging in sexual intercourse. For what do blind people come into existence? because stare at that place.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan ben Dahavai said, four things the ministering angels complained to me: Chigerin, why are they? Because they overturn their tables. Ilmim, why are they? Because they kiss in that place. Cherashim, why are they? Because they speak during intimacy. Somim, why are they? Because they gaze in that place.

hebrew_text: וּרְמִינְהוּ, שָׁאֲלוּ אֶת אִימָּא שָׁלוֹם: מִפְּנֵי מָה
human_translation: And raises a contradiction: Imma Shalom, was asked: For what
llm_translation: And they asked Imma Shalom: "For what reason..."

hebrew_text: בָּנַיִךְ יְפֵיפִין בְּיוֹתֵר? אָמְרָה לָהֶן: אֵינוֹ מְסַפֵּר עִמִּי לֹא בִּתְחִלַּת הַלַּיְלָה, וְלֹא בְּסוֹף הַלַּיְלָה, אֶלָּא בַּחֲצוֹת הַלַּיְלָה. וּכְשֶׁהוּא מְסַפֵּר, מְגַלֶּה טֶפַח וּמְכַסֶּה טֶפַח, וְדוֹמֶה עָלָיו כְּמִי שֶׁכְּפָאוֹ שֵׁד.
human_translation: are your children so beautiful? She said to them: does not converse with me neither at the beginning of the night nor at the end of the night, rather at midnight. And when he converses he reveals a handbreadth and covers a handbreadth, and as though he were being coerced by a demon
llm_translation: Your children are very beautiful? She said to them: He does not converse with me neither at the beginning of the night, nor at the end of the night, but in the middle of the night. And when he does converse, he uncovers a handbreadth and covers a handbreadth, and resembles one who is frightened by a demon.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַרְתִּי לוֹ: מָה טַעַם? וְאָמַר לִי: כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא אֶתֵּן אֶת עֵינַי בְּאִשָּׁה אַחֶרֶת, וְנִמְצְאוּ בָּנָיו בָּאִין לִידֵי מַמְזֵרוּת.
human_translation: And I said to What is the reason And he said to me: so that I will not set my eyes on another woman, his children consequently come to a mamzer status,
llm_translation: And I said to him: What is the reason? And he said to me: So that I do not set my eyes on another woman, and his children will end up being mamzerim.

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — בְּמִילֵּי דְתַשְׁמִישׁ, הָא — בְּמִילֵּי אַחְרָנְיָיתָא.
human_translation: not difficult. This with regard to matters of sexual intercourse, that with regard to other matters
llm_translation: Not difficult: this - in matters of utility, this - in matters of posteriority.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: זוֹ דִּבְרֵי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן דַּהֲבַאי, אֲבָל אָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּיוֹחָנָן בֶּן דַּהֲבַאי, אֶלָּא כֹּל מַה שֶּׁאָדָם רוֹצֶה לַעֲשׂוֹת בְּאִשְׁתּוֹ — עוֹשֶׂה. מָשָׁל לְבָשָׂר הַבָּא מִבֵּית הַטַּבָּח, רָצָה לְאׇכְלוֹ בְּמֶלַח — אוֹכְלוֹ. צָלִי — אוֹכְלוֹ. מְבוּשָּׁל — אוֹכְלוֹ. שָׁלוּק — אוֹכְלוֹ. וְכֵן דָּג הַבָּא מִבֵּית הַצַּיָּיד.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: That is the statement of Yoḥanan ben Dehavai. However, the Rabbis said: The halakha is not in accordance with Yoḥanan ben Dehavai. Rather, whatever a man wishes to do with his wife he may do. an allegory, like meat that comes from the butcher. he wants to eat it with salt, he may eat it roasted, he may eat it cooked, he may eat it boiled, he may eat it And likewise fish that come from the fisherman.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: These are the words of Yochanan ben Dahavai, but the sages said: The halacha is not like Yochanan ben Dahavai, rather, whatever a man wants to do with his wife - he may do. A parable: Meat that comes from the butcher shop, if he wants to eat it with salt - he may eat it. Roasted - he may eat it. Cooked - he may eat it. Boiled - he may eat it. And similarly, fish that comes from the fisherman.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַמֵּימָר: מַאן מַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת — רַבָּנַן, דְּאִי תֵּימָא מַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת מַמָּשׁ, אַמַּאי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּיוֹחָנָן בֶּן דַּהֲבַאי? הָא אִינְהוּ בְּקִיאִי בְּצוּרַת הַוָּלָד טְפֵי! וְאַמַּאי קָרוּ לְהוּ מַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת — דִּמְצַיְּינִי כְּמַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת.
human_translation: Ameimar said: Who are the ministering angels the Sages, Because if you say actual ministering angels, why did Rabbi Yoḥanan say the halakha is not in accordance with Yoḥanan ben Dehavai? are more knowledgeable about the forming of the fetus And why are called ministering angels? Because they stand out like ministering angels,
llm_translation: Amemar said: Who are the ministering angels? — The Rabbis. For if you were to say they are the actual ministering angels, why then did Rabbi Yochanan say, "The halakha does not follow Yochanan ben Dahavai"? They are more expert in the formation of the fetus! And why are they called ministering angels? Because they are as swift as ministering angels.

hebrew_text: הַהִיא דַּאֲתַאי לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי, אָמְרָה לוֹ: רַבִּי, עָרַכְתִּי לוֹ שׁוּלְחָן וַהֲפָכוֹ! אֲמַר לָהּ: בִּתִּי, תּוֹרָה הִתִּירָתֶךְ, וַאֲנִי מָה אֶעֱשֶׂה לִיךְ? הָהִיא דַּאֲתַאי לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב, אָמְרָה לוֹ: רַבִּי, עָרַכְתִּי לוֹ שׁוּלְחָן וַהֲפָכוֹ! אָמַר: מַאי שְׁנָא מִן בִּינִיתָא?
human_translation: A certain woman, who came before Rabbi said to him: My teacher, I set him a table, and he turned it over. said to her: My daughter, the Torah permitted you and what can I do for you a certain woman who came before Rav said to him: My teacher, I set a table for him and he turned it over. He said what is different from a fish [ binnita ]
llm_translation: That one who came before Rabbi, she said to him: Rabbi, I set the table for him and he overturned it! He said to her: My daughter, the Torah permitted you, and what shall I do for you? That one who came before Rav, she said to him: Rabbi, I set the table for him and he overturned it! He said: What is different from the construction?

hebrew_text: ״וְלֹא תָתוּרוּ אַחֲרֵי לְבַבְכֶם״, מִכָּאן אָמַר רַבִּי: אַל יִשְׁתֶּה אָדָם בְּכוֹס זֶה וְיִתֵּן עֵינָיו בְּכוֹס אַחֵר. אָמַר רָבִינָא: לֹא נִצְרְכָא, אֶלָּא דַּאֲפִילּוּ שְׁתֵּי נָשָׁיו.
human_translation: “And that you not go about after your own heart” Rabbi said from here a man should not drink from this cup while setting his eyes on another cup, Ravina said: is necessary only that even his two wives,
llm_translation: "And do not stray after your hearts," from here Rabbi said: A person should not drink from this cup and look at another cup. Ravina said: It is not necessary, rather even if he has two wives."

hebrew_text: ״וּבָרוֹתִי מִכֶּם הַמֹּרְדִים וְהַפּוֹשְׁעִים בִּי״, אָמַר רַבִּי לֵוִי: אֵלּוּ בְּנֵי תֵּשַׁע מִדּוֹת, בְּנֵי אׇסְנַ״‎ת משגע״‎ח.
human_translation: “And I will purge out from among you the rebels, and those that transgress against Me” Rabbi Levi said: These are children of nine traits, children of aleph , samekh , nun , tav , mem , shin , gimmel , ayin , ḥet .
llm_translation: "And I will purge out from among you the rebels, and them that transgress against Me," said Rabbi Levi: These are the students of the nine measures, the students of the Academy of Asenath, who are bewildered.

hebrew_text: בְּנֵי אֵימָה, בְּנֵי אֲנוּסָה, בְּנֵי שְׂנוּאָה, בְּנֵי נִידּוּי, בְּנֵי תְמוּרָה, בְּנֵי מְרִיבָה, בְּנֵי שִׁכְרוּת, בְּנֵי גְּרוּשַׁת הַלֵּב, בְּנֵי עִרְבּוּבְיָא, בְּנֵי חֲצוּפָה.
human_translation: Children of fear [ eima ], children of a woman who was raped [ anusa ]; children of a hated woman [ senua ], children of ostracism [ niddui ], children of substitution [ temura ], children of strife [ meriva ], children of drunkenness [ shikhrut ], children of a woman who was divorced in the heart [ gerushat halev ], children of mixture [ irbuveya ], children of a shameless woman [ ḥatzufa ]
llm_translation: Sons of fear, sons of rape, sons of hatred, sons of excommunication, sons of substitution, sons of contention, sons of drunkenness, sons of a heart's divorce, sons of mixed lineage, sons of impudence.

hebrew_text: אִינִי? וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: כׇּל אָדָם שֶׁאִשְׁתּוֹ תּוֹבַעְתּוֹ — הָוְיִין לוֹ בָּנִים שֶׁאֲפִילּוּ בְּדוֹרוֹ שֶׁל מֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ לֹא הָיוּ כְּמוֹתָם. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הָבוּ לָכֶם אֲנָשִׁים חֲכָמִים וּנְבֹנִים״, וּכְתִיב: ״וָאֶקַּח אֶת רָאשֵׁי שִׁבְטֵיכֶם״, וְלָא ״כְּתִיב נְבוֹנִים״.
human_translation: Is that so? But didn’t Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani say Rabbi Yonatan said: Any man whose wife demands of him will have children the likes of whom did not exist even in the generation of Moses our teacher? As it is stated: “Get you wise men, and understanding, and it is written “So I took the heads of your tribes, And it does not say understanding.
llm_translation: I? And Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said in the name of Rabbi Yonatan: Any man whose wife demands him - he should have children who even in the generation of Moses our teacher were not like them. As it is stated: "Give for yourselves wise and understanding men," and it is written: "And I took the heads of your tribes," and not "written understanding."

hebrew_text: וּכְתִיב ״יִשָּׂשכָר חֲמֹר גָּרֶם״, וּכְתִיב: ״מִבְּנֵי יִשָּׂשכָר יוֹדְעֵי בִינָה לַעִתִּים״!
human_translation: And it is written: “Issachar is a large-boned donkey” And it is written: “And of the children of Issachar, men that had understanding of the times”
llm_translation: And it is written, "Yissachar is a strong-boned donkey," and it is written: "Of the sons of Yissachar, men who understood the times."

hebrew_text: הַהִיא דְּמַרְצְיָא אַרְצוֹיֵי.
human_translation: That who entices
llm_translation: That which Marzeya said.

hebrew_text: הֲדַרַן עֲלָךְ וְאֵלּוּ מוּתָּרִין
llm_translation: We will return to you, and these are permitted.

hebrew_text: אַרְבָּעָה נְדָרִים הִתִּירוּ חֲכָמִים: נִדְרֵי זֵרוּזִין, וְנִדְרֵי הֲבַאי, וְנִדְרֵי שְׁגָגוֹת, וְנִדְרֵי אוֹנָסִין. נִדְרֵי זֵרוּזִין כֵּיצַד? הָיָה מוֹכֵר חֵפֶץ, וְאָמַר: ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֵינִי פּוֹחֵת לְךָ מִן הַסֶּלַע״, וְהַלָּה אוֹמֵר: ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֵינִי מוֹסִיף לָךְ עַל הַשֶּׁקֶל״,
human_translation: The Sages dissolved four vows Vows of exhortation, vows of exaggeration, vows that are unintentional, and vows circumstances beyond control. Vows of exhortation How so? One was selling an item and said: I will not lower for you than a sela , that is konam , as if an offering, And the other one, says: I will not raise to you more than a shekel, that is konam
llm_translation: Four vows the sages permitted: vows of alacrity, vows of coming, vows of inadvertence, and vows of compulsion. Vows of alacrity, how so? If one was selling an item and said, "Its price shall not be less for you than a sela," and the buyer says, "Its price shall not be more for you than a shekel."

hebrew_text: שְׁנֵיהֶם רוֹצִין בִּשְׁלֹשָׁה דִּינָרִין.
human_translation: both want at three dinars,
llm_translation: Both of them desire three dinars.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אַרְבָּעָה נְדָרִים הִתִּירוּ חֲכָמִים כּוּ׳. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר מֶמֶל לְרַבִּי אַמֵּי: אֲמַרְתְּ לַן מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה נְשִׂיאָה: מַאן תְּנָא אַרְבָּעָה נְדָרִים — רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דְּאָמַר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן: לְעוֹלָם אֵין אֶחָד מֵהֶן נָזִיר, לְפִי שֶׁלֹּא נִיתְּנָה נְזִירוּת אֶלָּא לְהַפְלָאָה.
human_translation: The Sages dissolved four vows. Rabbi Abba bar Memel said to Rabbi Ami: You said to us in the name of Rabbi Yehuda Nesia: Who taught four vows? It Rabbi Yehuda, who said in the name of Rabbi Tarfon: actually neither of them a nazirite, because naziriteship is determined only by explicitness
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Gemara: Four vows the sages permitted. Rabbi Abba bar Memel said to Rabbi Amei: You told us in the name of Rabbi Yehudah Nasi: Who is the Tanna of the four vows? - It is Rabbi Yehudah, as he said in the name of Rabbi Tarfon: 'None of them is a Nazir, for Naziriteship was only given for wonderment.'"

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבָּנַן, מִי קָתָנֵי ״שְׁנֵיהֶן רָצוּ״? ״שְׁנֵיהֶן רוֹצִין״ קָתָנֵי.
