human_translation: Rava said: You even say the Rabbis, Does teach: Both wanted It teaches: Both want,
llm_translation: Rava said: Even if you say it is the Rabbis, who taught "both of them wanted"? It teaches "both of them want."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: אָמַר לוֹ טְפֵי מִסֶּלַע, וְהַלָּה אֹמֵר בְּצִיר מִשֶּׁקֶל, נִדְרָא הָוֵי, אוֹ זֵרוּזִין הָוֵי?
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: said to more than a sela , and the other less than a shekel, Is this a vow, Or is encouragement?
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: He said to him, "A drop from a rock," and the other one says, "From a shekel of seed," is it considered a vow, or is it considered a prompt?"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ, תְּנֵינָא: הָיָה מְסָרֵב בַּחֲבֵירוֹ שֶׁיֹּאכַל אֶצְלוֹ, וְאָמַר לוֹ ״קֻוֽנָּם בֵּיתְךָ שֶׁאֲנִי נִכְנָס״, ״טִיפַּת צוֹנֵן שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם״ — מוּתָּר לִיכָּנֵס לְבֵיתוֹ וְלִשְׁתּוֹת הֵימֶנּוּ צוֹנֵן, שֶׁלֹּא נִתְכַּוֵּון זֶה אֶלָּא לְשׁוּם אֲכִילָה וּשְׁתִיָּה.
human_translation: said to him: We learned was importuning another that he should eat with him and said to him: Entering your house is konam for me, A drop of cold that I taste it is permitted to enter his house and drink cold since he intended it only for the purpose of eating and drinking
llm_translation: He said to him, "We learned: If one was invited by his friend to eat with him, and he said to him, 'Your house is established for me to enter,' 'I taste a drop of cold,' he is permitted to enter his house and drink cold water from it, as this one did not intend except for eating and drinking."

hebrew_text: וְאַמַּאי? וְהָא ״טִיפַּת צוֹנֵן״ קָאָמַר! אֶלָּא מִשְׁתַּעֵי אִינִישׁ הָכִי. הָכָא נָמֵי מִשְׁתַּעֵי אִינִישׁ הָכִי.
human_translation: And why But he said: A drop of cold Rather, a person speaks this way Here also, a person speaks this way.
llm_translation: And why? And this, "a drop of cold," is what he is saying! Rather, a person deviates thus. Here too, a person deviates thus.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ:
human_translation: said to him:
llm_translation: He said to him:

hebrew_text: מִי דָּמֵי? גַּבֵּי צוֹנֵן, צַדִּיקִים אוֹמְרִים מְעַט וְעוֹשִׂין הַרְבֵּה —
human_translation: Are comparable? Concerning cold righteous say little and do much.
llm_translation: Who is similar? Regarding a cold person, the righteous say little and do much —

hebrew_text: הָכָא סְפֵיקָא הוּא, דִּלְמָא פָּחוֹת מִסֶּלַע וְיוֹתֵר עַל שֶׁקֶל קָאָמַר, וְזֵירוּזִין הָוֵי, אוֹ דִּלְמָא דַּוְקָא קָאָמַר, וְנִידְרָא הָוֵי. תִּבְּעֵי.
human_translation: here it is uncertain. Perhaps says less than a sela , and more than a shekel; and is an exhortation Or, perhaps he meant specifically and it is a vow, The dilemma remains
llm_translation: Here is a doubt, perhaps less than a sela and more than a shekel he is saying, and it is a kind of jest, or perhaps he is saying it precisely, and it is a vow. It is inquired.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב אַסִּי: אַרְבָּעָה נְדָרִים הַלָּלוּ צְרִיכִין שְׁאֵלָה לְחָכָם. כִּי אַמְרִיתָא קַמֵּיהּ דִּשְׁמוּאֵל, אָמַר: תַּנָּא תָּנֵי ״אַרְבָּעָה נְדָרִים הִתִּירוּ חֲכָמִים״, וְאַתְּ אָמְרַתְּ צְרִיכִין שְׁאֵלָה לְחָכָם?!
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said Rav Asi said: These four vows require a request to a halakhic authority When I said before Shmuel, he said: The tanna teaches the Sages dissolved four vows, and you say they require a request to a halakhic authority?
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav Assi: These four vows require consultation with a sage. For when you said before Shmuel, he said: A Tanna taught, "The sages permitted these four vows," and you say they require consultation with a sage?!

hebrew_text: רַב יוֹסֵף מַתְנִי לַהּ לְהָא שְׁמַעְתָּא בְּהַאי לִישָּׁנָא: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב אַסִּי: אֵין חָכָם רַשַּׁאי לְהַתִּיר אֶלָּא כְּעֵין אַרְבָּעָה נְדָרִים הַלָּלוּ. קָסָבַר אֵין פּוֹתְחִין בַּחֲרָטָה.
human_translation: Rav Yosef taught this halakha in this manner: Rav Yehuda said Rav Asi said: A halakhic authority is able to dissolve only similar to these four vows he holds that does not broach on regret.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef teaches her to hear in this matter: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav Assi: A sage is not permitted to permit except like these four vows. He holds that one does not begin with a sharp knife.

hebrew_text: הַהוּא דַּאֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב הוּנָא, אָמַר לֵיהּ: לִבָּךְ עֲלָךְ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא, וְשַׁרְיֵיהּ.
human_translation: a certain who came before Rav Huna said to him: Is your heart upon you? He said to him: No. And dissolved for him.
llm_translation: That one who came before Rav Huna, he said to him: "Is your heart upon you?" He said to him: "No, and release it."

hebrew_text: הָהוּא דַּאֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִילּוּ הָיוּ עֲשָׂרָה בְּנֵי אָדָם שֶׁיְּפַיְּיסוּךְ בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה מִי נָדַרְתָּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לֹא, וְהִתִּירוֹ.
human_translation: a certain who came before Rabba bar Rav Huna said to him: Had there been ten people who appeased you at the time would you have made the vow? He said to him: No. And he dissolved for him.
llm_translation: That one who came before Rabba bar Rav Huna, he said to him: If there were ten people who would appease you at that moment, would you have made a vow? He said to him: No, and they annulled it.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אוֹמְרִים לוֹ לָאָדָם: לֵב זֶה עָלֶיךָ? אִם אָמַר ״לָאו״ — מַתִּירִין אוֹתוֹ. רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם אָבִיו: אוֹמְרִים לוֹ לָאָדָם: אִילּוּ הָיוּ עֲשָׂרָה בְּנֵי אָדָם שֶׁיְּפַיְּיסוּךְ בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה מִי נָדַרְתָּ? אִם אָמַר ״לָאו״ — מַתִּירִין אוֹתוֹ.
human_translation: is taught Rabbi Yehuda says: say to the person Is this heart, upon you? If he says no, they dissolve it. Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, says in the name of his father: They say to the person Had there been ten people who appeased you at the time, would you have made the vow? If he says no, they dissolve it.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Yehuda says: They say to a person: "Is this matter upon you?" If he says "no" - they permit him. Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yose, says in the name of his father: They say to a person: "If ten people were to appease you at that moment, would you still have made a vow?" If he says "no" - they permit him.

hebrew_text: (סִימָן: אַסִּי וְאֶלְעָזָר, יוֹחָנָן וְיַנַּאי).
human_translation: a mnemonic Asi and Elazar, Yoḥanan and Yannai.
llm_translation: Section: Assi and Elazar, Yochanan and Yannai.

hebrew_text: הַהוּא דַּאֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי אַסִּי אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כְּדוּ תָּהֵית? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא, וְשַׁרְיֵיהּ. הָהוּא דַּאֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: בָּעֵית נָדוּר? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִילּוּ לָא מַרְגְּזִין לִי לָא בָּעֵינַן כְּלוּם. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: תְּהֵא כְּבָעֵית. הָהִיא אִיתְּתָא דְּאַדַּרְתַּהּ לִבְרַתַּהּ, אֲתַאי לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, אָמַר לַהּ: אִילּוּ הֲוָה יָדְעַתְּ דְּאָמְרָן מְגֵירָתִיךְ עֲלַהּ דִּבְרַתִּךְ:
human_translation: a certain who came before Rabbi Asi said to him: Do you have regret? He said to him No, And he dissolved for him. a certain who came before Rabbi Elazar, said to him: Did you want to vow? He said to If they had not angered me, I would not have wanted anything. He said to him: Let it be like you want, a certain woman who took a vow with regard to her daughter came before Rabbi Yoḥanan He said to her: Had you known that your neighbors would say about your daughter:
llm_translation: That one who came before Rabbi Assi said to him: "Were you present?" He said to him: "No, and they permitted him." That one who came before Rabbi Elazar said to him: "Do you require a vow?" He said to him: "If they do not upset me, we do not need anything." He said to him: "Let it be as if you require." That woman who adorned herself for her husband, came before Rabbi Yochanan, he said to her: "If only you had known that your spinning wheel is upon your word."

hebrew_text: אִילּוּ לָא חֲמָאת בָּהּ אִימַּהּ מִילִּין דַּעֲזִיבָה — בִּכְדִי לָא אַדַּרְתַּהּ! מִי אַדַּרְתַּהּ? אֲמַרָה לֵיהּ: לָא, וְשַׁרְיַיהּ.
human_translation: Had her mother not seen inappropriate [ aziva ] matters in her she would not have taken a vow with regard to her for nothing; would you have taken a vow with regard to her? She said to him: No, and he dissolved for her.
llm_translation: If she had not been angry with her, would she have left her words? — In order not to return to her! Did she return to her? She said to him: No, and she left.

hebrew_text: בַּר בְּרַתֵּיה דְּרַבִּי יַנַּאי סָבָא אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יַנַּאי סָבָא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִילּוּ הֲוָה יָדְעַתְּ דְּפָתְחִין פִּינְקְסָךְ וּמְמַשְׁמְשִׁין בְּעוֹבָדָךְ, מִי נְדַרְתְּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא, וְשַׁרְיֵיהּ.
human_translation: The son of the daughter of Rabbi Yannai the Elder came before Rabbi Yannai the Elder He said to him: Had you known that they open your record book [ pinekas ] and examine your actions, would you have vowed? He said to him: No, and he dissolved for him.
llm_translation: Son of the daughter of Rabbi Yannai the Elder came before Rabbi Yannai the Elder. He said to him: If you had known that they open your wine cask and make personal use of your wine, would you have taken a vow? He said to him: No, and it is permitted.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: מַאי קְרָאָה — ״וְאַחַר נְדָרִים לְבַקֵּר״. וְאַף עַל גַּב דִּפְתַח רַבִּי יַנַּאי לֵיהּ — אֲנַן לָא פָּתְחִינַן לֵיהּ בְּהָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba said: What is the verse “And after vows to make inquiry” And although Rabbi Yannai broached with him we do not broach in this for
llm_translation: Rabbi Abba said: What is the verse? "And after vows to inquire." And even though Rabbi Yannai began with it, we did not begin with it in this matter.

hebrew_text: וְלָא פָּתְחִינַן בְּהָדָא אַחְרָנִייתָא, דְּאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַאי פְּתַח לֵיהּ רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל לְהָהוּא סָבָא: ״יֵשׁ בּוֹטֶה כְּמַדְקְרוֹת חָרֶב וּלְשׁוֹן חֲכָמִים מַרְפֵּא״. כׇּל הַבּוֹטֶה — רָאוּי לְדוֹקְרוֹ בְּחֶרֶב, אֶלָּא — לְשׁוֹן חֲכָמִים מַרְפֵּא.
human_translation: And we do not broach in this other as Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What did Rabban Gamliel broach for a certain elderly man “There is one who speaks like the piercing of a sword, but the tongue of the wise is health” Anyone who verbally expresses appropriate to pierce him with a sword, but “The tongue of the wise is health,”
llm_translation: We did not begin with the following matter, as Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: What did Rabban Gamliel open with to that elder? "There is a botéh like the punctures of a sword, and the tongue of the sages heals." Anyone who is a botéh is fit to be pierced with a sword, except the tongue of the sages heals.

hebrew_text: וְלָא פָּתְחִינַן בַּהֲדָא אַחְרָנִייתָא, דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי נָתָן אוֹמֵר: הַנּוֹדֵר — כְּאִילּוּ בָּנָה בָּמָה, וְהַמְקַיְּימוֹ — כְּאִילּוּ מַקְרִיב עָלָיו קׇרְבָּן. בְּרֵישָׁא פָּתְחִינַן. בְּסֵיפָא, אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: פָּתְחִינַן, רָבָא אָמַר: לָא פָּתְחִינַן.
human_translation: We do not broach using this other as it is taught Rabbi Natan says: One who vows as if he built altar and one who fulfills as if he sacrifices an offering on it. With the first clause, we may broach the latter clause Abaye said: We do broach Rava said: We do not broach
llm_translation: We did not begin with this latter teaching, as it was taught: Rabbi Natan says: One who vows — it is as though he built an altar, and one who fulfills it — it is as though he offered a sacrifice upon it. In the beginning, we began. In the end, Abbaye said: We began, Rava said: We did not begin.

hebrew_text: רַב כָּהֲנָא מַתְנֵי לַהּ לְהָא שְׁמַעְתָּא בְּהָדֵין לִישָּׁנָא. רַב טַבְיוֹמֵי מַתְנֵי הָכִי: בְּסֵיפָא לָא פָּתְחִינַן. בְּרֵישָׁא, אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: פָּתְחִינַן, רָבָא אָמַר: לָא פָּתְחִינַן. וְהִלְכְתָא: לָא פָּתְחִינַן לָא בְּרֵישָׁא וְלָא בְּסֵיפָא.
human_translation: Rav Kahana taught this halakha in this wording, Rav Tavyumei taught this way: in the last clause, we do not broach in the first clause, Abaye said: We do broach Rava said: We do not broach dissolution And the halakha is we do not broach either in the first clause or in the latter clause.
llm_translation: Rav Kahana teaches it to him to hear in that one to sleep. Rav Tavyomei teaches thus: In the end, we did not open. In the beginning, Abbaye said: We opened, Rava said: We did not open. And the halakha is: We did not open, neither in the beginning nor in the end.

hebrew_text: וְלָא פָּתְחִינַן בְּהָא נָמֵי דִּשְׁמוּאֵל. דְּאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁמְּקַיְּימוֹ — נִקְרָא רָשָׁע. אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ, מַאי קְרָא: ״וְכִי תֶחְדַּל לִנְדֹּר לֹא יִהְיֶה בְךָ חֵטְא״, וְיָלֵיף ״חֲדָלָה״ ״חֲדָלָה״. כְּתִיב הָכָא: ״וְכִי תֶחְדַּל לִנְדֹּר״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״שָׁם רְשָׁעִים חָדְלוּ רֹגֶז״.
human_translation: And we also do not broach with this of Shmuel, as Shmuel said: although he fulfills it, he is called wicked. Rabbi Abbahu said: What is the verse “But if you refrain [ teḥdal ] from vowing there will be no sin in you” and he derives ḥadala ḥadala It is written here: “But if you refrain [ teḥdal ] from vowing,” and it is written there: “There the wicked cease [ ḥadlu ] from troubling”
llm_translation: We did not begin with the statement of Shmuel. For Shmuel said: Even though he fulfills it, he is called wicked. Rabbi Avahu said, what is the verse: "And if you refrain from vowing, there will be no sin in you," and he expounded "refrain" twice. It is written here: "And if you refrain from vowing," and it is written there: "There the wicked cease from troubling."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף, אַף אֲנַן נָמֵי תְּנֵינָא: ״כְּנִדְרֵי כְשֵׁרִים״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם, ״כְּנִדְרֵי רְשָׁעִים״ — נָדַר בְּנָזִיר וּבְקׇרְבָּן וּבִשְׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: We, too, learn like the vows of the virtuous, he has not said anything. Like the vows of the wicked, he has vowed with regard to a nazirite, or with regard to an offering, or with regard to an oath.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said, "We also learned: 'Like the vows of righteous people'—he did not say anything; 'Like the vows of wicked people'—he vowed regarding Naziriteship, sacrifices, and oaths."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: כׇּל הַכּוֹעֵס כׇּל מִינֵי גֵיהִנָּם שׁוֹלְטִין בּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָסֵר כַּעַס מִלִּבֶּךָ וְהַעֲבֵר רָעָה מִבְּשָׂרֶךָ״, וְאֵין ״רָעָה״ אֶלָּא גֵּיהִנָּם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כֹּל פָּעַל ה׳ לַמַּעֲנֵהוּ וְגַם רָשָׁע לְיוֹם רָעָה״.
human_translation: Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said Rabbi Yonatan said: Anyone who gets angry, all kinds of Gehenna rule over him, as it is stated: “Therefore remove vexation from your heart and put away evil from your flesh” and the evil is nothing other than Gehenna, as it is stated: “The Lord has made everything for His own purpose and even the wicked for the day of evil”
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said Rabbi Yonatan: Anyone who gets angry, all types of Gehinnom rule over him, as it is stated: "Remove anger from your heart and put away evil from your flesh." And "evil" is none other than Gehinnom, as it is stated: "The Lord has made everything for His purpose, even the wicked for the day of evil."

hebrew_text: וְלֹא עוֹד אֶלָּא שֶׁהַתַּחְתּוֹנִיּוֹת שׁוֹלְטוֹת בּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְנָתַן ה׳ לְךָ שָׁם לֵב רַגָּז וְכִלְיוֹן עֵינַיִם וְדַאֲבוֹן נָפֶשׁ״, אֵיזֶהוּ דָּבָר שֶׁמְּכַלֶּה אֶת הָעֵינַיִם וּמַדְאִיב אֶת הַנֶּפֶשׁ — הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר: אֵלּוּ הַתַּחְתּוֹנִיּוֹת.
human_translation: And not only that, but hemorrhoids will control him, as it is stated: “But the Lord shall give you there a trembling heart, and failing of eyes, and languishing of soul” Which matter that causes failing of the eyes and causes languishing of the soul? You must say this hemorrhoids.
llm_translation: And not only that, but the lower ones dominate him, as it says: "And the Lord will give you there a trembling heart, failing of eyes, and despair of soul." What is the thing that weakens the eyes and causes distress to the soul? — One would say: These are the lower ones.

hebrew_text: עוּלָּא בְּמִיסְּקֵיהּ לְאַרְעָא דְּיִשְׂרָאֵל אִיתְלְווֹ לֵיהּ תְּרֵין בְּנֵי חוֹזָאֵי בַּהֲדֵיהּ. קָם חַד שַׁחְטֵיהּ לְחַבְרֵיהּ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ לְעוּלָּא: יָאוּת עֲבַדִי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִין, וּפְרַע לֵיהּ בֵּית הַשְּׁחִיטָה. כִּי אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: דִּלְמָא חַס וְשָׁלוֹם אַחְזִיקִי יְדֵי עוֹבְרֵי עֲבֵירָה? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נַפְשְׁךָ הִצַּלְתָּ.
human_translation: Ulla, on his ascent to Eretz Yisrael, had two residents of Ḥozai join him. one arose slaughtered the other. said to Ulla: Did I act properly? He said to him: Yes, and open the place of the slaughter, When came before Rabbi Yoḥanan, said to him: Perhaps, Heaven forbid, I strengthened the hands of sinners He said to him: You saved yourself
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Ulah b'miskeiha l'ar'a d'Yisrael itlavu lei trein b'nei chozaei bahadeih. Kam chad shachteih l'chavrei. Amar lei l'Ulah: Yaut avadi? Amar lei: Ein, u'fara lei beit hashchitah. Ki ata l'kameih d'Rabbi Yochanan, amar lei: Dilmah chas v'shalom achziki yedei ovrei aveirah? Amar lei: Nafshecha hitzalta. English translation: Ulah in his travels to the Land of Israel was accompanied by two of the disciples of Chozaei. One of them slaughtered an animal for his companions. He said to Ulah: Have I done well? He replied: No, and he nullified the slaughter. When he came before Rabbi Yochanan, he said to him: Perhaps you should have held back the hands of those who transgressed? He replied: You have saved yourself.

hebrew_text: קָא תָמַהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, מִכְּדִי כְּתִיב: ״וְנָתַן ה׳ לְךָ שָׁם לֵב רַגָּז״ בְּבָבֶל כְּתִיב? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָהוּא שַׁעְתָּא
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan wondered: Now, it is written “But the Lord shall give you there a trembling heart” is written with regard to Babylonia, said to him: At that moment
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan was astonished, as it is written: "And the Lord will give you there a trembling heart" - is it written in Babylon? He said to him: At that time.

hebrew_text: לָא עָבְרִינַן יַרְדְּנָא.
human_translation: we had not crossed the Jordan River,
llm_translation: We do not pass the Jordan.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא: כׇּל הַכּוֹעֵס, אֲפִילּוּ שְׁכִינָה אֵינָהּ חֲשׁוּבָה כְּנֶגְדּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״רָשָׁע כְּגֹבַהּ אַפּוֹ בַּל יִדְרֹשׁ אֵין אֱלֹהִים כׇּל מְזִמּוֹתָיו״. רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה מִדִּיפְתִּי אָמַר: מְשַׁכֵּחַ תַּלְמוּדוֹ וּמוֹסִיף טִיפְּשׁוּת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי כַעַס בְּחֵיק כְּסִילִים יָנוּחַ״, וּכְתִיב: ״וּכְסִיל יִפְרֹשׂ אִוֶּלֶת״. רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק אָמַר: בְּיָדוּעַ שֶׁעֲוֹנוֹתָיו מְרוּבִּין מִזְּכִיּוֹתָיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּבַעַל חֵמָה רַב פָּשַׁע״.
human_translation: Rabba bar Rav Huna said: Anyone who gets angry, even the Divine Presence is not important to him, as it is stated: “The wicked, in the height of his anger says: He will not require; all his thoughts are: There is no God” Rabbi Yirmeya of Difti said: forgets his learning and increases foolishness, as it is stated: “For anger rests in the bosom of fools” and it is written: “But a fool unfolds folly” Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: it is acknowledged that his sins are more numerous than his merits, as it is stated: “And a wrathful man abounds in transgression”
llm_translation: Rabba bar Rav Huna said: Anyone who becomes angry, even the Divine Presence is not considered opposite him, as it is stated: "The wicked, in the haughtiness of his countenance, will not seek; there is no God in all his thoughts." Rabbi Yirmeya of Difti said: He forgets his learning and adds foolishness, as it is stated: "For anger rests in the bosom of fools," and it is written: "And a fool spreads folly." Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: It is known that his sins outweigh his merits, as it is stated: "And a man of great wrath will bear the penalty."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַדָּא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: אִלְמָלֵא (לֹא) חָטְאוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל לֹא נִיתַּן לָהֶם אֶלָּא חֲמִשָּׁה חוּמְשֵׁי תוֹרָה וְסֵפֶר יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בִּלְבַד, שֶׁעֶרְכָּהּ שֶׁל אֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל הוּא. מַאי טַעְמָא: ״כִּי בְּרֹב חׇכְמָה רׇב כָּעַס״.
human_translation: Rav Adda, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: Had Israel not sinned they would have been given the five books of the Torah and the book of Joshua alone. because it the arrangement of Eretz Yisrael. What is the reason, “For in much wisdom is much vexation”
llm_translation: Rav Adda, son of Rabbi Chanina, said: If the Israelites had not sinned, they would have been given only five portions of the Torah and the book of Joshua alone, for it is the appraisal of the land of Israel. What is the reason? "For with much wisdom comes much vexation."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַסִּי: אֵין נִזְקָקִין לֶ״אֱלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״, חוּץ מִ״קּוּנָּם אִשְׁתִּי נֶהֱנֵית לִי שֶׁגָּנְבָה אֶת כִּיסִי וְשֶׁהִכְּתָה אֶת בְּנִי״, וְנוֹדַע שֶׁלֹּא גָּנְבָה וְשֶׁלֹּא הִכַּתּוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Asi said: One does not attend to the God of Israel except for Benefiting from me is konam for my wife because she stole my purse or she hit my son, and it became known that she did not steal or did not hit
llm_translation: Rabbi Assi said: We only rely on "the God of Israel" except for "when my wife benefits from me, claiming that she stole my purse and that she struck my son," and it is known that she did not steal and they were not struck.

hebrew_text: הָהִיא דַּאֲתַאי לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב אַסִּי, אָמַר לַהּ: בְּמַאי נְדַרְתְּ? בֵּ״אלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״. אֲמַר לַהּ: אִי נְדַרְתְּ בְּ״מוֹהִי״ שֶׁהִיא כִּינּוּי בְּעָלְמָא — מִזְדְּקִיקְנָא לִךְ, הַשְׁתָּא דְּלָא נְדַרְתְּ בְּ״מוֹהִי אֶלָּא בֵּ״אלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״, לָא מִזְדְּקִיקְנָא לִךְ.
human_translation: a certain who came before Rav Asi. He said to her: With what did you vow? By the God of Israel. He said to her: If you would have vowed By mohi , which is merely a substitute name, I would have attended to your now that you did not vow by mohi but rather, by the God of Israel, I will not attend to your
llm_translation: That one who came before Rav Assi, he said to her: "With what did you make a vow?" She said to him: "By the God of Israel." He said to her: "If you made a vow by 'my waters,' which is a common expression, I will allow it for you. But now that you did not make a vow by 'my waters' but rather by 'the God of Israel,' I will not allow it for you."

hebrew_text: רַב כָּהֲנָא אִיקְּלַע לְבֵי רַב יוֹסֵף, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לִטְעוֹם מָר מִידֵּי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא מָרֵי כּוֹלָּא, לָא טָעֵימְנָא לֵיהּ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא מָרֵי כּוֹלָּא, לָא טָעֲימַתְּ לֵיהּ. הָנִיחָא לְרַב כָּהֲנָא, דְּאָמַר: ״לָא מָרֵי כּוֹלָּא״. אֶלָּא לְרַב יוֹסֵף, אַמַּאי אֲמַר ״לָא מָרֵי כּוֹלָּא״? הָכִי הוּא דְּקָאָמַר לֵיהּ: ״לָא מָרֵי כּוֹלָּא״ הוּא דְּקָאָמְרַתְּ, הִלְכָּךְ לָא טָעֲימַתְּ לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rav Kahana happened to the home of Rav Yosef. said to him: Let the Master eat something. He said to him: No, the Master of all I will not eat it. said to him: No, the Master of all you will not eat it. Rav Kahana’s No, the Master of all well But for Rav Yosef, why did he say: No, the Master of all This is what he said to him: No, the Master of all is what you said; therefore, you may not eat it,
llm_translation: Rav Kahana entered the house of Rav Yosef, he said to him: "To taste master from your hand." He said to him: "My master, I have not tasted at all." He said to him: "My master, I have not tasted from you." Rav Kahana left, saying: "I have not tasted at all." Rather, to Rav Yosef, why did he say "I have not tasted at all"? This is what he meant when he said to him: "I have not tasted at all," that is what you are saying, therefore I have not tasted from you.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: הִלְכְתָא, פּוֹתְחִין בַּחֲרָטָה, וְנִזְקָקִין לֵ״אלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״.
human_translation: Rava said Rav Naḥman said: halakha broach regret, and one attends to the God of Israel
llm_translation: Rava said, Rav Nachman said: The halakha is, we begin with carving, and we make a blessing "to the God of Israel."

hebrew_text: מִשְׁתַּבַּח לֵיהּ רָבָא לְרַב נַחְמָן בְּרַב סְחוֹרָה דְּאָדָם גָּדוֹל הוּא. אָמַר לוֹ: כְּשֶׁיָּבֹא לְיָדְךָ, הֲבִיאֵהוּ לְיָדִי. הֲוָה לֵיהּ נִדְרָא לְמִישְׁרֵא. אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב נַחְמָן.
human_translation: Rava praised Rav Seḥora to Rav Naḥman that he is a great man. said to him: When comes to you, bring him to me. had a vow to dissolve, He came before Rav Naḥman.
llm_translation: Rava praised Rav Nachman son of Rav Sechora, saying: "He is a great man." He said to him: "When it comes into your hand, bring it to me." A vow was upon him to act honestly. He came before Rav Nachman.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נְדַרְתְּ אַדַּעְתָּא דְּהָכִי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִין. אַדַּעְתָּא דְּהָכִי? אִין. כַּמָּה זִימְנִין. אִיקְּפַד רַב נַחְמָן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: זִיל לְקִילְעָךְ.
human_translation: said to him: Did you vow with such in mind? He said to him: Yes, with such a matter in mind, Yes. several times, Rav Naḥman became upset said to him: Go to your tent [ kilakh ]
llm_translation: He said to him: "Have you vowed to know such a thing?" He said to him: "No." "To know such a thing?" "No." How many times? Rav Nachman became angry. He said to him: "Go to your destruction."

hebrew_text: נְפַק רַב סְחוֹרָה וּפְתַח פִּיתְחָא לְנַפְשֵׁיהּ. רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: אֵיזֶה הִיא דֶּרֶךְ יְשָׁרָה שֶׁיָּבוֹר לוֹ הָאָדָם. כֹּל שֶׁהִיא תִּפְאֶרֶת לְעוֹשֶׂיהָ וְתִפְאֶרֶת לוֹ מִן הָאָדָם. וְהַשְׁתָּא דְּאִיקְּפַד רַב נַחְמָן — אַדַּעְתָּא דְּהָכִי לָא נְדַרִי. וּשְׁרָא לְנַפְשֵׁיהּ.
human_translation: Rav Seḥora went out and made opening for himself Rabbi says: What is the proper path that a person should choose? any that a glory to the one who does it and a glory from his fellow men. now that Rav Naḥman became upset he would not have made the vow with knowledge of this and he dissolved for himself.
llm_translation: Rav Sachorah went out and opened a discussion for himself. Rabbi says: What is the straight path that a person should choose for himself? Everything that is praiseworthy for its doer and praiseworthy for him in the eyes of others. And now that Rav Nachman became upset - the knowledge that is not vowed. And he sang for himself.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בְּרַבִּי הֲוָה לֵיהּ נִדְרָא לְמִישְׁרֵא. אֲתָא לְקַמַּיְיהוּ דְּרַבָּנַן, אָמְרִי לֵיהּ: נְדַרְתְּ אַדַּעְתָּא דְּהָכִי? אָמַר: אִין. אַדַּעְתָּא דְּהָכִי? אִין. כַּמָּה זִימְנִין,
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi had a vow to dissolve. He came before the Sages They said to him: Did you vow with the knowledge of this He said: Yes. with the knowledge of this Yes. several times,
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi, had a vow for a straight path. He came before the Sages, they said to him: "Did you have in mind such a thing?" He said: "No." "Did you have in mind such a thing?" "No." How many times...

hebrew_text: וַהֲווֹ מִצְטַעֲרִי רַבָּנַן מִשִּׁימְשָׁא לְטוּלָּא וּמִטּוּלָּא לְשִׁימְשָׁא.
human_translation: and the Sages were troubled from sun to shade, and from shade to sun.
llm_translation: And the rabbis were distressed from using oil for anointing and from anointing for using oil.

hebrew_text: (לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרָא: אַדַּעְתָּא דְּהָכִי? אִין. כַּמָּה זִימְנִין, וַהֲווֹ מִצְטַעֲרִי רַבָּנַן מִשִּׁימְשָׁא לְטוּלָּא וּמִטּוּלָּא לְשִׁימְשָׁא.)
human_translation: another version with knowledge of this Yes. several times and the Sages were troubled from sun to shade and from shade to sun,
llm_translation: Next Mishnah: Do you know this? No. How many times, and the Rabbis were distressed from using for taking and taking for using.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ בָּטְנִית בְּרֵיהּ דְּאַבָּא שָׁאוּל בֶּן בָּטְנִית: מִי נְדַרְתְּ אַדַּעְתָּא דְּמִצְטַעֲרִי רַבָּנַן מִטּוּלָּא לְשִׁימְשָׁא וּמִשִּׁימְשָׁא לְטוּלָּא? אֲמַר: לָא, וְשַׁרְיוּהּ.
human_translation: Botnit, son of Abba Shaul ben Botnit, said to him: Would you have vowed with knowledge that the Sages would be troubled from shade to sun and from sun to shade? He said: No, and they dissolved it.
llm_translation: He said to him, "Batnit, son of Abba Shaul Batnit: Have you vowed that the sages should be pained from using a towel for oil and from using oil for a towel?" He said: "No, and it is permitted."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בַּר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הֲוָה לֵיהּ נִדְרָא לְמִישְׁרֵא. אֲתָא לְקַמַּיְיהוּ דְּרַבָּנַן, אָמְרוּ לֵיהּ: נְדַרְתְּ אַדַּעְתָּא דְּהָכִי? אֲמַר לְהוּ: אִין. נְדַרְתָּא אַדַּעְתָּא דְּהָכִי? אֲמַר לְהוּ: אִין. כַּמָּה זִימְנִין. כֵּיוָן דַּחֲזָא הָהוּא קַצָּרָא דְּמִצְטַעֲרִי רַבָּנַן, מַחְיֵיהּ בְּאוּכְלָא דְקַצָּרֵי. אֲמַר: אַדַּעְתָּא דְּמָחֵי לִי קַצָּרָא לָא נְדַרִי, וְשַׁרְיֵהּ לְנַפְשֵׁיהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yishmael bar Rabbi Yosei had a vow to dissolve. He came before the Sages. They said to him: Did you vow with knowledge of this He said to them: Yes. Did you vow with knowledge of this He said to them: Yes. several times. When a certain launderer saw that the Sages were troubled he hit with a launderer’s tool said: Had I known that launderer would hit me I would not have vowed, and he dissolved it.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael bar Rabbi Yosei had a vow to straighten. He came before the Sages, they said to him: "Did you vow with the knowledge that it was like this?" He said to them: "No." "Did you vow with the knowledge that it was like this?" He said to them: "No." Several times. Once that certain reaper of cucumbers saw that the Sages were distressed, he would keep him alive with the food of cucumbers. He said: "The knowledge that keeps me alive with cucumbers, I did not vow, and he permits it to himself."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַחָא מִדִּיפְתִּי לְרָבִינָא: הַאי נוֹלָד הוּא, דְּלָא מַסֵּיק אַדַּעְתָּא דְּמָחֵי לֵיהּ קַצָּרָא. וּתְנֵינָא: אֵין פּוֹתְחִין לוֹ בַּנּוֹלָד! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הַאי לָאו נוֹלָד הוּא, דִּשְׁכִיחִי אַפִּיקוֹרֵי דִּמְצַעֲרִי רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: This is a new situation, because it would not enter mind that launderer would hit him. And we learned: We do not broach dissolution with using a new situation said to him: This is not a new situation since it is common heretics [ appikurei ] who who trouble the Sages.
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Acha, from Difti to Ravina: This one is a miscarriage, for it does not complete the formation of the head. And we learned: One does not open for it the womb! He said to him: This one is not a miscarriage, for it is common among the heretics to cause the Rabbis distress.

hebrew_text: דְּבֵיתְהוּ דְּאַבָּיֵי הֲוָה לַהּ הָהִיא בְּרַתָּא. הוּא אָמַר: לְקָרִיבַאי. הִיא אָמְרָה: לְקָרִיבַהּ. אֲמַר לַהּ: תִּיתְּסַר הֲנָאָתִי עֲלָךְ אִי עָבְרַתְּ אַדַּעְתַּאי וּמַינְסְּבַת לַהּ לְקָרִיבָךְ. אֲזַלַת וַעֲבַרַת עַל דַּעְתֵּיהּ וְאִינַּסְבָא לְקָרִיבַהּ. אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִילּוּ הֲוָה יָדְעַתְּ דַּעֲבַרַת עַל דַּעְתָּךְ וּמַנְסְבָא לַהּ לְקָרִיבַהּ מִי אַדַּרְתַּהּ? אֲמַר: לָא. וְשַׁרְיֵיהּ רַב יוֹסֵף.
human_translation: The wife of Abaye had a certain daughter. said: to my relative. said to her relative. He said to Benefit from me should be forbidden to you, if you defy my will and marry her to your relative. She went and defied his will and married her to her relative. came before Rav Yosef. said to him: If you had known that she would defy your will and marry her to her relative, would you have made the vow? He said: No. And Rav Yosef dissolved for him
llm_translation: The household of Abaye had a certain daughter. He said: "For my son." She said: "For my son." He said to her: "If I had known that you were acting against my will, and you still persisted in bringing him close, would you have been honored?" She went and acted against his will, and was not honored. She came before Rav Yosef. He said to her: "If you had known that you were acting against his will and still persisted in bringing him close, would you have been honored?" She said: "No." Rav Yosef permitted her.

hebrew_text: וּמִי שְׁרֵי כִּי הַאי גַּוְונָא? אִין, וְהָתַנְיָא: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּאָדָם אֶחָד שֶׁהִדִּיר אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ מִלַּעֲלוֹת לָרֶגֶל, וְעָבְרָה עַל דַּעְתּוֹ וְעָלְתָה לָרֶגֶל, וּבָא לִפְנֵי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי. אָמַר לוֹ: וְאִילּוּ הָיִיתָ יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁעוֹבֶרֶת עַל דַּעְתְּךָ וְעוֹלָה לָרֶגֶל כְּלוּם הִדַּרְתָּהּ? אָמַר לוֹ: לֹא, וְהִתִּירוֹ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי.
human_translation: And is it dissolved in a case like this, Yes, and it is taught an incident involving one man who vowed, his wife to ascend to the pilgrimage Festival, and she defied his will and ascended to the pilgrimage Festival. And he came before Rabbi Yosei said to him: And had you known that she would defy your will and ascend to on the pilgrimage Festival, would you have vowed at all? He said to him: No, and Rabbi Yosei dissolved it.
llm_translation: And who is permitted that this case? No, and it was taught: There was an incident with a certain man who prohibited his wife from ascending to the foot, and she transgressed his directive and ascended to the foot, and he came before Rabbi Yosei. He said to him: If you had known that she was transgressing your directive and ascending to the foot, would you have permitted her? He said to him: No, and Rabbi Yosei permitted him.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: אַף הָרוֹצֶה לְהַדִּיר אֶת חֲבֵירוֹ שֶׁיֹּאכַל אֶצְלוֹ, יֹאמַר לוֹ: ״כׇּל נֶדֶר שֶׁאֲנִי עָתִיד לִידּוֹר הוּא בָּטֵל״, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁיְּהֵא זָכוּר בִּשְׁעַת הַנֶּדֶר.
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: Even one who wants to take a vow another that he should eat with him, should say to him Any vow that I take in the future is void. And provided that he remembers at the time of the vow
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: Even one who wishes to invite his fellow to eat at his home should say to him: "Every vow that I may make in the future is nullified," provided that he remembers this at the time of making the vow.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ וְכֵיוָן דְּאָמַר ״כׇּל נֶדֶר שֶׁאֲנִי עָתִיד לִידּוֹר יְהֵא בָּטֵל״, לָא שָׁמַע לֵיהּ וְלָא אָתֵי בַּהֲדֵיהּ?
human_translation: And since he said: Any vow that I take in the future should be void, will not listen to him and will not come with him,
llm_translation: Gemara: Since he said, "Any vow that I may make in the future shall be null," he did not pay attention to it, and it did not come into effect with him?

hebrew_text: חַסּוֹרֵי מִיחַסְּרָא וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: הָרוֹצֶה שֶׁיֹּאכַל אֶצְלוֹ חֲבֵירוֹ וּמְסָרֵב בּוֹ וּמַדִּירוֹ — נִדְרֵי זֵירוּזִין הוּא. וְהָרוֹצֶה שֶׁלֹּא יִתְקַיְּימוּ נְדָרָיו כׇּל הַשָּׁנָה, יַעֲמוֹד בְּרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וְיֹאמַר: כׇּל נֶדֶר שֶׁאֲנִי עָתִיד לִידּוֹר יְהֵא בָּטֵל, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁיְּהֵא זָכוּר בִּשְׁעַת הַנֶּדֶר.
human_translation: is incomplete and is teaching like this: one who wants another to eat with him, and he urges him and makes a vow with regard to him, this is vows of exhortation, And one who desires his vows not be upheld the entire year should stand up on Rosh HaShana and say: Any vow that I take in the future should be void. And provided that he remembers at the time of the vow
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Those who are lacking from the festival, and thus it is taught: One who desires to eat with his fellow and he refuses him and excommunicates him - these are vows of abstinence. And one who wishes that his vows not be upheld throughout the year, he shall stand at the head of the year and say: Every vow that I am destined to make shall be null, provided that it is remembered at the time of the vow."

hebrew_text: אִי זָכוּר, עַקְרֵיהּ לִתְנָאֵיהּ, וְקַיֵּים לֵיהּ לְנִדְרֵיהּ! אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, תָּנֵי: וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא זָכוּר בִּשְׁעַת הַנֶּדֶר.
human_translation: If he remembers he has uprooted his stipulation and has upheld his vow. Abaye said: Teach: And provided that he does not remember at the time of the vow
llm_translation: If he remembered, his vows are nullified, and he fulfills his vows! Abaye said, it was taught: "And only if it is not remembered at the time of the vow."

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם כִּדְאָמְרִינַן מֵעִיקָּרָא. הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — כְּגוֹן שֶׁהִתְנָה בְּרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה, וְלֹא יָדַע בַּמֶּה הִתְנָה. וְהַשְׁתָּא קָא נָדַר. אִי זָכוּר בִּשְׁעַת הַנֶּדֶר, וְאָמַר ״עַל דַּעַת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה אֲנִי נוֹדֵר״ — נִדְרֵיהּ לֵית בֵּיהּ מַמָּשָׁא. לֹא אָמַר ״עַל דַּעַת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה אֲנִי נוֹדֵר״ — עַקְרֵיהּ לִתְנָאֵיהּ וְקַיֵּים לְנִדְרֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rava said: Actually, as we said initially, With what are we dealing here? where he stipulated on Rosh HaShana but he did not know with regard to which he made the stipulation, and now he makes a vow. If he remembers at the time of the vow and says: I am vowing in accordance with the initial intention, his vow has no substance. he did not say: I am vowing in accordance with the initial intention, he has uprooted his stipulation and upheld his vow.
llm_translation: Rava said: Always as we say initially. Here, what are we dealing with? For example, one who made a condition on Rosh Hashanah, and did not know what he conditioned. And now he is making a vow. If he remembered at the time of the vow and said, "I am vowing based on the original condition," his vows are not considered actual vows. If he did not say, "I am vowing based on the original condition," his vows are uprooted and his vows are fulfilled.

hebrew_text: רַב הוּנָא בַּר חִינָּנָא סָבַר לְמִידְרְשֵׁיהּ בְּפִירְקָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: תַּנָּא קָא מְסַתֵּים לַהּ סַתּוֹמֵי כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יִנְהֲגוּ קַלּוּת רֹאשׁ בִּנְדָרִים, וְאַתְּ דָּרְשַׁתְּ לֵיהּ בְּפִירְקָא?!
human_translation: Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana intended to teach at lecture, Rava said to him: tanna conceals it in order that not treat vows lightly, and you teach it at lecture?
llm_translation: Rav Huna son of Chinena thought to expound in his lecture. Rava said to him: A Mishna is concluding for him the anonymous statements so that people will not act frivolously with vows, and you are expounding to him in a lecture?!

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: פְּלִיגִי רַבָּנַן עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב, אוֹ לָא? וְאִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר פְּלִיגִי, הִלְכְתָא כְּוָתֵיהּ, אוֹ לָא? תָּא שְׁמַע, דִּתְנַן: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov or not? And if you say they disagree the halakha in accordance with his or not? Come hear, as we learned One who says to another:
llm_translation: He asked them: Do the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov regarding this matter, or not? And if you find that they do disagree, does the halakha follow his opinion, or not? Come and hear, as we learned: One who says to his fellow...

hebrew_text: ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֵינִי נֶהֱנֶה לְךָ אִם אִי אַתָּה נוֹטֵל לְבִנְךָ כּוֹר שֶׁל חִיטִּין וּשְׁתֵּי חָבִיּוֹת שֶׁל יַיִן״, הֲרֵי זֶה יָכוֹל לְהַתִּיר אֶת נִדְרוֹ שֶׁלֹּא עַל פִּי חָכָם, שֶׁיָּכוֹל לוֹמַר לוֹ: כְּלוּם אָמַרְתָּ אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל כְּבוֹדִי — זֶה הוּא כְּבוֹדִי.
human_translation: Benefiting from you is konam for me if you do not take for your son a kor of wheat and two barrels of wine this can dissolve his vow without a halakhic authority. because can say to you say any other than due to my honor, This is my honor,
llm_translation: "Kunnam that I do not benefit you if you do not take for your son a beam of wheat and two barrels of wine," he can permit his vow not in accordance with the opinion of a sage, for he can say to him: 'You only said it for my honor' - this is my honor."

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר ״זֶה הוּא כְּבוֹדִי״, הָא לָאו הָכִי — נֶדֶר הוּא. מַנִּי? אִי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב — נִדְרֵי זֵירוּזִין הָוֵי. אֶלָּא שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: פְּלִיגִי רַבָּנַן עֲלֵיהּ.
human_translation: The reason because said: This is my honor. But not so, it is a vow. Whose If Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, it is vows of exhortation Rather, conclude from Rabbis disagree with him
llm_translation: The reason for saying "This is my glory," if not so - it is a vow. Who said this? If Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov - it is vows of abstinence. Rather, learn from it: the Rabbis disagree with him.

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב הִיא, וּמוֹדֶה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב בְּהַאי דְּנִדְרָא הָוֵי, דְּאָמַר לֵיהּ: לָא כַּלְבָּא אֲנָא, דְּמִיתְהֲנֵינָא מִינָּךְ וְלָא מִיתְהֲנֵית מִינַּאי.
human_translation: Actually, it is Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, but Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov concedes in this that it is a vow because said to him: I am not a dog, that I benefit from you and you do not benefit from me.
llm_translation: Forever Rabbi Eliezer son of Jacob she, and admits Rabbi Eliezer son of Jacob in this of vow is, for said to him: "Not a dog I, that I benefit from you and you do not benefit from me."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאַתָּה נֶהֱנֵית לִי אִם אִי אַתָּה נוֹתֵן לִבְנִי כּוֹר שֶׁל חִיטִּין וּשְׁתֵּי חָבִיּוֹת שֶׁל יַיִן״, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: עַד שֶׁיִּתֵּן. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אַף זֶה יָכוֹל לְהַתִּיר אֶת נִדְרוֹ שֶׁלֹּא עַל פִּי חָכָם, שֶׁיָּכוֹל לוֹמַר: הֲרֵינִי כְּאִילּוּ הִתְקַבַּלְתִּי.
human_translation: Come hear one who says to another: Benefiting from me is konam for you if you do not give my son a kor of wheat and two barrels of wine, Rabbi Meir says: until he gives And the Rabbis say: Even this can dissolve his vow without a halakhic authority, as he can say: I hereby as though I received
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who says to his fellow, "Be a guarantor for me that you will benefit me; if not, you shall give my son a kor of wheat and two barrels of wine," Rabbi Meir says: Until he gives. And the Sages say: This too can permit his vow without the permission of a sage, for he can say: "Behold, it is as if I have been accepted."

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי כְּאִילּוּ הִתְקַבַּלְתִּי״, הָא לָאו הָכִי — נֶדֶר הוּא. מַנִּי? אִי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב — נִדְרֵי זֵירוּזִין הָוֵי, אֶלָּא לָאו: רַבָּנַן, וּפְלִיגִי!
human_translation: The reason because he said: I hereby as though I received it But not so, it would be a vow. Whose If Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, it is vows of exhortation. Rather, is it not the Rabbis, and disagree
llm_translation: Reason for saying "as if I have been accepted", this is not so - it is a vow. Who is the authority? If it is Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov - it is considered vows of fastidiousness. Rather, it is the sages, and they disagree!

hebrew_text: לָא, לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב, וּמוֹדֶה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בְּהַאי דְּנִדְרָא הָוֵי, מִשּׁוּם דְּאָמַר לֵיהּ: לָאו מַלְכָּא אֲנָא, דִּמְהַנֵּינָא לָךְ וְאַתְּ לָא מְהַנֵּית לִי.
human_translation: No, actually Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov. And Rabbi Eliezer concedes in this that it is a vow because says to him: I am not a king that I benefit to you and you do not benefit to me.
llm_translation: Not, always Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov, and admits Rabbi Eliezer in this vow is, because he said to him: "I am not a king, that we benefit you and you do not benefit me."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ מָר קַשִּׁישָׁא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב חִסְדָּא לְרַב אָשֵׁי, תָּא שְׁמַע: נִדְרֵי אוֹנָסִין, הִדִּירוֹ חֲבֵירוֹ שֶׁיֹּאכַל אֶצְלוֹ, וְחָלָה הוּא אוֹ חָלָה בְּנוֹ אוֹ שֶׁעִכְּבוֹ נָהָר. הָא לָאו הָכִי — נֶדֶר הוּא. מַנִּי? אִי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב — זֵירוּזִין הָוֵי. אֶלָּא לָאו: רַבָּנַן, וּפְלִיגִי!
human_translation: Mar Kashisha, son of Rav Ḥisda, said to Rav Ashi: Come hear vows circumstances beyond control, one’s friend took a vow with regard to him that he should eat with him, and he became sick, or his son became sick, or a river barred him if not this it would be a vow. Whose If Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, they are exhortation Rather, is it not the Rabbis, and disagree
llm_translation: He said to him, Master Kashisha, son of Rav Chisda, to Rav Ashe: Come and hear: Vows of compulsion, if his fellow vowed for him to eat with him, and he became ill, or his son became ill, or his river dried up. Is it not so — it is a vow. Who is the authority? If it is Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov — it is a precaution. Rather, is it not so: the Rabbis, and they disagree!

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב, וּמִי סָבְרַתְּ דְּאַדְּרֵיהּ מְזַמְּנָא לִזְמִינָא? לָא, דִּזְמִינָא אַדְּרֵיהּ לִמְזַמְּנָא. דַּאֲמַר לֵיהּ מְזַמְּנַתְּ לִי לִסְעוֹדְתָּיךְ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִין. נֶדֶר זֶה עָלֶיךָ? וְנָדַר. וְחָלָה הוּא אוֹ שֶׁחָלָה בְּנוֹ אוֹ שֶׁעִכְּבוֹ נָהָר — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ נִדְרֵי אוֹנָסִין.
human_translation: Actually, Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov. But do you hold that the host took a vow with regard to the guest? No, where the guest caused a vow by the host said to him: Do you invite me to your meal? said to him: Yes. Is this vow upon you, and he vowed, and he became sick, or his son became sick, or a river barred him these are vows circumstances beyond control.
llm_translation: Forever Rabbi Eliezer son of Jacob, and who thinks that he honors the inviter to invite? No, that the inviter should honor the invitee. For he said to him, "Do you invite me to your meal?" He said to him, "No." "Is this vow upon you?" "And he vowed." And if he or his son fell ill, or if a river blocked his way - these are vows made under duress.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: יָתֵר עַל כֵּן, אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֲנִי נֶהֱנֶה לָךְ אִם אִי אַתָּה מִתְאָרֵחַ אֶצְלִי וְתֹאכַל עִמִּי פַּת חַמָּה וְתִשְׁתֶּה עִמִּי כּוֹס חַמִּין״, וְהַלָּה הִקְפִּיד כְּנֶגְדּוֹ — אַף אֵלּוּ נִדְרֵי זֵירוּזִין. וְלֹא הוֹדוּ לוֹ חֲכָמִים. מַאי ״לֹא הוֹדוּ לוֹ חֲכָמִים״? לָאו
human_translation: Come hear Further Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov said: one who says to his friend: Benefiting from you is konam for me if you do not lodge with me, and eat hot bread with me, and drink a cup hot with me, and the other becomes irritated at him these are also vows of exhortation. But the Rabbis did not concede to him What The Rabbis did not concede to him? Does it not
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Come and hear: Moreover, Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov said: One who says to his fellow, 'I have a special dish that I will benefit you with if you do not dine with me, and you eat with me hot bread and drink with me a cup of hot wine,' and the other insists against him - these are also vows of abstention. And the sages did not acknowledge him. What does 'the sages did not acknowledge him' mean? No."

hebrew_text: דַּאֲפִילּוּ בְּקַמַּיְיתָא, וּשְׁמַע מִינַּהּ פְּלִיגִי רַבָּנַן עֲלֵיהּ. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: that even in the earlier and conclude from the Rabbis disagree with him? Conclude from
llm_translation: Even in the town of Kamayta, and hear from it the Rabbis argue about it. Hear from it.

hebrew_text: מַאי הָוֵי עֲלַהּ? תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רַב הוּנָא: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב, וְכֵן אָמַר רַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב.
human_translation: What was about Come hear which Rav Huna said: halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov. And so said Rav Adda bar Ahava: halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov.
llm_translation: What is the ruling? Come and hear, as Rav Huna said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov, and so too said Rav Adda bar Ahava: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ נִדְרֵי הֲבַאי, אָמַר: ״קֻוֽנָּם אִם לֹא רָאִיתִי בַּדֶּרֶךְ הַזֶּה כְּעוֹלֵי מִצְרַיִם״, ״אִם לֹא רָאִיתִי נָחָשׁ כְּקוֹרַת בֵּית הַבַּד״.
human_translation: Vows of exaggeration one said konam if I did not see on this road as those who ascended Egypt, if I did not see a snake as beam of an olive press,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: Vows made by travelers. He said: "May it be established if I did not see on this road like the ascent of Egypt." "If I did not see a snake like a beam of a house."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנָא: נִדְרֵי הֲבַאי — מוּתָּרִין, שָׁבוּעוֹת הֲבַאי — אֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: A Sage taught: vows of exaggeration [ havai ] are permitted; oaths of exaggeration are forbidden.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara: Tanah: Nidrei havai - mutarin, shavuot havai - asurin." English translation: "Gemara: It was taught: Vows of the heathens - permitted, oaths of the heathens - prohibited."

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָּמֵי שָׁבוּעוֹת הֲבַאי? אִילֵימָא דְּאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה אִם לֹא רָאִיתִי בַּדֶּרֶךְ הַזֶּה״ — מִידַּעַם קָאָמַר?!
human_translation: What are the circumstances oaths of exaggeration? If we say that said: an oath if I did not see on this road is he saying anything?
llm_translation: "How are the laws of oaths brought about? Perhaps you will say, 'If I have not seen a week on this road' - is this what the verse is teaching?!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: דְּאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁרָאִיתִי״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: אִם כֵּן לְמָה לִי לְמֵימַר? וְעוֹד: דּוּמְיָא דְּנֶדֶר קָתָנֵי! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא, בְּאוֹמֵר: ״יֵאָסְרוּ פֵּירוֹת הָעוֹלָם עָלַי בִּשְׁבוּעָה אִם לֹא רָאִיתִי בַּדֶּרֶךְ הַזֶּה כְּעוֹלֵי מִצְרַיִם״.
human_translation: Abaye said that where one says: an oath that I saw Rava said to him: If so, why do I to say And furthermore, teaches similar to a vow: Rather, Rava said: where he says: produce of the world shall be forbidden to me by an oath if I did not see on this road as those ascended Egypt.
llm_translation: Abaye said: For he said, "an oath that I have seen." Rava said to him: If so, why do I need to say? Furthermore, it is similar to a vow that is being taught! Rather, Rava said, by saying: "I will forbid the fruits of the world upon myself with an oath if I have not seen on this road like the ascenders of Egypt."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: וְדִלְמָא הַאי גַּבְרָא קִינָּא דְשׁוּמְשְׁמָנֵי חֲזָא וְאַסֵּיק לְהוֹן שְׁמָא ״עוֹלֵי מִצְרַיִם״, וְשַׁפִּיר מִשְׁתְּבַע?
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: And perhaps this man saw an anthill and called them: who ascended Egypt, and he took an oath properly.
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Perhaps this man, the zealot of the followers of Shimon, saw them and called them "the ascenders of Egypt," and it is fitting?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כִּי מִשְׁתְּבַע — אַדַּעְתָּא דִידַן מִשְׁתְּבַע, וַאֲנַן לָא מַסְּקִינַן נַפְשִׁין אַשּׁוּמְשְׁמָנֵי.
human_translation: said to him: When he takes an oath, he takes an oath based on our understanding, and we do not entertain in our mind referring to ants [ shumshemanei ].
llm_translation: He said to him: "When he swears - our knowledge swears, but we do not rely on the fat of the tails."

hebrew_text: וְעַל דַּעְתָּא דְנַפְשֵׁיהּ לָא עֲבִיד אִינִישׁ דְּמִשְׁתְּבַע? וְהָתַנְיָא: כְּשֶׁהֵן מַשְׁבִּיעִין אוֹתוֹ, אוֹמְרִים לוֹ: הֱוֵי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁלֹּא עַל תְּנַאי שֶׁבְּלִבְּךָ אָנוּ מַשְׁבִּיעִין אוֹתְךָ, אֶלָּא עַל דַּעְתֵּינוּ וְעַל דַּעַת בֵּית דִּין. לְאַפּוֹקֵי מַאי? לָאו לְאַפּוֹקֵי דְּאַסֵּיק לְהוּ לְאִיסְקוּנְדְּרֵי וְאַסֵּיק לְהוֹן שְׁמָא זוּזֵי.
human_translation: And does a person not take an oath according to his own understanding? But isn’t it taught When administer an oath they say to him: Know that we do not administer an oath to you based on a stipulation in your heart, Rather, based on our understanding and on the understanding of the court. What does to exclude? Does it not to exclude where one gave tokens [ iskundarei ] and he gives them title coins
llm_translation: And according to the opinion of his own soul, does a person not act as he desires? And it was taught: When they satisfy him, they say to him: Know that we are not satisfying you on our own terms that are in your heart, but on our own knowledge and the knowledge of the court. To what is this comparable? It is not comparable to one who is forced to go to the innkeeper and is forced to pay him money.

hebrew_text: וּמִדְּקָאָמַר ״עַל דַּעְתֵּינוּ״, מִכְּלָל דַּעֲבִיד אִינָשׁ דְּמִשְׁתְּבַע אַדַּעְתָּא דְנַפְשֵׁיהּ!
human_translation: And since says According to our understanding, by inference that a person commonly takes an oath according to his own understanding
llm_translation: And from where it says "on our own accord," it can be inferred that a person does what he pleases with his own mind!

hebrew_text: לָא, לְאַפּוֹקֵי מִקַּנְיָא דְרָבָא. דְּהָהוּא גַּבְרָא דַּהֲוָה מַסֵּיק בְּחַבְרֵיהּ זוּזֵי, אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ לְלֹוֶה: זִיל פְּרַע לִי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: פְּרַעְתִּיךָ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: אִם כֵּן, זִיל אִישְׁתְּבַע לֵיהּ דִּפְרַעְתֵּיהּ.
human_translation: No, to exclude that cane of Rava, as a certain man who claimed money from another. He came before Rava said to the borrower: Go repay me said to him: I repaid you. Rava said to him: If so, go take an oath to him that you repaid him.
llm_translation: Not to the owners of Rava's cattle. For that man who was collecting debts from his companions, came before Rava. He said to the lender: "Release me." He said to him: "I have released you." Rava said to him: "If so, go and demand from him the debt that I have released."

hebrew_text: אֲזַל וְאַיְיתִי קַנְיָא, וְיָהֵיב זוּזֵי בְּגַוֵּיהּ, וַהֲוָה מִסְתְּמִיךְ וְאָזֵיל וְאָתֵי עֲלֵיהּ לְבֵי דִּינָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ לְמַלְוֶה: נְקוֹט הַאי קַנְיָא בִּידָךְ. נְסַב סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה וְאִישְׁתְּבַע דְּפַרְעֵיהּ כֹּל מָה דַּהֲוָה לֵיהּ בִּידֵיהּ.
human_translation: went and brought cane, and placed money inside it, and was leaning upon it, and went upon it to the court. He said to the lender: Hold this cane in your hand took the Torah scroll and swore that he had repaid entire that had been in his possession.
llm_translation: He went and brought a reed, and gave it to the debtor, and he was appeased. He then went and came to the court. The lender said to him: "Take this reed in your hand." He took a Torah scroll and claimed all that was due to him with it.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא מַלְוֶה רְגַז וְתַבְרֵהּ לְהָהוּא קַנְיָא, וְאִישְׁתְּפֻךְ הָנְהוּ זוּזֵי לְאַרְעָא, וְאִישְׁתְּכַח דְּקוּשְׁטָא אִישְׁתְּבַע.
human_translation: That creditor became angry and broke that cane, and those coins fell to the ground. And it turned out that he had taken the oath in truth,
llm_translation: That one lent a regaz and tavreh to that one kanya, and the coins fell to the ground, and he found a purse and claimed it.

hebrew_text: וְאַכַּתִּי לָא עֲבִיד דְּמִישְׁתְּבַע אַדַּעְתָּא דְנַפְשֵׁיהּ? וְהָתַנְיָא: וְכֵן מָצִינוּ בְּמֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ כְּשֶׁהִשְׁבִּיעַ אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּעַרְבוֹת מוֹאָב, אָמַר לָהֶם: הֱווּ יוֹדְעִים שֶׁלֹּא עַל דַּעְתְּכֶם אֲנִי מַשְׁבִּיעַ אֶתְכֶם, אֶלָּא עַל דַּעְתִּי וְעַל דַּעַת הַמָּקוֹם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא אִתְּכֶם לְבַדְּכֶם וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: And still, does not commonly take an oath according to his own understanding? But isn’t it taught And so we found with regard to Moses our teacher. When he administered an oath to the Jewish people in the plains of Moab, he said to them: Know that I do not administer an oath upon you according to your understanding but according to my understanding and the understanding of the Omnipresent, as it is stated: “Neither with you only
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And is it not so that he does not do according to the will of his own soul? And it was taught: And so we find with Moses our teacher, when he adjured Israel in the plains of Moab, he said to them: Know that not by your own will am I adjuring you, but by my will and the will of the Omnipresent, as it is stated: "Not with you alone, etc."

hebrew_text: ״מַאי אֲמַר לְהוּ מֹשֶׁה לְיִשְׂרָאֵל? לָאו הָכִי קָאָמַר לְהוּ: דִּלְמָא עָבֵידְתּוּן מִילֵּי, וְאָמְרִיתוּן: עַל דַּעְתֵּינוּ — מִשּׁוּם הָכִי אֲמַר לְהוּ: עַל דַּעְתִּי. לְאַפּוֹקֵי מַאי? לָאו לְאַפּוֹקֵי דְּאַסִּיקוּ שְׁמָא לַעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה אֱלוֹהַּ. מִכְּלָל דַּעֲבִיד אִינִישׁ דְּמִשְׁתְּבַע אַדַּעְתָּא דְנַפְשֵׁיהּ!
human_translation: What did Moses say to Israel? Isn’t this what he said to them: Perhaps you will perform actions, and say: according to our understanding. Due to that he said to them: according to my understanding. What to exclude? Does it not to exclude that they give the title God, to idol worship by inference a person commonly takes an oath according to his own understanding.
llm_translation: "What did Moses say to the Israelites? Was it not this that he said to them: Perhaps you will do things on your own and say, 'It is by our own understanding' — therefore he said to them: 'By my own understanding.' To what does this come to exclude? It does not come to exclude that they should think that they are fit for idol worship. For it is a general principle that a person should always make his mind subservient to himself!"

hebrew_text: לָא, עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה אִיקְּרִי אֱלוֹהַּ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וּבְכָל אֱלֹהֵי מִצְרַיִם וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: No, idol worship is called: God, as it is written: “And against all the gods of Egypt
llm_translation: Not, foreign worship called god, as it is written: "And against all the gods of Egypt, etc."

hebrew_text: וְלַשְׁבַּע יָתְהוֹן דִּמְקַיְּימִיתוּן מִצְוֹת! מַשְׁמַע מִצְוֹת הַמֶּלֶךְ.
human_translation: And Let him administer an oath to them That you will fulfill the mitzvot, indicate commandments of the king,
llm_translation: And for the seven, they were established with commandments! Understand commandments of the king.

hebrew_text: וְלַשְׁבַּע יָתְהוֹן דִּמְקַיְּימִיתוּן כֹּל מִצְוֹת! מַשְׁמַע מִצְוַת צִיצִית, דְּאָמַר מָר: שְׁקוּלָה מִצְוַת צִיצִית כְּנֶגֶד כׇּל מִצְוֹת שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה.
human_translation: And let him administer an oath to them That you will fulfill all mitzvot. indicate the mitzva of ritual fringes, as the Master said: The mitzva of ritual fringes is equivalent to all the mitzvot in the Torah.
llm_translation: And for the seven, they are equivalent to all the commandments! Learn the commandment of tzitzit, as the Master said: "The commandment of tzitzit is equivalent to all the commandments of the Torah."

hebrew_text: וְלַשְׁבַּע יָתְהוֹן דִּמְקַיְּימִיתוּן תּוֹרָה! מַשְׁמַע: תּוֹרָה אַחַת. וְלַשְׁבַּע יָתְהוֹן דִּמְקַיְּימִיתוּן תּוֹרוֹת! מַשְׁמַע: תּוֹרַת מִנְחָה, תּוֹרַת חַטָּאת, תּוֹרַת אָשָׁם. וְלַשְׁבַּע יָתְהוֹן דִּמְקַיְּימִיתוּן [תּוֹרוֹת] וּמִצְוֹת! [תּוֹרוֹת] מַשְׁמַע: תּוֹרַת הַמִּנְחָה. מִצְוֹת, מַשְׁמַע: מִצְוֹת הַמֶּלֶךְ.
human_translation: And let him administer an oath to them: That you fulfill the Torah. indicates one Torah, And let him administer an oath: That you fulfill the Torahs, indicates the Torah of the meal-offering, the Torah of the sin-offering, the Torah of the guilt-offering. And let him administer an oath: That you fulfill the Torahs and mitzvot. Torahs indicate the Torah of the meal-offering, mitzvot indicate the commandments of the king.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And for seven they were established Torah! Understand: one Torah. And for seven they were established Torahs! Understand: the Torah of the meal offering, the Torah of the sin offering, the Torah of the guilt offering. And for seven they were established Torahs and commandments! Torahs Understand: the Torah of the meal offering. Commandments, understand: the commandments of the king.

hebrew_text: וְלַישְׁבַּע יָתְהוֹן דִּמְקַיְּימִיתוּן תּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ! תּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ, מַשְׁמַע: עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה. דְּתַנְיָא: חֲמוּרָה עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה, שֶׁכׇּל הַכּוֹפֵר בָּהּ — כְּאִילּוּ מוֹדֶה בַּתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ.
human_translation: And let him administer an oath: That you fulfill the entire Torah. the entire Torah indicate idol worship, as it is taught Idol worship is so severe that anyone who denies it is as though he concedes to the entire Torah.
llm_translation: And to swear they were established the entire Torah! The entire Torah, implies: idolatry. As it was taught: Severe is idolatry, for anyone who denies it — as if he admits to the entire Torah.

hebrew_text: וְלַישְׁבַּע יָתְהוֹן דִּמְקַיְּימִיתוּן עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה וְתוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ, אִי נָמֵי: שֵׁשׁ מֵאוֹת וּשְׁלֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה מִצְוֹת! אֶלָּא, מֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ מִילְּתָא דְּלָא טְרִיחָא נְקַט.
human_translation: And let him administer an oath: That you fulfill idol worship and the entire Torah. Or, alternatively, six hundred thirteen mitzvot, Rather, Moses our teacher used an expression that was not troublesome
llm_translation: And to the seven, they were sitting, that they fulfilled foreign worship and the entire Torah, meaning: six hundred and thirteen commandments! Rather, our teacher Moses took care of a matter that was not necessary.

hebrew_text: אִם לֹא רָאִיתִי נָחָשׁ כְּקוֹרַת בֵּית הַבַּד, וְלָא? וְהָא הָהוּא חִוְיָא דַּהֲוָה בִּשְׁנֵי שַׁבּוּר מַלְכָּא, רְמוֹ לֵיהּ תְּלֵיסַר אוּרָווֹתָא דְתִיבְנָא וּבְלַע יָתְהוֹן! אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: בְּטָרוּף, כּוּלְּהוּ נַחֲשֵׁי מִיטְרָף טְרִפִי! אַגַּבּוֹ טָרוּף קָאָמְרִינַן.
human_translation: If I did not see a snake as the beam of an olive press, And not But a certain snake that lived in the days of King Shapur they threw thirteen bundles of straw and it swallowed them, Shmuel said: that is notched, all snakes have notches We are saying that it is notched on its back,
llm_translation: If I did not see a snake as thick as the beam of a house, would I not? But there was that snake in the palace of the king, he swallowed twelve cedar beams that were there! Shmuel said: By tearing, all the snakes are torn to pieces! Regarding tearing, we say.

hebrew_text: וְלִתְנֵי ״טָרוּף״? מִילְּתָא אַגַּב אוֹרְחֵיהּ קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן, דְּקוֹרַת בֵּית הַבַּד גַּבּוֹ טָרוּף. לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? לְמִקָּח וּמִמְכָּר, לוֹמַר לָךְ: הַמּוֹכֵר קוֹרַת בֵּית הַבַּד לַחֲבֵירוֹ, אִי גַּבּוֹ טָרוּף — אִין, וְאִי לָא — לָא.
human_translation: And let teach notched; He teaches us a matter in passing, that the back of the beam of an olive press notched. What is the difference For buying and selling, to tell you one who sells the beam of an olive press to another, if its back is notched yes, and if not not
llm_translation: And to teach "taruf"? The matter because of its path is implied to us, that the wall of the house collapsed, it is taruf. What is derived from it? For buying and selling, to say to you: the seller of the wall of the house to his friend, if it is taruf - no, and if not - yes.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ נִדְרֵי שְׁגָגוֹת — ״אִם אָכַלְתִּי וְאִם שָׁתִיתִי״, וְנִזְכַּר שֶׁאָכַל וְשָׁתָה. ״שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹכֵל וְשֶׁאֲנִי שׁוֹתֶה״, וְשָׁכַח וְאָכַל וְשָׁתָה. אָמַר: ״קֻוֽנָּם אִשְׁתִּי נֶהֱנֵית לִי שֶׁגָּנְבָה אֶת כִּיסִי, וְשֶׁהִכְּתָה אֶת בְּנִי״, וְנוֹדַע שֶׁלֹּא הִכַּתּוּ, וְנוֹדַע שֶׁלֹּא גָּנְבָה.
human_translation: vows that are unintentional if I ate or if I drank, and he remembers that he ate or drank. I eat or I drink, and he forgets and eats or drinks. one said: Benefiting from me is konam for my wife because she stole my purse or she hit my son, and it became known that she had not hit him or it became known that she had not stolen.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "Vows of inadvertence - 'if I ate and if I drank,' and he remembered that he ate and drank. 'That I will eat and that I will drink,' and he forgot and ate and drank. He said: 'Their cup is forbidden to me, for she stole my purse, and she struck my son,' and it became known that they did not strike him, and it became known that she did not steal."

hebrew_text: רָאָה אוֹתָן אוֹכְלִין תְּאֵנִים, וְאָמַר: ״הֲרֵי עֲלֵיכֶם קׇרְבָּן״, וְנִמְצְאוּ אָבִיו וְאָחִיו וְהָיוּ עִמָּהֶן אֲחֵרִים. בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: הֵן מוּתָּרִים, וּמַה שֶּׁעִמָּהֶם — אֲסוּרִים. וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: אֵלּוּ וָאֵלּוּ מוּתָּרִין.
human_translation: One saw eating figs, and he said: to you an offering. And it was found his father and brother and there were others with them Beit Shammai says: They, are permitted and those that were with them are prohibited And Beit Hillel says: these and those are permitted
llm_translation: He saw them eating figs, and he said: "Behold, upon you is an offering," and his father and brother were found with them, and there were others with them. Beit Shammai says: They are permitted, but what is with them is forbidden. And Beit Hillel says: Both these and those are permitted.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנָא: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁנִּדְרֵי שְׁגָגוֹת מוּתָּרִין, כָּךְ שְׁבוּעוֹת שְׁגָגוֹת מוּתָּרוֹת. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי שְׁבוּעוֹת שְׁגָגוֹת? כְּגוֹן רַב כָּהֲנָא וְרַב אַסִּי, הָדֵין אָמַר: שְׁבוּעֲתָא דְּהָכִי אָמַר רַב, וְהָדֵין אָמַר: שְׁבוּעֲתָא דְּהָכִי אָמַר רַב. דְּכֹל חַד וְחַד אַדַּעְתָּא דְנַפְשֵׁיהּ שַׁפִּיר קָמִישְׁתְּבַע.
human_translation: The Sages taught: Just as vows that are unintentional are dissolved, so too, oaths that are unintentional are dissolved. What are the circumstances unintentional oaths? For example, Rav Kahana and Rav Asi, this said: an oath that Rav said this And that said: an oath that Rav said this as each one took an oath properly in his own mind
llm_translation: Talmudic text: A certain Tanna taught: Just as vows made in error are permitted, so too oaths made in error are permitted. How are the oaths made in error similar? For example, Rav Kahana and Rav Asi, each one said: The oath that Rav made was like this, and the other said: The oath that Rav made was like this. Each one knew his own reasoning and it was well explained.

hebrew_text: רָאָה אוֹתָן אוֹכְלִין. תְּנַן הָתָם: פּוֹתְחִין בְּשַׁבָּתוֹת וּבְיָמִים טוֹבִים. בָּרִאשׁוֹנָה הָיוּ אוֹמְרִים: אוֹתָן הַיָּמִים — מוּתָּרִים, וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הַיָּמִים — אֲסוּרִים, עַד שֶׁבָּא רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְלִימֵּד: נֶדֶר שֶׁהוּתַּר מִקְצָתוֹ הוּתַּר כֻּלּוֹ.
human_translation: One saw them eating, we learned there is broached based on Shabbatot and based on Festivals, Initially, they used to say: those days, permitted and all other days prohibited until Rabbi Akiva came and taught: A vow that was partially dissolved is dissolved completely.
llm_translation: He saw them eating. We learned there: One may open on Sabbaths and festivals. Initially, they used to say: those days - permitted, and all other days - forbidden, until Rabbi Akiva came and taught: a vow that was partially permitted, is entirely permitted.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא, כֹּל הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר: אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁאַבָּא בֵּינֵיכֶם, הָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר ״כּוּלְּכֶם אֲסוּרִין חוּץ מֵאַבָּא״, דְּכוּלְּהוֹן אֲסוּרִין וְאָבִיו מוּתָּר. לֹא נֶחְלְקוּ אֶלָּא בְּאוֹמֵר: אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁאַבָּא בֵּינֵיכֶם, הָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר: ״פְּלוֹנִי וּפְלוֹנִי אֲסוּרִין וְאַבָּא מוּתָּר״.
human_translation: Rabba said: Everyone wherever says: Had I known that father among you I would have said: All of you are prohibited except for father, then all are prohibited and his father permitted They disagreed only where one said: Had I known that father among you then I would have said: So-and-so and so-and-so, are prohibited and father is permitted
llm_translation: Rabba said: In all the world, wherever it is said: "If I had known that my father was among you, I would have said, 'All of you are forbidden except for my father,'" all of them are forbidden except for his father. They only disagreed in saying: "If I had known that my father was among you, I would have said, 'So-and-so and so-and-so are forbidden, but my father is permitted.'"

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא אָמַר: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא, כֹּל הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר: אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁאַבָּא בֵּינֵיכֶם הָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר: ״פְּלוֹנִי וּפְלוֹנִי אֲסוּרִין וְאַבָּא מוּתָּר״ — כּוּלָּם מוּתָּרִין. לֹא נֶחְלְקוּ אֶלָּא בְּאוֹמֵר: אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁאַבָּא בֵּינֵיכֶם, הָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר: ״כּוּלְּכֶם אֲסוּרִין חוּץ מֵאַבָּא״.
human_translation: And Rava said: Everyone that anywhere that one says: Had I known that father was among you I would have said: So-and-so and so-and-so are prohibited and father is permitted all are permitted They disagree only where one says: Had I known that father was among you I would have said: All of you are prohibited except for father.
llm_translation: Rava said: In all the world, wherever it is said, "If I had known that my father was among you, I would have said, 'So-and-so and so-and-so are forbidden, but my father is permitted'" - all of them are permitted. They only disagreed in saying, "If I had known that my father was among you, I would have said, 'All of you are forbidden except for my father.'"

hebrew_text: בֵּית שַׁמַּאי סָבְרִי לַהּ כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, דְּאָמַר: תְּפוֹס לָשׁוֹן רִאשׁוֹן.
human_translation: Beit Shammai hold in accordance with Rabbi Meir, who said: hold first expression.
llm_translation: House of Shammai hold like Rabbi Meir, for he said: "Grasp the first language."

hebrew_text: וּבֵית הִלֵּל סָבְרִי לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, דְּאָמַר: בִּגְמַר דְּבָרָיו אָדָם נִתְפָּס.
human_translation: And Beit Hillel hold in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, who said: A person is held accountable for the conclusion of his statement,
llm_translation: House of Hillel hold like Rabbi Yosei, for he said: In the finalization of his words, a person is apprehended.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְרָבָא: כֵּיצַד אָמַר רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא נֶדֶר שֶׁהוּתַּר מִקְצָתוֹ הוּתַּר כּוּלּוֹ? ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֵינִי נֶהֱנֶה לְכוּלְּכֶם״, הוּתַּר אֶחָד מֵהֶן — הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּם. ״שֶׁאֵינִי נֶהֱנֶה לֹא לָזֶה וְלָזֶה״, הוּתַּר הָרִאשׁוֹן — הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּם, הוּתַּר הָאַחֲרוֹן — הָאַחֲרוֹן מוּתָּר וְכוּלָּן אֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: Rav Pappa raised an objection to Rava In what case did Rabbi Akiva say a vow which was partially dissolved is dissolved completely? of all of you is konam that I will not benefit one of them was permitted all of them is permitted. of this one and of that one that I will not benefit the first was permitted all is permitted, the last was permitted, the last is permitted and all is forbidden.
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him, Rav Papa to Rava: How so did Rabbi Akiva say, a vow that was permitted in part, is it permitted in its entirety? "Their vow that I do not benefit all of you," if one of them was permitted - all of them are permitted. "That I do not benefit neither this one nor that one," if the first was permitted - all of them are permitted, if the last was permitted - the last one is permitted and all of them are forbidden.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַבָּה, מוֹקֵים לֵהּ לְרֵישָׁא, דְּאָמַר לָזֶה וְלָזֶה.
human_translation: Granted, according to Rabba, he establishes first clause, where he says: of this one and of that one,
llm_translation: In peace to Rabah, they establish for him at the beginning, for he said to this one and to that one.

hebrew_text: וְסֵיפָא — דְּאָמַר ״לְכוּלְּכֶם״.
human_translation: And the last clause where he says: of all of you
llm_translation: And the latter part - that it says, "to all of you."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְדִידָךְ: בִּשְׁלָמָא רֵישָׁא מוֹקֵים לֵהּ דְּאָמַר ״לְכוּלְּכֶם״.
human_translation: But according to you, granted, he establishes the first clause where he says: of all of you
llm_translation: Instead, according to our view: In the beginning, it establishes for him, as it says, "For all of you."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא סֵיפָא, דְּאָמַר ״לָזֶה וְלָזֶה״, רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הִיא, אַמַּאי פְּלִיגִי רַבָּנַן עֲלֵיהּ? וְהָאָמְרַתְּ דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל מוּתָּר!
human_translation: But the latter clause where he said: to this one and to that one, is Rabbi Akiva, why do the Rabbis disagree with him? But haven’t you said all agree permitted
llm_translation: Rather, the latter part, where it says "for this and for that," it is Rabbi Akiva. Why then do the Rabbis disagree with him? But didn't you say that all agree that it is permissible!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: וּלְרַבָּה לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא מִי נִיחָא סֵיפָא? בְּמַאי מוֹקֵים לֵהּ — דְּאָמַר ״לְכוּלְּכֶם״, הֵי דֵין הוּא רִאשׁוֹן וְהֵי דֵין הוּא אַחֲרוֹן?
human_translation: Rava said to And according to Rabba, does the latter clause work out well according to Rabbi Akiva? In what does he establish it? where one said: From all of you, which of them is the first one and which of them is the last one?
llm_translation: Rava said to him: And for Rabba to Rabbi Akiva, who is fitting the conclusion? With what is it established for him - as it says "to all of you," let him be the first judge and let him be the last judge?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: רֵישָׁא דְּאָמַר ״לְכוּלְּכֶם״, וְסֵיפָא, כְּגוֹן שֶׁתְּלָאָן זֶה בָּזֶה, וְאָמַר: ״פְּלוֹנִי כִּפְלוֹנִי, וּפְלוֹנִי כִּפְלוֹנִי״.
human_translation: Rather, The first clause where he said: From all of you, And the latter clause, for example, he linked them to one another and said: So-and-so like so-and-so, and so-and-so like so-and-so,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rather: the beginning that says "to all of you," and the end, for example, that one suspends this with this, and says: "So-and-so like so-and-so, and so-and-so like so-and-so."

hebrew_text: דַּיְקָא נָמֵי, דְּתַנְיָא: הוּתַּר הָאֶמְצָעִי — הֵימֶנּוּ וּלְמַטָּה מוּתָּרִין, וּלְמַעְלָה — אֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: is also precise, as it is taught the middle one was permitted from him and below, are permitted and above, are prohibited
llm_translation: Precisely it was stated, as it was taught: If the middle one is permitted — those below it and to the south are permitted, and those above it are forbidden.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה לְרָבָא: ״קֻוֽנָּם בָּצָל שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם, שֶׁהַבָּצָל רַע לַלֵּב״. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: וַהֲלֹא הַכּוּפְרִי יָפֶה לַלֵּב! הוּתַּר בַּכּוּפְרִי. וְלֹא בַּכּוּפְרִי בִּלְבַד הוּתַּר, אֶלָּא בְּכׇל הַבְּצָלִים. מַעֲשֶׂה הָיָה, וְהִתִּירוֹ רַבִּי מֵאִיר בְּכׇל הַבְּצָלִים.
human_translation: Rav Adda bar Ahava raised an objection to Rava: Onions are konam that I taste them, because onions are bad for the heart, said to him: But isn’t the kuferi good for the heart, is dissolved with regard to kuferi and not only with regard to kuferi but with regard to all onions. an incident occurred, and Rabbi Meir dissolved with regard to all onions.
llm_translation: He raised an objection to Rav Adda bar Ahava to Rava: "The onion is harmful to the heart." They said to him: "But isn't the beet good for the heart!" He permitted the beet. And not only the beet alone was permitted, but all onions were permitted. There was an incident, and Rabbi Meir permitted all onions.

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו, דְּאָמַר: אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁהַכּוּפְרִי יָפֶה לַלֵּב, הָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר ״כׇּל הַבְּצָלִים אֲסוּרִין וְכוּפְרִי מוּתָּר״?
human_translation: What, is it not where said: Had I known that the kuferi is good for the heart I would have said: All onions are forbidden and kuferi is permitted?
llm_translation: What is the reason that he said: "If I had known that the turnip is good for the heart, I would have said, 'All onions are forbidden, but turnips are permitted'?"

hebrew_text: לֹא, בְּאוֹמֵר: אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁהַכּוּפְרִי יָפֶה לַלֵּב, הָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר: ״בָּצָל פְּלוֹנִי וּפְלוֹנִי אֲסוּרִין וְכוּפְרִי מוּתָּר״. וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְאַלִּיבָּא דְרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: No, where one says: If I had known that the kuferi is good for the heart, I would have said: Such an onion and such are forbidden and kuferi is permitted, and Rabbi Meir in accordance with of Rabbi Akiva and in accordance with of the Rabbis.
llm_translation: Not, in saying: If I had known that the unripe fig is good for the heart, I would have said, "Regarding the onions of so-and-so and so-and-so, they are forbidden, but the unripe fig is permitted." And Rabbi Meir is of the opinion of Rabbi Akiva and of the opinion of the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרָבָא: רַבִּי נָתָן אוֹמֵר: יֵשׁ נֶדֶר שֶׁמִּקְצָתוֹ מוּתָּר וּמִקְצָתוֹ אָסוּר. כֵּיצַד? נָדַר מִן הַכַּלְכַּלָּה,
human_translation: Ravina raised an objection to Rava: Rabbi Natan says there is a vow that is partially dissolved and partially binding. How took a vow from a basket
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him, Ravina to Rava: Rabbi Natan says: There is a vow that part of it is permitted and part of it is forbidden. How so? He vowed from the "kalcala,"

hebrew_text: וְהָיוּ בָּהּ בְּנוֹת שׁוּחַ, וְאָמַר: ״אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁבְּנוֹת שׁוּחַ בְּתוֹכָהּ, לֹא הָיִיתִי נוֹדֵר״ — הַכַּלְכַּלָּה אֲסוּרָה, בְּנוֹת שׁוּחַ מוּתָּרוֹת. עַד שֶׁבָּא רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְלִימֵּד: נֶדֶר שֶׁהוּתַּר מִקְצָתוֹ — הוּתַּר כּוּלּוֹ. מַאי לָאו, דְּאָמַר אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁבְּנוֹת שׁוּחַ בְּתוֹכָהּ, הָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר ״תְּאֵנִים שְׁחוֹרוֹת וּלְבָנוֹת אֲסוּרוֹת, בְּנוֹת שׁוּחַ מוּתָּרוֹת״, וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הִיא, וּפְלִיגִי רַבָּנַן?
human_translation: and there were benot shuaḥ in it, and he said: Had I known that there were benot shuaḥ in it I would not have taken a vow, the basket are forbidden, the benot shuaḥ are permitted. until Rabbi Akiva came and taught: A vow which is dissolved partially is dissolved completely. What, is it not Had I known that benot shuaḥ were inside it, I would have said black and white figs are forbidden, benot shuaḥ are permitted, and this is Rabbi Akiva, and the Rabbis disagree
llm_translation: The daughters of Shuach were in it, and he said: "If I had known that the daughters of Shuach were inside, I would not have made a vow." — The vow is forbidden, the daughters of Shuach are permitted. Until Rabbi Akiva came and taught: A vow that was partially permitted — the entire vow is permitted. What is the reason? Because he said, "If I had known that the daughters of Shuach were inside, I would have said, 'Black and white figs are forbidden, the daughters of Shuach are permitted.'" And it was Rabbi Akiva, and did the Rabbis disagree?

hebrew_text: לָא, בְּאוֹמֵר: אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁבְּנוֹת שׁוּחַ בְּתוֹכָהּ, הָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר: ״כׇּל הַכַּלְכַּלָּה אֲסוּרָה, וּבְנוֹת שׁוּחַ מוּתָּרוֹת״.
human_translation: No, where he says: Had I known that there were benot shuaḥ in it I would have said the entire basket is forbidden and benot shuaḥ are permitted,
llm_translation: He does not say, for he says: "If I had known that there were daughters of Shuah among them, I would have said, 'All jewelry is forbidden, but daughters of Shuah are permitted.'"

hebrew_text: מַאן תְּנָא לְהָא דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: נָדַר מֵחֲמִשָּׁה בְּנֵי אָדָם כְּאֶחָד, הוּתַּר לְאֶחָד מֵהֶם — הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּן. ״חוּץ מֵאֶחָד מֵהֶן״ — הוּא מוּתָּר, וְהֵן אֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: Who taught that which the Sages taught: took a vow, in one from five people, is dissolved for one of them, all of them is dissolved; except for one of them, he, is permitted and they, are forbidden?
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna that taught what the Rabbis taught: One who vows from five men like one, it is permitted for one of them — they are all permitted. "Except for one of them" — he is permitted, and they are forbidden.

hebrew_text: אִי לְרַבָּה, רֵישָׁא רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְסֵיפָא דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל. אִי לְרָבָא, סֵיפָא רַבָּנַן וְרֵישָׁא דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל.
human_translation: If with Rabba, the first clause Rabbi Akiva, And the latter clause everyone agrees If with Rava, the latter clause Rabbis, and everyone agrees the first clause.
llm_translation: If for the majority, the beginning is Rabbi Akiva and the end is the words of everyone. If for the minority, the end is the Rabbis and the beginning is the words of everyone.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ נִדְרֵי אוֹנָסִין, הִדִּירוֹ חֲבֵירוֹ שֶׁיֹּאכַל אֶצְלוֹ, וְחָלָה הוּא אוֹ שֶׁחָלָה בְּנוֹ אוֹ שֶׁעִכְּבוֹ נָהָר — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ נִדְרֵי אוֹנָסִין.
human_translation: vows circumstances beyond control? one’s friend took a vow with regard to him that he should eat with him, and he became sick, or his son became sick, or a river barred him these are vows circumstances beyond control.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: Vows of compulsion, if one vowed to his fellow that he would eat with him, and he became ill, or his son became ill, or a river detained him - these are vows of compulsion.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ הָהוּא גַּבְרָא דְּאַתְפֵּיס זָכְווֹתָא בְּבֵי דִינָא, וְאָמַר: אִי לָא אָתֵינָא עַד תְּלָתִין יוֹמִין, לִיבַּטְלוּן הָנֵי זָכְווֹתַאי. אִיתְּנִיס וְלָא אֲתָא. אֲמַר רַב הוּנָא: בְּטִיל זָכְווֹתֵיהּ.
