human_translation: Should you conclude from arrangements are not made with a creditor, Rav Naḥman, son of Rabbi Yitzḥak, said:
llm_translation: Heard from her, do not arrange for the creditor? Said Rav Nachman son of Rabbi Yitzchak:

hebrew_text: לוֹמַר שֶׁאֵין מְקָרְעִין שְׁטַר כְּתוּבָּה.
human_translation: saying that do not tear the document of the marriage contract.
llm_translation: To say that one does not tear a written document.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ פּוֹתְחִין בְּיָמִים טוֹבִים וּבְשַׁבָּתוֹת. בָּרִאשׁוֹנָה הָיוּ אוֹמְרִים: אוֹתָן הַיָּמִים — מוּתָּרִין, וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הַיָּמִים אֲסוּרִין. עַד שֶׁבָּא רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְלִימֵּד שֶׁהַנֶּדֶר שֶׁהוּתַּר מִכְּלָלוֹ — הוּתַּר כּוּלּוֹ.
human_translation: may broach by Festivals and Shabbatot . At first they said those days is permitted, but all the rest of the days, e forbidden until Rabbi Akiva came and taught that a vow that is partially dissolved is dissolved entirely.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One may begin fasting on festive days and on Sabbaths. Originally, they used to say: On those days - it is permitted, and on all other days - it is forbidden. Until Rabbi Akiva came and taught that a vow that was permitted from its general category - the entire vow is permitted.

hebrew_text: כֵּיצַד? אָמַר ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֵינִי נֶהֱנֶה לְכוּלְּכֶם״, הוּתַּר אֶחָד מֵהֶן — הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּן.
human_translation: How so? said I will not benefit from all of you it is konam one of them was permitted all of them is permitted.
llm_translation: "How so? He said, 'Their nest that I do not benefit from all of you,' if one of them is permitted - all of them are permitted."

hebrew_text: ״שֶׁאֵינִי נֶהֱנֶה לָזֶה וְלָזֶה״, הוּתַּר הָרִאשׁוֹן — הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּן, הוּתַּר הָאַחֲרוֹן — הָאַחֲרוֹן מוּתָּר וְכוּלָּן אֲסוּרִין. הוּתַּר הָאֶמְצָעִי, הֵימֶנּוּ וּלְמַטָּה — מוּתָּר, הֵימֶנּוּ וּלְמַעְלָה — אָסוּר.
human_translation: I will not benefit from this and from that the first was permitted all is permitted. the last was permitted, the last is permitted, but all is forbidden, the middle was permitted, from him and below, is permitted; from him and above, is forbidden.
llm_translation: "Whoever does not benefit this one and that one," the first one is permitted — they are all permitted, the last one is prohibited — the last one is prohibited and they are all prohibited. The middle one is permitted, from it and below — permitted, from it and above — prohibited.

hebrew_text: ״שֶׁאֲנִי נֶהֱנֶה לָזֶה קׇרְבָּן וְלָזֶה קׇרְבָּן״ — צְרִיכִין פֶּתַח לְכׇל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד.
human_translation: I will benefit from this an offering, and from that an offering, an extenuation is required for each and every one,
llm_translation: "for I derive benefit from this offering and from that offering" - we need an opening for each and every one.

hebrew_text: ״קֻוֽנָּם יַיִן שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם, שֶׁהַיַּיִן רַע לַמֵּעַיִים״, אָמְרוּ לוֹ: וַהֲלֹא הַמְיוּשָּׁן יָפֶה לַמֵּעַיִים! הוּתַּר בִּמְיוּשָּׁן. וְלֹא בִּמְיוּשָּׁן בִּלְבַד הוּתַּר, אֶלָּא בְּכׇל הַיַּיִן. ״קֻוֽנָּם בָּצָל שֶׁאֵינִי טוֹעֵם, שֶׁהַבָּצָל רַע לַלֵּב״, אָמְרוּ לוֹ: הֲלֹא הַכּוּפְרִי יָפֶה לַלֵּב! הוּתַּר בַּכּוּפְרִי. וְלֹא בַּכּוּפְרִי בִּלְבַד הוּתַּר, אֶלָּא בְּכׇל הַבְּצָלִים. מַעֲשֶׂה הָיָה, וְהִתִּירוֹ רַבִּי מֵאִיר בְּכׇל הַבְּצָלִים.
human_translation: Wine is konam I taste it, as wine is bad for the intestines, they said to him: But aged wine is good for the intestines, is dissolved with regard to aged wine. And not only with regard to aged wine is it dissolved, but with regard to all wine, Onions are konam I will not taste them, as onions are bad for the heart, they said to him: But the kuferi is good for the heart, it is dissolved with regard to kuferi and not only with regard to kuferi but with regard to all onions. an incident occurred, and Rabbi Meir dissolved with regard to all onions.
llm_translation: "Kuvnam wine that I taste, for the wine is bad for the intestines," they said to him: Isn't aged wine good for the intestines! Permitted with aged wine. And not only with aged wine was it permitted, but with all wine. "Kuvnam onion that I taste, for the onion is bad for the heart," they said to him: Isn't leek good for the heart! Permitted with leek. And not only with leek was it permitted, but with all onions. There was an incident, and Rabbi Meir permitted with all onions."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ הוּתַּר הָאַחֲרוֹן — הָאַחֲרוֹן מוּתָּר, וְכוּלָּן אֲסוּרִין. מַאן תַּנָּא?
human_translation: the last was permitted, the last is permitted but all is forbidden. Who taught
llm_translation: The end one permitted, the last one permitted, and all of them forbidden. Who is the Tanna?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא, דְּאָמַר: עַד שֶׁיֹּאמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה״ לְכׇל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד.
human_translation: Rava said: It is Rabbi Shimon, who said unless he says: An oath, to each and every one
llm_translation: Rava said: Rabbi Shimon is he, who said: Until he says "week" to each and every one.

hebrew_text: קֻוֽנָּם יַיִן שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם וְכוּ׳. וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ דְּאֵין רַע! אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: וְעוֹד, ״יָפֶה״ קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: Wine is konam I taste it, And let him derive that not bad Rabbi Abba said: teaches: And furthermore, good.
llm_translation: Their line is gone out through all the earth, and their words to the end of the world. And let it come forth that there is no evil! Rabbi Abba said: Furthermore, "beautiful" it teaches.

hebrew_text: קֻוֽנָּם בָּצָל שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֵם שֶׁהַבָּצָל וְכוּ׳. וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ דְּאֵין רַע! אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: וְעוֹד, ״יָפֶה״ קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: Onions are konam I taste them, as onions And let him derive that not bad Rabbi Abba said: teaches: And furthermore, good.
llm_translation: Their measure in onion that I taste that the onion etc. And come out to it that there is no harm! Rabbi Abba said: And furthermore, "beautiful" it teaches.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ פּוֹתְחִין לָאָדָם בִּכְבוֹד עַצְמוֹ וּבִכְבוֹד בָּנָיו. אוֹמְרִים לוֹ: אִילּוּ הָיִיתָ יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁלְּמָחָר אוֹמְרִין עָלֶיךָ ״כָּךְ הִיא וִוסְתּוֹ שֶׁל פְּלוֹנִי, מְגָרֵשׁ אֶת נָשָׁיו״, וְעַל בְּנוֹתֶיךָ יְהוּ אוֹמְרִין ״בְּנוֹת גְּרוּשׁוֹת הֵן״, ״מָה רָאֲתָה אִמָּן שֶׁל אֵלּוּ לְהִתְגָּרֵשׁ״. וְאָמַר: ״אִילּוּ הָיִיתִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁכֵּן, לֹא הָיִיתִי נוֹדֵר״ — הֲרֵי זֶה מוּתָּר.
human_translation: may broach for a person by his own honor and the honor of his children. say to him: Had you known that tomorrow people will say about you: This is the habit [ veset ] of so-and-so, he divorces his wives and they will say about your daughters: They are daughters of divorce, What did their mother see to divorce, And said: Had I known it was so, I would not have vowed, it is dissolved.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One may open with honor for himself and with honor for his children. They say to him: If you had known that tomorrow they would say about you, "So-and-so's wife is divorced," you should divorce your wife, and regarding your daughters they would say, "They are daughters of divorcees," and, "What did the mother of these see to be divorced?" And he says: "If I had known that this would happen, I would not have vowed." — This is permitted.

hebrew_text: ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֲנִי נוֹשֵׂא אֶת פְּלוֹנִית כְּעוּרָה״ וַהֲרֵי הִיא נָאָה, ״שְׁחוֹרָה״ וַהֲרֵי הִיא לְבָנָה, ״קְצָרָה״ וַהֲרֵי הִיא אֲרוּכָּה — מוּתָּר בָּהּ. לֹא מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהִיא כְּעוּרָה וְנַעֲשֵׂת נָאָה, שְׁחוֹרָה וְנַעֲשֵׂת לְבָנָה, קְצָרָה וְנַעֲשֵׂת אֲרוּכָּה — אֶלָּא שֶׁהַנֶּדֶר טָעוּת.
human_translation: Marrying ugly so-and-so is konam for me, and she is beautiful, black, and she is white, short, and she is tall, he is permitted to her. Not because she was ugly and became beautiful, black and became white, short and became tall, rather, because the vow was mistaken
llm_translation: "‘Their measure is that I am carrying Plonit like a blind person.’ And behold, she is beautiful, ‘black’ and behold, she is white, ‘short’ and behold, she is long - it is permitted in her. Not because she is like a blind person and becomes beautiful, black and becomes white, short and becomes long - but because the vow was mistaken."

hebrew_text: וּמַעֲשֶׂה בְּאֶחָד שֶׁנָּדַר מִבַּת אֲחוֹתוֹ הֲנָיָיה, וְהִכְנִיסוּהָ לְבֵית רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל וְיִיפּוּהָ. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: בְּנִי, מִזּוֹ נָדַרְתָּ? אָמַר לוֹ: לָאו, וְהִתִּירָהּ רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל.
human_translation: And an incident with regard to one who vowed benefit from the daughter of his sister, And they brought her into house of Rabbi Yishmael and he beautified her. Rabbi Yishmael said to him: My son, did you vow from this He said to him: No, and Rabbi Yishmael permitted her
llm_translation: And it happened that one vowed from the daughter of his sister a vow, and they brought her to the house of Rabbi Yishmael and they redeemed her. Rabbi Yishmael said to him: My son, from what did you vow? He said to him: No, and Rabbi Yishmael annulled it.

hebrew_text: בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה בָּכָה רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל וְאָמַר: בְּנוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל נָאוֹת הֵן, אֶלָּא שֶׁהָעֲנִיּוּת מְנַוַּולְתָּן. וּכְשֶׁמֵּת רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל הָיוּ בְּנוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל נוֹשְׂאוֹת קִינָה, וְאוֹמְרוֹת: ״בְּנוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּכֶינָה״, וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר בְּשָׁאוּל: ״בְּנוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל שָׁאוּל בְּכֶינָה״.
human_translation: At that time Rabbi Yishmael wept and said: The daughters of Israel are beautiful, but poverty makes them ugly. And when Rabbi Yishmael died, the daughters of Israel raised a lamentation, saying: Daughters of Israel, weep for Rabbi Yishmael. And it likewise states about Saul, “Daughters of Israel, weep over Saul,
llm_translation: At that moment, Rabbi Yishmael cried out and said: "The daughters of Israel are beautiful, but poverty makes them repulsive." And when Rabbi Yishmael died, the daughters of Israel took up a lamentation, saying: "Daughters of Israel, weep for Rabbi Yishmael." This is similar to what is said about Saul: "Daughters of Israel, weep for Saul."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַעֲשֶׂה לִסְתּוֹר?! חַסּוֹרֵי מְחַסְּרָא וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ כְּעוּרָה וְנַעֲשֵׂת נָאָה, שְׁחוֹרָה וְנַעֲשֵׂת לְבָנָה, קְצָרָה וְנַעֲשֵׂת אֲרוּכָּה. מַעֲשֶׂה בְּאֶחָד שֶׁנָּדַר מִבַּת אֲחוֹתוֹ וְהִכְנִיסוּהָ לְבֵית רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל וְיִיפּוּהָ וְכוּ׳.
human_translation: an incident to contradict is incomplete and this is what it is teaching: Rabbi Yishmael says: Even if she was ugly and became beautiful, black and became white, short and became tall, An incident with regard to one who vowed from the daughter of his sister, And they brought her into Rabbi Yishmael’s house and he beautified her.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Is it possible to hide a blemish?! Deficient from deficiency, and thus it was taught: Rabbi Yishmael says: Even if she is dark and becomes fair, black and becomes white, short and becomes tall. There was an incident with one who vowed regarding his sister's daughter, and they brought her to the house of Rabbi Yishmael and beautified her, and so forth.

hebrew_text: תָּנָא: שֵׁן תּוֹתֶבֶת הָיְתָה לָהּ, וְעָשָׂה לָהּ רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל שֵׁן שֶׁל זָהָב מִשֶּׁלּוֹ. כִּי שְׁכֵיב רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, פְּתַח עֲלֵיהּ הַהוּא סַפְדָנָא הָכִי: ״בְּנוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּכֶינָה הַמַּלְבִּישְׁכֶן וְכוּ׳״.
human_translation: taught: She had a false tooth [ shen totevet ], and Rabbi Yishmael made her a gold tooth from his own When Rabbi Yishmael died, a certain eulogizer began about him like this: Daughters of Israel, weep for Rabbi Yishmael, who clothed you.
llm_translation: Mishna: A toothpick she had, and Rabbi Yishmael made for her a golden tooth. When Rabbi Yishmael lay down, that certain sophist opened with this lamentation: "Daughters of Israel, upon Rabbi Yishmael with the lamentation who clothes you, etc."

hebrew_text: הָהוּא דַּאֲמַר לַהּ לִדְבֵיתְהוּ ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאִי אַתְּ נֶהֱנֵית לִי עַד שֶׁתַּטְעִימִי תַּבְשִׁילֵךְ לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה וּלְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן״. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה טְעֵים, אֲמַר, קַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה לַעֲשׂוֹת שָׁלוֹם בֵּין אִישׁ לְאִשְׁתּוֹ אָמְרָה תּוֹרָה שְׁמִי שֶׁנִּכְתַּב בִּקְדוּשָּׁה יִמָּחֶה עַל הַמַּיִם הַמְאָרְרִים בְּסָפֵק, וַאֲנִי עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה.
human_translation: a certain who said to his wife: Benefiting from me is konam you until you have given Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon your cooked food to taste, Rabbi Yehuda tasted He said: a fortiori And what that to make peace between a man and his wife, the Torah said: My name, that is written in sanctity, shall be blotted out in the waters that curse, in uncertain I, all the more so,
llm_translation: That one who said to his wife, "Your oath that you will not benefit from me until you taste your dish, is binding for Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon." Rabbi Yehuda said, "Taste it," he said, "a fortiori: If to make peace between a man and his wife, the Torah said, 'My name that is written in holiness shall be erased in the bitter waters in a doubtful case,' then how much more so in my case."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן לָא טְעֵים, אֲמַר: יָמוּתוּ כׇּל בְּנֵי אַלְמָנָה, וְאַל יָזוּז שִׁמְעוֹן מִמְּקוֹמוֹ. וְעוֹד: כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא לִתְרַגְּלִי לְמִינְדָּר.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon did not taste. He said: Let all the children of the widow die, and Shimon will not budge from his place. And furthermore, So that they should not become used to taking vows.
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon did not taste, he said: "Let all the sons of a widow die, and let Shimon not move from his place." And furthermore: so that I do not become accustomed to the inn.

hebrew_text: הַהוּא דְּאָמַר לִדְבֵיתְהוּ ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאִי אַתְּ נֶהֱנֵית לִי עַד שֶׁתָּרוֹקִּי בּוֹ בְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל״. אֲתָת וּרְקַק אַלְּבוּשֵׁיהּ. אָמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַחָא מִדִּפְתִּי לְרָבִינָא: וְהָא הַאי לְזִילוּתָא קָא מִיכַּוֵּין! אָמַר לֵיהּ: מִירָק עַל מָנֵי דְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל זִילוּתָא רַבְּתָא הִיא.
human_translation: a certain who said to his wife: Benefiting from me is konam you until you have spat on Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. She came and spat on his clothing. Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: But this intended the humiliation said to him: Spittle on the clothing of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel is a great humiliation
llm_translation: That one who said to his wife, "Your adornments are forbidden to me until you spit upon them in the presence of Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel." She spat and moistened her garments. Rav Acha said to Ravina: But is this not for degradation that they are preparing! He said to him: The spitting in the presence of Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel is a great honor.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא דַּאֲמַר לִדְבֵיתְהוּ ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאִי אַתְּ נֶהֱנֵית לִי עַד שֶׁתַּרְאִי מוּם יָפֶה שֶׁבִּיךְ לְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי״.
human_translation: a certain who said to his wife: Benefiting from me is konam you until you show some beautiful [ yafeh ] part of you to Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei.
llm_translation: That one who said to his wife, "Your beauty is not pleasing to me until you show me the blemish that is in you," to Rabbi Yishmael son of Rabbi Yosei.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָהֶם: שֶׁמָּא רֹאשָׁהּ נָאֶה? אָמְרוּ לוֹ: סְגַלְגַּל. שֶׁמָּא שְׂעָרָהּ נָאֶה? דּוֹמֶה לַאֲנִיצֵי פִּשְׁתָּן. שֶׁמָּא עֵינֶיהָ נָאוֹת? טְרוּטוֹת הֵן. שֶׁמָּא אׇזְנֶיהָ נָאוֹת? כְּפוּלוֹת הֵן. שֶׁמָּא חוֹטְמָהּ נָאֶה? בָּלוּם הוּא. שֶׁמָּא שִׂפְתוֹתֶיהָ נָאוֹת? עָבוֹת הֵן. שֶׁמָּא צַוָּארָהּ נָאֶה? שָׁקוּט הוּא. שֶׁמָּא כְּרֵיסָהּ נָאֶה? צָבֶה הוּא. שֶׁמָּא רַגְלֶיהָ נָאוֹת? רְחָבוֹת כְּשֶׁל אֲווֹזָא. שֶׁמָּא שְׁמָהּ נָאֶה? ״לִכְלוּכִית״ שְׁמָהּ. אָמַר לָהֶן: יָפֶה קוֹרִין אוֹתָהּ לִכְלוּכִית, שֶׁהִיא מְלוּכְלֶכֶת בְּמוּמִין, וְשַׁרְיַיהּ.
human_translation: He said to Perhaps her head is beautiful? They said to him: round [ segalgal ]. Perhaps her hair is beautiful? resembles stalks of flax. Perhaps her eyes are beautiful? They are narrow [ terutot ]. Perhaps her ears are beautiful? They are double Perhaps her nose is beautiful? It is stubby. Perhaps her lips are beautiful? They are thick. Perhaps her neck is beautiful? It is low Perhaps her stomach is beautiful? It is swollen. Perhaps her feet are beautiful? as wide as a goose’s. Perhaps her name is beautiful? Her name is Likhlukhit. He said to them: It is fitting [ yafeh ] she is called Likhlukhit, as she is dirty [ melukhlekhet ] with blemishes, and he permitted her
llm_translation: He said to them: "Perhaps her head is beautiful?" They said to him: "Like a skull." "Perhaps her hair is beautiful?" Resembles the fibers of flax. "Perhaps her eyes are beautiful?" They are round. "Perhaps her ears are beautiful?" They are folded. "Perhaps her nose is beautiful?" It is crooked. "Perhaps her lips are beautiful?" They are thick. "Perhaps her neck is beautiful?" It is thin. "Perhaps her stomach is beautiful?" It is bloated. "Perhaps her legs are beautiful?" Broad like those of a goose. "Perhaps her name is beautiful?" Her name is "Kilkulkit." He said to them: "It is beautiful to call her 'Kilkulkit,' for she is full of blemishes, and permitted."

hebrew_text: הָהוּא בַּר בָּבֶל דִּסְלֵיק לְאַרְעָא דְיִשְׂרָאֵל, נְסֵיב אִיתְּתָא. אֲמַר לַהּ: בַּשִּׁילִי לִי תְּרֵי טַלְפֵי. בַּשִּׁילָה לֵיהּ תְּרֵי טַלְפֵי. רְתַח עֲלַהּ. לִמְחַר אֲמַר לַהּ: בַּשִּׁילִי לִי גְּרִיוָא. בַּשִּׁילָה לֵיהּ גְּרִיוָא. אֲמַר לַהּ: זִילִי אַיְיתִי לִי תְּרֵי בוּצִינֵי. אֲזַלַת וְאַיְיתַי לֵיהּ תְּרֵי שְׁרָגֵי.
human_translation: a certain Babylonian who went up to Eretz Yisrael married a woman He said to her: Cook two lentils, for me. She cooked two lentils for him. He grew angry with her. On the following day, he said to her: Cook a se’a [ geriva ] for me, She cooked an se’a for him, He said to her: Go and bring me two butzinei , She went and brought him two lamps [ sheraggei ],
llm_translation: That Babylonian man who ascended to the Land of Israel, married a woman. He said to her: "Cook for me two dishes." She cooked for him two dishes. He became angry. The next day he said to her: "Cook for me a pudding." She cooked for him a pudding. He said to her: "Go and bring me two dates." She went and brought him two figs.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לַהּ: זִילִי תְּבַרִי יָתְהוֹן עַל רֵישָׁא דְבָבָא. הֲוָה יָתֵיב בָּבָא בֶּן בּוּטָא אַבָּבָא וְקָא דָאֵין דִּינָא. אֲזַלַת וּתְבַרַת יָתְהוֹן עַל רֵישֵׁיהּ. אֲמַר לַהּ: מָה הָדֵין דַּעֲבַדְתְּ? אֲמַרָה לֵיהּ: כָּךְ צִיוַּנִי בַּעְלִי. אֲמַר: אַתְּ עָשִׂית רְצוֹן בַּעְלִיךְ, הַמָּקוֹם יוֹצִיא מִמֵּךְ שְׁנֵי בָּנִים כְּבָבָא בֶּן בּוּטָא.
human_translation: he said to her: Go and break them on the head of the bava , Bava ben Buta was sitting as a judge at the gate. She went and broke them on his head, He said to her: What is this you have done? She said to him: This is what my husband commanded me He said: You fulfilled your husband’s desire, may the Omnipresent bring forth from you two sons, like Bava ben Buta.
llm_translation: He said to her: Go prepare a meal for them at the head of the house of the father. Babba ben Buta was sitting and judging. She went and prepared a meal for them at their head. He said to her: What did you do? She said to him: Thus my husband instructed me. He said: Since you did the will of your husband, may the Omnipresent bring forth from you two sons like Babba ben Buta.

hebrew_text: הַדְרָן עֲלָךְ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר
llm_translation: We will return to you, Rabbi Eliezer.

hebrew_text: נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה , אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ.
human_translation: a betrothed young woman, her father and her husband nullify her vows.
llm_translation: A betrothed maiden, her father and her husband annul her vows.

hebrew_text: הֵפֵר הָאָב וְלֹא הֵפֵר הַבַּעַל, הֵפֵר הַבַּעַל וְלֹא הֵפֵר הָאָב — אֵינוֹ מוּפָר. וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁקִּיֵּים אֶחָד מֵהֶן.
human_translation: the father nullified and the husband did not nullify the husband nullified and the father did not nullify is not nullified. And needless to say, if one of them ratified
llm_translation: The father annulled the vow but the husband did not annul it, the husband annulled it but the father did not annul it - it is not annulled. And needless to say that one of them fulfilled the annulment.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ הַיְינוּ רֵישָׁא: אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: אוֹ אָבִיהָ אוֹ בַעְלָהּ קָתָנֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Is this the first clause Her father and her husband nullify her vows? lest you say: is teaching either her father or her husband teaches us
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara, ha'inu reisha: avia uva'alah mifirin nedareha! Mahu d'teima: o avia o va'alah katanai, ka mashma lan. English translation: This is the beginning of the matter: her father and her husband annul her vows! Lest you say: either her father or her husband is a minor, it is implied to us.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁקִּיֵּים אֶחָד מֵהֶן. לְמָה לִי לְמִיתְנָא? הַשְׁתָּא יֵשׁ לוֹמַר הֵפֵר זֶה בְּלֹא זֶה — וְלֹא כְּלוּם, קִיֵּים אֶחָד מֵהֶן לְמָה לִי? צְרִיכָא לְמִיתְנֵי?!
human_translation: And needless to say, if one of them ratified Why do I to teach Now, was stated one nullified without the other, is nothing, one of them ratified why do I necessary to teach
llm_translation: "And it is not necessary to say that one of them is fulfilled. Why do I need to learn this? Now, one can say that this one annuls without this one - and it is as if nothing, if one of them is fulfilled, why do I need it? It is necessary to learn?!"

hebrew_text: כִּי אִיצְטְרִיךְ לֵיהּ כְּגוֹן דְּהֵפֵר אֶחָד מֵהֶן וְקִיֵּים אֶחָד, וְחָזַר הַמְקַיֵּים וְנִשְׁאַל עַל הֲקָמָתוֹ. מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: מַאי דְּאוֹקִי הָא עַקְרֵיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דִּמְפִירִין שְׁנֵיהֶם בְּבַת אַחַת.
human_translation: It was necessary for in where one of them nullified and one ratified and the one who ratified retracted and requested of his ratification Lest you say: That which he ratified he uprooted, teaches us that they both must nullify together.
llm_translation: When he needs it, for example, if he nullified one of them and fulfilled one, and the one who fulfilled it returned and was asked about his fulfillment. What might you say? What is the reason that his fulfillment is valid? It teaches us that they nullified both at the same time.

hebrew_text: וְנַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ, מְנָלַן? אָמַר רַבָּה, אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְאִם הָיוֹ תִהְיֶה לְאִישׁ וּנְדָרֶיהָ עָלֶיהָ״. מִכָּאן לְנַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה שֶׁאָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ. אֵימָא הַאי קְרָא בִּנְשׂוּאָה כְּתִיב!
human_translation: And a betrothed young woman, her father and her husband nullify her vows. From where do we Rabba said: The verse states: “And if she be to a husband, and her vows are upon her… From here with regard to a betrothed young woman that her father and her husband nullify her vows. say this verse is written with regard to a married
llm_translation: The betrothed maiden, her father and her husband annul her vows, from where? Rabba said, Scripture says: "And if she shall be to a man, and her vows shall be upon her." From here we learn that the betrothed maiden, whose father and husband annul her vows. Say, perhaps this verse is written regarding a married woman!

hebrew_text: אִי מִשּׁוּם נְשׂוּאָה, קְרָא אַחֲרִינָא כְּתִיב: ״וְאִם בֵּית אִישָׁהּ נָדָרָה״. אֵימָא תַּרְוַיְיהוּ בִּנְשׂוּאָה?! וְכִי תֵּימָא תְּרֵי קְרָאֵי בִּנְשׂוּאָה לְמָה לִי — לְמֵימַר שֶׁאֵין הַבַּעַל מֵיפֵר בְּקוֹדְמִין.
human_translation: if due to a married woman, a different verse is written “And if vowed in her husband’s house” Say both with regard to a married woman. And if you would say: Why do I two verses with regard to a married woman? to say that the husband cannot nullify earlier
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If because of marriage, another verse is written: "And if in her husband's house she vowed." Say both in marriage?! And if you say, why do I need two verses about marriage — to say that the husband does not annul vows made in advance.

hebrew_text: וְלָאו מִמֵּילָא שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ?
human_translation: And do you not learn it by itself,
llm_translation: And not from the word itself did you hear its type?

hebrew_text: אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא, דַּהֲוָיָה קִדּוּשִׁין מַשְׁמַע.
human_translation: if you wish, say that “she be” indicates betrothal
llm_translation: If you ask, say, that it would be considered Kiddushin.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא אָב לְחוֹדֵיהּ מֵיפֵר! אִם כֵּן ״וְאָסְרָה אִסָּר בֵּית אָבִיהָ״, ״יָנִיא אוֹתָהּ״ לְמָה לִי? הַשְׁתָּא יֵשׁ לוֹמַר בִּמְקוֹם אָרוּס מֵיפֵר אָב לְחוֹדֵיהּ, שֶׁלֹּא בִּמְקוֹם אָרוּס, מִיבַּעְיָא?
human_translation: Say a father can nullify on his own. If so, why do I she binds herself with a bond in her father’s house, disallow her, Now it can be said in the presence of a betrothed, father nullifies on his own, is necessary where there is no betrothed?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima av l'chodeih meifar! Im ken 'v'osra isar beit avia', 'yania otah' l'mah li? Hashta yesh lomar bimkom arus meifar av l'chodeih, shelo bimkom arus, mibaya?"

hebrew_text: אֵימָא אָב לִיבְעֵי אָרוּס, וְאָרוּס לְחוֹדֵיהּ מֵיפֵר. וְכִי תֵּימָא: אָב דִּכְתַב רַחֲמָנָא לְמָה לִי, מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ דְּאִי הֵקִים — הֵקִים!
human_translation: Say the father requires the betrothed’s but the betrothed can nullify on his own. And if you would say: why do I father that the Merciful One writes is necessary that if ratified ratified,
llm_translation: Father may want to annul the betrothal, but the betrothed can annul it on his own. And if you say: If the father wrote, "Why do I need mercy?" - he needs it, for if he established it, he established it!

hebrew_text: אִם כֵּן, ״בֵּית אִישָׁהּ נָדָרָה״ לְמַאי כְּתִב? קַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה בִּמְקוֹם אָב אָרוּס מֵיפֵר לְחוֹדֵיהּ, שֶׁלֹּא בִּמְקוֹם אָב מִיבַּעְיָא?!
human_translation: If so, for what did write she vowed in her husband’s house” an a fortiori If in the presence of the father, a betrothed man nullifies on his own, when no in the presence of the father, is it necessary
llm_translation: "If so, 'a woman's vow in her father's house' - for what did he write? A fortiori: And if in the case where a father can annul his daughter's vow, how much more so in a case where there is no father present is it necessary?!"

hebrew_text: אֵימָא: ״אִם בֵּית אִישָׁהּ נָדָרָה״, לוֹמַר שֶׁאֵין הַבַּעַל מֵיפֵר בְּקוֹדְמִין!
human_translation: Say “And if she vowed in her husband’s house” to say, that the husband cannot nullify preceded
llm_translation: Mother: "If a woman makes a vow in her husband's house," to say that the husband does not annul vows made in advance!

hebrew_text: וּמִינֵּיהּ, אָרוּס מֵיפֵר בְּקוֹדְמִין.
human_translation: But from that, the betrothed can nullify preceded
llm_translation: And from its types, a betrothed one annuls with precedence.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו מִשּׁוּם שׁוּתָּפוּתֵיהּ דְּאָב.
human_translation: Rather, is it not because of his partnership with the father?
llm_translation: Rather, not because of partnership of a father.

hebrew_text: דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל תָּנָא: ״בֵּין אִישׁ לְאִשְׁתּוֹ בֵּין אָב לְבִתּוֹ״, מִכָּאן לְנַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה שֶׁאָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ. וּלְתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, ״אִם הָיוֹ תִהְיֶה לְאִישׁ״ מַאי עָבֵיד לֵיהּ?
human_translation: The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught between a man and his wife, between a father and his daughter, From here with regard to a betrothed young woman that her father and her husband nullify her vows. And according to the tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, what does he do if she be to a husband”
llm_translation: In the school of Rabbi Yishmael, it was taught: "Between a man and his wife, between a father and his daughter," from here to a betrothed maiden whose father and husband annul her vows. And according to the Tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, "If she will be for a man," what can be done for her?

hebrew_text: מוֹקֵים לְאִידַּךְ דְּרָבָא. וְרָבָא, הַאי דְּתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל מַאי עָבֵיד לֵיהּ? מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לוֹמַר שֶׁהַבַּעַל מֵיפֵר נְדָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ.
human_translation: establishes to other of Rava And Rava, what does he do with this that the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught He requires that to say that the husband can nullify vows that are between him and her,
llm_translation: Establish for the other, Rava. And Rava, this that is taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael, what does he do with it? He requires it to say that the husband annuls vows between him and her.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: בַּעַל מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז, אוֹ מִקְלָישׁ קָלֵישׁ? הֵיכָא קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לַן: כְּגוֹן דִּנְדַרָה מִתְּרֵין זֵיתִין וּשְׁמַע אָרוּס וְהֵיפֵר לַהּ, וַאֲכַלְתִּנּוּן.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before a husband sever or weaken which do we raise the dilemma, where she vowed from two olives, and betrothed heard and nullified for her, and ate those
llm_translation: He asked them: Does one separate with a Ba'al Migaz or with a Kalish? Where is he asking us: For example, if one vows to abstain from olives and hears an engagement and annuls it, and they ate them.

hebrew_text: אִי אָמְרִינַן מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז — לָקְיָיא. אִי אָמְרִינַן מִקְלָישׁ קָלֵישׁ — אִיסּוּרָא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא. מַאי?
human_translation: If we say severs is flogged If we say weakens is merely a prohibition what
llm_translation: If we say "from a winepress come forth wine" - it is fitting. If we say "from a palm branch comes forth a palm branch" - it is a mere prohibition. What is the reason?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אֵימָתַי אָמְרוּ מֵת הַבַּעַל נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לָאָב — בִּזְמַן שֶׁלֹּא שָׁמַע הַבַּעַל קוֹדֶם שֶׁיָּמוּת, אוֹ שֶׁשָּׁמַע וְשָׁתַק, אוֹ שֶׁשָּׁמַע וְהֵפֵר וּמֵת בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם. זוֹ הִיא שֶׁשָּׁנִינוּ: מֵת הַבַּעַל נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לָאָב.
human_translation: Come hear When did they say the husband dies, authority reverts to the father, when the husband had not heard before he died; or where he heard and was silent; or where he heard and nullified and died on the same day. This is what we learned the husband dies, authority reverts to the father.
llm_translation: Come and hear: When did they say that if the husband dies, the wife is released from the authority of the father-in-law? When the husband did not hear before he died, or he heard and remained silent, or he heard and annulled the vow, and died on that day. This is what we learned: if the husband dies, the wife is released from the authority of the father-in-law.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל אִם שָׁמַע וְקִיֵּים, אוֹ שֶׁשָּׁמַע וְשָׁתַק וּמֵת בַּיּוֹם שֶׁלְּאַחֲרָיו — אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: But if heard and ratified or where he heard, and was silent, and died on the following day, cannot nullify
llm_translation: But if he heard and fulfilled, or if he heard and remained silent and died on the following day - he cannot annul.

hebrew_text: שָׁמַע אָבִיהָ וְהֵפֵר לָהּ, וְלֹא הִסְפִּיק בַּעַל לִשְׁמוֹעַ עַד שֶׁמֵּת הָאָב — זוֹ הִיא שֶׁשָּׁנִינוּ: מֵת הָאָב, לֹא נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לַבַּעַל. שָׁמַע בַּעְלָהּ וְהֵפֵר לָהּ, וְלֹא הִסְפִּיק הָאָב לִשְׁמוֹעַ עַד שֶׁמֵּת הַבַּעַל — זוֹ הִיא שֶׁשָּׁנִינוּ: מֵת הַבַּעַל, נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לָאָב.
human_translation: her father heard and nullified for her but the husband did not manage to hear before the father died, this is what we learned the father dies, the authority does not revert to the husband, her husband heard and nullified for her, and the father did not manage to hear before the husband died, this is what we learned If the husband dies, the authority reverts to the father.
llm_translation: Heard her father and annulled for her, and the husband did not have the opportunity to hear until the father died - this is what we learned: when the father died, the husband's authority is not removed. Heard her husband and annulled for her, and the father did not have the opportunity to hear until the husband died - this is what we learned: when the husband died, the father's authority is removed.

hebrew_text: שָׁמַע בַּעְלָהּ וְהֵפֵר לָהּ, וְלֹא הִסְפִּיק הָאָב לִשְׁמוֹעַ עַד שֶׁמֵּת — אֵין הַבַּעַל יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר, שֶׁאֵין הַבַּעַל מֵיפֵר אֶלָּא בְּשׁוּתָּפוּת.
human_translation: her husband heard and nullified for her, and the father did not manage to hear before he died, the husband cannot nullify as the husband can nullify only in partnership
llm_translation: Heard her husband and annulled for her, and did not suffice the father to hear until he died - the husband cannot annul, for the husband only annuls with consent.

hebrew_text: שָׁמַע אָבִיהָ וְהֵפֵר לָהּ, וְלֹא הִסְפִּיק הַבַּעַל לִשְׁמוֹעַ עַד שֶׁמֵּת — חוֹזֵר הָאָב וּמֵפֵר חֶלְקוֹ שֶׁל בַּעַל. אָמַר רַבִּי נָתָן: הֵן הֵן דִּבְרֵי בֵּית שַׁמַּאי. בֵּית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: her father heard and nullified for her, and the husband did not manage to hear before he died, the father may go back and nullify husband’s portion, Rabbi Natan said: This is the statement of Beit Shammai, Beit Hillel say he cannot nullify
llm_translation: Heard her father and annulled for her, and the husband did not have the opportunity to hear until she died - the father goes back and annuls the portion of the husband. Rabbi Natan said: These are the words of Beit Shammai. Beit Hillel say: He cannot annul.

hebrew_text: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: לְבֵית שַׁמַּאי מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז, לְבֵית הִלֵּל מִקְלָשׁ קָלֵישׁ. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Conclude from this according to Beit Shammai, severs according to Beit Hillel, weakens Conclude from this
llm_translation: Listen to the conclusion: Beit Shammai prohibits mixing wine with oil, Beit Hillel permits mixing vinegar with oil. Listen to the conclusion.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָבָא: יֵשׁ שְׁאֵלָה בְּהָקֵם, אוֹ אֵין שְׁאֵלָה בְּהָקֵם? אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר יֵשׁ שְׁאֵלָה בְּהָקֵם: יֵשׁ שְׁאֵלָה בְּהָפֵר, אוֹ אֵין שְׁאֵלָה בְּהָפֵר?
human_translation: Rava raises a dilemma: Is there a request about ratification or is there no a request about ratification if you say a request to ratification, is there a request about nullification Or is there no a request to nullification
llm_translation: Question of Rava: Is there a question in establishment, or is there no question in establishment? If you will find to say there is a question in establishment: Is there a question in nullification, or is there no question in nullification?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: נִשְׁאָלִין עַל הֶהָקֵם, וְאֵין נִשְׁאָלִין עַל הֶהָפֵר.
human_translation: Come hear which Rabbi Yoḥanan says: may be requested to ratification but may not be requested to nullification.
llm_translation: Come and hear, for Rabbi Yochanan said: We inquire about establishment, but we do not inquire about nullification.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבָּה: ״קַיָּים לִיכִי, קַיָּים לִיכִי״, וְנִשְׁאַל עַל הֲקָמָה רִאשׁוֹנָה, מַהוּ?
human_translation: Rabba asks: It is ratified for you, it is ratified for you, and was requested about the first ratification what is
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ravah: "kayam lichi, kayam lichi," ve'nish'al al ha'kamah rishonah, mahhu? Ravah asked: "It stands for me, it stands for me," and he was asked about the first resurrection, what is it?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רָבָא: אִם נִשְׁאַל עַל הָרִאשׁוֹנָה — שְׁנִיָּה חָלָה עָלָיו. בָּעֵי רַבָּה: ״קַיָּים לִיכִי, וּמוּפָר לִיכִי, וְלָא תֵּיחוּל הֲקָמָה אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן חָלָה הֲפָרָה״, מַהוּ?
human_translation: Come hear which Rava said If was requested to the first second goes into effect for him. Rabba asks: ratified for you and nullified for you, and the ratification will not take effect unless the nullification takes effect, what is
llm_translation: Come and hear, for Rava said: If one was asked about the first matter — a second question arises upon him. Rabba inquired: "Is it established for you, and is it nullified for you, and do you not anticipate revival except if the cow miscarried?" What is the ruling?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע מִפְּלוּגְתָּא דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי. דִּתְנַן: ״הֲרֵי זוֹ תְּמוּרַת עוֹלָה תְּמוּרַת שְׁלָמִים״ — הֲרֵי זוֹ תְּמוּרַת עוֹלָה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: אִם לְכָךְ נִתְכַּוֵּין מִתְּחִלָּה, הוֹאִיל וְאִי אֶפְשָׁר לִקְרוֹת שְׁנֵי שֵׁמוֹת כְּאֶחָד — דְּבָרָיו קַיָּימִין.
human_translation: Come hear from the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei, as we learned This is hereby a substitute for a burnt-offering, a substitute for a peace-offering, it becomes a substitute for a burnt-offering; the statement of Rabbi Meir, And Rabbi Yosei says: If this is what he intended from the outset, since it is impossible to give it two names at once his statement is effective,
llm_translation: Come and hear a dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei. For it was taught: "Behold, this is a substitution of a burnt offering, a substitution of a peace offering" - this is a substitution of a burnt offering, according to the words of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Yosei says: If that is the case, it should have been intended from the beginning, since it is impossible to read two names as one - his words stand.

hebrew_text: וַאֲפִילּוּ רַבִּי מֵאִיר לָא קָאָמַר, דְּלָא אָמַר ״לָא תֵּיחוּל זוֹ אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן חָלָה זוֹ״, אֲבָל הָכָא דְּאָמַר ״לֹא תֵּיחוּל הֲקָמָה אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן חָלָה הֲפָרָה״ — רַבִּי מֵאִיר נָמֵי מוֹדֶה דַּהֲפָרָה חָלָה.
human_translation: And even Rabbi Meir says where he did not state: This will not take effect unless this takes effect. Here, however, where he said: The ratification will not take effect unless the nullification takes effect, even Rabbi Meir concedes that the nullification takes effect.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Even Rabbi Meir did not say, for he did not say, "Do not expect this unless this one is sick," but here, where he said, "Do not expect the standing unless the cow is sick" - Rabbi Meir also agrees that the cow is sick.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבָּה: ״קַיָּים וּמוּפָר לִיכִי״ בְּבַת אַחַת, מַהוּ? תָּא שְׁמַע דְּאָמַר רַבָּה: כׇּל דָּבָר שֶׁאֵינוֹ בְּזֶה אַחַר זֶה, אֲפִילּוּ בְּבַת אַחַת אֵינוֹ.
human_translation: Rabba asks: It is ratified and nullified for you simultaneously, what is Come hear which Rabba said: Any that is not sequentially are not even simultaneously.
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ravah: "Kaiyam uMufr lichi" bevat achad, mah? Ta shma de'amar Ravah: Kol davar she'eino beze achar ze, afilu bevat achad einu.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבָּה: ״קַיָּים לִיכִי הַיּוֹם״, מַהוּ? מִי אָמְרִינַן: כְּמַאן דַּאֲמַר לַהּ ״מוּפָר לִיכִי לְמָחָר״, אוֹ דִלְמָא הָא לָא אֲמַר לַהּ?
human_translation: Rabba raises dilemma: is ratified for you today, what is Do we say like one who said to her: It is nullified for you tomorrow? Or perhaps, he did not say to her
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ravah: "Kaiyam lichi hayom," mah hu? Mi amrinan: ke'man d'amar lah "mufar lichi l'machar," o dilma ha la amar lah?

hebrew_text: אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר הָא לָא אֲמַר לַהּ, אֲמַר לַהּ ״מוּפָר לִיכִי לְמָחָר״, מַהוּ? מִי אָמְרִינַן: לִמְחַר לָא מָצֵי מֵיפַר, דְּהָא קַיְּימֵיהּ לְנִדְרַיהּ הַיּוֹם, אוֹ דִלְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּלָא אֲמַר לַהּ ״קַיָּים לִיכִי הַיּוֹם״, כִּי קָאָמַר לַהּ ״מוּפָר לִיכִי לְמָחָר״, מֵהַיּוֹם קָאָמַר.
human_translation: If you say he did not say to her he said to her: It is nullified for you tomorrow, what is Do we say on the following day he cannot nullify as he has ratified the vow today, Or perhaps, since he did not say to her: It is ratified for you today, when he says to her: It is nullified for you tomorrow, he is saying from today,
llm_translation: If you find him saying, "Here, I did not say to her," and he said to her, "I am nullifying it for tomorrow," what is the ruling? Do we say: Tomorrow he cannot nullify it, for he upheld his vow today, or perhaps: since he did not say to her, "I am upholding it today," when he said to her, "I am nullifying it for tomorrow," he is speaking from today.

hebrew_text: וְאִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר אֲפִילּוּ הָכִי, כֵּיוָן דְּקִיְּימוֹ הַיּוֹם — לִמְחַר כְּמַאן דְּאִיתֵיהּ דָּמֵי, אֲמַר לַהּ ״קַיָּים לִיכִי שָׁעָה״, מַהוּ? מִי אָמְרִינַן: כְּמַאן דַּאֲמַר לַהּ ״מוּפָר לִיכִי לְאַחַר שָׁעָה״ דָּמֵי, אוֹ דִלְמָא: הָא לָא אֲמַר לָהּ?
human_translation: And if you say: Nevertheless, since he ratified it today, on the following day it is considered in force he said to her: It is ratified for you an hour, what is Do we say like one who said to her: It is nullified for you after an hour Or perhaps, he did not say to her
llm_translation: "And if you should find to say even so, since he fulfilled the day - tomorrow, like one who has it, he said to her, 'I am established for an hour,' what is the ruling? Do we say that it is like one who said to her, 'I am annulled for after an hour,' or perhaps he did not say to her?"

hebrew_text: אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר הָא לָא אֲמַר לַהּ, מִיהוּ אֲמַר לַהּ, מַאי? מִי אָמְרִינַן: כֵּיוָן דְּקִיְּימוֹ קִיְּימוֹ, אוֹ דִלְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּכוּלֵּיהּ יוֹמָא בַּר הֲקָמָה וּבַר הֲפָרָה הוּא, כִּי אָמַר ״מוּפָר לִיכִי לְאַחַר שָׁעָה״ מַהְנֵי?
human_translation: If you say that he did not say to her still, he said to her what Do we say since he has ratified this he has ratified it Or, perhaps since the entire day is valid for ratification and valid for nullification, when he says: It is nullified for you after an hour, is effective.
llm_translation: If you find to say "Ha la" he said to her, who said to her, what? Who do we say: since they established, they established, or perhaps: since all the day is a time of sunrise and a time of sunset, for he said, "It is permissible to eat after an hour," what is the law?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה״, וְשָׁמַע בַּעְלָהּ וְאָמַר ״וַאֲנִי״ — אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. וְאַמַּאי? נֵימָא ״וַאֲנִי״ דְּאָמַר הוּא עַל נַפְשֵׁיהּ דְּהָוֵי נָזִיר, אֲבָל ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה״ דִּילַהּ, דְּשָׁעָה אַחַת קַיְּימָא, לְאַחַר שָׁעָה אִי בָּעֵי — לֵיפַר, אַמַּאי אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר? לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּכֵיוָן שֶׁקִּיְּימוֹ — קִיְּימוֹ? לָא, קָסָבַר: כֹּל ״וַאֲנִי״ — כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר ״קַיָּים לִיכִי לְעוֹלָם״ דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Come hear: I am hereby a nazirite, and her husband heard and said: And I, he can no nullify And why Let us say that And I, that he said to himself, that he should be a nazirite. But her I am hereby a nazirite, After an hour, if he wants to nullify why can he not nullify not because once he has ratified it he has ratified it No, holds anyone And I, is like one who says: It is ratified for you forever.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Come and hear: 'Behold, I am a Nazirite,' and her husband heard and said, 'And I' — he cannot annul. And why? Say, 'And I,' for he said it upon himself that he should be a Nazirite, but 'Behold, I am a Nazirite' of hers, since it stands for one hour, if he wants to annul after an hour, he may annul. And why can he not annul? Is it not because since he established it, has he established it? No, he holds: every 'And I' is like one who says, 'I am established forever,' it is as if he said."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מֵת הָאָב — לֹא נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לַבַּעַל. מֵת הַבַּעַל — נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לָאָב. בָּזֶה יִפָּה כֹּחַ הָאָב מִכֹּחַ הַבַּעַל.
human_translation: the father dies, authority does not revert to the husband, the husband dies, authority reverts to the father, In this the power of the father is enhanced relative to the power of the husband.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If the father dies, the husband does not lose his rights. If the husband dies, the father loses his rights. In this case, the power of the father is greater than the power of the husband.

hebrew_text: בְּדָבָר אַחֵר יִפָּה כֹּחַ הַבַּעַל מִכֹּחַ הָאָב: שֶׁהַבַּעַל מֵפֵר בִּבְגָר, וְהָאָב אֵינוֹ מֵפֵר בִּבְגָר.
human_translation: In another matter, the power of the husband is enhanced relative to the power of the father, as the husband nullifies during adulthood, whereas the father does not nullify during adulthood.
llm_translation: In another matter, the strength of the husband is greater than the strength of the father, for the husband annuls with a mature object, while the father does not annul with a mature object.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַאי טַעְמָא — דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״בִּנְעֻרֶיהָ בֵּית אָבִיהָ״.
human_translation: What is the reason, that the verse states: “Being in her youth, in her father’s house”
llm_translation: Gemara: What is the reason? - Because the verse says, "In her youth, the house of her father."

hebrew_text: מֵת הַבַּעַל נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לָאָב מְנָלַן? אָמַר רַבָּה: דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״וְאִם הָיוֹ תִהְיֶה לְאִישׁ וּנְדָרֶיהָ עָלֶיהָ״ —
human_translation: From where do we the husband died authority reverts to the father? Rabba said: that the verse states: “And if she be [ hayo tihyeh ] to a husband, and her vows are upon her”
llm_translation: The husband died, does the permission of the father-in-law help us? Rabba said: As the verse says, "And if she was to a man, and her vows were upon her."

hebrew_text: מַקִּישׁ קוֹדְמֵי הֲוָיָה שְׁנִיָּה לְקוֹדְמֵי הֲוָיָה רִאשׁוֹנָה. מָה קוֹדְמֵי הֲוָיָה רִאשׁוֹנָה — אָב מֵיפַר לְחוֹדֵיהּ, אַף קוֹדְמֵי הֲוָיָה שְׁנִיָּה — אָב מֵיפַר לְחוֹדֵיהּ.
human_translation: juxtaposes preceding second being to those preceding first being Just as preceding first being father nullifies on his own, so too, those preceding second being father nullifies on his own.
llm_translation: He juxtaposes one that was first to one that was second. Just as the one that was first nullifies its counterpart, so too the one that was second nullifies its counterpart.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי בִּנְדָרִים שֶׁלֹּא נִרְאוּ לָאָרוּס. אֲבָל בִּנְדָרִים שֶׁנִּרְאוּ לָאָרוּס — לָא מָצֵי מֵיפַר אָב!
human_translation: Say this applies to vows that were not disclosed to the betrothed, but with regard to vows that were disclosed to the betrothed, father cannot nullify
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima hanei milay bin'darim shelo nir'u la'arus. Aval bin'darim she'nir'u la'arus - la matzei meifar av!" English translation: "Say these words regarding vows that were not seen by the betrothed. But vows that were seen by the betrothed - one cannot annul!"

hebrew_text: אִי בִּנְדָרִים שֶׁלֹּא נִרְאוּ לָאָרוּס — מִ״בִּנְעֻרֶיהָ בֵּית אָבִיהָ״ נָפְקָא.
human_translation: If to vows that were not disclosed to the betrothed, is derived from “being in her youth, in her father’s house”
llm_translation: If with vows that were not seen by the betrothed - "from her youth in her father's house" is derived.

hebrew_text: בָּזֶה יִפָּה כֹּחַ הָאָב מִכֹּחַ הַבַּעַל כּוּ׳. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי?
human_translation: In this the power of the father is enhanced relative to the power of the husband. What are the circumstances
llm_translation: This is similar to the strength of the father compared to the strength of the husband. How so?

hebrew_text: אִילֵּימָא שֶׁקִּידְּשָׁהּ כְּשֶׁהִיא נַעֲרָה, וּבָגְרָה. מִכְּדֵי מִיתָה מוֹצִיאָה, וּבַגְרוּת מוֹצִיאָה מֵרְשׁוּת אָב. מָה מִיתָה — לֹא נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לַבַּעַל, אַף בַּגְרוּת — לֹא נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לַבַּעַל!
human_translation: If we say where he betrothed her when she was a young woman, and she reached majority, After all, death removes her and majority removes her from the father’s authority, Just as death authority does not revert to the husband so too, majority authority does not revert to the husband.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Firstly, that she was consecrated when she was a young girl, and she became an adult. From the time she reaches maturity, she is removed from her father's authority, and from adulthood she is removed from her father's authority. Just as in the case of maturity - her husband's authority is not removed, so too in the case of adulthood - her husband's authority is not removed!"

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא שֶׁקִּידְּשָׁהּ כְּשֶׁהִיא בּוֹגֶרֶת — הָא תְּנֵינָא חֲדָא זִימְנָא: הַבּוֹגֶרֶת שֶׁשָּׁהֲתָה שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ?
human_translation: Rather, which he betrothed her when she was a grown woman, The Gemara asks: Didn’t we learn on another occasion, a grown woman who waited twelve months
llm_translation: Rather, that he sanctified her when she was a virgin - but didn't we learn once: A virgin who has reached twelve months?

hebrew_text: הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא: אָמְרַתְּ הַבּוֹגֶרֶת שֶׁשָּׁהֲתָה שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ, בְּבוֹגֶרֶת לְמָה לִי שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ? בּוֹגֶרֶת בִּשְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם סַגִּי לַהּ! תָּנֵי: בּוֹגֶרֶת, וְשֶׁשָּׁהֲתָה שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ.
human_translation: This is itself difficult: You said a grown woman who waited twelve With regard to a grown woman, why do I a twelve-month a grown woman, thirty days suffice for her Teach A grown woman and who waited twelve months.
llm_translation: The matter is difficult: The Bogeret said that she waited twelve months, why do I need twelve months for a Bogeret? A Bogeret is sufficient with thirty days! It was taught: A Bogeret, and she waited twelve months.

hebrew_text: מִכׇּל מָקוֹם קַשְׁיָא! אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: הָכָא דַּוְקָא, וּבוֹגֶרֶת קָתָנֵי הָתָם מִשּׁוּם דְּבָעֵי אִיפְּלוֹגֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר וְרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: In any case, difficult. If you wish, say here actually and a grown woman is taught there because wants Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis disagree.
llm_translation: From every place it is difficult! If you wish, say: Here specifically, and the young girl is mentioned there because they require the dispute of Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: בּוֹגֶרֶת דַּוְקָא. וְאַיְּידֵי דְּנָסֵיב רֵישָׁא ״בָּזֶה״ — נָסֵיב סֵיפָא נָמֵי ״בָּזֶה״.
human_translation: if you wish, say A grown woman, actually since it needs to cite the first clause: In this cites latter clause In this
llm_translation: If you ask: specifically a "bogeret." And since the beginning states "with this" - the end also states "with this."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ נָדְרָה וְהִיא אֲרוּסָה. נִתְגָּרְשָׁה בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם, נִתְאָרְסָה בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם, אֲפִילּוּ לְמֵאָה — אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ הָאַחֲרוֹן מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ. זֶה הַכְּלָל: כֹּל שֶׁלֹּא יָצְאָה לִרְשׁוּת עַצְמָהּ שָׁעָה אַחַת — אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ הָאַחֲרוֹן מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ.
human_translation: she took a vow as a betrothed woman was divorced on the same day, she was betrothed on the same day even to one hundred her father and her last husband nullify her vows. This is the principle: any who has not left into her own jurisdiction for one moment, her father and her final husband nullify her vows.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: If a woman made a vow while she was engaged. If she was divorced on that same day, or if she got married on that same day, even if it is to a hundred men, her father and her last husband annul her vows. This is the principle: as long as she has not had a moment to herself - her father and her last husband annul her vows.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָלַן דְּאָרוּס אַחֲרוֹן מֵיפֵר נְדָרִים שֶׁנִּרְאוּ לְאָרוּס רִאשׁוֹן? אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל, אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְאִם הָיוֹ תִהְיֶה לְאִישׁ וּנְדָרֶיהָ עָלֶיהָ״. נְדָרִים שֶׁהָיוּ עָלֶיהָ כְּבָר. דִּלְמָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי שֶׁלֹּא נִרְאוּ לְאָרוּס רִאשׁוֹן, אֲבָל נְדָרִים שֶׁנִּרְאוּ לְאָרוּס רִאשׁוֹן — לָא מָצֵי מֵיפַר אָרוּס אַחֲרוֹן!
human_translation: From where do we that final betrothed can nullify vows that were disclosed to the first betrothed? Shmuel said the verse states: “And if she be to a husband and her vows are upon vows that were upon her already. Perhaps this statement applies that were not discerned by the first betrothed, but vows that were discerned by the first betrothed, final betrothed cannot nullify.
llm_translation: Gemara: From where do we derive that if a woman was engaged to one man and then became engaged to another, the second fiancé can annul vows that were made when she was engaged to the first fiancé? Shmuel said, the verse states: "And if she is married to a man, and her vows are upon her." Vows that were already upon her. Perhaps these matters were not seen by the first fiancé, but vows that were seen by the first fiancé - the last fiancé cannot annul them!

hebrew_text: ״עָלֶיהָ״ קְרָא יַתִּירָא הוּא.
human_translation: “upon her” is a superfluous verse.
llm_translation: "Upon it" Scripture extra it is.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דִּשְׁמוּאֵל: נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה — אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ, כֵּיצַד? שָׁמַע אָבִיהָ וְהֵפֵר לָהּ, וְלֹא הִסְפִּיק הַבַּעַל לִשְׁמוֹעַ עַד שֶׁמֵּת, וְנִתְאָרְסָה בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם, וַאֲפִילּוּ מֵאָה פְּעָמִים — אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ הָאַחֲרוֹן מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ. שָׁמַע בַּעְלָהּ וְהֵפֵר לָהּ, וְלֹא הִסְפִּיק הָאָב לִשְׁמוֹעַ עַד שֶׁמֵּת הַבַּעַל — חוֹזֵר הָאָב וּמֵפֵר חֶלְקוֹ שֶׁל בַּעַל.
human_translation: It is taught in accordance with of Shmuel: a betrothed young woman, her father and her husband nullify her vows. How so? her father heard and nullified for her, and the husband did not manage to hear before he died, and she was betrothed on the same day or even one hundred times her father and her final husband nullify her vows. her husband heard and nullified for her, and the father did not manage to hear before the husband died, the father may go back and nullify husband’s portion.
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Shmuel: A betrothed maiden—her father and her husband annul her vows. How so? If her father heard and annulled the vow for her, and her husband did not have the opportunity to hear the vow until he died, and she became betrothed to another on that day, even a hundred times—her father and her last husband annul her vows. If her husband heard and annulled the vow for her, and her father did not have the opportunity to hear the vow until the death of the husband—her father returns and annuls the portion of the husband.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי נָתָן: הֵן הֵן דִּבְרֵי בֵּית שַׁמַּאי. אֲבָל בֵּית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. בְּמַאי פְּלִיגִי?
human_translation: Rabbi Natan said: This is the statement of Beit Shammai, However, Beit Hillel say cannot nullify About what disagree?
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Natan: Yes, yes, the words of Beit Shammai. But Beit Hillel says: He cannot annul. In what do they argue?

hebrew_text: בֵּית שַׁמַּאי סָבְרִי: נְדָרִים נָמֵי שֶׁרָאוּי לָאָרוּס, נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לָאָב, וּמִיגָּז גָּיֵיז. בֵּית הִלֵּל סָבְרִי: אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ אַחֲרוֹן מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ, וְלָא מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז.
human_translation: Beit Shammai hold: Even vows that were disclosed to the betrothed, authority reverts to the father. he severs Beit Hillel hold her father and her final husband nullify her vows, and he does not sever
llm_translation: House of Shammai holds: Vows that are fitting for a betrothed woman, her father can annul, and from the time of betrothal, her husband. House of Hillel holds: Her father and her last husband can annul her vows, but not from the time of betrothal.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: גֵּירוּשִׁין כִּשְׁתִיקָה דָּמְיָא, אוֹ כַּהֲקָמָה דָּמְיָא?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before divorce like silence, or like ratification
llm_translation: He asked them: Is divorce like silence, or is it like standing?

hebrew_text: לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? כְּגוֹן שֶׁנָּדְרָה וְשָׁמַע בַּעְלָהּ וְגֵרְשָׁהּ, וְאַהְדְּרַהּ בְּיוֹמֵיהּ. אִי אָמַר מָר כִּשְׁתִיקָה דָּמֵי, מָצֵי מֵיפַר לַהּ. וְאִי אָמַר מָר כַּהֲקָמָה דָּמֵי, לָא מָצֵי מֵיפַר לַהּ.
human_translation: What is difference in where she took a vow, and her husband heard and divorced her, and he remarried her on the same day. If the Master says like silence, can nullify for her, But if the Master says like ratification, he cannot nullify for her,
llm_translation: For what case does it emerge? For example, if she vowed and her husband heard and divorced her, and she annulled it on that day. If the Master says it is like silence, he can annul it for her. And if the Master says it is like an enactment, he cannot annul it for her.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אֵימָתַי אָמְרוּ ״מֵת הַבַּעַל, נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לָאָב״ — בִּזְמַן שֶׁלֹּא שָׁמַע הַבַּעַל, אוֹ שָׁמַע וְהֵפֵר, אוֹ שָׁמַע וְשָׁתַק וּמֵת בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ גֵּירוּשִׁין כִּשְׁתִיקָה דָּמוּ, לִיתְנֵי נָמֵי ״אוֹ שָׁמַע וְגֵירַשׁ״! מִדְּלָא תָּנֵי הָכִי — שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ גֵּירוּשִׁין כַּהֲקָמָה דָּמוּ.
human_translation: Come hear When did they say the husband died authority reverts to the father? When the husband did not hear or he heard and nullified or heard and was silent, and died on that day. And if you say divorce is like silence, let also teach Or he heard and divorced From that he did not teach this learn from divorce is like ratification.
llm_translation: Come and hear: When did they say, "If the husband dies, the wife's permission is annulled"? - When the husband did not hear, or heard and annulled, or heard and remained silent and died on that day. And if you say, divorce is like silence, let it also teach, "or heard and divorced"! Since it did not teach this - divorce is like standing.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: אֲבָל אִם שָׁמַע וְקַיָּים, אוֹ שָׁמַע וְשָׁתַק וּמֵת בְּיוֹם שֶׁל אַחֲרָיו — אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ גֵּירוּשִׁין כַּהֲקָמָה דָּמוּ, לִיתְנֵי ״וְאִם שָׁמַע וְגֵירֵשׁ״! אֶלָּא מִדְּלָא קָתָנֵי הָכִי, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: גֵּירוּשִׁין כִּשְׁתִיקָה דָּמוּ.
human_translation: State the latter clause But if he heard and ratified or he heard and was silent, and died on the following day, cannot nullify But if you say divorce is like ratification, let teach: And if he heard and divorced Rather, from that does not teach this, learn from divorce is like silence.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: aval im shama v'kayam, o shama v'shatak u'met b'yom she'l achareiav - ein yachol l'hafair. V'ei amarta geirushin ka'hakamah damu, litnei 'v'im shama v'geirash'! Ela mid'la katanai hachi, shema minah: geirushin kishetikah damu." English translation: "Say the latter clause: but if he heard and fulfilled, or heard and remained silent and died on the following day - he cannot annul. And if you say that divorce is like establishing, let it teach 'and if he heard and divorced'! Rather, since it did not teach thus, infer from it: divorce is like silence."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מֵהָא לֵיכָּא לְמִשְׁמַע מִינֵּיהּ. אִי רֵישָׁא דַּוְקָא — נָסֵיב סֵיפָא מִשּׁוּם רֵישָׁא. אִי סֵיפָא דַּוְקָא — נָסֵיב רֵישָׁא מִשּׁוּם סֵיפָא.
human_translation: Rather, one cannot learn from this If the first clause precisely, formulates the last clause because of the first clause, If the last clause precisely, formulates the first clause because of the last clause,
llm_translation: Rather, from here we can infer his intention. If the beginning specifically - we derive the end from the beginning. If the end specifically - we derive the beginning from the end.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: נָדְרָה וְהִיא אֲרוּסָה, וְנִתְגָּרְשָׁה וְנִתְאָרְסָה בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם, אֲפִילּוּ לְמֵאָה — אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ הָאַחֲרוֹן מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ גֵּירוּשִׁין כִּשְׁתִיקָה דָּמוּ, דְּאִי כַּהֲקָמָה דָּמוּ — מִי מָצֵי מֵיפַר אָרוּס אַחֲרוֹן נִידְרֵי דְּאוֹקֵים אָרוּס רִאשׁוֹן?
human_translation: Come hear she took a vow she was betrothed, and was divorced, and was betrothed on the same day, even to one hundred her father and her final husband nullify her vows. Learn from divorce is like silence, because if like ratification, could the final betrothed nullify vows that first betrothed had ratified?
llm_translation: Come and hear: If a woman vowed while she was engaged, and then she was divorced and remarried to him on the same day, even a hundred times - her father and her last husband annul her vows. Learn from this that divorces are like silence, for if his silence is effective, who can annul the vows of a woman who is engaged to another man while her first engagement is still valid?

hebrew_text: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן, בְּשֶׁלֹּא שָׁמַע אָרוּס רִאשׁוֹן. אִי הָכִי, מַאי אִירְיָא בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם? אֲפִילּוּ לְאַחַר מֵאָה יָמִים נָמֵי!
human_translation: With what are we dealing here? in which the first betrothed man did not hear If so, why specifically on that day? The same would hold true even after one hundred days as well.
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with what? With regard to the case of a first betrothed who did not hear. If so, what is the meaning of him during the day? Even after one hundred days, it is also valid!

hebrew_text: כְּשֶׁלֹּא שָׁמַע אָרוּס וְשָׁמַע הָאָב, דְּבוֹ בַּיּוֹם הוּא דְּמָצֵי מֵיפַר, אֲבָל מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ לֹא מָצֵי מֵיפַר.
human_translation: in which betrothed did not hear but the father heard As it is on the same day that he can nullify but he cannot nullify from this forward.
llm_translation: As he did not hear the betrothed and heard the father, the betrothal is valid on that day that it is found to be invalid, but from here and onwards it is not found to be invalid.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: נָדְרָה בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם, גֵּירְשָׁהּ וְהֶחְזִירָהּ בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם — אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: גֵּירוּשִׁין כַּהֲקָמָה דָּמוּ.
human_translation: Come hear she took a vow on that day, he divorced her and remarried her on the same day, he cannot nullify Learn from divorce is like ratification.
llm_translation: Listen: If he vowed upon her during the day, divorced her, and remarried her on the same day - he cannot annul it. Learn from it: Divorces are like the establishment of the world.

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: הָכָא בִּנְשׂוּאָה עָסְקִינַן, וְהַיְינוּ טַעְמָא דְּאֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר, מִשּׁוּם דְּאֵין הַבַּעַל מֵיפֵר בְּקוֹדְמִין.
human_translation: Say here, we are dealing with a married woman, and that is the reason that he cannot nullify because the husband cannot nullify that precede
llm_translation: They said: Here we are dealing with a case of marriage, and this is the reason why he cannot annul, because the husband does not annul with regard to previous vows.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ דֶּרֶךְ תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים, עַד שֶׁלֹּא הָיְתָה בִּתּוֹ יוֹצְאָה מֵאֶצְלוֹ, אוֹמֵר לָהּ: כׇּל נְדָרִים שֶׁנָּדַרְתְּ בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתִי — הֲרֵי הֵן מוּפָרִין. וְכֵן הַבַּעַל, עַד שֶׁלֹּא תִּכָּנֵס לִרְשׁוּתוֹ, אוֹמֵר לָהּ: כׇּל נְדָרִים שֶׁנָּדַרְתְּ עַד שֶׁלֹּא תִּכָּנְסִי לִרְשׁוּתִי — הֲרֵי הֵן מוּפָרִין. שֶׁמִּשֶּׁתִּכָּנֵס לִרְשׁוּתוֹ — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: The practice of Torah scholars before his daughter would leave him would say to her: All vows that you vowed in my house are hereby nullified. And similarly, the husband, before she would enter his jurisdiction, would say to her: All vows that you vowed before you entered my jurisdiction are hereby nullified. because once she enters his jurisdiction he cannot nullify
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: The way of the disciples of the sages is that until his daughter has not yet left his domain, he says to her: "All vows that you have vowed in my house are hereby annulled." Similarly, a husband, until she enters his domain, says to her: "All vows that you have vowed until you enter my domain are hereby annulled." Once she enters his domain, he cannot annul them.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ בָּעֵי רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: בַּעַל, מַהוּ שֶׁיָּפֵר בְּלֹא שְׁמִיעָה? ״וְשָׁמַע אִישָׁהּ״ דַּוְקָא הוּא, אוֹ לָאו דַּוְקָא הוּא?
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama asks: a husband, what is with regard nullifying without hearing “And her husband hears is specifically Or is not specifically
llm_translation: Gemara: Ramei son of Hama asked: Regarding a husband, what is the law if he annuls a vow without his wife's hearing? "And her husband heard" specifically, or not specifically?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא, תָּא שְׁמַע: דֶּרֶךְ תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים, עַד שֶׁלֹּא יָצָאת בִּתּוֹ מֵאֶצְלוֹ, אוֹמֵר לָהּ: כׇּל נְדָרִים שֶׁנָּדַרְתְּ בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתִי — הֲרֵי הֵן מוּפָרִין, וְהָא לָא שְׁמַע!
human_translation: Rava said: Come hear The practice of Torah scholars before his daughter would leave him would say to her: All vows that you vowed in my house are hereby nullified. But did not hear
llm_translation: Rava said, "Come and hear: The way of the disciples of the sages, until his daughter has not left his domain, he says to her: 'All vows that you vowed in my house - behold, they are annulled,' and this is not heard!"

hebrew_text: לְכִי שָׁמַע הוּא דְּמֵיפַר. אִם כֵּן, כִּי לָא שְׁמַע, לְמָה לֵיהּ לְמֵימַר? הָא קָמַשְׁמַע לַן: אוֹרְחֵיהּ דְּצוּרְבָּא מֵרַבָּנַן לְהַדּוֹרֵי.
human_translation: when he hear is when he nullifies If so, when he has not heard why for him to state This teaches us the practice of a Torah scholar to pursue
llm_translation: Go and hear, for it is similar. If so, because he did not hear, why did he need to say it? This is what he intended to tell us: the way of the rock from the Sages to the generations.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע מִסֵּיפָא: וְכֵן הַבַּעַל, עַד שֶׁלֹּא תִּכָּנֵס לִרְשׁוּתוֹ, אוֹמֵר לָהּ. הָכָא נָמֵי, דְּאָמַר לַהּ: ״לְכִי שָׁמַעְנָא״.
human_translation: Come hear from the latter clause And similarly, the husband, before she would enter his jurisdiction, would say to her: Here too, that he says to her: When I hear
llm_translation: Come and hear from the latter part: And similarly the husband, until she enters his domain, says to her. Here too, as he said to her: "Go, I have heard."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשְׁתּוֹ ״כׇּל נְדָרִים שֶׁתִּדּוֹרִי עַד שֶׁאָבֹא מִמָּקוֹם פְּלוֹנִי הֲרֵי הֵן קַיָּימִין״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם. ״הֲרֵי הֵן מוּפָרִין״, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: מוּפָר. וְהָא לָא שְׁמַע.
human_translation: Come hear One who says to his wife: All vows that you vow until I arrive from such and such a place are hereby ratified, has not said anything, are hereby nullified, Rabbi Eliezer says: nullified. But he did not hear
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Ta shema: ha'omer le'ishto 'kol nedarim shetidorai ad she'avo mimaqom ploni henei hen kayamim' - lo amar kelum. 'Henei hen mufarim', Rabbi Eliezer omer: mufar. Ve'ha la shema." English translation: "Come and hear: One who says to his wife, 'All vows that you will make are valid until I come from a certain place,' he has not said anything. 'They are nullified,' Rabbi Eliezer says: nullified. But isn't this a contradiction?"

hebrew_text: הָכָא נָמֵי, דְּאָמַר: ״לְכִי שָׁמַעְנָא״. וּלְמָה לִי מִן הַשְׁתָּא? לְכִי שָׁמַע לֵיפַר לַהּ! קָסָבַר: דִּלְמָא מִטְּרִידְנָא הָהִיא שַׁעְתָּא.
human_translation: Here too, that he says: When I hear But why do I from now; let him nullify for her when he hears He reasons: Perhaps I will be preoccupied at that moment
llm_translation: Here is the translation of the Talmudic text: Here it is stated, that he said: "Go and listen." And why do I need it now? Go and listen to refute it! He holds: perhaps we are disturbing her at that moment.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הָאוֹמֵר לְאַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס ״כׇּל נְדָרִים שֶׁנּוֹדֶרֶת אִשְׁתִּי מִכָּאן וְעַד שֶׁאָבֹא מִמָּקוֹם פְּלוֹנִי הָפֵר״, וְהֵפֵר לֵהּ, יָכוֹל יְהוּ מוּפָרִין — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אִישָׁהּ יְקִימֶנּוּ וְאִישָׁהּ יְפֵרֶנּוּ״. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה.
human_translation: Come hear one who says to a steward [ apotropos ] All vows that my wife vows from now until I arrive from such and such a place nullify, and nullified her, might they would be nullified. the verse states: “Her husband may ratify it, or her husband may nullify it” the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya.
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who says to his apotropos, "All vows that my wife vows from here until I come from a certain place, annul them," and he annuls them for her, can they be annulled? The Talmud teaches: "Her husband shall establish it, and her husband shall annul it." These are the words of Rabbi Yoshiyah.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: מָצִינוּ בְּכׇל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ שְׁלוּחוֹ שֶׁל אָדָם כְּמוֹתוֹ?
human_translation: Rabbi Yonatan said to him: We have found everywhere in the Torah a person’s agent is like himself.
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Yonatan: We found in all the Torah entirely his sending like his death?

hebrew_text: וַאֲפִילּוּ רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה לָא קָאָמַר אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דִּגְזֵירַת הַכָּתוּב הוּא ״אִישָׁהּ יְקִימֶנּוּ וְאִישָׁהּ יְפֵרֶנּוּ״, אֲבָל דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא שְׁלוּחוֹ שֶׁל אָדָם כְּמוֹתוֹ. וְהָא לָא שְׁמִיעַ לֵיהּ!
human_translation: And even Rabbi Yoshiya says only because it is a Torah edict, “her husband may ratify it, or her husband may nullify it” But to everyone, a person’s agent is like himself But were not heard by
llm_translation: Even Rabbi Yoshiyah did not say this, rather because of the decree of the verse: "Her husband may establish it, or her husband may annul it." But in all other cases, a person's messenger is like himself. And this is not heard!

hebrew_text: הָכָא נָמֵי, דְּאָמַר לֵיהּ: לְכִי שָׁמַעְנָא מֵיפַר לַהּ. לְכִי שָׁמַע לֵיפַר לַהּ? הוּא סָבַר: דִּלְמָא מִטְּרִידְנָא.
human_translation: Here too, in which says to When I hear will be nullified for her. Let him nullify for her when he hears He reasons: Perhaps I will be preoccupied
llm_translation: Here is the translation of the Talmudic text you provided: Talmudic text: Here, it is taught, that he said to him: "Go and hear from Iphar for her." Go and hear from Iphar for her? He thought: Perhaps we will be troubled.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: חֵרֵשׁ, מַהוּ שֶׁיָּפֵר לְאִשְׁתּוֹ? אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר בַּעַל מֵיפֵר בְּלֹא שְׁמִיעָה — מִשּׁוּם דְּבַר מִישְׁמַע הוּא, אֲבָל חֵרֵשׁ דְּלָאו בַּר מִישְׁמַע הוּא, הַיְינוּ דְּרַבִּי זֵירָא.
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama asks: a deaf man, what is with regard to his nullifying for his wife? If you say a husband can nullify without hearing because he is capable of hearing. But a deaf man, who is not capable of hearing, this is of Rabbi Zeira.
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ramei bar Ḥama asked: A deaf-mute, what can he do to fulfill his obligation to his wife? If you will say that a husband can fulfill his obligation without her hearing his words, because it is a matter that can be inferred, but a deaf-mute, who cannot infer meaning, that is the opinion of Rabbi Zeira.

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: כׇּל הָרָאוּי לְבִילָּה — אֵין בִּילָּה מְעַכֶּבֶת בּוֹ, וְכֹל שֶׁאֵין רָאוּי לְבִילָּה — בִּילָּה מְעַכֶּבֶת בּוֹ.
human_translation: As Rabbi Zeira said: any suitable for mingling mingling is not indispensable for it. But any not suitable for mingling, mingling is indispensable for it,
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: Anyone fit for intercourse - intercourse does not prevent him, and anyone not fit for intercourse - intercourse prevents him.

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִלְמָא: ״וְשָׁמַע אִישָׁהּ״ לָא מְעַכֵּב. אָמַר רָבָא: תָּא שְׁמַע ״וְשָׁמַע אִישָׁהּ״ — פְּרָט לְאֵשֶׁת חֵרֵשׁ. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Or perhaps “and her husband hears it” does not is indispensable Rava said: Come hear “And her husband hears it”; excludes the wife of a deaf man. Learn from
llm_translation: Or perhaps: "And he heard his wife" does not invalidate. Rava said: Come and hear "And he heard his wife" - excluding the wife of a deaf-mute. Learn from it.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: בַּעַל, מַהוּ שֶׁיָּפֵר לִשְׁתֵּי נָשָׁיו בְּבַת אַחַת? ״אוֹתָהּ״ דַּוְקָא, אוֹ לָאו דַּוְקָא?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before a husband, what is with regard to nullifying for his two wives simultaneously? her specifically Or, not specifically
llm_translation: He asked them: A husband, what is the law if he divorces both his wives at once? Specifically "her," or not specifically "her"?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבִינָא, תָּא שְׁמַע: אֵין מַשְׁקִין שְׁתֵּי סוֹטוֹת כְּאַחַת, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁלִּבָּהּ גַּס בַּחֲבֶירְתָּהּ.
human_translation: Ravina said: Come hear two sota women are not given to drink as one. because the heart emboldened [ gas ] in the the other
llm_translation: Ravina said, come and hear: One may not give two sotot to drink at once, because her heart is arrogant towards her companion.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: לֹא מִן הַשֵּׁם הוּא זֶה, אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״וְהִשְׁקָהּ״ — אוֹתָהּ, לְבַדָּהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: This is not for reason [ lo min hashem hu zeh ], but because it is stated: “And he shall make her drink” her by herself.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: Not from the name itself, rather because it is stated "and he shall cause her to drink" - her alone.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ בּוֹגֶרֶת שֶׁשָּׁהֲתָה שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ, וְאַלְמָנָה שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: הוֹאִיל וּבַעְלָהּ חַיָּיב בִּמְזוֹנוֹתֶיהָ — יָפֵר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֵין הַבַּעַל מֵיפֵר עַד שֶׁתִּכָּנֵס לִרְשׁוּתוֹ.
human_translation: a grown woman who waited twelve months or a widow thirty days Rabbi Eliezer says: Since her husband is obligated for her sustenance, he can nullify But the Rabbis say: The husband does not nullify until she enters his jurisdiction.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: A pregnant woman who was pregnant for six months and a widow for thirty days, Rabbi Eliezer says: Since her husband is obligated in her sustenance - he should provide. And the Sages say: The husband does not provide until she enters his domain.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַבָּה: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר וּמִשְׁנָה רִאשׁוֹנָה אָמְרוּ דָּבָר אֶחָד. דִּתְנַן: נוֹתְנִין לַבְּתוּלָה שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ לְפַרְנֵס עַצְמָהּ. הִגִּיעַ שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ — אוֹכֶלֶת מִשֶּׁלּוֹ, וְאוֹכֶלֶת בִּתְרוּמָה. אֲבָל הַיָּבָם אֵינוֹ מַאֲכִיל בִּתְרוּמָה.
human_translation: Rabba says: Rabbi Eliezer and the initial mishna said the same thing, as we learned A virgin is given twelve months to prepare herself, twelve-month arrived, partakes of his food, And she partakes of teruma However, a man, whose married brother died childless [ yavam ], does not enable to partake of teruma
llm_translation: Gemara said: Rabba said: Rabbi Eliezer and the first Mishnah said one thing. As we learned: They give to a virgin twelve months to provide for herself. When twelve months have passed, she eats from his, and she eats from the terumah. But the yavam does not feed her terumah.

hebrew_text: עָשְׂתָה שִׁשָּׁה חֳדָשִׁים בִּפְנֵי הַבַּעַל, וְשִׁשָּׁה חֳדָשִׁים בִּפְנֵי הַיָּבָם, וַאֲפִילּוּ כּוּלָּן בִּפְנֵי הַבַּעַל חָסֵר יוֹם אֶחָד, אוֹ כּוּלָּן בִּפְנֵי הַיָּבָם חָסֵר יוֹם אֶחָד — אֵינָהּ אוֹכֶלֶת בִּתְרוּמָה. זוֹ מִשְׁנָה רִאשׁוֹנָה. בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל אַחֲרֵיהֶם אָמְרוּ: אֵין הָאִשָּׁה אוֹכֶלֶת בִּתְרוּמָה עַד שֶׁתִּכָּנֵס לַחוּפָּה.
human_translation: completed six months under the aegis of the husband, and six months under the aegis of the yavam ; or even completed all of those under the aegis of the husband, less one day; or all of them under the aegis of the yavam less one day, she may not partake of teruma . This is initial mishna. a court after them, The woman may not partake of teruma until she enters the canopy,
llm_translation: She made six months in front of the husband, and six months in front of the yavam, and even if all of them in front of the husband lack one day, or all of them in front of the yavam lack one day — she does not eat terumah. This is the first Mishnah. The court of the later authorities said: A woman does not eat terumah until she enters the wedding canopy.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי, דִּלְמָא לָא הִיא: עַד כָּאן לָא קָא אַשְׁמְעִינַן מִשְׁנָה רִאשׁוֹנָה אֶלָּא לְמֵיכַל בִּתְרוּמָה דְּרַבָּנַן. אֲבָל נְדָרִים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא — אֵימָא לָא.
human_translation: Abaye said to him: Perhaps it is not so. The initial mishna teaches us only about partaking of teruma by rabbinic law, but vows, Torah law, say cannot
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye, perhaps it is not so: until here we have not heard the first Mishnah except to eat Terumah of the Rabbis. But vows of the Torah — I will say no.

hebrew_text: וְעַד כָּאן לָא שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אֶלָּא גַּבֵּי נְדָרִים, כִּדְרַב פִּנְחָס מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרָבָא דְּאָמַר כׇּל הַנּוֹדֶרֶת עַל דַּעַת בַּעְלָהּ הִיא נוֹדֶרֶת. אֲבָל תְּרוּמָה — אֲפִילּוּ מִדְּרַבָּנַן נָמֵי לָא אָכְלָה.
human_translation: And you did not hear Rabbi Eliezer only with regard to vows. like that Rav Pineḥas in the name of Rava, who said: Any who takes a vow, takes a vow upon the consent of her husband, But teruma , even teruma by rabbinic law, she may not partake
llm_translation: Until here, you did not listen to Rabbi Eliezer except regarding vows, as Rav Pinchas in the name of Rava said: "Every vow made is made with the knowledge of her husband." But regarding terumah—even if it is from the Rabbis, she did not eat.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ שׁוֹמֶרֶת יָבָם, בֵּין לְיָבָם אֶחָד, בֵּין לִשְׁנֵי יְבָמִין. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: יָפֵר. רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: לְאֶחָד, אֲבָל לֹא לִשְׁנַיִם. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: לֹא לְאֶחָד וְלֹא לִשְׁנַיִם.
human_translation: a widow waiting for her yavam whether for one yavam , whether for two yevamin , Rabbi Eliezer says: can nullify Rabbi Yehoshua says: for one but not for two. Rabbi Akiva says: cannot for one or for two
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: A woman who is awaiting yibum, whether for one yavam or for two yevamim. Rabbi Eliezer says: She may perform chalitzah. Rabbi Yehoshua says: For one, but not for two. Rabbi Akiva says: Neither for one nor for two.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: מָה אִם אִשָּׁה שֶׁקָּנָה הוּא לְעַצְמוֹ — הֲרֵי הוּא מֵיפֵר נְדָרֶיהָ, אִשָּׁה שֶׁהִקְנוּ לוֹ מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁיָּפֵר נְדָרֶיהָ?
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer said: Just as a woman he acquired for himself he nullifies her vows, a woman acquired for him from Heaven, isn’t it logical that he should nullify her vows?
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer said: What if a woman acquired for herself - behold, he annuls her vows. A woman who was acquired for him from heaven - is it not the law that he should annul her vows?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: לֹא, אִם אָמַרְתָּ בְּאִשָּׁה שֶׁקָּנָה הוּא לְעַצְמוֹ — שֶׁאֵין לַאֲחֵרִים בָּהּ רְשׁוּת, תֹּאמַר בְּאִשָּׁה שֶׁהִקְנוּ לוֹ מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם, שֶׁיֵּשׁ לַאֲחֵרִים בָּהּ רְשׁוּת?!
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva said to him: No, if you say a woman he acquired for himself, over whom others have no authority, shall you say a woman acquired for him from Heaven, over whom others have authority?
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Akiva: No, if you say about a woman that he acquired her for himself - that others do not have a share in her, you will say about a woman that they acquired for him from heaven, that others have a share in her?!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: עֲקִיבָא, דְּבָרֶיךָ בִּשְׁנֵי יְבָמִין, מָה אַתָּה מֵשִׁיב עַל יָבָם אֶחָד? אָמַר לוֹ: אֵין הַיְּבָמָה גְּמוּרָה לַיָּבָם כְּשֵׁם שֶׁהָאֲרוּסָה גְּמוּרָה לְאִישָׁהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: Akiva, your statement applies with two yevamin , how do you reply in one yavam ? said to him: A yevama is not the full-fledged of the yavam in the way that a betrothed woman her husband’s full-fledged
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Yehoshua: Akiva, your words in two yevamim, what do you respond on one yavam? He said to him: The yevamah is not complete to the yavam as the betrothed woman is complete to her husband.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ בִּשְׁלָמָא רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר אֵין זִיקָה, וְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ סָבַר יֵשׁ זִיקָה. אֶלָּא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ? אִי יֵשׁ זִיקָה, אֵין בְּרֵירָה.
human_translation: make sense: Rabbi Akiva holds bond is not substantial. And Rabbi Yehoshua holds bond is substantial, However, Rabbi Eliezer, what is his reason? if bond is substantial, there is, no designation.
llm_translation: Gemara: In Shlama, Rabbi Akiva holds there is no liability, and Rabbi Yehoshua holds there is liability. Rather, Rabbi Eliezer, what is his reasoning? If there is liability, there is no choice.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַמֵּי: כְּגוֹן שֶׁעָשָׂה בָּהּ מַאֲמָר. וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר סָבַר לַהּ כְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי, דְּאָמְרִי: מַאֲמָר קוֹנֶה קִנְיָן גָּמוּר.
human_translation: Rav Ami said: where performed levirate betrothal with her. but Rabbi Eliezer holds like Beit Shammai, who say: Levirate betrothal effects a full-fledged acquisition
llm_translation: Rabbi Ammi said: For example, if he made a statement regarding it. And Rabbi Eliezer holds like Beit Shammai, for they say: A statement acquires complete ownership.
