hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר לְךָ: הָנֵי מִילֵּי בְּחַד יָבָם, אֲבָל בִּשְׁנֵי יְבָמִין — לָא. מִי אִיכָּא מִידֵּי דְּכִי אָתֵי אֲחוּהִי אָסַר עֲלֵיהּ בְּבִיאָה, אוֹ בְּגִיטָּא וּמֵפֵר? וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר: אֵין זִיקָה.
human_translation: But Rabbi Yehoshua say to you, That levirate applies with one yavam , but with two yevamin not Is there anything when his brother comes, can render forbidden to by sexual intercourse or by a bill of divorce, and can nullify And Rabbi Akiva holds bond is not substantial
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua says to you: These matters with one yavam, but with two yevamim - no. Who is it from that when his brother comes, his sister-in-law is prohibited to him through intercourse, or through a bill of divorce and release? And Rabbi Akiva holds: there is no connection.

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי (אֱלִיעֶזֶר) [אֶלְעָזָר], דְּאָמַר: מַאֲמָר לְבֵית שַׁמַּאי אֵין קוֹנֶה אֶלָּא לִדְחוֹת בַּצָּרָה. מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: And according to Rabbi Elazar, who said levirate betrothal, according to Beit Shammai, does not effect acquisition except removes a rival wife what can be said?
llm_translation: And for Rabbi (Eliezer) Elazar, who said: The saying to the House of Shammai is not acquiring except to push away in distress. What is there to say?

hebrew_text: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — כְּגוֹן שֶׁעָמַד בַּדִּין, וְאִיתְחַיֵּיב לָהּ מְזוֹנוֹת, וְכִדְרַב פִּנְחָס מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרָבָא: דְּאָמַר כׇּל הַנּוֹדֶרֶת — עַל דַּעַת בַּעְלָהּ הִיא נוֹדֶרֶת.
human_translation: Here we are dealing with where stood in judgment and he was obligated her sustenance. And in accordance with Rav Pineḥas in the name of Rava, who said: Any who vows, she vows upon her husband’s consent.
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with - for example, when he stood in judgment, and he became obligated to provide her sustenance, and as Rav Pinchas in the name of Rava said: Anyone who makes a vow - it is a vow with the knowledge of her husband.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: וּמָה אִם אִשָּׁה שֶׁקָּנָה לְעַצְמוֹ — הֲרֵי הוּא מֵיפֵר נְדָרֶיהָ, אִשָּׁה שֶׁהִקְנוּ לוֹ מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם — אֵינוֹ דִין שֶׁמֵּיפֵר נְדָרֶיהָ? וְאִי בְּשֶׁעָשָׂה בָּהּ מַאֲמָר, קָנָה לְעַצְמוֹ הוּא! שֶׁקָּנָה לְעַצְמוֹ עַל יְדֵי שָׁמַיִם.
human_translation: We learned Rabbi Eliezer said: Just as a woman he acquired for himself he nullifies her vows, a woman acquired for him from Heaven, isn’t it logical that he should nullify her vows? Now if to where performed levirate betrothal, it he acquired for himself where he acquired for himself by means of Heaven.
llm_translation: We learned: Rabbi Eliezer said: And what if a woman acquires for herself - behold, he annuls her vows. A woman who was acquired for him from heaven - is it not the law that he annuls her vows? And if he made a statement regarding her, he acquired her for himself! For he acquired her for himself through heaven.

hebrew_text: תִּפְשׁוֹט דְּבָעֵי רַבָּה: מַאֲמָר לְבֵית שַׁמַּאי, אֵירוּסִין עוֹשֶׂה אוֹ נִשּׂוּאִין עוֹשֶׂה? תִּפְשׁוֹט דְּנִשּׂוּאִין עוֹשֶׂה. דְּאִי אֵירוּסִין עוֹשֶׂה — הָא תְּנַן: נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה, אָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ.
human_translation: you resolve that Rabba raised: levirate betrothal, according to Beit Shammai, effect betrothal, or does it effect marriage? you resolve that it effects marriage. Because if effects betrothal, Didn’t we learn a betrothed young woman, her father and her husband nullify her vows?
llm_translation: The Gemara asks: Regarding the statement of Beit Shammai, does betrothal make or marriage make? The Gemara concludes that marriage makes. For if betrothal makes, then we learned in a Mishnah: A betrothed maiden, her father and her husband annul her vows.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: מַאי ״יָפֵר״ — יָפֵר בְּשׁוּתָּפוּת.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: what nullify he nullifies in partnership
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: What is "yapeir" - he should beautify with partnership.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי כְּרַבִּי אַמֵּי: שׁוֹמֶרֶת יָבָם, בֵּין יָבָם אֶחָד בֵּין שְׁנֵי יְבָמִין, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: יָפֵר, וְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: לְאֶחָד וְלֹא לִשְׁנַיִם. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: לֹא לְאֶחָד וְלֹא לִשְׁנַיִם.
human_translation: It is also taught that in accordance with Rabbi Ami: a widow awaiting her yavam , whether one yavam , two yevamin , Rabbi Eliezer says: can nullify and Rabbi Yehoshua says: for one but not for two. Rabbi Akiva says: not for one, and not for two
llm_translation: It was taught in a baraita: Nami the Elder said in the name of Rabbi Ammi: A woman who is awaiting the levirate marriage, whether she has one yavam or two yevamim, Rabbi Eliezer says: she may perform chalitzah, and Rabbi Yehoshua says: for one and not for two. Rabbi Akiva says: neither for one nor for two.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: וּמָה אִם אִשָּׁה שֶׁאֵין לוֹ חֵלֶק בָּהּ עַד שֶׁלֹּא תָּבֹא לִרְשׁוּתוֹ, מִשֶּׁבָּאת לִרְשׁוּתוֹ — נִגְמְרָה לוֹ. אִשָּׁה, שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ חֵלֶק עַד שֶׁלֹּא תָּבֹא לִרְשׁוּתוֹ, מִשֶּׁבָּאת לִרְשׁוּתוֹ — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁתִּגְמוֹר לוֹ?
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer said And just as if a woman in whom he has no share until she enters into his jurisdiction once she enters into his jurisdiction, she is fully his a woman he has a share before she enters his jurisdiction, once she enters his jurisdiction, is it not logical that she be fully his
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer said: And what if a woman who has no portion in her until she comes into his possession, once she comes into his possession — she is completed for him. A woman who has a portion until she comes into his possession, once she comes into his possession — is it not the law that she is not completed for him?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: לֹא, אִם אָמַרְתָּ בְּאִשָּׁה שֶׁקָּנָה הוּא לְעַצְמוֹ, שֶׁכְּשֵׁם שֶׁאֵין לוֹ חֵלֶק בָּהּ, כָּךְ אֵין לַאֲחֵרִים חֵלֶק בָּהּ. תֹּאמַר בְּאִשָּׁה שֶׁהִקְנוּ לוֹ מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם, שֶׁכְּשֵׁם שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ עִמָּהּ חֵלֶק — כָּךְ יֵשׁ לַאֲחֵרִים חֵלֶק בָּהּ!
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva said to him: No, If you spoke of a woman he acquired for himself that Just as he has no share in her so others have no share in her. Will you say with regard to a woman acquired for him from Heaven, for whom, just as he has a share in her, so do others, have a share in her,
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Akiva: No, if you say about a woman that he acquired her for himself, that just as he has no share in her, so too others have no share in her. You might say about a woman that he acquired her from heaven, that just as he has a share with her, so too others have a share in her!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: עֲקִיבָא, דְּבָרֶיךָ — בִּשְׁנֵי יְבָמִין, מָה אַתָּה מֵשִׁיב עַל יָבָם אֶחָד? אָמַר לוֹ: כְּלוּם חִלַּקְנוּ עַל יָבָם אֶחָד וְעַל שְׁנֵי יְבָמִין בֵּין שֶׁעָשָׂה בָּהּ מַאֲמָר בֵּין שֶׁלֹּא עָשָׂה בָּהּ מַאֲמָר? וְכִשְׁאָר דְּבָרִים כֵּן נְדָרִים.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: Akiva, your statement with two yevamin , what do you answer for one yavam ? replied to him: Did we distinguish between one yavam and two yevamin , whether he performed levirate betrothal or whether he did not perform levirate betrothal? And as other matters so vows.
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Yehoshua: Akiva, your words — in the case of two brothers-in-law, what do you respond regarding one brother-in-law? He said to him: Have we not distinguished between one brother-in-law and two brother-in-laws, whether he performed chalitzah or did not perform chalitzah? And regarding other matters, similarly vows.

hebrew_text: בַּלָּשׁוֹן הַזֶּה אָמַר בֶּן עַזַּאי: חֲבָל עָלֶיךָ בֶּן עַזַּאי שֶׁלֹּא שִׁימַּשְׁתָּ אֶת רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא.
human_translation: Ben Azzai stated discussion in this language: Woe [ ḥaval ] to you, ben Azzai, that you did not serve Rabbi Akiva
llm_translation: In this language, Ben Azzai said: "Woe unto you, Ben Azzai, for you did not serve Rabbi Akiva."

hebrew_text: מַאי
human_translation: what
llm_translation: What is it?

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אַמֵּי? דְּקָתָנֵי: בֵּין שֶׁעָשָׂה בָּהּ מַאֲמָר וּבֵין שֶׁלֹּא עָשָׂה בָּהּ מַאֲמָר.
human_translation: is it taught in accordance with of Rabbi Ami? that which is taught Whether he performed levirate betrothal or whether he did not perform levirate betrothal.
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rabbi Ammi: As it was taught: Whether one made a statement regarding it or did not make a statement regarding it.

hebrew_text: אִי נָמֵי מֵרֵישָׁא דְּקָתָנֵי: מִשֶּׁנִּכְנְסָה לִרְשׁוּתוֹ נִגְמְרָה לוֹ. וְאִי דְּלָא קַדֵּישׁ, מַאי ״נִגְמְרָה לוֹ״? תִּפְשׁוֹט מִינֵּיהּ כְּשֶׁעָשָׂה בָּהּ מַאֲמָר.
human_translation: Alternatively, from the first clause which teaches: Once she enters his jurisdiction, she is fully his If where he did not betroth what she fully his Deduce from it in which he has performed levirate betrothal.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Iy namei meresha d'katanei: mi'shenichnesa lireshuto nigmera lo. Ve'iy d'la kadish, mai 'nigmera lo'? Tifshot mineih k'she'asa bah ma'amar." English translation: "If she enters his domain, it is considered completed for him. And if he did not sanctify, what does 'it is considered completed for him' mean? You should understand from it when he makes a statement about her."

hebrew_text: מַאי ״וְכִשְׁאָר דְּבָרִים כֵּן נְדָרִים״ דְּקָתָנֵי? אָמַר רָבָא, הָכִי קָתָנֵי: אִי אַתָּה מוֹדֶה שֶׁאֵין חַיָּיבִין סְקִילָה, כְּנַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה?
human_translation: What And as other matters so vows, that teaches Rava said: This is what is teaching: Do you not concede that not liable to stoning as a betrothed young woman?
llm_translation: What is the meaning of "and like other matters, so are vows" that is taught? Rava said, thus it is taught: If you admit that they are not liable for stoning, like a betrothed maiden?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי, מַתְנִיתִין נָמֵי דַּיְקָא: אֵין יְבָמָה גְּמוּרָה לְאִישָׁהּ כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאֲרוּסָה גְּמוּרָה לְאִישָׁהּ.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: The mishna is also precisely A yevama is not her husband’s full-fledged in the same manner that a betrothed woman her husband’s full-fledged
llm_translation: Rav Ashe said, the Mishnah also supports this explicitly: A yevamah is not fully married to her husband just as an engaged woman is fully married to her husband.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשְׁתּוֹ ״כׇּל הַנְּדָרִים שֶׁתִּדּוֹרִי מִכָּאן עַד שֶׁאָבֹא מִמָּקוֹם פְּלוֹנִי הֲרֵי הֵן קַיָּימִין״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם. ״הֲרֵי הֵן מוּפָרִין״ — רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אֹמֵר: מוּפָר, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֵינוֹ מוּפָר. אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: אִם הֵפֵר נְדָרִים שֶׁבָּאוּ לִכְלַל אִיסּוּר — לֹא יָפֵר נְדָרִים שֶׁלֹּא בָּאוּ לִכְלַל אִיסּוּר?!
human_translation: One who says to his wife: All vows that you will vow from now until I arrive from such and such a place are hereby ratified, has not said anything, are hereby nullified, Rabbi Eliezer said: nullified, while the Rabbis say: not nullified. Rabbi Eliezer said If one can nullify vows that have reached the status of a prohibition, shall he not nullify vows that have not reached the status of a prohibition?
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who says to his wife, "All vows that you may make from now until I return from a certain place are hereby valid," — he has said nothing. "They are hereby annulled," — Rabbi Eliezer says: They are annulled, but the Sages say: They are not annulled. Rabbi Eliezer said: If he annulled vows that were included in a prohibition — he should not annul vows that were not included in a prohibition?!

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״אִישָׁהּ יְקִימֶנּוּ וְאִישָׁהּ יְפֵרֶנּוּ״. אֶת שֶׁבָּא לִכְלַל הָקֵם — בָּא לִכְלַל הָפֵר, לֹא בָּא לִכְלַל הָקֵם — לֹא בָּא לִכְלַל הָפֵר.
human_translation: said to him states: her husband may ratify it, or her husband may nullify it” That which has reached the status of ratification, has reached the status of nullification. has not reached the status of ratification not reached the status of nullification
llm_translation: They said to him: Behold he says, "Her husband shall establish it, and her husband shall annul it." If he came to include establishing, he came to include annulment; if he did not come to include establishing, he did not come to include annulment.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר מֵיחָל חָלִין וּבָטְלִין, אוֹ דִלְמָא לָא חָלִין כְּלָל? לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ,
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before According to Rabbi Eliezer, take effect and are canceled Or perhaps they do not take effect at all. In what a difference
llm_translation: The Gemara raises a question: Does Rabbi Eliezer maintain that they are permitted and annulled, or perhaps they are not permitted at all? What practical difference does it make?

hebrew_text: כְּגוֹן דְּאַתְפֵּיס אַחֲרִינָא בְּהָדֵין נִדְרָא. אִי אָמְרַתְּ חָלִין — הָוְיָא תְּפִיסוּתָא. אִי אָמְרַתְּ לָא חָלִין — לָא אִיכָּא מְשָׁשָׁא.
human_translation: where another associated with this vow. If you say take effect, the association takes effect. If you say do not take effect has no substance,
llm_translation: For example, if he catches another person in that matter, if you say it is mundane - it is considered a valid catch. If you say it is not mundane - there is no suspicion.

hebrew_text: מַאי? תָּא שְׁמַע, אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: אִם הֵפֵר נְדָרִים שֶׁבָּאוּ לִכְלַל אִיסּוּר, לֹא יָפֵר נְדָרִים שֶׁלֹּא בָּאוּ לִכְלַל אִיסּוּר? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ לָא חָלִין!
human_translation: What, Come hear Rabbi Eliezer said: If one can nullify vows that have reached the status of a prohibition, shall he not nullify vows that have not reached the status of a prohibition? Learn from it do not take effect
llm_translation: What? Come and hear, Rabbi Eliezer said: If one annulled vows that were included in prohibition, should he not annul vows that were not included in prohibition? Learn from this that they are not annulled!

hebrew_text: מִי קָתָנֵי ״שֶׁאֵינָן בָּאִין״? ״שֶׁלֹּא בָּאוּ״ קָתָנֵי, עֲדַיִין לֹא בָּאוּ.
human_translation: Does teach That do not reach teaches: That have not reached they have not yet reached
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Who is the one who holds "that they do not come"? It teaches "that they have not come," meaning they have not yet come.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, אָמַר לָהֶן רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: וּמָה בִּמְקוֹם שֶׁאֵין מֵיפֵר נִדְרֵי עַצְמוֹ מִשֶּׁנָּדַר, מֵיפֵר נִדְרֵי עַצְמוֹ עַד שֶׁלֹּא יָדוּר. מְקוֹם שֶׁמֵּפֵר נִדְרֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ מִשֶּׁתִּדּוֹר, אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁיָּפֵר נִדְרֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ עַד שֶׁלֹּא תִּדּוֹר?
human_translation: Come hear Rabbi Eliezer said to them: And just as in a situation where he cannot nullify his own vows once he has vowed, he can nullify his own vows before he vows a situation where he can nullify his wife’s vows after she vows, is it not logical that he should nullify his wife’s vows before she vows?
llm_translation: Come and hear, Rabbi Eliezer said to them: In a place where one does not annul his own vows immediately after making them, he may annul his own vows until he takes a vow. In a place where one annuls his wife's vows immediately after she makes them, it is not the same that he may annul his wife's vows until she takes a vow.

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו, דְּאִשְׁתּוֹ דּוּמְיָא דִּילֵיהּ, מָה [הוּא] דְּלָא חָיְילִין — אַף אִשְׁתּוֹ נָמֵי דְּלָא חָיְילִין? לָא, הָא כִּדְאִיתָא וְהָא כִּדְאִיתָא.
human_translation: What, is it not referring to his wife’s similar to his own just as his do not take effect so too his wife do not take effect No, this as it is, and that as it is;
llm_translation: What is the reason that his wife is similar to his cloak, that just as he does not need to redeem his cloak - so too his wife, does he not need to redeem her? No, this one is as this one, and that one is as that one.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, אָמְרוּ לוֹ לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: וּמָה מִקְוֶה שֶׁמַּעֲלֶה אֶת הַטְּמֵאִין מִטּוּמְאָתָן — אֵין מַצִּיל עַל הַטְּהוֹרִים מִלִּיטָּמֵא, אָדָם שֶׁאֵין מַעֲלֶה אֶת הַטְּמֵאִין מִטּוּמְאָתָן — אֵינוֹ דִּין הוּא שֶׁלֹּא יַצִּיל עַל הַטְּהוֹרִין מִלִּיטָּמֵא?
human_translation: Come hear They said to Rabbi Eliezer: And just as a ritual bath, which elevates the impure from their impurity does not save the pure from becoming impure a person, who does not elevate the impure from their impurity, is it not logical that he should not save pure from becoming impure?
llm_translation: Come and hear, they said to Rabbi Eliezer: "And how does a mikveh that raises the impure from their impurity not save the pure from becoming impure? A person who does not raise the impure from their impurity - is it not right that he should not save the pure from becoming impure?"

hebrew_text: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ לָא חָיְילִין!
human_translation: learn from do not take effect
llm_translation: Hear from it, it is not valid!

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא, אָמְרוּ לוֹ לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: אִם מַטְבִּילִין כְּלִי טָמֵא לִיטָּהֵר, יַטְבִּילוּ כְּלִי לִכְשֶׁיִּטְמָא לִיטָּהֵר? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ חָיְילִין.
human_translation: Say the latter clause They said to Rabbi Eliezer: If one immerses an impure vessel to purify shall one immerse a vessel when it will become impure it will be purified? Learn from take effect
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa, amru lo le'Rabbi Eliezer: Im matbilin keli tamei l'taher, yatbilu keli l'k'she'yitma l'taher? Shema minah chayilin." English translation: "The final clause: They said to Rabbi Eliezer: If they immerse a vessel that is impure to become pure, should they immerse a vessel so that it becomes impure to become pure? Learn from it, troops."

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: רַבָּנַן לָא קָיְימִי לְהוֹן בְּטַעְמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, וְהָכִי קָאָמְרִי לֵיהּ: מַאי סְבִירָא לָךְ? אִי סְבִירָא לָךְ דְּחָיְילִין וּבָטְלִין — תִּהְוֵי כְּלִי תְּיוּבְתָּךְ, אִי לָא סְבִירָא לָךְ דְּחָיְילִין — תִּהְוֵי מִקְוֶה תְּיוּבְתָּךְ.
human_translation: say the Rabbis could not determine the reasoning of Rabbi Eliezer, and this is what said to him: What do you hold? If you hold that take effect and are nullified, a vessel will be your refutation, If you do not hold that they take effect, a ritual bath will be your refutation.
llm_translation: The sages said: The Rabbis did not establish themselves according to the reasoning of Rabbi Eliezer. And thus they say to him: What do you think? If you think that they are nullified and annulled - they will be like a vessel of impurity for you. But if you do not think that they are nullified - they will be a source of impurity for you.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, אָמַר לָהֶם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: וּמָה זְרָעִים טְמֵאִים, כֵּיוָן שֶׁזְּרָעָן בְּקַרְקַע טְהוֹרִין, זְרוּעִין וְעוֹמְדִים — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ לָא חָיְילִין.
human_translation: Come hear: Rabbi Eliezer said to them: And just as ritually impure seeds, once one has sown them in the ground, pure, are already sown not all the more so Learn from do not take effect
llm_translation: Come and hear, Rabbi Eliezer said to them: And what about impure seeds, since when they are sown in pure soil, they sprout and stand - all the more so? Learn from it that they are not effective.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן לָא דָּרְשִׁי קַל וָחוֹמֶר? וְהָא תַּנְיָא: יָכוֹל יִמְכּוֹר אָדָם אֶת בִּתּוֹ כְּשֶׁהִיא נַעֲרָה? אָמְרַתְּ קַל וָחוֹמֶר: מְכוּרָה כְּבָר — יוֹצְאָה, אֵינָהּ מְכוּרָה — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא תִּימָּכֵר?
human_translation: And the Rabbis, do they not teach a fortiori But isn’t it taught Can a person sell his daughter when she is a young woman? You say an a fortiori already sold goes free who has not been sold, is it not logical that she cannot be sold
llm_translation: The Sages did not derive a law through a fortiori reasoning? But it was taught: Can a man sell his daughter when she is a young girl? You said it is derived through a fortiori reasoning: if she is already sold - she goes out free, if she is not sold - it is not the law that she should not be sold?

hebrew_text: אִין, בְּעָלְמָא דָּרְשִׁי קַל וָחוֹמֶר, וְשָׁאנֵי הָכָא דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״אִישָׁהּ יְקִימֶנּוּ וְאִישָׁהּ יְפֵרֶנּוּ״. אֶת שֶׁבָּא לִכְלַל הָקֵם — בָּא לִכְלַל הָפֵר, אֶת שֶׁלֹּא בָּא לִכְלַל הָקֵם — לֹא בָּא לִכְלַל הָפֵר.
human_translation: Yes, generally they do teach a fortiori but here it is different, as the verse states: “Her husband may ratify it, or her husband may nullify it” That which has become eligible ratification, has become eligible for nullification. that which has not become eligible ratification, has not become eligible for nullification.
llm_translation: There is, in the world, a fortiori argument, and it is different here where the verse says, "Her husband may establish it, or her husband may annul it." What comes to include establishing - comes to include annulment, what does not come to include establishing - does not come to include annulment.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הֲפָרַת נְדָרִים כׇּל הַיּוֹם. יֵשׁ בַּדָּבָר לְהָקֵל וּלְהַחֲמִיר
human_translation: nullification of vows all day There is in this matter a leniency, and a stricture,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One may annul vows all day. There is room for leniency and stringency in this matter.

hebrew_text: כֵּיצַד? נָדְרָה בְּלֵילֵי שַׁבָּת — יָפֵר בְּלֵילֵי שַׁבָּת וּבְיוֹם הַשַּׁבָּת עַד שֶׁתֶּחְשַׁךְ. נָדְרָה עִם חֲשֵׁכָה — מֵפֵר עַד שֶׁלֹּא תֶּחְשַׁךְ, שֶׁאִם חָשְׁכָה וְלֹא הֵפֵר — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר,
human_translation: How so? took a vow on Shabbat evening, can nullify on Shabbat evening, and on Shabbat day until dark. she took a vow with nightfall can nullify until nightfall, since, if it became dark and he had not nullified he cannot nullify
llm_translation: How so? If she vowed on the nights of Shabbat - he may annul on the nights of Shabbat and on the day of Shabbat until it gets dark. If she vowed at dusk - he may annul until it does not get dark, for if it gets dark and he did not annul - he cannot annul.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תַּנְיָא: הֲפָרַת נְדָרִים כׇּל הַיּוֹם. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אָמְרוּ: מֵעֵת לְעֵת. מַאי טַעְמָא דְּתַנָּא קַמָּא, אָמַר קְרָא: ״בְּיוֹם שׇׁמְעוֹ״.
human_translation: It is taught nullification of vows all day Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, said: for period What is the reason for the first tanna ? the verse states: on the day that he hears them”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara: Tanya: Hafarat Nedarim kol hayom. Rabbi Yosei bar Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Elazar bar Rabbi Shimon said: Me'et le'et. Ma'ai ta'ama de'tana kama, amar kra: 'Beyom shemo.'" English translation: "Gemara: It was taught in a Baraita: Nullification of vows all day. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, said: From time to time. What is the reason that the first Tanna taught, as the verse states: 'On the day of his hearing.'"

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן מַאי טַעְמַיְיהוּ — דִּכְתִיב: ״מִיּוֹם אֶל יוֹם״.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, what is their reason? It is written: “From day to day”
llm_translation: The Sages: What is their reasoning? As it is written: "From day to day."

hebrew_text: וּלְתַנָּא קַמָּא, הָא כְּתִיב ״מִיּוֹם אֶל יוֹם״! אִיצְטְרִיךְ. דְּאִי ״בְּיוֹם שׇׁמְעוֹ״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא בִּימָמָא — אִין, בְּלֵילְיָא — לָא, כְּתִיב ״מִיּוֹם אֶל יוֹם״.
human_translation: And according to the first tanna , isn’t it written: “From day to day”? is necessary, as if “on the day that he hears them,” I would say during the day, yes, at night not it is written: “From day to day,”
llm_translation: And to the first Tanna, this is written "from day to day"! It was necessary. For if "on the day he heard," I would say during the day — yes, at night — no, it is written "from day to day."

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״מִיּוֹם אֶל יוֹם״, הָא כְּתִיב ״בְּיוֹם שׇׁמְעוֹ״! אִיצְטְרִיךְ, דְּאִי כְּתִיב ״מִיּוֹם אֶל יוֹם״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא מֵחַד בְּשַׁבָּא לְחַד בְּשַׁבָּא לֵיפַר לָהּ, כְּתִיב ״בְּיוֹם שׇׁמְעוֹ״.
human_translation: And according to the one who said “from day to day” isn’t it written: “On the day that he hears them?” was necessary, as if written “from day to day,” I would say can nullify for her from one Sunday to Sunday. is written: “On the day that he hears them”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And according to the one who says "from day to day," is it not written "on the day he heard"? It is necessary, for if it were written "from day to day," I would say that one can fulfill it from one Sabbath to another Sabbath, to exempt her, but it is written "on the day he heard." English translation:

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּאוֹתוֹ הַזּוּג. לֵוִי סָבַר לְמִיעְבַּד כְּהָנֵי תַּנָּאֵי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב, הָכִי אָמַר חֲבִיבִי: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּאוֹתוֹ הַזּוּג.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: The halakha is not in accordance with that pair [ zug ], Levi thought to act in accordance with those tanna’im . Rav said to him: So said my uncle [ ḥavivi ], The halakha is not in accordance with that pair.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Shimon ben Pazzi said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: The halakha is not like that pair. Levi thought to reconcile the opinions of the Tannaim. Rav said to him, thus said my beloved: The halakha is not like that pair.

hebrew_text: חִיָּיא בַּר רַב שָׁדֵי גִּירָא וּבָדֵיק. רַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא יָתֵיב וְקָאֵים.
human_translation: Ḥiyya bar Rav, would shoot an arrow [ gira ] and examine Rabba bar Rav Huna would sit and stand
llm_translation: Ḥiyya bar Rav Shadai Gira and Badeik. Rabbah bar Rav Huna sat and stood.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן הָתָם: מְפִירִין נְדָרִים בְּשַׁבָּת, וְנִשְׁאָלִין לִנְדָרִים שֶׁהֵן לְצוֹרֶךְ הַשַּׁבָּת. אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מְפִירִין נְדָרִים בְּשַׁבָּת לְצוֹרֶךְ הַשַּׁבָּת, אוֹ דִלְמָא אֲפִילּוּ שֶׁלֹּא לְצוֹרֶךְ?
human_translation: We learned elsewhere may nullify vows on Shabbat and one may request to vows that are for the purpose of Shabbat. A dilemma was raised before nullify vows on Shabbat when for the purpose of Shabbat, or perhaps even when they are not for the purpose
llm_translation: We learned there: One may annul vows on Shabbat, and one may inquire about vows that are for the need of Shabbat. It was asked of them: Do we annul vows on Shabbat for the need of Shabbat, or perhaps even if not for the need?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּתָנֵי רַב זוּטֵי דְּבֵי רַב פַּפֵּי: אֵין מְפִירִין נְדָרִים אֶלָּא לְצוֹרֶךְ הַשַּׁבָּת. אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי, הָא לָא תְּנַן הָכִי: נָדְרָה עִם חֲשֵׁיכָה — מֵפֵר לָהּ עַד שֶׁלֹּא תֶּחְשַׁךְ. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ לְצוֹרֶךְ הַשַּׁבָּת — אִין, שֶׁלֹּא לְצוֹרֶךְ הַשַּׁבָּת — לָא, מַאי אִירְיָא חָשְׁכָה? אֲפִילּוּ בְּתוֹךְ הַיּוֹם אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר דְּשֶׁלֹּא לְצוֹרֶךְ!
human_translation: Come hear that Rav Zuti from the school of Rav Pappi taught: Vows may be nullified only for the purpose of Shabbat. Rav Ashi said: We did not learn that way she took a vow with nightfall can nullify for her until nightfall. And if you say are for the purpose of Shabbat, yes, that are not for the purpose of Shabbat, no, why specify nightfall? even during the day he may not nullify that is not for the purpose
llm_translation: Come and hear, as it was taught by Rav Zutai of the house of Rav Pappai: One may annul vows only for the sake of the Sabbath. Rav Ashe said, did we not learn thus: If one vowed at nightfall — he may annul it for her until it gets dark. And if you say for the sake of the Sabbath — yes, if not for the sake of the Sabbath — no, what is the meaning of nightfall? Even in the middle of the day, he cannot annul it if not for the sake of the Sabbath!

hebrew_text: תַּנָּאֵי הִיא: הֲפָרַת נְדָרִים כׇּל הַיּוֹם, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אָמְרוּ: מֵעֵת לְעֵת.
human_translation: tanna’im : Nullification of vows all day Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, said: for period
llm_translation: It is taught in a Baraita: The nullification of vows is the entire day, Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Elazar son of Rabbi Shimon said: From time to time.

hebrew_text: לְמַאן דְּאָמַר כׇּל הַיּוֹם אִין, טְפֵי לָא — אֲפִילּוּ שֶׁלֹּא לְצוֹרֶךְ הַשַּׁבָּת מֵפֵר. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מֵעֵת לְעֵת, לְצוֹרֶךְ הַשַּׁבָּת — אִין, שֶׁלֹּא לְצוֹרֶךְ הַשַּׁבָּת — לָא.
human_translation: According to the one who says all day, yes, not more he may nullify even not for the purpose of Shabbat, According to the one who says for period, for the purpose of Shabbat, yes, not necessary for Shabbat, may not
llm_translation: To whom that said all the day no, a drop no — even that not for the need of the Sabbath nullifies. To whom that said from time to time, for the need of the Sabbath — yes, that not for the need of the Sabbath — no.

hebrew_text: וְנִשְׁאָלִין לִנְדָרִים שֶׁהֵן לְצוֹרֶךְ הַשַּׁבָּת. אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: כְּשֶׁלֹּא הָיָה לָהֶם פְּנַאי, אוֹ דִלְמָא כְּשֶׁהָיָה לָהֶם פְּנַאי? תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאִיזְדְּקִיקוּ לֵיהּ רַבָּנַן לִבְרֵיהּ דְּרַב זוּטְרָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב זְעֵירָא אֲפִילּוּ בִּנְדָרִים שֶׁהָיָה לָהֶם פְּנַאי מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם.
human_translation: And one may request to vows that are for the purpose of Shabbat. A dilemma was raised before when those did not have the opportunity or perhaps when they did have the opportunity? Come hear: that the Sages attended to the son of Rav Zutra, son of Rav Zeira, even for vows that they had the opportunity while it was still day,
llm_translation: And they asked about vows that are for the need of the Sabbath. It was asked of them: When they did not have free time, or perhaps when they did have free time? Come and hear, for the Rabbis were strict with Rav Zutra's son, the son of Rav Zeira, even regarding vows that they had free time from the middle of the day.

hebrew_text: סָבַר רַב יוֹסֵף לְמֵימַר: נִשְׁאָלִין נְדָרִים בְּשַׁבָּת, בְּיָחִיד מוּמְחֶה — אִין, בִּשְׁלֹשָׁה הֶדְיוֹטוֹת — לָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּמִתְחֲזֵי כְּדִינָא.
human_translation: Rav Yosef thought to say: requesting vows on Shabbat, yes, of a single expert of three laymen not because it looks like judgment,
llm_translation: Rav Yosef thought to say: If vows are asked about on Shabbat, in a private place - no, in a public place of three - yes, because it appears like a legal judgment.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: כֵּיוָן דִּסְבִירָא לַן אֲפִילּוּ מְעוּמָּד, אֲפִילּוּ בִּקְרוֹבִים, וַאֲפִילּוּ בַּלַּיְלָה — לָא מִתְחֲזֵי כְּדִינָא.
human_translation: Abaye said to him: Since we hold even is standing, even by relatives, and even at night, does not look like a judgment.
llm_translation: He said to him, Abaye: Since he reasons with us, even while standing, even with relatives, and even at night - it does not appear like judgment.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא אָמַר רַב הוּנָא אָמַר רַב: הֲלָכָה, מְפִירִין נְדָרִים בַּלַּיְלָה. וְהָא מַתְנִיתִין הִיא: נָדְרָה בְּלֵילֵי שַׁבָּת! אֶלָּא אֵימָא: הֲלָכָה, נִשְׁאָלִין בַּלַּיְלָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba said Rav Huna said Rav said: halakha one can nullify vows at night. But this is the mishna: took a vow on Shabbat evening, Rather, say halakha one can request at night.
llm_translation: Rabbi Abba said in the name of Rav Huna who said in the name of Rav: The halakha is that vows are annulled at night. But isn't this a Mishnah: She vowed on the nights of Shabbat! Rather say: The halakha is that inquiries are made at night.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי אַבָּא לְרַב הוּנָא: אֲמַר רַב הָכִי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִישְׁתִּיק. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִישְׁתִּיק קָא אָמְרַתְּ, אוֹ שָׁתֵי קָאָמְרַתְּ?
human_translation: Rabbi Abba said to Rav Huna: Did Rav say that? said to him: was silent [ ishtik ] said to him: Did you say: He was silent [ ishtik ], or did you say: drinking [ shatei ],
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Abba to Rav Huna: Did Rav Haki say? He said to him: He was silent. He said to him: You say he was silent, did you mean he was drinking?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אִיקָא בַּר אָבִין: אִיזְדְּקִיק לֵיהּ רַב לְרַבָּה
human_translation: Rav Ika bar Avin said: Rav attended to Rabba,
llm_translation: Rav Ikka bar Avin said: Rav strengthened Rabba.

hebrew_text: בְּקִיטוֹנָא דְבֵי רַב, עוֹמֵד, יְחִידִי, וּבַלַּיְלָה.
human_translation: in room [ kitona ] of the study hall, standing, alone and at night.
llm_translation: In the small courtyard of the house of Rav, he stands, alone, and at night.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: הֲלָכָה, נִשְׁאָלִין נְדָרִים עוֹמֵד, יְחִידִי, וּבַלַּיְלָה, וּבַשַּׁבָּת, וּבִקְרוֹבִים, וַאֲפִילּוּ הָיָה לָהֶן פְּנַאי מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם.
human_translation: Rabba said Rav Naḥman said: halakha one can request vows standing alone, and at night, on Shabbat, and by relatives, and even those had the opportunity while it was still day,
llm_translation: Rabba said in the name of Rav Nachman: The halakha is that vows are asked about standing, alone, at night, on Shabbat, and in close proximity, even if they had free time from midday.

hebrew_text: עוֹמֵד? וְהָתַנְיָא: יָרַד רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל מִן הַחֲמוֹר וְנִתְעַטֵּף וְיָשַׁב וְהִתִּיר לוֹ נִדְרוֹ. רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל סָבַר: פּוֹתְחִין בַּחֲרָטָה. מִיעְקַר נִדְרָא בָּעִינַן, וּבָעֵי עַיּוֹנֵי, אַהָכִי יָשַׁב. וְרַב נַחְמָן סָבַר: אֵין פּוֹתְחִין בַּחֲרָטָה, וַאֲפִילּוּ מְעוּמָּד.
human_translation: standing? But it is taught Rabban Gamliel alighted from a donkey, and wrapped himself and sat, and dissolved vow for him. Rabban Gamliel holds broach on regret. We require that the vow be uprooted, and he needed to examine therefore, he sat down. But Rav Naḥman holds not broach on regret, and even standing.
llm_translation: He stands? And it was taught: Rabban Gamliel descended from the donkey, wrapped himself, and sat, and he permitted his vow. Rabban Gamliel thought: We begin with a sharp object. We require the original vow, and we need experts, so he sat. And Rav Nachman thought: We do not begin with a sharp object, even if one is standing.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא לְרַב נַחְמָן: חֲזִי מָר הַאי מֵרַבָּנַן דַּאֲתָא מִמַּעְרְבָא וְאָמַר: אִיזְדְּקִיקוּ לֵיהּ רַבָּנַן לִבְרֵיהּ דְּרַב הוּנָא בַּר אָבִין, וּשְׁרוֹ לֵיהּ נִדְרֵיהּ וַאֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ: זִיל וּבְעִי רַחֲמֵי עַל נַפְשָׁךְ דַּחֲטָאת. דְּתָנֵי רַב דִּימִי אֲחוּהּ דְּרַב סָפְרָא: כׇּל הַנּוֹדֵר, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהוּא מְקַיְּימוֹ — נִקְרָא חוֹטֵא. אָמַר רַב זְבִיד: מַאי קְרָא — ״וְכִי תֶחְדַּל לִנְדֹּר לֹא יִהְיֶה בְךָ חֵטְא״, הָא לֹא חָדַלְתָּ — אִיכָּא חֵטְא.
human_translation: Rava said to Rav Naḥman: Master, see that Sage who came from the West, and said: The Sages attended to the son of Rav Huna bar Avin, and they dissolved his vow and said to him: Go and request mercy for yourself, for you have sinned As Rav Dimi, the brother of Rav Safra teaches: anyone who takes a vow, even if he fulfills it, he is called a sinner. Rav Zevid said: What verse “But if you refrain to vow, it will be no sin in you” that you did not refrain there is sin.
llm_translation: Rava said to Rav Nachman: "See, Master, this scholar who came from Ma'arava and said: 'Let the Rabbis be strict with the son of Rav Huna bar Avin, and annul his vows for him, and they said to him: 'Go and request mercy for yourself for sin.' For Rav Dimi, the brother of Rav Safra, taught: 'Anyone who vows, even though he fulfills it, is called a sinner.' Rav Zebid said: What is the verse? 'If you refrain from vowing, you will not incur guilt.' If you did not refrain, there is guilt."

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא: הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשְׁתּוֹ ״כׇּל נְדָרִים שֶׁתִּדּוֹרִי, אִי אֶפְשִׁי שֶׁתִּדּוֹרִי״, ״אֵין זֶה נֶדֶר״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם. ״יָפֶה עָשִׂית״, וְ״אֵין כְּמוֹתֵךְ״, וְ״אִם לֹא נָדַרְתְּ, מַדִּירֵךְ אֲנִי״ — דְּבָרָיו קַיָּימִין.
human_translation: It is taught One who says to his wife: Any vows which you will vow, I do not want [ ee efshi ] you to vow, This is not a vow, has not said anything, You have done well, There are none like you, If you had not taken a vow, I, myself, would have taken a vow you his statement is substantial,
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: One who says to his wife, "All vows that you may take in the future are hereby nullified," or "I prohibit you from taking any vows," this is not considered a vow at all - he has said nothing. But if he says, "You have done well," or "There is none like you," or "If you have not vowed, I hereby prohibit you," his words are upheld.

hebrew_text: לֹא יֹאמַר אָדָם לְאִשְׁתּוֹ בְּשַׁבָּת ״מוּפָר לִיכִי״, ״בָּטֵיל לִיכִי״, כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁאוֹמֵר לָהּ בַּחוֹל, אֶלָּא אוֹמֵר לָהּ: ״טְלִי וְאִכְלִי״, ״טְלִי וּשְׁתִי״, וְהַנֶּדֶר בָּטֵל מֵאֵלָיו. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: וְצָרִיךְ שֶׁיְּבַטֵּל בְּלִבּוֹ.
human_translation: A man should not say to his wife on Shabbat: It is nullified for you, It is canceled for you, in the manner that he would say to her on weekdays. Rather, he should say to her, Take and eat Take and drink and the vow is canceled on its own. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And he must cancel in his heart;
llm_translation: A person should not say to his wife on Shabbat, "You are forbidden to me," "You are prohibited to me," as he would say to her on a weekday. Rather, he should say to her, "Take and eat," "Take and drink," and the vow is annulled from him. Rabbi Yochanan said: And he must annul it in his heart.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: בַּשַּׁבָּת מְבַטֵּל בְּלִבּוֹ, בַּחוֹל מוֹצִיא בִּשְׂפָתָיו. וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: אֶחָד זֶה וְאֶחָד זֶה — מְבַטֵּל בְּלִבּוֹ, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לְהוֹצִיא בִּשְׂפָתָיו.
human_translation: It is taught Beit Shammai say: On Shabbat he cancels in his heart on a weekday he articulates with his lips. And Beit Hillel say: Both this and that he cancels in his heart, and he need not articulate with his lips.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: Beit Shammai say: On Shabbat, one may nullify in his heart; on a weekday, he must verbalize. Beit Hillel say: Whether on Shabbat or on a weekday, one may nullify in his heart, and there is no need to verbalize.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: חָכָם שֶׁאָמַר בִּלְשׁוֹן בַּעַל, וּבַעַל שֶׁאָמַר בִּלְשׁוֹן חָכָם — לָא אָמַר כְּלוּם.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A halakhic authority who pronounced with language a husband, or a husband who pronounced with language a halakhic authority, has not said anything.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: A wise person who speaks in the language of an ignoramus, and an ignoramus who speaks in the language of a wise person — he has not said anything.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: ״זֶה הַדָּבָר״ — הֶחָכָם מַתִּיר וְאֵין בַּעַל מַתִּיר. שֶׁיָּכוֹל: וּמָה חָכָם שֶׁאֵין מֵפֵר — מַתִּיר, בַּעַל שֶׁמֵּפֵר — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁמַּתִּיר? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר:
human_translation: As it is taught “This is the thing a halakhic authority dissolves but a husband does not dissolve As, might And just as a halakhic authority, who cannot nullify dissolves a husband, who can nullify is it not logical that he should dissolve the verse states:
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "This is the matter" - the wise one permits, but the husband does not permit. So that he can: And what wise one does not annul - permits, a husband who annuls - is it not proper that he permits? The Torah teaches:

hebrew_text: ״זֶה הַדָּבָר״ — חָכָם מַתִּיר, וְאֵין בַּעַל מַתִּיר. תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: ״זֶה הַדָּבָר״ — בַּעַל מֵפֵר וְאֵין חָכָם מֵפֵר. שֶׁיָּכוֹל: וּמָה בַּעַל שֶׁאֵין מַתִּיר — מֵפֵר, חָכָם שֶׁמַּתִּיר — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁמֵּפֵר, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״זֶה הַדָּבָר״ — בַּעַל מֵפֵר, וְאֵין חָכָם מֵפֵר.
human_translation: “This is the thing” a halakhic authority dissolves but a husband does not dissolve is taught another “this is the thing” a husband nullifies but a halakhic authority does not nullify As, might Just as a husband, who cannot dissolve nullifies a halakhic authority, who can dissolve is it not logical that he should nullify the verse states: “This is the thing,” a husband nullifies but a halakhic authority does not nullify
llm_translation: "The matter" — a sage permits, and a layman does not permit. It was taught in another source: "The matter" — a layman annuls, and a sage does not annul. So that he can: And what is the case of a layman who does not permit — he annuls, a sage who permits — it is not proper for him to annul. The Scripture teaches: "The matter" — a layman annuls, and a sage does not annul.

hebrew_text: נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״זֶה הַדָּבָר״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״זֶה הַדָּבָר״ בִּשְׁחוּטֵי חוּץ. מָה בִּשְׁחוּטֵי חוּץ — אַהֲרֹן וּבָנָיו וְכׇל יִשְׂרָאֵל, אַף פָּרָשַׁת נְדָרִים — אַהֲרֹן וּבָנָיו וְכׇל יִשְׂרָאֵל. וּמָה כָּאן רָאשֵׁי הַמַּטּוֹת — אַף לְהַלָּן רָאשֵׁי הַמַּטּוֹת.
human_translation: It is stated here, “This is the thing,” and it is stated elsewhere: This is the thing in slaughtering outside Just as with regard to slaughtered outside Aaron and his sons and all Israel, so too, the portion about vows Aaron and his sons and all Israel. And just as here, the heads of the tribes so too, there, the heads of the tribes.
llm_translation: It is stated here "this is the matter," and it is stated there "this is the matter" in matters of slaughtering outside. Just as in matters of slaughtering outside - Aaron and his sons and all of Israel, so too in the section of vows - Aaron and his sons and all of Israel. And just as here the heads of the tribes - so too there the heads of the tribes.

hebrew_text: בְּפָרָשַׁת נְדָרִים לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא? אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב: לְהַכְשִׁיר שְׁלֹשָׁה הֶדְיוֹטוֹת. וְהָא ״רָאשֵׁי הַמַּטּוֹת״ כְּתִיב! אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: בְּיָחִיד מוּמְחֶה.
human_translation: With regard to the portion on vows, for what halakha Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov says: to authorize three laymen But isn’t it written: “The heads of the tribes”? Rav Ḥisda said, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan: by a single expert.
llm_translation: In the tractate of Nedarim, for what halakha? Rav Aḥa bar Ya'akov said: to validate three laymen. But isn't it written "chiefs of the tribes"? Rav Ḥisdah said, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan: in a unique case, it is permitted.

hebrew_text: רָאשֵׁי הַמַּטּוֹת בִּשְׁחוּטֵי חוּץ לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא? אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: לוֹמַר שֶׁיֵּשׁ שְׁאֵלָה בְּהֶקְדֵּשׁ.
human_translation: “the heads of the tribes” to slaughtered outside For what halakha Rav Sheshet said: to say that there is requesting of consecrated
llm_translation: Heads of the tribes in the slaughtered animals outside, for what purpose is the halakha? Rav Sheshet said: To say that there is a question in matters of consecration.

hebrew_text: לְבֵית שַׁמַּאי דְּאָמַר אֵין שְׁאֵלָה בְּהֶקְדֵּשׁ, ״רָאשֵׁי הַמַּטּוֹת״ דִּכְתִיב בִּשְׁחוּטֵי חוּץ לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא? בֵּית שַׁמַּאי לֵית לְהוּ גְּזֵירָה שָׁוָה.
human_translation: According to Beit Shammai, who say there is no requesting of consecrated “the heads of the tribes” as it were written about slaughtered outside to what halakha ? Beit Shammai do not have verbal analogy.
llm_translation: To the House of Shammai who says: One does not inquire about consecrated items, "the heads of the tribes" as it is written in the slaughtering of the Paschal lamb, what is the halakha? Beit Shammai does not have a similar decree.

hebrew_text: ״זֶה הַדָּבָר״ בְּפָרָשַׁת נְדָרִים לְמַאי כְּתִיב? לוֹמַר: חָכָם מַתִּיר וְאֵין בַּעַל מַתִּיר, בַּעַל מֵפֵר וְאֵין חָכָם מֵפֵר.
human_translation: for what is “this is the thing,” in the portion on vows, written? to say a halakhic authority dissolves but a husband does not dissolve a husband nullifies but a halakhic authority does not nullify
llm_translation: "This matter" in the tractate of Nedarim - what is it written for? To say: The wise one permits and the husband does not permit, the husband annuls and the wise one does not annul.

hebrew_text: ״זֶה הַדָּבָר״ בִּשְׁחוּטֵי חוּץ לְמַאי כְּתִיב? לוֹמַר: עַל הַשְּׁחִיטָה חַיָּיב, וְאֵין חַיָּיב עַל הַמְּלִיקָה.
human_translation: for what is written “this is the thing,” in slaughtered outside to say is liable for slaughtering but not liable for pinching
llm_translation: "This matter" in regards to slaughtering outside the Temple, what is written? To say: Regarding slaughtering one is liable, but one is not liable for salting."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְבֵית שַׁמַּאי, לְהַכְשִׁיר שְׁלֹשָׁה הֶדְיוֹטוֹת מְנָלַן? נָפְקָא לְהוּ מִדְּרַב אַסִּי בַּר נָתָן.
human_translation: But according to Beit Shammai, from where do we to authorize three laymen derive it from Rav Asi bar Natan.
llm_translation: Rather, according to the House of Shammai, how do they derive the validity of three laymen? It was derived for them from the teaching of Rav Assi bar Nathan.

hebrew_text: דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיְדַבֵּר מֹשֶׁה אֶת מֹעֲדֵי ה׳ אֶל בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״, וְהָתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי אוֹמֵר: ״מוֹעֲדֵי״ נֶאֶמְרוּ, וְלֹא נֶאֶמְרָה שַׁבַּת בְּרֵאשִׁית עִמָּהֶן. בֶּן עַזַּאי אוֹמֵר: ״מוֹעֲדֵי״ נֶאֶמְרוּ, וְלֹא נֶאֱמַר פָּרָשַׁת נְדָרִים עִמָּהֶן.
human_translation: as it is written: “And Moses declared the Festivals of the Lord to the children of Israel” And it is taught Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: The Festivals are stated, but Shabbat, Creation, is not stated with them. Ben Azzai says: The Festivals are stated, but the portion on vows is not stated with them.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: It is written: "And Moses spoke the appointed times of the Lord to the children of Israel." And it was taught: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean says: "Appointed times" were stated, and the Sabbath in Genesis was not stated with them. Ben Azzai says: "Appointed times" were stated, and the portion of vows was not stated with them.

hebrew_text: רַב אַסִּי בַּר נָתָן קַשְׁיָא לֵיהּ הָא מַתְנִיתָא. אֲתָא לִנְהַרְדְּעָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב שֵׁשֶׁת וְלָא אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ, אֲתָא אַבָּתְרֵיהּ לְמָחוֹזָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מוֹעֲדֵי ה׳ נֶאֶמְרוּ, וְלֹא נֶאֶמְרָה שַׁבַּת בְּרֵאשִׁית עִמָּהֶן?
human_translation: Rav Asi bar Natan had a difficulty with this baraita . He came to Neharde’a before Rav Sheshet, but he did not find him He pursued him to Meḥoza said to the Festivals of the Lord were stated, but Shabbat, Creation, was not stated with them?
llm_translation: Rav Assi bar Nathan found it difficult, this Mishnah. He came to Nehardea before Rav Sheshet, but did not find him. He came after him to Mahoza. He said to him: "Appointed times of the Lord were stated, and Shabbat was not stated along with them in the beginning?"

hebrew_text: וְהָא כְּתִיב שַׁבָּת עִמָּהֶן! וְתוּ: מוֹעֲדֵי ה׳ נֶאֶמְרוּ, וְלֹא נֶאֶמְרָה פָּרָשַׁת נְדָרִים עִמָּהֶן? וְהָא מִסִּיטְרָא כְּתִיבָא! אֲמַר לֵיהּ, הָכִי קָתָנֵי:
human_translation: But Shabbat is written with them And furthermore, the Festivals of the Lord are stated, but the portion on vows is not stated with them? Isn’t it next to said to him: This is what is teaching:
llm_translation: And this, as it is written, "Shabbat with them!" And come and see: the appointed times of the Lord were mentioned, and the portion of Nedarim was not mentioned with them? And this is written in the Misitra! He said to him, so it is taught:

hebrew_text: מוֹעֲדֵי ה׳ צְרִיכִין קִידּוּשׁ בֵּית דִּין, שַׁבַּת בְּרֵאשִׁית אֵין צְרִיכָה קִידּוּשׁ בֵּית דִּין.
human_translation: The Festivals of the Lord require sanctification by the court, Shabbat, Creation, does not require sanctification by the court.
llm_translation: The festivals of the Lord require sanctification by the court, Shabbat at the beginning does not require sanctification by the court.

hebrew_text: מוֹעֲדֵי ה׳ צְרִיכִין מוּמְחֶה, וְאֵין פָּרָשַׁת נְדָרִים צְרִיכִין מוּמְחֶה, אֲפִילּוּ בֵּית דִּין הֶדְיוֹטוֹת.
human_translation: The Festivals of the Lord require an expert, But the portion on vows does not require an expert, even a court of laymen.
llm_translation: Appointed times of the Lord require a blemish, and the portion of vows does not require a blemish, even in the court of laymen.

hebrew_text: וְהָא בְּפָרָשַׁת נְדָרִים ״רָאשֵׁי הַמַּטּוֹת״ כְּתִיב! אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: בְּיָחִיד מוּמְחֶה.
human_translation: But in the portion on vows “the heads of the tribes” is written. Rav Ḥisda said, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan: by a single expert
llm_translation: In the matter of vows, "the heads of the tribes" is written! Rav Hisda said, and some say it was Rabbi Yochanan: In a private individual, it is erased.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִינָא: הַשּׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְמֵיקַט, מֵפֵר אֲפִילּוּ מִכָּאן וְעַד עֲשָׂרָה יָמִים. מֵתִיב רָבָא: אֵימָתַי אָמְרוּ מֵת הַבַּעַל נִתְרוֹקְנָה רְשׁוּת לָאָב — בִּזְמַן שֶׁלֹּא שָׁמַע הַבַּעַל, אוֹ שֶׁשָּׁמַע וְשָׁתַק, אוֹ שֶׁשָּׁמַע וְהֵפֵר וּמֵת בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם. אֲבָל שָׁמַע וְקִיֵּים, אוֹ שֶׁשָּׁמַע וְשָׁתַק וּמֵת בַּיּוֹם שֶׁל אַחֲרָיו — אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥanina says: who is silent in order to annoy [ lemeikat ] can nullify even from now until ten days Rava raised an objection When did they say the husband dies, authority reverts to the father? when the husband did not hear or when he heard and was silent, or when he heard and nullified and died on the same day. But he heard and ratified or if he heard and was silent and died on the following day, he, cannot nullify
llm_translation: Rabbi Chanina said: One who remains silent in order to be lenient, violates the vow even from here to ten days. Rava raises an objection: When did they say that the husband's vow is annulled? When the husband did not hear, or when he heard and remained silent, or when he heard and annulled it and died on that day. But if he heard and fulfilled the vow, or if he heard and remained silent and died on the following day, he cannot annul the vow.

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו, בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְמֵיקַט? לֹא, בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְקַיֵּים. אִי הָכִי, הַיְינוּ אוֹ שָׁמַע וְקִיֵּים! אֶלָּא, בְּשׁוֹתֵק סְתָם.
human_translation: What, is not to one who is silent in order to annoy No, to one who is silent in order to sustain If so, this is Or he heard and ratified, Rather, to one who is silent without any specific
llm_translation: What is the reason why one remains silent with the intention to acquit? No, one remains silent with the intention to fulfill. If so, this is the same as "hear and fulfill"! Rather, one remains silent without specifying.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב חִסְדָּא: חוֹמֶר בְּהָקֵם מִבְּהָפֵר, וּבְהָפֵר מִבְּהָקֵם. חוֹמֶר בְּהָקֵם —
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda raised an objection stringent in ratification than in nullification, and in nullification than in ratification. stringency in ratification
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Ḥisda raised a contradiction: A stringency in establishing a boundary overruled by a leniency in breaking it, and a leniency in breaking it overruled by a stringency in establishing it. A stringency in establishing it—

hebrew_text: שֶׁהַשְּׁתִיקָה מְקַיֶּימֶת, וְאֵין שְׁתִיקָה מְבַטֶּלֶת. קִיֵּים בְּלִבּוֹ — קַיָּים, הֵפֵר בְּלִבּוֹ — אֵינוֹ מוּפָר. קִיֵּים — אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר, הֵפֵר — אֵין יָכוֹל לְקַיֵּים. קָתָנֵי: שֶׁהַשְּׁתִיקָה מְקַיֶּימֶת, מַאי לָאו בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְמֵיקַט?
human_translation: that silence ratifies but silence does not cancel, ratified in his heart, it is ratified, he nullified in his heart, it is not nullified. If he ratified he can no longer nullify if he nullified he can no longer ratify teaches that silence ratifies What, is it not to one who is silent in order to annoy
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "The one who remains silent upholds, and silence does not annul. If one upheld in his heart - he upholds, if he annulled in his heart - it is not annulled. If one upheld - he cannot annul, if he annulled - he cannot uphold. It was taught: 'The one who remains silent upholds,' what is it? Is it not that he remains silent with the intention to protest?"

hebrew_text: לֹא, בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְקַיֵּים. הַיְינוּ: קִיֵּים בְּלִבּוֹ קַיָּים! אֶלָּא בְּשׁוֹתֵק סְתָם.
human_translation: No, to one who is silent in order to sustain this is If ratified in his heart, it is ratified. Rather, to is silent without specifying
llm_translation: Not, in order to fulfill. That is: fulfilled in his heart fulfilled! Rather, in order to fulfill silently.

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן חוֹמֶר בְּהָקֵם מִבְּהָפֵר, בְּהָפֵר מִבְּהָקֵם מְנָא לַן? אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: נִשְׁאָלִין עַל הֶהָקֵם, וְאֵין נִשְׁאָלִין עַל הֶהָפֵר.
human_translation: We found stringent in ratification than in nullification where we in in nullification than in ratification? Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One can request the ratification but one cannot request the nullification
llm_translation: We find a stringency in establishing from nullification, but from nullification to establishing, how do we know? Rabbi Yochanan said: We inquire about establishing, but we do not inquire about nullification.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב כָּהֲנָא: ״וְאִם הַחֲרֵשׁ יַחֲרִישׁ לָהּ אִישָׁהּ וְגוֹ׳״, בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְמֵיקַט הַכָּתוּב מְדַבַּר. אַתָּה אוֹמֵר בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְמֵיקַט, אוֹ אֵינוֹ אֶלָּא בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְקַיֵּים?
human_translation: Rav Kahana raised an objection “But if her husband altogether hold his peace at her The verse is speaking of one who is silent in order to annoy you say to one who is silent in order to annoy or it is only to one who is silent in order to ratify
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: "And if the deaf man remains silent to her, his wife, etc." - he remains silent in order to fulfill what is written. Do you say he remains silent in order to fulfill, or is it rather that he remains silent in order to transgress?

hebrew_text: כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר ״כִּי הֶחֱרִשׁ לָהּ״, הֲרֵי בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְקַיֵּים הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר, הָא מָה אֲנִי מְקַיֵּים ״אִם הַחֲרֵשׁ יַחֲרִישׁ לָהּ אִישָׁהּ״ — בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְמֵיקַט הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר! תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: When it says, because he held his peace at her the verse is speaking of one who is silent in order to ratify How do I realize “If her husband altogether holds his peace at her”? the verse is speaking of one who is silent in order to annoy a conclusive refutation [ teyuveta ]
llm_translation: When he says "if he remains silent for her," behold, he is silent in order to fulfill what is written, so what am I fulfilling "if a man remains silent for his wife" - he is silent in order to fulfill what is written! A contradiction.

hebrew_text: וְלוֹקֵים: הָא — בְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְקַיֵּים, הָא — בְּשׁוֹתֵק סְתָם! קְרָאֵי יַתִּירִי כְּתִיבִי.
human_translation: And let interpret this to one who is silent in order to ratify that to one who was silent without specifying Superfluous verses are written
llm_translation: And they argue: This one - by specifying in order to fulfill, this one - by specifying generally! The verses are written extra.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רָבָא: נָדְרָה עִם חֲשֵׁכָה — מֵפֵר לָהּ עַד שֶׁלֹּא חָשְׁכָה, שֶׁאִם לֹא הֵפֵר וְחָשְׁכָה — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. אַמַּאי? לֶהֱוֵי כְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְמֵיקַט! תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: Rava raised objection she took a vow with nightfall can nullify until nightfall, since, if it became dark and he had not nullified he cannot nullify Why Let like one who is silent in order to annoy a conclusive refutation
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: If one made a vow with "nightfall," he may annul it for her until it is not nightfall, for if he did not annul it and it became nightfall, he cannot annul it. Why? It should be like one who is silent in order to speak! This is a refutation.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב אָשֵׁי: ״יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי שֶׁיֵּשׁ נְדָרִים, אֲבָל אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁיֵּשׁ מְפִירִין״ — יָפֵר. ״יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי שֶׁיֵּשׁ מְפִירִין, אֲבָל אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁזֶּה נֶדֶר״, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָפֵר, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: יָפֵר.
human_translation: Rav Ashi raised an objection I know that there are vows, but I do not know that there are those who nullify he can nullify I know there are those who nullify, but I do not know that this is a vow Rabbi Meir says: He cannot nullify but the Rabbis say: he can nullify
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Ashi asks, "I know that there are vows, but I do not know that there are annulments" — he annuls. "I know that there are annulments, but I do not know that this is a vow," Rabbi Meir says: he does not annul, and the Sages say: he annuls.

hebrew_text: וְאַמַּאי? לֶיהֱוֵי כְּשׁוֹתֵק עַל מְנָת לְמֵיקַט! תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: But why Let like one who is silent in order to annoy, a conclusive refutation
llm_translation: And why? Let him be silent in order to be saved! It is better.

hebrew_text: הָדְרָן עֲלָךְ נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה
llm_translation: We will return to you, betrothed maiden.

hebrew_text: וְאֵלּוּ נְדָרִים שֶׁהוּא מֵפֵר: דְּבָרִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ: ״אִם אֶרְחַץ״ וְ״אִם לֹא אֶרְחַץ״, ״אִם אֶתְקַשֵּׁט״ וְ״אִם לֹא אֶתְקַשֵּׁט״.
human_translation: And these are vows that he, can nullify: matters that involve affliction If I bathe, or: If I do not bathe; If I adorn myself [ etkashet ], or: If I do not adorn myself.
llm_translation: And these are vows that one may annul: matters that involve self-affliction. "If I bathe" and "If I do not bathe," "If I adorn myself" and "If I do not adorn myself."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: אֵין אֵלּוּ נִדְרֵי עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ. וְאֵלּוּ הֵן נִדְרֵי עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ: אָמְרָה ״קֻוֽנָּם פֵּירוֹת הָעוֹלָם עָלַי״ — הֲרֵי זֶה יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. ״פֵּירוֹת מְדִינָה זוֹ עָלַי״ — יָבִיא לָהּ מִמְּדִינָה אַחֶרֶת. ״פֵּירוֹת חֶנְווֹנִי זֶה עָלַי״ — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. וְאִם לֹא הָיְתָה פַּרְנָסָתוֹ אֶלָּא מִמֶּנּוּ — הֲרֵי זֶה יָפֵר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei said: These are not vows of affliction. Rather, these are vows of affliction: she said: The produce of the world is konam for me as if an offering, he can nullify The produce of this country is for me, he may bring her from another country. The produce of this storekeeper is for me, he cannot nullify But if his sustenance only from him, he can nullify the statement of Rabbi Yosei.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei said: These are not vows of affliction of the soul. And these are vows of affliction of the soul: If she said, "Let the fruits of the world be forbidden to me" — she can annul it. "Let the fruits of this province be forbidden to me" — she can bring them from another province. "Let the fruits of Chenwoni be forbidden to me" — she cannot annul it. And if his sustenance only comes from him — he can annul it, these are the words of Rabbi Yosei.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ נִדְרֵי עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ הוּא דְּמֵפֵר, שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ אֵינוֹ מֵפֵר? וְהָא תַּנְיָא: ״בֵּין אִישׁ לְאִשְׁתּוֹ בֵּין אָב לְבִתּוֹ״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהַבַּעַל מֵפֵר נְדָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ!
human_translation: vows of affliction that he can nullify, that do not involve affliction he cannot nullify? But isn’t it taught between a man and his wife, between a father and his daughter” teaches that a husband can nullify vows that between him and her,
llm_translation: Gemara: Is it that vows of affliction are annulled, as they do not contain affliction, they are not annulled? But it was taught in a Baraita: "Between a man and his wife, between a father and his daughter" — this teaches that a husband annuls vows between him and his wife!

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: הָלֵין וְהָלֵין מֵפֵר, מִיהוּ עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ — מֵפֵר לְעוֹלָם. אֲבָל אֵין בָּהֶן עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ, כִּדְאִיתַהּ תְּחוֹתֵיהּ — הָוְיָא הֲפָרָה, מִכִּי מְגָרֵשׁ לַהּ — חָיֵיל עֲלַהּ נִדְרַהּ. בִּדְבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ. אֲבָל יֵשׁ בָּהֶן עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ — לָא חָיֵיל עֲלַיהּ נִדְרַהּ.
human_translation: say he can nullify these and those. however, affliction, he nullifies forever, But do not involve affliction while she is under his it is an nullification, when divorces her, her vow takes effect upon her, to matters that between him and her, that do not involve affliction. However, involves affliction, her vow does not take effect upon her
llm_translation: They said: If he divorces and she divorces, he permanently annuls. But if there is no annulment of the soul, as it is below, it is considered a cow. Since he divorces her, her vow is valid. In matters between him and her where there is no annulment of the soul. But if there is an annulment of the soul, her vow is not valid.

hebrew_text: וּדְבָרִים שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ, כִּי מְגָרֵשׁ לַהּ חָיְילָא עֲלַהּ? וְהָא תְּנַן, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי אוֹמֵר: יָפֵר, שֶׁמָּא יְגָרְשֶׁנָּה וּתְהֵא אֲסוּרָה לוֹ. אַלְמָא: כִּי מְגָרֵשׁ לַהּ וּמֵפַר לַהּ מֵעִיקָּרָא — הָוְיָא הֲפָרָה!
human_translation: And matters that do not involve affliction, when divorces they take effect upon her? But didn’t we learn Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says: he should nullify perhaps he will divorce her, and she will be forbidden to him, Apparently, if he divorces her having nullified her from the outset, it is nullification,
llm_translation: And matters that do not involve affliction of the soul, for it is like a military camp to her? But didn't we learn, Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri says: It is better, lest he divorce her and she becomes forbidden to him. This implies: for it is like a divorce and annulling from the outset — it is considered a heifer!

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: הָלֵין וְהָלֵין הָוְיָא הֲפָרָה. אֶלָּא: נִדְרֵי עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ מֵפֵר, בֵּין לְעַצְמוֹ וּבֵין לַאֲחֵרִים. אֵין בָּהֶן עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ, לְעַצְמוֹ — מֵפֵר, לַאֲחֵרִים — אֵינוֹ מֵפֵר. וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: אֵלּוּ נְדָרִים שֶׁהוּא מֵפֵר בֵּין לְעַצְמוֹ וּבֵין לַאֲחֵרִים — נְדָרִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ.
human_translation: say these and those, is nullification. Rather, Vows of affliction he can nullify, both with respect to himself and with respect to others, do not involve affliction he can nullify with respect to himself, he cannot nullify with respect to others; And this is what is teaching: These are vows that he can nullify both for himself and for others: Vows that involve affliction.
llm_translation: They said: "Halin and Halin is considered a nullification. Rather, vows of affliction annul, whether for oneself or for others. If there is affliction for oneself, one annuls; for others, one does not annul." And so it is taught: "These are vows that one annuls, whether for oneself or for others - vows that involve affliction of the soul."

hebrew_text: ״אִם אֶרְחַץ״, הֵיכִי קָאָמַר? אִילֵּימָא דְּאָמְרָה ״קֻוֽנָּם פֵּירוֹת עוֹלָם עָלַי אִם אֶרְחַץ״ — לְמָה לֵהּ הֲפָרָה? לָא תִּרְחַץ וְלָא לִיתַּסְרָן פֵּירוֹת עוֹלָם אֵלּוּ עֲלַהּ!
human_translation: If I bathe, what is speaking? If we say that she said: The produce of the world is konam for me if I bathe, why, does she nullification not bathe and this produce of the world will not be forbidden to her.
llm_translation: "If I wash," what is it saying? If you say that it means, "Their vine is from the vine of Sodom, and from the fields of Gomorrah; their grapes are grapes of gall, their clusters are bitter," why should the heifer be slaughtered for it? Do not wash, and do not let the fruits of the world be harmed, these are its leaves!

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד: בְּהָא לֵימָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אֵין אֵלּוּ נִדְרֵי עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ? דִּלְמָא רָחֲצָה וְאִיתַּסְרוּ פֵּירוֹת עוֹלָם עֲלַהּ.
human_translation: And furthermore, With regard to this would Rabbi Yosei say these are not vows of affliction? perhaps she will bathe and the produce of the world will be forbidden to her,
llm_translation: And furthermore: In this matter, Rabbi Yosei said, "Are these not vows of affliction of the soul? Perhaps she bathed and the fruits of the world were removed from her."

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא: דְּאָמְרָה ״קֻוֽנָּם הֲנָאַת רְחִיצָה עָלַי לְעוֹלָם אִם אֶרְחַץ״, מִשּׁוּם הָכִי מֵיפֵר לָהּ. דְּהֵיכִי תַּעֲבֵיד? תִּרְחַץ — מִתַּסְרָא הֲנָאַת רְחִיצָה עֲלַהּ, לָא תִּרְחַץ אִית לַהּ נִיוּוּלָא. וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי סָבַר: אֶפְשָׁר דְּלָא רָחֲצָה, וּלְנִיוּוּל לָא חָיְישִׁינַן.
human_translation: But rather, that she said: The benefit of bathing is konam for me forever if I bathe. due to that he may nullify her as what can she do she bathes, the benefit of bathing is forbidden to her. she does not bathe, she will disfigurement [ nivvula ]. And Rabbi Yosei, maintains it is possible for her not to bathe, we are not concerned about disfigurement.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And rather, it is that which said, "If the benefit of washing is upon me forever, if I will wash," because of this he nullifies it for her. How will he act? She should wash — if the benefit of washing is upon her, she should not wash, there is no concern for her. And Rabbi Yosei holds: It is possible that she did not wash, and we are not concerned for her.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, לִיתְנֵי הָכִי, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: תְּנַאי זֶה אֵין בּוֹ עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ!
human_translation: If so, let teach like this: Rabbi Yosei says this condition does not involve affliction,
llm_translation: So it is not taught thus, Rabbi Yosei says: This Mishna does not involve endangering a life!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא דְּאָמְרָה: ״הֲנָאַת רְחִיצָה עָלַי לְעוֹלָם אִם אֶרְחַץ הַיּוֹם״. וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי סָבַר: נִיוּוּל דְּחַד יוֹמָא לָא שְׁמֵיהּ נִיוּוּל.
human_translation: Rather, that she said: The benefit of bathing is for me forever if I bathe today. And Rabbi Yosei maintains disfigurement from one day is not called disfigurement.
llm_translation: Rather, it said: "The pleasure of bathing is upon me forever if I bathe today." And Rabbi Yosei holds: A one-day delay is not called a delay.

hebrew_text: שַׁנֵּית ״אִם אֶרְחַץ״. ״אִם לֹא אֶרְחַץ״ הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִלֵּימָא דְּאָמְרָה: ״תִּיתְּסַר הֲנָאַת רְחִיצָה לְעוֹלָם עָלַי אִם לֹא אֶרְחַץ הַיּוֹם״ — לְמָה לָהּ הֲפָרָה? תִּתְסְחֵי! אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: דְּאָמְרָה ״הֲנָאַת רְחִיצָה עָלַי לְעוֹלָם אִם לֹא אֶרְחַץ בְּמֵי מִשְׁרָה״.
human_translation: You answered If I bathe, If I do not bathe, what are the circumstances? If we say that she said: The benefit of bathing shall be forbidden to me forever if I do not bathe today, why does she nullification Let her bathe Rav Yehuda said: where she said: The benefit of bathing is to me forever if I do not bathe in water soaked.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Shaneit 'im erchatz'. 'Im lo erchatz' heichi damei? Ileima de'amra: 'Tittesar hanat rechitzah le'olam alai im lo erchatz hayom' — lama lah hafarah? Titschei! Amar Rav Yehudah: de'amra 'hanat rechitzah alai le'olam im lo erchatz b'mei mishra."

hebrew_text: דִּכְווֹתֵיהּ דְּקָתָנֵי ״אִם לֹא אֶתְקַשֵּׁט״ — אִם לֹא אֶתְקַשֵּׁט בְּנֵפְטְ. לִכְלוּךְ הוּא!
human_translation: similarly that which teaches: If I do not adorn myself, if I do not adorn myself with naphtha [ neft ]. is filthy
llm_translation: His beard, as it is taught: "If I do not adorn myself" - if I do not adorn myself with oil. It is a disgrace!

hebrew_text: אָמַר [רַב יְהוּדָה], דְּאָמְרָה: ״הֲנָאַת רְחִיצָה לְעוֹלָם עָלַי אִם אֶרְחַץ הַיּוֹם, וּשְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶרְחַץ״, ״הֲנָאַת קִישּׁוּט עָלַי לְעוֹלָם אִם אֶתְקַשֵּׁט הַיּוֹם, וּשְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶתְקַשֵּׁט״.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said where she said: The benefit of bathing to me forever if I bathe today, and an oath that I will not bathe The benefit of adornment to me forever if I adorn myself today, and an oath that I will not adorn myself
llm_translation: He said Rav Yehudah, as it was said: "The benefit of bathing is upon me forever if I bathe today, and the detriment of neglecting grooming is upon me forever if I adorn myself today, and a week passes without adorning myself."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: הַאי ״אֵלּוּ נְדָרִים וּשְׁבוּעוֹת״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְמִיתְנֵי! אֲמַר לֵיהּ, תְּנִי: אֵלּוּ נְדָרִים וּשְׁבוּעוֹת. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: שְׁבוּעוֹת נָמֵי הַיְינוּ נְדָרִים. דִּתְנַן: ״כְּנִדְרֵי רְשָׁעִים״ — נָדַר בְּנָזִיר וּבְקׇרְבָּן וּבִשְׁבוּעָה.
human_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: this should have taught: These are the vows and oaths said to him: Teach These are the vows and oaths. And if you wish, say oaths are also vows. As we learned Like the vows of the wicked, vowed with respect to a nazirite, and with regard to an offering, and with regard to an oath.
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Does he require that the phrase "these are vows and oaths" be explicitly stated in the Mishnah? He said to him, teach: "These are vows and oaths." And if you wish, say: Oaths are also vows. As we learned: "Like the vows of the wicked" - he vowed to be a Nazirite, and to bring a sacrifice, and to take an oath.

hebrew_text: וַאֲמַרוּ רַבָּנַן: רְחִיצָה אִית בַּהּ עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ כִּי לָא רָחֲצָה? וּרְמִינְהִי: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאָסוּר בְּכוּלָּן — אֵין עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת אֶלָּא בְּאוֹכֵל וְשׁוֹתֶה וְעוֹשֶׂה מְלָאכָה בִּלְבַד. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ כִּי לָא רָחֲצָה אִיכָּא עִנּוּי, בְּיוֹם הַכִּיפּוּרִים כִּי רָחַץ לִיחַיַּיב כָּרֵת!
human_translation: And the Rabbis, say bathing when she does not bathe it involves affliction? raises a contradiction Although one is prohibited from any one is punished karet only when one eats or drinks or performs labor alone. And if you say when does not bathe there is affliction, if one bathes on Yom Kippur, he should be liable karet ,
llm_translation: The sages said: There is immersion in it for affliction of the soul, for she did not immerse? And raise a contradiction: Even though they are all forbidden - the punishment of excision applies only to one who eats, drinks, and works alone. And if you say that she did not immerse, there is affliction, on Yom Kippur, for if he bathed, he is liable to excision!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מֵעִנְיָנָא דִקְרָא. גַּבֵּי יוֹם הַכִּיפּוּרִים דִּכְתִיב ״תְּעַנּוּ אֶת נַפְשׁוֹתֵיכֶם״ — מִילְּתָא דְּיָדַע עִינּוּיָא הַשְׁתָּא. רְחִיצָה לָא יָדַע עִינּוּיָא הַשְׁתָּא. גַּבֵּי נְדָרִים דִּכְתִיב ״כׇּל נֵדֶר וְכׇל שְׁבוּעַת אִסָּר לְעַנּוֹת נָפֶשׁ״ — מִילְּתָא דְּאָתְיָא לֵיהּ לִידֵי עִנּוּי, וְכִי לָא רָחֲצָה אָתְיָא לִידֵי עִנּוּי.
human_translation: Rava said: from the context of the verse. With regard to Yom Kippur, where it is written: you shall afflict your souls” a matter for which one knows the affliction now, bathing, does not know the affliction now, with regard to vows, where it is written: “Every vow and every binding oath to afflict the soul, a matter that leads to affliction, and if she does not bathe it leads to affliction.
llm_translation: Rava said: From the matter of the verse. Regarding Yom Kippur, as it is written, "You shall afflict your souls" — this refers to affliction of the soul now. Regarding immersion, it does not refer to affliction of the soul now. Regarding vows, as it is written, "Every vow and every binding oath to afflict the soul" — this refers to something that leads to affliction, and if immersion does not lead to affliction.

hebrew_text: וְרָמֵי דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי אַדְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי: מַעְיָין שֶׁל בְּנֵי הָעִיר, חַיֵּיהֶן וְחַיֵּי אֲחֵרִים — חַיֵּיהֶן קוֹדְמִין לְחַיֵּי אֲחֵרִים. בְּהֶמְתָּם [וּבֶהֱמַת אֲחֵרִים — בְּהֶמְתָּם] קוֹדֶמֶת לְבֶהֱמַת אֲחֵרִים. כְּבִיסָתָן וּכְבִיסַת אֲחֵרִים — כְּבִיסָתָן קוֹדֶמֶת לִכְבִיסַת אֲחֵרִים. חַיֵּי אֲחֵרִים וּכְבִיסָתָן — חַיֵּי אֲחֵרִים קוֹדְמִין לִכְבִיסָתָן.
human_translation: raises a contradiction of Rabbi Yosei and of Rabbi Yosei. a spring belonging to the residents of a city, their lives, and the lives of others, their lives take precedence over the lives of others. their animals and the animals of others, their animals take precedence over the animals of others. their laundry and the laundry of others, their laundry takes precedence over the laundry of others. the lives of others and their laundry, the lives of others take precedence over their laundry.
llm_translation: The statement of Rabbi Yosei after Rabbi Yosei: The spring of the inhabitants of the city, their animals and the animals of others - their animals take precedence over the animals of others. Their livestock and the livestock of others - their livestock take precedence over the livestock of others. Their laundry and the laundry of others - their laundry takes precedence over the laundry of others. The animals of others and their laundry - the animals of others take precedence over their laundry.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: כְּבִיסָתָן קוֹדֶמֶת לְחַיֵּי אֲחֵרִים. הַשְׁתָּא כְּבִיסָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי יֵשׁ בָּהּ צַעַר,
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei says: their laundry takes precedence over the lives of others, Now, laundry, Rabbi Yosei said involves pain
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei says: The laundering precedes the lives of others. Another teaching: Regarding laundering, Rabbi Yosei said: It involves distress.

hebrew_text: גּוּף כּוּלּוֹ לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?! אָמְרִי: אִין, כְּבִיסָה אַלִּימָא לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי. דְּאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הַאי עַרְבּוּבִיתָא דְרֵישָׁא — מַתְיָא לִידֵי עֲוִירָא, עַרְבּוּבִיתָא דְמָאנֵי — מַתְיָא לִידֵי שַׁעְמוּמִיתָא, עַרְבּוּבִיתָא דְגוּפָא — מַתְיָא לִידֵי שִׁיחְנֵי וְכִיבֵי.
human_translation: not all the more so entire body, say Yes, laundering is stronger, according to Rabbi Yosei, As Shmuel said: Grime on head leads to blindness, grime on clothes leads to madness, grime on body leads to boils and sores,
llm_translation: The entire body, not to mention?! They said: No, like a laundry. Meaning to say, according to Rabbi Yosei. For Samuel said: This first mixture is susceptible to blindness, the second mixture is susceptible to leprosy, the third mixture is susceptible to baldness and impetigo.

hebrew_text: שְׁלַחוּ מִתָּם: הִזָּהֲרוּ בְּעַרְבּוּבִיתָא. הִזָּהֲרוּ בַּחֲבוּרָה. הִזָּהֲרוּ בִּבְנֵי עֲנִיִּים, שֶׁמֵּהֶן תֵּצֵא תּוֹרָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״יִזַּל מַיִם מִדַּלָּיו״, שֶׁמֵּהֶן תֵּצֵא תּוֹרָה.
human_translation: sent from there, Be careful with regard to grime, Be careful in the company be careful of the sons of paupers, as from them the Torah will issue forth. As it is stated: “Water shall flow from his branches [ midalyav ]” as from them the Torah, will issue forth.
llm_translation: Send them: Be careful in the evening. Be careful in the company. Be careful with the children of the poor, for from them Torah will come forth, as it is said: "Water shall drip from his bucket," from them Torah will come forth.

hebrew_text: וּמִפְּנֵי מָה אֵין מְצוּיִין תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים לָצֵאת תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים מִבְּנֵיהֶן? אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף, שֶׁלֹּא יֹאמְרוּ: תּוֹרָה יְרוּשָּׁה הִיא לָהֶם. רַב שֵׁשֶׁת בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִידִי אוֹמֵר: כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יִתְגַּדְּרוּ עַל הַצִּבּוּר. מָר זוּטְרָא אוֹמֵר: מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהֵן מִתְגַּבְּרִין עַל הַצִּבּוּר. רַב אָשֵׁי אוֹמֵר: מִשּׁוּם דְּקָרוּ לְאִינָשֵׁי ״חֲמָרֵי״.
human_translation: And for what reason is it not common for Torah scholars to give rise to Torah scholars from among their sons? Rav Yosef said: so that they should not say the Torah is their inheritance. Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, said: so that they should not be presumptuous [ yitgadderu ] toward the community, Mar Zutra said: Because they lord over the community Rav Ashi said: Because they call people donkeys.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And why are the students of the sages not found to be marrying off their daughters to the students of the sages? Rav Yosef said, so that they should not say, 'Torah is our inheritance.' Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, said, in order that they should not become arrogant towards the community. Mar Zutra said, because they are domineering over the community. Rav Ashe said, because people have called them 'donkeys.'" English translation:

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא אוֹמֵר: שֶׁאֵין מְבָרְכִין בַּתּוֹרָה תְּחִלָּה. דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״מִי הָאִישׁ הֶחָכָם וְיָבֵן אֶת זֹאת״ — דָּבָר זֶה נִשְׁאַל לַחֲכָמִים וְלַנְּבִיאִים וְלֹא פֵּירְשׁוּהוּ,
human_translation: Ravina says: because they do not first recite a blessing over the Torah As Rav Yehuda said Rav said: What is which is written: “Who is the wise man that may understand this, This matter, was asked of the Sages, and of the prophets, but they could not explain it.
llm_translation: Ravina says: One does not recite a blessing before studying Torah. As Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: What is the meaning of the verse, "Who is the wise man that may understand this?" - this matter was asked of the sages and the prophets, and they did not explain it.

hebrew_text: עַד שֶׁפֵּירְשׁוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בְּעַצְמוֹ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֹּאמֶר ה׳ עַל עׇזְבָם אֶת תּוֹרָתִי וְגוֹ׳״. הַיְינוּ ״לֹא שָׁמְעוּ בְּקוֹלִי״, הַיְינוּ ״לֹא הָלְכוּ בָּהּ״! אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: שֶׁאֵין מְבָרְכִין בַּתּוֹרָה תְּחִלָּה.
human_translation: until the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself explained as it is written “And the Lord said: Because they have forsaken My Torah “have not obeyed My voice” is “nor walked therein.” Rav Yehuda said Rav said: that they do not first recite a blessing over the Torah,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Until the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself explained it, as it is written: "And the Lord said, 'Because they have forsaken My Torah, and so on.'" That is, "They did not listen to My voice," that is, "They did not walk in it!" Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: One does not recite a blessing over the Torah first.

hebrew_text: אִיסִי בַּר יְהוּדָה לָא אֲתָא לִמְתִיבְתָּא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי תְּלָתָא יוֹמֵי. אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ וַרְדִּימוֹס בְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי טַעְמָא לָא אָתֵי מָר לְבֵי מִדְרְשָׁא דְּאַבָּא הָא תְּלָתָא יוֹמִין? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כִּי טַעְמֵיהּ דַּאֲבוּךְ לָא יָדַעְנָא, הֵיכָא אֵיתָאי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לֵימָא מָר מַאי קָאָמַר לֵיהּ, דִּלְמָא יָדַעְנָא טַעְמֵיהּ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָא דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: כְּבִיסָתָן קוֹדְמִין לְחַיֵּי אֲחֵרִים, קְרָא מְנָלַן?
human_translation: Isi bar Yehuda did not come to the academy of Rabbi Yosei three days. Vardimus, son of Rabbi Yosei, found him said to him: What is the reason that the Master did not come to Father’s academy these three days? He said to him: When I do not know your father’s reasoning, how can I come? said to him: Let the Master say what he, is saying to him; perhaps I know his reasoning. He said to him: that which is taught Rabbi Yosei says their laundry takes precedence over the lives of others, from where do we a verse
llm_translation: Isi son of Judah did not come to the study hall of Rabbi Yosei for three days. He found him in the marketplace, the son of Rabbi Yosei. He said to him: "Why did the master not come to the study hall of my father for three days?" He said to him: "For the reasons of your father we do not know, where did he go?" He said to him: "Let the master say, what is he saying to him, perhaps we know his reasons." He said to him: "As it is taught, Rabbi Yosei says: Their laundering precedes the lives of others, where is this verse from?"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וּמִגְרְשֵׁיהֶם יִהְיוּ לִבְהֶמְתָּם וְגוֹ׳״. מַאי ״חַיָּיתָם״? אִילֵּימָא חַיָּה — וַהֲלֹא חַיָּה בִּכְלַל בְּהֵמָה הִיא. אֶלָּא מַאי ״חַיָּיתָם״ — חַיּוּתָא מַמָּשׁ. פְּשִׁיטָא! אֶלָּא לָאו כְּבִיסָה, דְּהָא אִיכָּא צַעְרָא דְעַרְבּוּבִיתָא.
human_translation: said to him: As it is written “And their open land shall be for their animals What is “their beasts”? If we say beast, as isn’t a beast included in animal, Rather, what is “their beasts ḥayyatam their actual lives [ ḥiyyuta ]. is obvious Rather, is it not laundering as there is pain grime
llm_translation: He said to him, as it is written: "And their fields shall be for their livestock, etc." What is meant by "their livestock"? If you say it means a wild animal - but isn't a wild animal included in the category of livestock? Rather, what is meant by "their livestock" - actual livestock. This is obvious! Rather, it is not like laundry, for there is the inconvenience of mixed wool.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: אֵין אֵלּוּ נִדְרֵי עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ. אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, מַהוּ שֶׁיָּפֵר מִשּׁוּם דְּבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ? תָּא שְׁמַע, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: אֵין אֵלּוּ נִדְרֵי עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ. אֲבָל דְּבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ הָוַיִין.
