human_translation: Rabbi Yosei said these are not vows of affliction. A dilemma was raised According to Rabbi Yosei, what is can nullify as matters that between him and her? Come hear Rabbi Yosei said: These are not vows of affliction, however, they are matters between him and her.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yosei: These are not vows of self-affliction. They asked him: To Rabbi Yosei, what if he annuls it because of matters between him and her? Come and hear, Rabbi Yosei said: These are not vows of self-affliction. But matters between him and her are valid.

hebrew_text: דִּלְמָא לְדִידְהוּ קָאָמַר לְהוּ. לְדִידִי אֲפִילּוּ דְּבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ לָא הָוַיִין. לְדִידְכוּ, דְּאָמְרִיתוּ הָוַיִין נִדְרֵי עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ — אוֹדוֹ לִי דְּאֵין אֵלּוּ נִדְרֵי עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ.
human_translation: Perhaps was speaking to their According to my they are not even matters between him and her. according to your that you say they are vows of affliction, agree with me these are not vows of affliction.
llm_translation: Perhaps according to their opinion he is saying to them. According to my opinion, even matters between him and her are not considered. According to your opinion, since you said they are vows of affliction of the soul - admit to me that these are not vows of affliction of the soul.

hebrew_text: מַאי? רַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה אוֹמֵר: מֵפֵר, רַב הוּנָא אוֹמֵר: אֵין מֵפֵר,
human_translation: What Rav Adda bar Ahava says: He can nullify Rav Huna says: He cannot nullify
llm_translation: What? Rav Adda bar Ahava says: it is nullified. Rav Huna says: it is not nullified.

hebrew_text: שֶׁלֹּא מָצִינוּ שׁוּעָל שֶׁמֵּת בַּעֲפַר פִּיר.
human_translation: as we do not find a fox dying in the earth of the lair
llm_translation: We did not find a fox that died in the dust of the pit.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה: דְּבָרִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶן עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ — מֵפֵר, בֵּין בֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ, בֵּין בֵּינָהּ לְבֵין אֲחֵרִים. שֶׁאֵין בָּהֶן עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ בֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ — מֵפֵר. בֵּינָהּ לְבֵין אֲחֵרִים — אֵינוֹ מֵפֵר. כֵּיצַד? אָמְרָה ״קֻוֽנָּם פֵּירוֹת עָלַי״ — הֲרֵי זֶה יָפֵר. ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֵינִי עוֹשָׂה לְפִי אַבָּא״, ״לְפִי אָחִיךָ״, ״לְפִי אָבִיךָ״, ״לְפִי אָחִי״, וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶתֵּן תֶּבֶן לִפְנֵי בְּהֶמְתְּךָ וּמַיִם לִפְנֵי בְּקָרֶךָ״ — אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: it is taught in accordance with of Rav Adda bar Ahava: matters that involve affliction can nullify, whether between him and her or between her and others. that do not involve affliction, between him and her, he can nullify between her and others, he cannot nullify How so? she said: Produce is konam for me, he can nullify I will not prepare for father, as that is konam For your brother, For your father, For my brother, or: I will not place straw before your animal, or: water before your cattle, he cannot nullify
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rav Adda bar Ahava: Matters that involve endangering life - one may violate Shabbat whether between himself and his wife, between his wife and another person. Matters that do not involve endangering life between himself and his wife - one may violate Shabbat. Between his wife and another person - one may not violate Shabbat. How so? If she says, "Prepare fruits for me," he may violate Shabbat. If she says, "Prepare fruits in a way that I do not like," "According to your brother," "According to your father," "According to your brother-in-law," and "I will not give straw before your animal and water before your cattle" - he cannot violate Shabbat.

hebrew_text: ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶכְחוֹל״, ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶפְקוֹס״, וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אֲשַׁמֵּשׁ מִטָּתִי״ — יָפֵר מִשּׁוּם דְּבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ.
human_translation: I will not paint that I will not rouge [ efkos ] that or: I will not engage in sexual intercourse, that can nullify as matters that between him and her.
llm_translation: "Shelo echchol," "shelo efkos," and "shelo ashammesh mitati" - he may annul the vow because of matters between him and her.

hebrew_text: ״שֶׁלֹּא אַצִּיעַ לָךְ מִטָּתֶךָ״, וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶמְזוֹג לְךָ אֶת הַכּוֹס״, וְ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶרְחַץ לָךְ פָּנֶיךָ יָדֶיךָ וְרַגְלֶיךָ״ — אֵין צָרִיךְ לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: I will not make your bed, that or: I will not prepare your cup for you, that or: I will not wash your face, your hands, or your feet, that need not nullify
llm_translation: "that I may not offer to you from your bed," and "that I may not mix for you the cup," and "that I may not wash your face, your hands, and your feet" - there is no need to annul.

hebrew_text: רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: יָפֵר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״. דָּבָר אַחֵר: ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״ — מִכָּאן לְחָכָם שֶׁאֵין מַתִּיר נִדְרֵי עַצְמוֹ.
human_translation: Rabban Gamliel says: He should nullify as it is stated: “He shall not profane his word” Alternatively, “He shall not profane his word,” from here that a halakhic authority cannot dissolve his own vows.
llm_translation: Rabban Gamliel says: Beautiful, as it is stated: "He shall not profane his word." Another explanation: "He shall not profane his word" — from here we learn that a wise person does not permit his own vows.

hebrew_text: מַאן שָׁמְעִינַן דְּאָמַר ״שֶׁלֹּא אֶכְחוֹל וְשֶׁלֹּא אֶפְקוֹס״ דְּבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ הָוַיִין — רַבִּי יוֹסֵי, וְקָתָנֵי דְּמֵפַר מִשּׁוּם דְּבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ.
human_translation: whom we heard that he said I will not paint that or: I will not rouge matters that between him and her? Rabbi Yosei, and teaches can nullify as matters that between him and her.
llm_translation: One who we heard that said "not to be lenient and not to be strict" regarding matters between him and his wife - it is Rabbi Yosei, and the smaller ones taught in the name of Rabbi Yosei because of matters between him and his wife.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: ״וְשֶׁלֹּא אֲשַׁמֵּשׁ מִטָּתִי״ — יָפֵר מִשּׁוּם דְּבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ. הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא דְּאָמְרָה: ״הֲנָאַת תַּשְׁמִישִׁי עָלֶיךָ״, לְמָה לִי הֲפָרָה? הָא מְשׁוּעְבֶּדֶת לֵיהּ! אֶלָּא בְּאוֹמֶרֶת ״הֲנָאַת תַּשְׁמִישְׁךָ עָלַי״, וְכִדְרַב כָּהֲנָא,
human_translation: The Master said I will not engage in sexual intercourse, that can nullify as matters that between him and her. What are the circumstances If we say that she said: The benefit of my intercourse is to you, why do I nullification She is obligated to him Rather, she said: The benefit of your intercourse is to me, and in accordance with of Rav Kahana.
llm_translation: Master said: "And if I do not derive benefit from my bed" — he may annul the vow because of matters between him and her. How so? If you say the vow was made: "The benefit of my use upon you," why do I need a cow? She is already obligated to him! Rather, the vow was made by saying, "The benefit of your use upon me," as Rav Kahana said,

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: ״הֲנָאַת תַּשְׁמִישִׁי עָלֶיךָ״ — כּוֹפָהּ וּמְשַׁמַּשְׁתּוֹ. ״הֲנָאַת תַּשְׁמִישְׁךָ עָלַי״ — יָפֵר, שֶׁאֵין מַאֲכִילִין אֶת הָאָדָם דָּבָר הָאָסוּר לוֹ.
human_translation: As Rav Kahana said The benefit of my intercourse is to you, he can compel her to have relations with him. The benefit of your intercourse is to me, he must nullify because we do not feed a person something that is forbidden to him.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rabbi Kahana said: "The benefit of my use is upon you" - she may compel him and make him serve her. "The benefit of your use is upon me" - he may annul it, for one does not feed a person something that is forbidden to him.

hebrew_text: מַאן תְּנָא הָא דְּתַנְיָא: דְּבָרִים הַמּוּתָּרִים וַאֲחֵרִים נָהֲגוּ בָּהֶן אִיסּוּר — אִי אַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִנְהוֹג בָּהֶם הֶיתֵּר כְּדֵי לְבַטְּלָן, מִשּׁוּם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״, דָּבָר אַחֵר: ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״ — מִכָּאן לְתַלְמִיד חָכָם שֶׁאֵין מֵפֵר נִדְרֵי עַצְמוֹ. מַנִּי? רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל הִיא.
human_translation: Who taught that which is taught matters that are permitted, but others were accustomed to them a prohibition, you are not allowed to treat them as permitted in a manner cause the negation of as it is stated: “He shall not profane his word” Alternatively, “He shall not profane his word”; from here that a halakhic authority cannot dissolve his own vows. Whose It is Rabban Gamliel,
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna who taught this: Regarding permissible matters and others where prohibition is customary - if you are permitted to engage in them in order to annul them, as it is stated "he shall not profane his word," another interpretation: "he shall not profane his word" - from here we learn that a Torah scholar does not annul his own vows. Who is this? Rabban Gamliel.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָבָא מֵרַב נַחְמָן: תַּשְׁמִישׁ הַמִּטָּה לְרַבָּנַן, עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ הוּא, אוֹ דְּבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: תְּנֵיתוּהָ, ״וּנְטוּלָה אֲנִי מִן הַיְּהוּדִים״,
human_translation: Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman: sexual intercourse according to the Rabbis, is it affliction or matters that between him and her? said to him: You learned And I am removed from the Jews,
llm_translation: Rava asked Rabbah bar Rav Nahman: Is the use of the bed for the Sages considered a matter of self-affliction, or is it a private matter between him and her? He said to him: Teach it, "And I am taken from among the Jews."

hebrew_text: יָפֵר חֶלְקוֹ, וּמְשַׁמַּשְׁתּוֹ, וּתְהֵא נְטוּלָה מִן הַיְּהוּדִים. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ נֶדֶר עִנּוּי נֶפֶשׁ הָוֵי, אַמַּאי תְּהֵא נְטוּלָה מִן הַיְּהוּדִים? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ דְּבָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ הָוַיִין.
human_translation: must nullify his part, and she may engage in intercourse with him, but she is removed from Jews, And if you say that is a vow of affliction, why should she be removed from Jews? learn from here are matters that between him and her,
llm_translation: He should nullify his portion, and she should be divorced, and she should be excluded from the Jews. And if you say, "A vow of self-affliction should be," why should she be excluded from the Jews? Learn from this that matters between him and her are possible.

hebrew_text: לְרַבָּנַן תִּבְּעֵי לָךְ, מִשּׁוּם דִּ״נְטוּלָה אֲנִי מִן הַיְּהוּדִים״ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי קָתָנֵי לַהּ, דְּאָמַר רַב הוּנָא: כּוּלֵּיהּ פִּירְקִין רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא. מִמַּאי — כֵּיוָן דְּקָתָנֵי: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר אֵין אֵלּוּ נִדְרֵי עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ, לְמָה לֵיהּ תּוּ לְמִיתְנֵא ״הֲרֵי זֶה יָפֵר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי״? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא.
human_translation: According to the Rabbis, you have the dilemma, because I am removed from the Jews, was taught by Rabbi Yosei. As Rav Huna said: Our entire chapter is Rabbi Yosei. From where Since teaches: Rabbi Yosei says these are not vows of affliction, why does it need to teach further, He can nullify the statement of Rabbi Yosei? Learn from this from this forward, is Rabbi Yosei.
llm_translation: The sages demand of you, because "I am removed from the Jews," Rabbi Yosei the Katan said to her, as Rav Huna said: All of it is the reasoning of Rabbi Yosei. From where? Since he taught: Rabbi Yosei says, "These are not vows of self-affliction." Why then is it taught in the Mishnah, "This one may annul, the words of Rabbi Yosei"? Learn from it: From here and onwards, it is Rabbi Yosei.

hebrew_text: אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּלֵוִי: כׇּל נְדָרִים בַּעַל מֵפֵר לְאִשְׁתּוֹ, חוּץ מִן ״הֲנָאָתִי עַל פְּלוֹנִי״, שֶׁאֵינוֹ מֵפֵר. אֲבָל ״הֲנָאַת פְּלוֹנִי עָלַי״ — מֵפֵר.
human_translation: Shmuel said in the name of Levi: A husband can nullify all vows for his wife, except for Benefit me for so-and-so, which he cannot nullify, But Benefit from so-and-so for me, he can nullify
llm_translation: Samuel said in the name of Levi: All vows a husband annuls for his wife, except for "my benefit upon so-and-so," which he does not annul. But "the benefit of so-and-so upon me" - he annuls.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: ״פֵּירוֹת מְדִינָה זוֹ עָלַי״ — יָבִיא לָהּ מִמְּדִינָה אַחֶרֶת, אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: דְּקָאָמְרָה שֶׁתָּבִיא.
human_translation: we learned The produce of this country for me, he can bring her from another country. Rav Yosef said: who said That you bring.
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: "The fruits of this province are upon me" — if one brings her from another province, Rav Yosef said: what she said is that she should bring.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: ״פֵּירוֹת חֶנְוָנִי זֶה עָלַי״ — אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. הָכָא נָמֵי דְּקָא אָמְרָה שֶׁתָּבִיא אַתָּה.
human_translation: Come hear: The produce of this storekeeper is for me, cannot nullify Here too, where she said that you bring
llm_translation: Come and hear: "The fruits of the Kenani are upon me" — he cannot annul. Here too, it is because she said, "You shall bring it."

hebrew_text: לֹא הָיְתָה פַּרְנָסָתוֹ אֶלָּא מִמֶּנּוּ — הֲרֵי זֶה יָפֵר. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ דְּקָא אָמְרָה שֶׁ״תָּבִיא אַתָּה״, אַמַּאי יָפֵר? אֶלָּא מִדְּסֵיפָא דְּלָא מַיְיתֵי בַּעַל הָוֵי, רֵישָׁא דְּקָא מַיְיתָא הִיא!
human_translation: if his sustenance only from him, he can nullify And if you say where said that you bring why can nullify Rather, from the latter clause the husband does not bring her, the first clause that she brings,
llm_translation: His livelihood was only from him - this one may annul. And if you say that she said, "You shall bring it," why may he annul? Rather, from the end where the husband does not come, it is the beginning that he comes!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: רֵישָׁא אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר, וּדְקָא מַיְיתָא הִיא.
human_translation: Rather, first clause cannot nullify and that she brings.
llm_translation: Rather: the beginning cannot be nullified, and what is brought is it.

hebrew_text: וּמַתְנִיתִין רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא. דְּאָמַר רַב הוּנָא: כּוּלֵּיהּ פִּרְקִין רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא. וּמַאי ״אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר״, מִשּׁוּם עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ, אֲבָל מֵפֵר נְדָרִים שֶׁבֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ.
human_translation: And the mishna is Rabbi Yosei, As Rav Huna said: Our entire chapter is Rabbi Yosei. And what cannot nullify as affliction, but he can nullify vows that between him and her.
llm_translation: Mishnah: Rabbi Yosei is the one who said, as Rav Huna said: The entire chapter is Rabbi Yosei. And what is meant by "he cannot annul"? Because of causing distress to the soul, but he can annul vows between him and his wife.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: נָדְרָה מִשְׁתֵּי כִכָּרוֹת, בְּאַחַת מִתְעַנָּה, וּבְאַחַת אֵין מִתְעַנָּה, מִתּוֹךְ שֶׁהוּא מֵפֵר לַמִּתְעַנָּה — מֵפֵר לְשֶׁאֵינוֹ מִתְעַנָּה. וְרַב אַסִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מֵפֵר לַמִּתְעַנָּה, וְאֵין מֵפֵר לְשֶׁאֵין מִתְעַנָּה.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said: vowed two loaves from one deprive herself, and from one not deprive herself, since can nullify with regard to the deprive herself, he can nullify with regard to the not deprive herself. And Rav Asi said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: can nullify with regard to the deprive herself, but he cannot nullify with regard to the not deprive herself.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: If one vows from two measures, in one he fasts and in the other he does not fast, since he is annulling the fasting, he annuls for the one in which he does not fast. And Rav Assi said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: He annuls for the one in which he fasts, but he does not annul for the one in which he does not fast.

hebrew_text: וְאִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רַב אַסִּי מֵרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: נָדְרָה מִשְׁתֵּי כִכָּרוֹת, בְּאַחַת מִתְעַנָּה וּבְאַחַת אֵין מִתְעַנָּה, מַהוּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מֵפֵר לַמִּתְעַנָּה וְאֵין מֵפֵר לְשֶׁאֵין מִתְעַנָּה.
human_translation: And some say Rav Asi raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan: vowed from two loaves from one deprive herself, and from one not deprive herself, what is said to him: can nullify with regard to the deprive herself, but he cannot nullify with regard to the not deprive herself.
llm_translation: And there are those who say, Rav Assi asked Rabbi Yochanan: She vowed two loaves, one to fast and one not to fast, what is the ruling? He said to him: He annuls the one for fasting but does not annul the one for not fasting.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר, וְהָיְתָה שׁוֹתֶה יַיִן, וּמִטַּמְּאָה לְמֵתִים
human_translation: raised an objection a woman who vowed a nazirite, and she drank wine or became impure with the dead,
llm_translation: He raised an objection against him: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite, and she was drinking wine, and she would become impure for the dead.

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי זוֹ סוֹפֶגֶת אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים. הֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ וְהִיא לֹא יָדְעָה שֶׁהֵפֵר לָהּ, וְהָיְתָה שׁוֹתָה יַיִן וּמִיטַּמְּאָהּ לְמֵתִים — אֵינָהּ סוֹפֶגֶת אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים.
human_translation: she incurs [ sofeget ] the forty her husband nullified for her, but she did not know that he nullified it for her, and she drank wine or became impure through the dead, she does not incur the forty
llm_translation: Behold, this one absorbs the forty lashes. Her husband annulled the vow for her, and she did not know that he annulled it for her, and she would drink wine and defile herself for the dead - she does not absorb the forty lashes.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ מֵפֵר לַמִּתְעַנָּה וְאֵין מֵפֵר לְשֶׁאֵין מִתְעַנָּה, דִּלְמָא מִן יַיִן דְּאִית לַהּ צַעֲרָא — הֵפֵר לָהּ, מִן חַרְצָן וּמִן זַג — לֹא הֵפֵר לָהּ, דְּהָא לָא אִית לַהּ צַעֲרָא. וְתִסְפּוֹג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים!
human_translation: And if you say can nullify with regard to the deprive herself, but he cannot nullify with regard to the not deprive herself, Perhaps nullified for her wine to as she suffers pain seeds and skins to he did not nullify for her, as she suffers no pain she should receive the forty
llm_translation: And if you say that one may annul a vow for affliction, but one may not annul a vow for no affliction, perhaps if she refrained from wine, which causes her distress - he may annul the vow for her. But if she refrained from vinegar and from brine - he may not annul the vow for her, because she does not experience distress. And soak in the forty!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: אֵין נְזִירוּת לַחֲצָאִין.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: naziriteship cannot take effect partially.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: There is no Nazirite vow for half measures.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: הָא קׇרְבָּן לַחֲצִי נְזִירוּת אִיכָּא?! אֶלָּא אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: אֵין נְזִירוּת לַחֲצָאִין, וְאֵין קׇרְבָּן לַחֲצָאִין.
human_translation: Abaye said to him: but an offering is for partial naziriteship. Rather, Abaye said Naziriteship cannot take effect partially, and no offering is for partial
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: Is there a Korban for half Nezirut?! Rather, Abaye said: There is no half Nezirut, and there is no Korban for half.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר וְהִפְרִישָׁה בְּהֶמְתָּהּ וְאַחַר כָּךְ הֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ — מְבִיאָה חַטַּאת הָעוֹף, וְאֵינָהּ מְבִיאָה עוֹלַת הָעוֹף. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ אֵין קׇרְבָּן לַחֲצִי נְזִירוּת, אַמַּאי מְבִיאָה חַטָּאת הָעוֹף?
human_translation: raises an objection a woman who vowed to be a nazirite and she designated her animal and afterward her husband nullified for her, she must bring a bird sin-offering but she does not bring a bird burnt-offering. And if you say no offering is for partial naziriteship, why must she bring a bird sin-offering?
llm_translation: The question was raised: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite and then consecrated her animal, and afterwards her husband annulled it for her - she brings a sin offering of a bird, but does not bring a burnt offering of a bird. And if you say there is no offering for partial Nazirite status, why then does she bring a sin offering of a bird?

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא מַאי — יֵשׁ קׇרְבָּן לַחֲצִי נְזִירוּת? שָׁלֹשׁ בְּהֵמוֹת בָּעֵי לְאֵתוֹיֵי: חַטָּאת, עוֹלָה, וּשְׁלָמִים! אֶלָּא, לְעוֹלָם אֵין קׇרְבָּן לַחֲצִי נְזִירוּת. וְחַטַּאת הָעוֹף דְּמַתְיָא — מִשּׁוּם דְּחַטָּאת עַל הַסָּפֵק.
human_translation: But rather, what an offering is for partial naziriteship? should be required to bring three animals a sin-offering, a burnt-offering, and a peace-offering, Rather, Actually, no offering is for partial naziriteship, and the bird sin-offering that she must bring, because sin-offering in uncertainty.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And rather what — is there a sacrifice for half of Naziriteship? Three animals are needed to bring: sin offering, burnt offering, and peace offerings! Rather, indeed, there is no sacrifice for half of Naziriteship. And the sin offering of a bird is similar — because a sin offering is for a doubt.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר וְנִטְמֵאת, וְאַחַר כָּךְ הֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ — מְבִיאָה חַטַּאת הָעוֹף, וְאֵין מְבִיאָה עוֹלַת הָעוֹף. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ מֵפֵר לַמִּתְעַנָּה וְאֵין מֵפֵר לְשֶׁאֵין מִתְעַנָּה,
human_translation: raised an objection a woman who vowed to be a nazirite and she became ritually impure and afterward her husband nullified for her, she must bring a bird sin-offering but does not bring a bird burnt-offering. And if you say can nullify with regard to the deprive herself, but he cannot nullify with regard to not deprive herself,
llm_translation: He raised an objection against him: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite and became impure, and afterwards her husband annulled it for her - she brings a sin offering of a bird, but does not bring a burnt offering of a bird. And if you say he annulled it for her to enable her to fast, and he did not annul it for when she is not fasting,

hebrew_text: דִּלְמָא מִיַּיִן דְּאִית לַהּ צַעֲרָא — הֵפֵר לָהּ, מִטּוּמְאַת מֵת, דְּלֵית לַהּ צַעֲרָא — לֹא הֵפֵר לָהּ?
human_translation: Perhaps nullified for her wine to as she suffers pain impurity by the dead he did not nullify for her, as she suffers no pain
llm_translation: Perhaps from wine that has distress - he nullified it, from impurity of a corpse, that does not have distress - he did not nullify it?

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: מִטּוּמְאַת מֵת נָמֵי אִית לַהּ צַעֲרָא — דִּכְתִיב: ״וְהַחַי יִתֵּן אֶל לִבּוֹ״, וְתַנְיָא, הָיָה רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״וְהַחַי יִתֵּן אֶל לִבּוֹ״, דְּיִסְפּוֹד — יִסְפְּדוּן לֵיהּ, דְּיִבְכּוּן — יִבְכּוּן לֵיהּ, דְּיִקְבַּר — יִקְבְּרוּנֵיהּ.
human_translation: say impurity by the dead to also suffers pain As it is written: “And the living shall lay it to his heart” and it is taught Rabbi Meir would say: What which is written: “And the living shall lay it to his heart”? who eulogizes will be eulogized who weeps will be wept for who buries will be buried
llm_translation: They said: From the impurity of a dead person there is sorrow for him - as it is written: "And the living will lay it to his heart." And it was taught, Rabbi Meir would say: What is the meaning of "And the living will lay it to his heart"? - that they should eulogize him, that they should weep for him, that they should bury him.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֲנִי נֶהֱנֶה לַבְּרִיּוֹת״ — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר, וִיכוֹלָה הִיא לֵיהָנוֹת בְּלֶקֶט, שִׁכְחָה, וּבְפֵאָה.
human_translation: of people is konam that I will benefit cannot nullify but she may benefit from Gleanings, forgotten and produce of the corners [ pe’a ]
llm_translation: Mishnah: "Kunnam she'ani nehenah la'briyot" - einu yachol lehafair, vi'icholah hi lehenot be'lek'et, shich'cha, u'vepe'ah.

hebrew_text: ״קֻוֽנָּם כֹּהֲנִים לְוִיִּם נֶהֱנִים לִי״ — יִטְּלוּ עַל כׇּרְחוֹ. ״כֹּהֲנִים אֵלּוּ וּלְוִיִּם אֵלּוּ נֶהֱנִים לִי״ — יִטְּלוּ אֲחֵרִים.
human_translation: priests Levites benefit from me, konam they can take against his will. these priests and these Levites benefit from me, taken by others.
llm_translation: "‘Their rods, the Kohanim and the Leviim, are Mine’ — they shall be taken by force. ‘These Kohanim and these Leviim are Mine’ — others shall be taken."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אַלְמָא אֶפְשָׁר דְּמִתַּזְנָה מִדִּילֵיהּ, מִכְּלָל דְּבַעַל לָאו בִּכְלַל ״בְּרִיּוֹת״ הוּא. אֵימָא סֵיפָא: יְכוֹלָה לֵיהָנוֹת בְּלֶקֶט שִׁכְחָה וּפֵאָה, אֲבָל מִדְּבַעַל לָא אָכְלָה, אַלְמָא בַּעַל בִּכְלַל ״בְּרִיּוֹת״ הוּא!
human_translation: Apparently, can be sustained from his, by inference that a husband is not included in people, say the latter clause she may benefit from gleanings, forgotten and pe’a . but she may not eat to husband. Apparently, a husband is included in people,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara: Alma, it is possible that she committed adultery from her own accord, which implies that a husband is not included in the category of 'creatures.' Eima seifa: She may benefit from gleanings, forgotten sheaves, and corners of the field, but she may not eat from her husband's produce, which implies that a husband is included in the category of 'creatures'!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר עוּלָּא: לְעוֹלָם לָאו בִּכְלַל ״בְּרִיּוֹת״ הוּא, וְעוֹד: אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר — מִפְּנֵי שֶׁיְּכוֹלָה לֵיהָנוֹת בְּלֶקֶט שִׁכְחָה וּפֵאָה.
human_translation: Ulla said: Actually, is not included in people, And furthermore he cannot nullify because she may benefit from gleanings, forgotten and pe’a .
llm_translation: Ula said: Always not included "creatures" it is, and furthermore: cannot annul — because she can benefit from gleanings, forgotten sheaf, and corner.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם בַּעַל בִּכְלַל ״בְּרִיּוֹת״ הוּא, וּ״מָה טַעַם״ קָאָמַר: מָה טַעַם אֵין יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר? מִפְּנֵי שֶׁיְּכוֹלָה לֵיהָנוֹת בְּלֶקֶט שִׁכְחָה וּפֵאָה.
human_translation: Rava said Actually, a husband is included in people, And states What is the reason, What is the reason cannot nullify Because she may benefit from gleanings, forgotten and pe’a .
llm_translation: Rava said: Always a "ba'al" is included in "briyot," and "what reason" is he saying: what reason cannot annul? Because she can benefit from gleanings, forgotten sheaves, and corners.

hebrew_text: רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם בַּעַל לָאו בִּכְלַל ״בְּרִיּוֹת״ הוּא. וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: נִתְגָּרְשָׁה, יְכוֹלָה לֵיהָנוֹת בְּלֶקֶט שִׁכְחָה וּפֵאָה.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman said: Actually, is not included in people, And this is what is teaching: she becomes divorced she may benefit from gleanings, forgotten and pe’a .
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said: Always a Baal Lav is included in the category of "creatures." And thus it was taught: If she was divorced, she is permitted to benefit from gleanings, forgotten sheaves, and corners of the field.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רָבָא לְרַב נַחְמָן: וּבַעַל לָאו בִּכְלַל בְּרִיּוֹת הוּא? וְהָתְנַן: ״נְטוּלָה אֲנִי מִן הַיְּהוּדִים״ — יָפֵר חֶלְקוֹ, וּתְהֵא מְשַׁמַּשְׁתּוֹ, וּתְהֵא נְטוּלָה מִן הַיְּהוּדִים.
human_translation: Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman: And is a husband not included in people? But didn’t we learn I am removed from the Jews, must nullify his part, and she may engage in intercourse with him, but she is removed from Jews,
llm_translation: He raised an objection to Rav Nachman: Is a Baal Lav included in the category of creatures? But we learned: "I am exempt from the Jews" - his portion should be annulled, and she should serve him, and she should be exempt from the Jews.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ בַּעַל לָאו בִּכְלַל ״בְּרִיּוֹת״ הוּא, נִדְרֵי עִינּוּי נֶפֶשׁ הֵן, וְיָפֵר לָהּ לְעוֹלָם!
human_translation: But if you say a husband is not included in people, it is a vow of affliction, and he can nullify for her forever.
llm_translation: "If you say that a Baal Lo Ba in general is not included in 'creatures,' they are vows of self-affliction, and he shall fulfill them forever!"

hebrew_text: אֵימָא לָךְ: שָׁאנֵי הָכָא, דְּמוֹכְחָא מִלְּתָא דְּעַל הֶיתֵּרָא קָאָסְרָה נַפְשַׁהּ.
human_translation: I say to you here it is different, as it is clear as she to render forbidden to herself that is permitted
llm_translation: Concerning you: the difference here, that it is evident from the matter that she has made herself forbidden.

hebrew_text: יְכוֹלָה לֵיהָנוֹת בְּלֶקֶט שִׁכְחָה וּפֵאָה. וְלָא קָתָנֵי וּבְמַעְשַׂר עָנִי. וְהָתַנְיָא בְּבָרַיְיתָא: וּבְמַעְשַׂר עָנִי!
human_translation: she may benefit from gleanings, forgotten and pe’a . does not teach and from poor man’s tithe. But isn’t it taught in a baraita and from poor man’s tithe?
llm_translation: She can benefit from gleanings, forgotten sheaves, and corners of the field. And it does not teach this law with regards to the tithe for the poor. And it was taught in a baraita: And also with regards to the tithe for the poor!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: לָא קַשְׁיָא הָא — רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, הָא — רַבָּנַן. דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אֵין אָדָם צָרִיךְ לִקְרוֹת שֵׁם עַל מַעְשַׂר עָנִי שֶׁל דְּמַאי.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: not difficult, This Rabbi Eliezer, that the Rabbis, as we learned Rabbi Eliezer says: A person need not designate by name, the poor man’s tithe of doubtfully tithed produce [ demai ],
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: It is not difficult - this one is Rabbi Eliezer, and this one is the Rabbis. As we learned: Rabbi Eliezer says, "A person does not need to recite the name over the tithe of the poor man's produce of Demai."

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: קוֹרֵא שֵׁם, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לְהַפְרִישׁ. מַאי לָאו, לְמַאן דְּאָמַר סְפֵקוֹ טוֹבֵל, קָסָבַר: אִית לֵיהּ טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה, וְכֵיוָן דְּאִית לֵיהּ טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה — לָא מַהְנְיָא.
human_translation: And the Rabbis say: He must designate by name, but he need not set aside What, is it not according to the one, who says uncertainty renders forbidden as untithed produce tevel holds has the benefit of discretion, And since he has the benefit of discretion, is ineffective,
llm_translation: The sages say: One may recite the name without separating. What is the reason? According to the one who says his doubt immerses, he holds: there is benefit in it, and since there is benefit in it, it is not problematic.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר [אֵינוֹ] קוֹרֵא שֵׁם, קָסָבַר: סְפֵקוֹ אֵינוֹ טוֹבֵל, וְכׇל שֶׁסְּפֵקוֹ אֵינוֹ טוֹבֵל — לֵית לֵיהּ טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה, וּשְׁרֵי לֵיהּ לְאִיתְהֲנוֹיֵי.
human_translation: And according to the one, who says he need not designate by name, holds uncertainty does not render forbidden as untithed produce. And whenever that uncertainty does not render forbidden as untithed produce, does not have the benefit of discretion And is permitted to benefit
llm_translation: And for the one who says he does not recite the Name, he holds: one who is in doubt does not immerse, and anyone who is in doubt does not immerse — he does not have the benefit of pleasure, and it is permitted for him to engage in pleasure.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא סְפֵקוֹ טוֹבֵל, וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר וְרַבָּנַן בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר סָבַר: לֹא נֶחְשְׁדוּ עַמֵּי הָאָרֶץ עַל מַעְשַׂר עָנִי. כֵּיוָן דְּאִילּוּ מַפְקַר נִכְסֵיהּ וְהָוֵי עָנִי וְשָׁקֵל לֵיהּ הוּא — לֵית לֵיהּ פְּסֵידָא.
human_translation: Abaye said to him: that everyone uncertainty renders forbidden as and Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis disagree with regard to this Rabbi Eliezer maintains amei ha’aretz are not suspected of poor man’s tithe. because were declare his property ownerless and become a poor man, and take himself, he no loss
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: The majority of the world immerses doubtfully, and Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis disagree on this. Rabbi Eliezer holds: The common people are not suspected of tithing poor produce. Since if one were to declare his property ownerless and become poor, and he would then take tithes from it - there is no loss to him.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי: נִכְסֵיהּ לָא מַפְקַר אִינִישׁ, דְּמִירְתַת דִּלְמָא זָכֵי בְּהוּ אִינִישׁ אַחֲרִינָא. הִלְכָּךְ — נֶחְשְׁדוּ.
human_translation: And the Rabbis maintain a person does not declare his property ownerless as he is afraid perhaps someone else will acquire it Consequently, are suspected
llm_translation: The sages hold: One's property is not considered ownerless, for perhaps someone else will acquire it. Therefore, they were suspected.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אוֹמֵר: כָּאן בְּמַעְשַׂר עָנִי הַמִּתְחַלֵּק בְּתוֹךְ הַבַּיִת, דִּכְתִיבָא בֵּיהּ נְתִינָה: ״וְנָתַתָּה לַלֵּוִי לַגֵּר וְגוֹ׳״ — מִשּׁוּם הָכִי אָסוּר לֵיהּ לְאִיתְהֲנוֹיֵי.
human_translation: Rava says Here, to poor man’s tithe distributed in the house, as giving is written with regard to “And you shall give to the Levite, to the stranger, Due to that is prohibited to derive benefit
llm_translation: Rava says: Here, in the case of a poor person who divides within the house, as it is written in it giving: "And you shall give to the Levite, to the stranger, etc." — therefore, it is forbidden to derive benefit from it.

hebrew_text: כָּאן בְּמַעְשַׂר עָנִי הַמִּתְחַלֵּק בְּתוֹךְ הַגֳּרָנוֹת. כֵּיוָן דִּכְתִיב בֵּיהּ ״וְהִנַּחְתָּ בִּשְׁעָרֶיךָ״, שְׁרֵי לֵיהּ לְאִיתְהֲנוֹיֵי.
human_translation: There, to poor man’s tithe that is distributed in the threshing floor. Since with regard to it is written: “And you shall leave it at your gates” is permitted to benefit
llm_translation: Here in Maaser, a poor person who divides among the granaries. Once it is written in it, "And you shall set it down at your gates," it is permitted for enjoyment.

hebrew_text: כֹּהֲנִים וּלְוִיִּם נֶהֱנִין לִי יִטְּלוּ כּוּ׳. אַלְמָא טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה אֵינָהּ מָמוֹן.
human_translation: priests and Levites benefit from me, they can take Apparently, benefit of discretion is not monetary
llm_translation: The priests and Levites benefit for me they shall take thus. Therefore, the enjoyment of benefit is not considered money.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: ״כֹּהֲנִים אֵלּוּ וּלְוִיִּם אֵלּוּ נֶהֱנִין לִי״ — יִטְּלוּ אֲחֵרִים, אֲבָל לְהָנֵי — לָא. אַלְמָא טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה מָמוֹן!
human_translation: say the latter clause these priests and these Levites benefit from me, taken by others. But these not Apparently, benefit of discretion is monetary value,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima seifa: 'Kohanim elu u'leviim elu nehenin li' — yitlu acheirim, aval lehanei — la. Alma tovat hana'ah mammon!" English translation: "Say the latter clause: 'These are the priests and these are the Levites who benefit me' — let others take, but to these — no. Hence, the pleasure of benefit is better than money!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוֹשַׁעְיָא: לָא קַשְׁיָא, הָא רַבִּי, וְהָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. דְּתַנְיָא: הַגּוֹנֵב טִבְלוֹ שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ וַאֲכָלוֹ — מְשַׁלֵּם לוֹ דְּמֵי טִבְלוֹ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ מְשַׁלֵּם אֶלָּא דְּמֵי חוּלִּין שֶׁבּוֹ. מַאי לָאו בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי,
human_translation: Rav Hoshaya said: not difficult; this Rabbi and that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught one steals another’s untithed produce and eats it, he must pay him the value of his untithed produce, the statement of Rabbi Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: He pays only the value of the non-sacred it contained. What, is it not they disagree about this:
llm_translation: Rav Hoshaya said: It is not difficult, this one is Rabbi, and this one is Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. As it was taught: One who steals the tithe of his fellow and eats it - he must repay him the value of the tithe, the words of Rabbi. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: He only repays him the value of the non-sacred items within it. What is the point of their disagreement in this matter?

hebrew_text: דְּרַבִּי סָבַר: טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה מָמוֹן, וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בַּר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר: טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה אֵינָהּ מָמוֹן?
human_translation: That Rabbi holds benefit of discretion is monetary value, And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds benefit of discretion is not monetary value,
llm_translation: Rabbi Savar: Good of pleasure is money, and Rabbi Yosei bar Rabbi Yehuda Savar: Good of pleasure is not money?

hebrew_text: לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה אֵינָהּ מָמוֹן. אֶלָּא הָכָא בְּמַתָּנוֹת שֶׁלֹּא הוּרְמוּ קָא מִיפַּלְגִי.
human_translation: No, as everyone benefit of discretion is not monetary Rather, here they disagree with regard to gifts that have not been separated
llm_translation: Not, of all the world, pleasure is not money. Rather here, in gifts that were not thrown, they disagree.

hebrew_text: וְאִי טוֹבַת הֲנָאָה אֵינָהּ מָמוֹן — מָה לִי הוּרְמוּ, מָה לִי לֹא הוּרְמוּ?
human_translation: But if benefit of discretion is not monetary value, what is to me have been separated, what is to me if they have not been separated?
llm_translation: And if the benefit of pleasure is not monetary - what do I need deception for, what do I need no deception for?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא, הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא דְרַבִּי: קַנְסוּהּ רַבָּנַן לְגַנָּב כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא לִיגְנוֹב. וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בַּר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר: קַנְסוּהּ רַבָּנַן לְבַעַל הַבַּיִת, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא לִישַׁהֵי לְטִיבְלֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rather, this is the reasoning of Rabbi The Sages penalized the thief so that he would not steal And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds the Sages penalized the owner so that he would not delay his untithed produce,
llm_translation: Rather, this is the reason of Rabbi: The Rabbis penalized the thief in order that he should not steal. And Rabbi Yosei, the son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds: The Rabbis penalized the homeowner in order that he should not neglect to immerse his utensils.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: שָׁאנֵי תְּרוּמָה, דְּהַיְינוּ טַעְמָא דְּיִטְּלוּ עַל כׇּרְחוֹ — מִשּׁוּם דִּתְרוּמָה לָא חַזְיָא אֶלָּא לְכֹהֲנִים, וְכֵיוָן דְּקָא אָתֵי לְמֵיסְרָא עֲלַיְיהוּ, שַׁוְּיָא עַפְרָא בְּעָלְמָא.
human_translation: Rava said teruma is different, as this is the reason that can take against his will Because teruma is fit only for priests, and since he came to render it prohibited to them, he made it, like mere dust.
llm_translation: Rava said: The case of Terumah is different, for the reason that they take it by force - because Terumah is not seen except by the priests, and since it comes to be thrown upon them, it is considered as mere dust of the world.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֵינִי עוֹשָׂה עַל פִּי אַבָּא״, וְ״עַל פִּי אָבִיךָ״, וְ״עַל פִּי אָחִי״, וְ״עַל פִּי אָחִיךָ״ — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. ״שֶׁאֵינִי עוֹשָׂה עַל פִּיךָ״ — אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: I will not produce for father, that is konam or: For your father, or: For my brother, or: For your brother, cannot nullify I will not produce for you, that need not nullify
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "Their decree that I do not follow according to the word of my father," and "according to the word of your father," and "according to the word of my brother," and "according to the word of your brother" — one cannot annul. "That I do not follow according to your word" — it does not need to be annulled.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: יָפֵר, שֶׁמָּא תַּעֲדִיף עָלָיו יוֹתֵר מִן הָרָאוּי לוֹ.
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva says: He should nullify perhaps she will exceed more for him than is fitting for him
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva says: Beautiful, lest you prefer him more than is fitting for him.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי אוֹמֵר: יָפֵר, שֶׁמָּא יְגָרְשֶׁנָּה וּתְהִי אֲסוּרָה עָלָיו.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says should nullify Perhaps he will divorce her, and she will be forbidden to him
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri says: "He should divorce her, lest she become forbidden to him."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי. לְמֵימְרָא דְּקָסָבַר שְׁמוּאֵל אָדָם מַקְדִּישׁ דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא בָּא לְעוֹלָם? וּרְמִינְהִי: הַמַּקְדִּישׁ מַעֲשֵׂה יְדֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ —
human_translation: Shmuel said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri. Is this to say that Shmuel maintains a person can consecrate an entity that has not come into the world? And raises a contradiction one consecrates his wife’s earnings,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara said Shmuel: Halacha like Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri. To say, from the statement of Shmuel, does a person sanctify something that has not come into the world? And raise a contradiction: one who sanctifies the work of his wife's hands — English translation: Gemara said Shmuel: The halacha is in accordance with Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri. To say, from the statement of Shmuel, does a person sanctify something that has not come into the world? And raise a contradiction: one who sanctifies the work of his wife's hands —

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי זוֹ עוֹשָׂה וְאוֹכֶלֶת. וְהַמּוֹתָר — רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: הֶקְדֵּשׁ, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן הַסַּנְדְּלָר אוֹמֵר: חוּלִּין. וְאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן הַסַּנְדְּלָר. אַלְמָא אֵין אָדָם מַקְדִּישׁ דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא בָּא לְעוֹלָם.
human_translation: she may work and sustain And the surplus Rabbi Meir says consecrated Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar says non-sacred. And Shmuel said the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar. Apparently, a person cannot consecrate an entity that has not come into the world,
llm_translation: Behold, this one performs and eats. And the permissible — Rabbi Meir says: it is consecrated, Rabbi Yochanan the Sandal-maker says: it is mundane. And Shmuel said: the halakha is according to Rabbi Yochanan the Sandal-maker. This implies that a person does not consecrate something that is not destined for the world.

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא: כִּי קָאָמַר הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי — עַל הַעֲדָפָה הוּא דְּקָאָמַר.
human_translation: And if you would say when is saying the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri he was saying with regard to the surplus,
llm_translation: And if you will say: When he said "the halacha is like Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri" - it is regarding preference that he said.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן נוּרִי בְּהַעֲדָפָה. אִי נָמֵי: הֲלָכָה כְּתַנָּא קַמָּא. אִי נָמֵי: (אֵין) הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא!
human_translation: let say: halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri with regard to surplus. Alternatively, halakha is in accordance with the first tanna , Alternatively, halakha is not in accordance with Rabbi Akiva,
llm_translation: Let us say: the halakha is like Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri in preference. If you say: the halakha is like the first Tanna. If you say: (No,) the halakha is not like Rabbi Akiva!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: שָׁאנֵי קוּנָּמוֹת, הוֹאִיל וְאָדָם אוֹסֵר פֵּירוֹת חֲבֵירוֹ עָלָיו, אוֹסֵר נָמֵי דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא בָּא לְעוֹלָם עָלָיו.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Yosef said konamot are different; since a person can prohibit to himself another’s produce he can also prohibit to himself an entity that has not yet come into the world.
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Yosef said: The case of Kunamot is different, since when a person restricts the produce of his fellow upon himself, he also restricts something that has not yet come into the world upon himself.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: בִּשְׁלָמָא אָדָם אוֹסֵר פֵּירוֹת חֲבֵירוֹ עָלָיו, שֶׁהֲרֵי אָדָם אוֹסֵר פֵּירוֹתָיו עַל חֲבֵירוֹ. אֶלָּא יֶאֱסוֹר דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא בָּא לְעוֹלָם עַל חֲבֵירוֹ, שֶׁהֲרֵי אֵין אָדָם אוֹסֵר פֵּירוֹת חֲבֵירוֹ עַל חֲבֵירוֹ!
human_translation: Abaye said to him: Granted, a person can prohibit another’s produce to himself, since a person can prohibit his produce to another. But he can prohibit an entity that has not come into the world to another person, that a person cannot prohibit another’s produce to other
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: Granted, a person may forbid his fruits upon his fellow, for behold, a person forbids his fruits upon his fellow. Rather, he should forbid something that will never come upon his fellow, for behold, a person does not forbid his fruits upon his fellow's fellow!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: בְּאוֹמֶרֶת ״יִקְדְּשׁוּ יָדַי לְעוֹשֵׂיהֶן״, דְּיָדַיִם הָא אִיתַנְהוּ בָּעוֹלָם.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: with says: My hands are consecrated to the One Who made them. as hands are in the world.
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: With regard to the statement "They shall sanctify My hands for the work," hands, they are present in the world.

hebrew_text: וְכִי אָמְרָה הָכִי — קָדְשָׁה? וְהָא מְשַׁעְבְּדָן יְדַיהּ לְבַעַל! דְּאָמְרָה: לְכִי מִגָּרְשָׁה. הַשְׁתָּא מִיהַת לָא מִגָּרְשָׁה, וּמִמַּאי דְּכִי אַמְרַהּ הָכִי מַהְנְיָא?
human_translation: And if she said like this, are they consecrated But aren’t her hands pledged to her husband, who said: when I become divorced. She is not divorced now in any event, and from where that when she says like this, is effective?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And did she say so - that she is sanctified? But she is still serving her husband! For she said: 'Go from her domain.' Now, if she is not going from her domain, then what is the meaning of her saying so?" English translation: "And did she say so - that she is sanctified? But she is still serving her husband! For she said: 'Go from her domain.' Now, if she is not going from her domain, then what is the meaning of her saying so?"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אִילָא: וּמָה אִילּוּ אוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״שָׂדֶה זוֹ שֶׁאֲנִי מוֹכֵר לְךָ, לִכְשֶׁאֶקָּחֶנָּה מִמְּךָ — תִּקָּדֵישׁ״, מִי לָא קָדְשָׁה?
human_translation: Rabbi Ila said: And what if says to another This field that I am selling to you when I will buy it from you, let it be consecrated? Is not consecrated
llm_translation: Rabbi Ila said: And what if one says to his fellow, "This field that I am selling to you, when I will take it from you - it shall be consecrated," who has consecrated it?

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: מִי דָּמֵי? ״שָׂדֶה זוֹ שֶׁאֲנִי מוֹכֵר לְךָ״ — הַשְׁתָּא בִּידֵיהּ הִיא. אִשָּׁה, בְּיָדָהּ לְהַקְדִּישׁ מַעֲשֵׂה יָדֶיהָ?! הָא לָא דָּמֵי אֶלָּא לָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״שָׂדֶה זוֹ שֶׁמָּכַרְתִּי לְךָ, לִכְשֶׁאֶקָּחֶנָּה מִמְּךָ — תִּקָּדֵישׁ״, מִי קָדְשָׁה?
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya objects to this Are comparable? this field that I am selling to you now is in his possession, woman, in her power to consecrate her handiwork? This is comparable only to one who said to another: this field that I sold to you when I will buy it from you, let it be consecrated. is consecrated
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: Rabbi Yirmeya objects to her: Who is similar? "This field that I am selling to you" — now it is in her possession. A woman, in her possession to consecrate the work of her hands?! Is it not similar only to one who says to his fellow, "This field that I sold to you, when I will take it from you — you shall consecrate it," who has consecrated it?

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב פָּפָּא: מִי דָּמֵי?! גַּבֵּי זְבִינָא — פְּסִיקָא מִילְּתַיְיהוּ. גַּבֵּי אִשָּׁה מִי פְּסִיקָא מִילְּתָא? הָא לָא דָּמֵי אֶלָּא לָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״שָׂדֶה זוֹ שֶׁמִּשְׁכַּנְתִּי לְךָ, לִכְשֶׁאֶפְדֶּנָּה מִמְּךָ — תִּקָּדֵישׁ״, מִי לָא קָדְשָׁה?
human_translation: Rav Pappa objects to this Are comparable? In the sale the matter is clear-cut, in a woman, is the matter clear-cut? this is comparable only to who said to another: this field that I pledged to you, when I will redeem it from you, let it be consecrated. is not consecrated
llm_translation: Rav Papa objects to her: Who is similar?! Regarding a purchase — their words are final. Regarding a woman, is the matter final? Isn't it only when one says to his fellow, "This field that I acquired from you, when I redeem it from you — it shall be consecrated," who has not consecrated it?

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב שִׁישָׁא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִידִי: מִי דָּמֵי? שָׂדֶה בְּיָדוֹ לִפְדּוֹתוֹ. אִשָּׁה בְּיָדָהּ לְהִתְגָּרֵשׁ?! הָא לָא דָּמְיָא אֶלָּא לָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״שָׂדֶה זוֹ שֶׁמִּשְׁכַּנְתִּי לְךָ לְעֶשֶׂר שָׁנִים, לִכְשֶׁאֶפְדֶּנָּה מִמְּךָ — תִּקָּדֵישׁ״, מִי לָא קָדְשָׁה?
human_translation: Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, objects to this Are comparable? a field, it is in power to redeem it a woman, in her power to be divorced this is comparable only to one who said to another: this field that I pledged to you for ten years, when I will redeem it from you, let it be consecrated. is it not consecrated
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rav Shisha, son of Rav Idi, objects to her: Who is similar? A field in his hand to redeem it. A woman in her hand to divorce herself?! Is it not comparable only to one who says to his fellow, "This field that I have acquired for you for ten years, when I redeem it from you - it shall be consecrated," has she not consecrated it? English translation: Rav Shisha, son of Rav Idi, objects to her: Who is similar? A field in his hand to redeem it. A woman in her hand to divorce herself?! Is it not comparable only to one who says to his fellow, "This field that I have acquired for you for ten years, when I redeem it from you - it shall be consecrated," has she not consecrated it?

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב אָשֵׁי: מִי דָּמֵי?! הָתָם קִיץ. אִשָּׁה מִי אִית לַהּ קִיצּוּתָא?
human_translation: Rav Ashi objects to this Are comparable? There, fixed a woman, is there a fixed
llm_translation: Rav Ashi objects to her: Who is similar?! There, it is summer. Does a woman have a summer garment?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: שָׁאנֵי קוּנָּמוֹת, דְּכִי קְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף דָּמֵי, וְכִדְרָבָא.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Ashi said konamot are different. as is akin to inherent sanctity. And in accordance with of Rava.
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Ashe said: The laws of kilayim are different, for the sanctity of the body is similar, as in the case of Rav Aha.

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר רָבָא: הֶקְדֵּשׁ, חָמֵץ וְשִׁחְרוּר — מַפְקִיעִין מִידֵי שִׁעְבּוּד.
human_translation: As Rava said: Consecration leavened bread and emancipation abrogate lien
llm_translation: Rava said: One who consecrates, leaven, and freedom — exempt from servitude.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי לְמָה לִי שֶׁמָּא יְגָרְשֶׁנָּה? תְּנִי: וְעוֹד שֶׁמָּא יְגָרְשֶׁנָּה.
human_translation: If so, why do I Perhaps he will divorce her? Teach And furthermore, perhaps he will divorce her.
llm_translation: Thus, why to me lest he divorce her? It was taught: And furthermore, lest he divorce her.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ נָדְרָה אִשְׁתּוֹ וְסָבוּר שֶׁנָּדְרָה בִּתּוֹ, נָדְרָה בִּתּוֹ וְסָבוּר שֶׁנָּדְרָה אִשְׁתּוֹ, נָדְרָה בְּנָזִיר וְסָבוּר שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּקׇרְבָּן, נָדְרָה בְּקׇרְבָּן וְסָבוּר שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר, נָדְרָה מִתְּאֵנִים וְסָבוּר שֶׁנָּדְרָה מִן הָעֲנָבִים, נָדְרָה מִן הָעֲנָבִים וְסָבוּר שֶׁנָּדְרָה מִן הַתְּאֵנִים — הֲרֵי זֶה יַחְזוֹר וְיָפֵר.
human_translation: wife took a vow and he thought that his daughter had taken a vow, his daughter took a vow and he thought that his wife had taken a vow, vowed to a nazirite and he thought that she had vowed to an offering, she vowed to an offering and he thought that she had vowed to a nazirite, she took a vow figs to and he thought that she had taken a vow grapes she took a vow grapes and he thought that she had taken a vow figs to he repeat and nullify
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: If his wife took a vow, and he thought she took a vow regarding his daughter, she took a vow regarding his daughter, and he thought she took a vow regarding his wife, she took a vow regarding his wife. If she took a vow regarding a Nazirite, and he thought she took a vow regarding a sacrifice, she took a vow regarding a sacrifice, and he thought she took a vow regarding a Nazirite. If she took a vow regarding figs, and he thought she took a vow regarding grapes, she took a vow regarding grapes, and he thought she took a vow regarding figs — he must go back and annul it.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ לְמֵימְרָא דְּ״יָנִיא אוֹתָהּ״ דַּוְקָא הוּא?
human_translation: Is this to say that disallowed her [ otah ]” is precise?
llm_translation: Gemara: "G'ma to the statement of 'Yania, is it specifically that?"

hebrew_text: וְהָא גַּבֵּי קְרָעִים דִּכְתִיב ״עַל״ ״עַל״, דִּכְתִיב: ״עַל שָׁאוּל וְעַל יְהוֹנָתָן בְּנוֹ״.
human_translation: But with regard to tears as it is written “for,” “for,” about which is written: for Saul, and for Jonathan his son,
llm_translation: And this regarding the tearing of garments, as it is written "upon" "upon," as it is written: "Upon Saul and upon Jonathan his son."

hebrew_text: וְתַנְיָא: אָמְרוּ לוֹ ״מֵת אָבִיו״ וְקָרַע, וְאַחַר כָּךְ נִמְצָא בְּנוֹ — יָצָא יְדֵי קְרִיעָה.
human_translation: And is taught they said to him his father had died and he rent and afterward it was discovered his son, he has fulfilled rending
llm_translation: And it was taught in a Baraita: They said to him, "Your father has died," and he tore his garment, and afterwards his son was found - he has fulfilled the obligation of tearing.

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי, לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בִּסְתָם, וְהָא בִּמְפָרֵשׁ.
human_translation: is not difficult That non-specific this specified
llm_translation: They said, it is not difficult: this in the case of implicit, and this in the case of explicit.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: אָמְרוּ לוֹ ״מֵת אָבִיו״ וְקָרַע, וְאַחַר כָּךְ נִמְצָא בְּנוֹ — לֹא יָצָא יְדֵי קְרִיעָה. אָמְרוּ לוֹ ״מֵת לוֹ מֵת״, וּכְסָבוּר אָבִיו הוּא וְקָרַע, וְאַחַר כָּךְ נִמְצָא בְּנוֹ — יָצָא יְדֵי קְרִיעָה.
human_translation: And it is taught they said to him his father had died and he rent and afterward it was discovered his son, he has not fulfilled rending they said to him of his had died, and he thought it was his father and he rent and afterward it was discovered his son, he has fulfilled rending
llm_translation: And it was taught: They said to him, "Your father is dead," and he tore his garment, and afterwards his son was found - he has not fulfilled the obligation of tearing his garment. They said to him, "His father is dead to him," and he thought it was his own father and he tore his garment, and afterwards his son was found - he has fulfilled the obligation of tearing his garment.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: כָּאן בְּתוֹךְ כְּדֵי דִבּוּר, כָּאן לְאַחַר כְּדֵי דִבּוּר.
human_translation: Rav Ashi says Here, within the time required for speaking There, after the time required for speaking
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: Here within the time it takes for speech, here after the time it takes for speech.

hebrew_text: הָא דְּקָאָמְרַתְּ יָצָא יְדֵי קְרִיעָה — שֶׁנִּמְצָא בְּנוֹ בְּתוֹךְ כְּדֵי דִבּוּר. הָא דְּאָמְרַתְּ לֹא יָצָא יְדֵי קְרִיעָה — לְאַחַר כְּדֵי דִבּוּר.
human_translation: This where you said he has fulfilled rending where it was discovered within the time required for speaking his son. that where you said he has not fulfilled rending after the time required for speaking
llm_translation: This that you said "he has fulfilled the obligation of tearing" - if it was found within the time it takes to speak. This that you said "he has not fulfilled the obligation of tearing" - after the time it takes to speak.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: מִי שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ חוֹלֶה בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתוֹ וְנִתְעַלֵּף, וְכִמְדוּמֶּה שֶׁמֵּת, וְקָרַע, וְאַחַר כָּךְ מֵת — לֹא יָצָא יְדֵי קְרִיעָה. אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי מִשּׁוּם בַּר קַפָּרָא: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא שֶׁמֵּת לְאַחַר כְּדֵי דִיבּוּר, אֲבָל בְּתוֹךְ כְּדֵי דִיבּוּר — כְּדִבּוּר דָּמֵי.
human_translation: And it is taught One who has an ill in his house, and fainted and it seemed that died and he rent and afterward he died, has not fulfilled rending Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said in the name of Bar Kappara: They taught only if died after the time required for speaking But within the time required for speaking it is like speech,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught: One who has a sick person in his house and he became critically ill, and he is silent as if dead, and he tears his garments, and afterwards he dies - he has not fulfilled the obligation of tearing. Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi in the name of Bar Kappara: They only taught that if he died after the time of speaking, he has not fulfilled the obligation of tearing, but if it is within the time of speaking - it is considered as if he spoke.

hebrew_text: וְהִילְכְתָא: תּוֹךְ כְּדֵי דִבּוּר — כְּדִבּוּר דָּמֵי, חוּץ מִמְּגַדֵּף וְעוֹבֵד עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה וּמְקַדֵּשׁ וּמְגָרֵשׁ.
human_translation: And the halakha within for speaking is like continuous speech, except for blasphemes or an idol worshipper, or betroths or divorces
llm_translation: The Gemara: Within the time it takes for speech - like the speech of blood, except for one who blasphemes, serves idolatry, sanctifies, or divorces.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אָמְרָה ״קֻוֽנָּם תְּאֵנִים וַעֲנָבִים אֵלּוּ שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֶמֶת״, קִיֵּים לִתְאֵנִים — כּוּלּוֹ קַיָּים, הֵפֵר לִתְאֵנִים — אֵינוֹ מוּפָר עַד שֶׁיָּפֵר אַף לַעֲנָבִים. אָמְרָה ״קֻוֽנָּם תְּאֵנָה שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֶמֶת וַעֲנָבָה שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֶמֶת״ — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ שְׁנֵי נְדָרִים.
human_translation: said: Tasting these figs and grapes is konam for me, upheld with regard to figs, the entire is upheld, he nullified with regard to figs it is not nullified until he also nullifies with regard to grapes. she said: Tasting a fig and tasting a grape are konam for me, these are two vows;
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "She said, 'Kunam figs and grapes are what I taste.' If she fulfilled her vow for figs - it applies to all types of figs, if she annulled her vow for figs - it is not annulled until she also annuls it for grapes." She said, "Kunam fig is what I taste and kunam grape is what I taste" - these are two separate vows.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַנִּי מַתְנִיתִין? רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, דְּתַנְיָא: ״אִישָׁהּ יְקִימֶנּוּ וְאִישָׁהּ יְפֵרֶנּוּ״, אָמְרָה ״קֻוֽנָּם תְּאֵנִים וַעֲנָבִים אֵלּוּ שֶׁאֲנִי טוֹעֶמֶת״, קִיֵּים לִתְאֵנִים — כּוּלּוֹ קַיָּים,
human_translation: Whose the mishna? Rabbi Yishmael, as it is taught “Her husband may uphold it, or her husband may nullify it” said: Tasting these figs and grapes is konam for me, upheld with regard to figs, the entire is upheld.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara, who is the Tanna? Rabbi Yishmael, as it was taught: "Her husband may establish it, and her husband may annul it." She said, "Their measure is figs and grapes, these are what I taste." If she established it for figs - it is entirely established.

hebrew_text: הֵפֵר לִתְאֵנִים — אֵינוֹ מוּפָר עַד שֶׁיָּפֵר אַף לַעֲנָבִים, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״אִישָׁהּ יְקִימֶנּוּ וְאִישָׁהּ יְפֵרֶנּוּ״, מָה ״יְקִימֶנּוּ״ — מִמֶּנּוּ, אַף ״יְפֵרֶנּוּ״ — מִמֶּנּוּ. וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: מִי כְּתִיב ״יָפֵר מִמֶּנּוּ״? וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: מַקִּישׁ הֲפָרָה לַהֲקָמָה, מָה הֲקָמָה — מִמֶּנּוּ, אַף הֲפָרָה — מִמֶּנּוּ.
human_translation: he nullified with regard to figs, it is not nullified until he will also nullify for grapes. the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says states: “Her husband may uphold it, or her husband may nullify it.” Just as “may uphold it” yekimennu part of it mimmennu so too, “he may nullify it” yeferennu part of it [ mimmennu ]. And Rabbi Yishmael Is it written: He may nullify part of it, And Rabbi Akiva juxtaposes nullification to upholding; just as upholding part of it, so too, nullification part of it.
llm_translation: He nullified for figs — it is not nullified until he nullifies also for grapes, the words of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: Behold, he says "her husband shall establish it and her husband shall nullify it," what "shall establish it" — from him, also "shall nullify it" — from him. And Rabbi Yishmael: Where is it written "shall nullify from him"? And Rabbi Akiva: He compares the heifer to the establishment, just as the establishment — from him, so too the heifer — from him.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: זוֹ דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, אֲבָל חֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: מַקִּישׁ הֲקָמָה לַהֲפָרָה; מָה הֲפָרָה — מַה שֶּׁהֵפֵר הֵפֵר, אַף הֲקָמָה — מַה שֶּׁקִּיֵּים קִיֵּים.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This the statement of Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva. But the Rabbis say: juxtaposes upholding to nullification; just as nullification, that which he nullified he has nullified, so too, upholding, that which he upheld he has upheld,
llm_translation: Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: These are the words of Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva, but the Sages say: We derive an analogy between the heifer and the calf; just as the calf was slaughtered, so too the heifer must be slaughtered, just as the calf was standing, so too the heifer must be standing.

hebrew_text: אָמְרָה ״קֻוֽנָּם תְּאֵנָה״, אָמַר רָבָא: מַתְנִיתִין רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא. דְּאָמַר: עַד שֶׁיֹּאמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה״ לְכׇל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד.
human_translation: said: a fig konam Rava said: The mishna is Rabbi Shimon, as said unless he states an oath to each and every one
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: It was said, "Their fig tree," Rava said: This is a teaching of Rabbi Shimon. As he said: Until he says "a week" to each and every one.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי שֶׁיֵּשׁ נְדָרִים, אֲבָל אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁיֵּשׁ מְפִירִין״, יָפֵר. ״יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי שֶׁיֵּשׁ מְפִירִין, אֲבָל אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁזֶּה נֶדֶר״, רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָפֵר, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: יָפֵר.
human_translation: I know that there are vows, but I don’t know that there are those who nullify he can nullify I know there are those who nullify but I do not know that this a vow, Rabbi Meir says he cannot nullify but the Rabbis say he can nullify
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "I know that vows exist, but I do not know that annulments exist," he may annul. "I know that annulments exist, but I do not know that this is a vow," Rabbi Meir says: he may not annul, and the Sages say: he may annul.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ וּרְמִינְהוּ: ״בְּלֹא רְאוֹת״, פְּרָט לַסּוֹמֵא. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַסּוֹמֵא.
human_translation: raises a contradiction “Without seeing” to exclude a blind person the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says to include a blind person
llm_translation: Gemara: And they raised a dilemma: "Without seeing," excluding the blind. The words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: to include the blind.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: הָכָא מֵעִנְיָנֵיהּ דִּקְרָא וְהָכָא מֵעִנְיָנֵיהּ דִּקְרָא. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר: גַּבֵּי רוֹצֵחַ כְּתִיב ״וַאֲשֶׁר יָבֹא אֶת רֵעֵהוּ בַיַּעַר״ — כׇּל דְּבַר מֵיעַל לְיַעַר, וְסּוֹמֵא נָמֵי בַּר מֵיעַל לְיַעַר הוּא. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ ״בְּלֹא רְאוֹת״ לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַסּוֹמֵא — מִ״יַּעַר״ נָפְקָא לֵיהּ. אֶלָּא שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: ״בְּלֹא רְאוֹת״ פְּרָט לְסּוֹמֵא.
human_translation: Rava said: Here, from the context of the verse, and there, from the context of the verse. Rabbi Yehuda maintains with regard to killer it is written: “And a man who goes into the forest with his neighbor anyone is capable of entering a forest, and a blind person is also capable of entering a forest. And if you say “without seeing” to include a blind person, is derived from “forest,” Rather, learn from it “without seeing” to exclude a blind person
llm_translation: Rava said: Here it is regarding the subject of the verse, and here it is regarding the subject of the verse. Rabbi Yehuda holds: concerning a murderer, it is written, "And if he comes upon his neighbor in the forest" - anything that is from the forest, and the blind son of the forest is included in it. And if you say that "without seeing" is to include the blind - he is derived from "forest." Rather, learn from it: "without seeing" is a specification for the blind.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי מֵאִיר סָבַר: כְּתִיב ״בִּבְלִי דַעַת״ — כׇּל דְּבַר מִידָּע, וְסּוֹמֵא לָאו בַּר מִידָּע הוּא. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ ״בְּלֹא רְאוֹת״ פְּרָט לַסּוֹמֵא — מִ״בְּלִי דַעַת״ נָפְקָא לֵיהּ. אֶלָּא שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: ״בְּלֹא רְאוֹת״ לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַסּוֹמֵא.
human_translation: Rabbi Meir maintains: It is written without knowledge” anyone who is capable of knowing but a blind person is not capable of knowing And if you say “without seeing” to exclude a blind person, is derived from “without knowledge.” Rather, learn from it “without seeing” to include a blind person
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir holds: as it is written "bivli da'at" - anything from knowledge, and blind is not from knowledge he is. And if you say "without seeing" is to exclude the blind - from "bivli da'at" it emerges. Rather, learn from it: "without seeing" to include the blind.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַמַּדִּיר הֲנָאָה מֵחֲתָנוֹ, וְהוּא רוֹצֶה לָתֵת לְבִתּוֹ מָעוֹת, אוֹמֵר לָהּ: הֲרֵי הַמָּעוֹת הָאֵלּוּ נְתוּנִין לָךְ בְּמַתָּנָה, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא לְבַעְלִיךְ רְשׁוּת בָּהֶן, אֶלָּא מָה שֶׁאַתְּ נוֹשֵׂאת וְנוֹתֶנֶת בְּפִיךְ.
human_translation: one who vows benefit to his son-in-law, but he wishes to give his daughter, money, he say to her: This money is hereby given to you as a gift, provided that your husband has no rights to it, only that which you pick up and place in your mouth.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who prohibits deriving benefit from his wife, and he wishes to give money to his daughter, he says to her: "Behold, these coins are given to you as a gift, on the condition that your husband does not have any authority over them, but only what you carry and transfer in your mouth."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא דְּאָמַר לַהּ ״מָה שֶׁאַתְּ נוֹשֵׂאת וְנוֹתֶנֶת בְּפִיךְ״, אֲבָל אָמַר ״מַה שֶּׁתִּרְצִי עֲשִׂי״, קְנָה יָתְהוֹן בַּעַל. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ אָמַר ״מַה שֶּׁתִּרְצִי עֲשִׂי״ — לָא קְנָה יָתְהוֹן בַּעַל. מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַבִּי זֵירָא:
human_translation: Rav said they taught only where he said to her: That which you pick up and place in your mouth But he said: Do as you please the husband acquires And Shmuel says even he said: Do as you please the husband does not acquire it. Rabbi Zeira objects to this
llm_translation: Gemara: Rav said: They only taught this halacha when she says to her husband, "Whatever you desire, do," but if she says, "Whatever I desire, do," the husband acquires the items. And Shmuel says: Even if she says, "Whatever I desire, do," the husband does not acquire the items. Rabbi Zeira objects to him:

hebrew_text: כְּמַאן אָזְלָא הָא שְׁמַעְתָּא דְּרַב — כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, דְּאָמַר: יַד אִשָּׁה כְּיַד בַּעְלָהּ.
human_translation: In accordance with whose does Rav’s halakha correspond? in accordance with Rabbi Meir, who said the hand of a woman is like the hand of her husband.
llm_translation: As to where did the statement of Rav go? Like Rabbi Meir, who said: "The hand of a woman is like the hand of her husband."

hebrew_text: וּרְמִינְהוּ: כֵּיצַד מִשְׁתַּתְּפִין בְּמָבוֹי? מַנִּיחַ אֶת הֶחָבִית וְאוֹמֵר: הֲרֵי זֶה לְכׇל בְּנֵי מָבוֹי. וּמְזַכֶּה לָהֶן עַל יְדֵי עַבְדּוֹ וְשִׁפְחָתוֹ הָעִבְרִים, וְעַל יְדֵי בְּנוֹ וּבִתּוֹ הַגְּדוֹלִים, וְעַל יְדֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ.
human_translation: And raise a contradiction How does one merge into an alleyway He places a barrel and says: This is for all the residents of the alleyway. and he may transfer possession to them by means of his Hebrew slave or maidservant, and by means of his adult son or daughter, and by means of his wife.
llm_translation: And they asked: How do they participate in the alleyway? He places the barrel and says: This is for all the residents of the alleyway. And he acquires it for them through his male and female Hebrew slaves, and through his adult son and daughter, and through his wife.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ קְנָה יָתְהוֹן בַּעְלַהּ, עֵירוּב לָא נָפֵיק מֵרְשׁוּתֵיהּ דְּבַעַל!
human_translation: And if you say husband acquires the eiruv has not left the husband’s domain
llm_translation: And if you say, "Acquire her with her husband," the eruv does not emerge from the domain of her husband!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: אַף עַל גַּב דְּאָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר יַד אִשָּׁה כְּיַד בַּעְלָהּ, מוֹדֶה רַבִּי מֵאִיר לְעִנְיַן שִׁיתּוּף, דְּכֵיוָן דִּלְזַכּוֹת לַאֲחֵרִים הוּא מִיַּד בַּעְלָהּ — זָכְיָא.
human_translation: Rava said Even though Rabbi Meir said the hand of a woman is like the hand of her husband, Rabbi Meir concedes with regard to the merging that since it to acquire for others from the hand of her husband, she can acquire
llm_translation: Rava said: Even though Rabbi Meir said, "A woman's hand is like her husband's hand," Rabbi Meir concedes regarding partnership, for since she is benefiting others, she is immediately like her husband — she is acquitted.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: אֵלּוּ שֶׁזָּכִין לָהֶן: [עַל יְדֵי] בְּנוֹ וּבִתּוֹ הַגְּדוֹלִים, וְעַבְדּוֹ וְשִׁפְחָתוֹ הָעִבְרִים. וְאֵלּוּ שֶׁאֵין זָכִין לָהֶן: עַל יְדֵי בְּנוֹ וּבִתּוֹ הַקְּטַנִּים, וְעַבְדּוֹ וְשִׁפְחָתוֹ הַכְּנַעֲנִים, וְאִשְׁתּוֹ!
human_translation: Ravina raised an objection to Rav Ashi These are who can acquire on behalf of by means of his adult son or daughter, and his Hebrew slave or maidservant. And these are who cannot acquire on behalf of by means of his minor son or daughter, or his Canaanite slave or maidservant, or his wife.
llm_translation: Ravina raised an objection to Rav Ashi: These are the ones who merit to be supported by their master: through his adult son and daughter, and his Hebrew slave and maidservant. And these are the ones who do not merit to be supported by their master: through his minor son and daughter, and his Canaanite slave and maidservant, and his wife!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: מַתְנִיתִין בְּשֶׁיֵּשׁ לָהּ חָצֵר בְּאוֹתוֹ מָבוֹי עָסְקִינַן, דְּמִגּוֹ דְּזָכְיָא לְנַפְשַׁהּ — זָכְיָא לְאַחֲרִינֵי.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Ashi said: the mishna we are dealing with who possesses a courtyard in that alleyway, As, since she acquires for herself she acquires for others.
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Ashe said: In the case where it has a courtyard, we are dealing with that same alleyway, for if it acquires for itself, it acquires for others.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״וְנֵדֶר אַלְמָנָה וּגְרוּשָׁהּ יָקוּם עָלֶיהָ״, כֵּיצַד? אָמְרָה ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה לְאַחַר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם״, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁנִּשֵּׂאת בְּתוֹךְ שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: “But every vow of a widow, and of her that is divorced, shall stand against her” How so? said: I am hereby a nazirite after thirty days, even if she was married within thirty days, cannot nullify
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "And a vow of a widow or divorced woman shall stand against her." How so? She said, "Behold, I am a nazirite after thirty days." Even though she accepted it within thirty days, she cannot annul it.

hebrew_text: נָדְרָה וְהִיא בִּרְשׁוּת הַבַּעַל — מֵפֵר לָהּ. כֵּיצַד? אָמְרָה ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה לְאַחַר שְׁלֹשִׁים״, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁנִּתְאַלְמְנָה אוֹ נִתְגָּרְשָׁה בְּתוֹךְ שְׁלֹשִׁים — הֲרֵי זֶה מוּפָר. נָדְרָה בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם וְנִתְגָּרְשָׁה בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם, הֶחְזִירָה בּוֹ בְּיוֹם — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. זֶה הַכְּלָל: כׇּל שֶׁיָּצְאָה לִרְשׁוּת עַצְמָהּ שָׁעָה אַחַת — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: she took a vow while she was under the jurisdiction of husband, he can nullify for her. How so? she said I am hereby a nazirite for after thirty even if she was widowed or divorced within thirty- is nullified. she took a vow on that, day and was divorced on that day, took her back on that day, he cannot nullify This is the principle: Once she has left into her own jurisdiction a single hour, can no nullify
llm_translation: Vowed and she in the permission of the husband — he annuls for her. How so? She said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite after thirty," even though she became a widow or divorced within thirty — this is annulled. She vowed upon him in the day and was divorced from him in the day, she returned to him in the day — he cannot annul. This is the principle: anything that she went out to her own permission for one hour — he cannot annul.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תַּנְיָא: אַלְמָנָה וּגְרוּשָׁה שֶׁאָמְרָה ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה לִכְשֶׁאִנָּשֵׂא״ וְנִשֵּׂאת, רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: יָפֵר, וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָפֵר. וְסִימָנָא: יְלֵלִי. אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ שֶׁאָמְרָה ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה לִכְשֶׁאֶתְגָּרֵשׁ״ וְנִתְגָּרְשָׁה, רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָפֵר, וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: יָפֵר.
human_translation: It is taught a widow or a divorcée who said: I am hereby a nazirite for when I will get married, and she was married, Rabbi Yishmael says can nullify whereas Rabbi Akiva says he cannot nullify And the mnemonic yod , lamed , lamed , yod : a married woman who said I am hereby a nazirite for when I will get divorced, and she was divorced, Rabbi Yishmael says cannot nullify whereas Rabbi Akiva says can nullify
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara: It was taught in a Baraita: A widow or a divorced woman who said, 'I will be a Nazirite when I marry,' and then she marries, Rabbi Yishmael says: She should fulfill her vow, and Rabbi Akiva says: She should not fulfill her vow. And the mnemonic is: Yeleli. The wife of a man who said, 'I will be a Nazirite when I divorce,' and then she is divorced, Rabbi Yishmael says: She should not fulfill her vow, and Rabbi Akiva says: She should fulfill her vow."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״וְנֵדֶר אַלְמָנָה וּגְרוּשָׁה וְגוֹ׳״, עַד שֶׁיְּהֵא נֶדֶר בִּשְׁעַת אַלְמָנוּת וְגֵרוּשִׁין. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר: הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״כֹּל אֲשֶׁר אָסְרָה עַל נַפְשָׁהּ״, עַד שֶׁיְּהֵא אִיסּוּרֵי נֶדֶר בִּשְׁעַת אַלְמָנוּת וְגֵרוּשִׁין.
human_translation: Rabbi Yishmael said: It says: “But every vow of a widow, and of her that is divorced the vow must be in the time of the widowhood or divorce. Rabbi Akiva, maintains: It says: with which she has bound her soul, that the binding of the vow, must be at the time of widowhood or divorce.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael said: "Behold he says 'and a vow of a widow, and a divorcee, etc.', until there is a vow at the time of widowhood and divorces." Rabbi Akiva holds: "Behold he says 'all that she forbade upon her soul', until there are prohibitions of vows at the time of widowhood and divorces."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: מַתְנִיתִין — רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הִיא. אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, מַתְנִיתִין תָּלְיָא נַפְשַׁהּ בְּיוֹמֵי, בָּרַיְיתָא תָּלְיָא נַפְשַׁהּ בְּנִישּׂוּאִין.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: The mishna is Rabbi Akiva. Abaye said: Even you say Rabbi Yishmael, the mishna who made her dependent on days, baraita who made her dependent on marriage.
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisdah said: The Mishnah is that of Rabbi Akiva. Abbaye said: Even if you were to say it is that of Rabbi Yishmael, the Mishnah depends on itself in matters of days, the Baraita depends on itself in matters of marriage.

hebrew_text: שָׁלְמוּ יוֹמֵי וְלָא נִתְגָּרְשָׁה, שָׁלְמוּ יוֹמֵי וְלָא מִיתְנַסְבָא.
human_translation: the days will be completed and she was not divorced, the days will be completed and she was not married.
llm_translation: They completed the days and she was not divorced, they completed the days and she was not betrothed.

hebrew_text: ״זֶה הַכְּלָל״ דְּקָתָנֵי גַּבֵּי ״נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה״ — לְאֵיתוֹיֵי הָלַךְ הָאָב עִם שְׁלוּחֵי הַבַּעַל אוֹ שֶׁהָלְכוּ שְׁלוּחֵי הָאָב עִם שְׁלוּחֵי הַבַּעַל, בְּנַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה, דְּאָבִיהָ וּבַעְלָהּ מְפִירִין נְדָרֶיהָ.
human_translation: This is the principle, which is taught in A betrothed young woman, to include the father went with the messengers of the husband and where the messengers father went with the messengers of the husband. In a betrothed young woman, that her father and her husband can nullify her vows.
llm_translation: "This is the principle" that is taught regarding "a betrothed maiden" — for the purpose of clarifying whether the father accompanied the emissaries of the husband or whether the emissaries of the father accompanied the emissaries of the husband, in the case of a betrothed maiden, where her father and her husband annul her vows.

hebrew_text: ״זֶה הַכְּלָל״ דְּקָתָנֵי גַּבֵּי ״וְאֵלּוּ נְדָרִים״, לְאֵיתוֹיֵי מָסַר הָאָב לִשְׁלוּחֵי הַבַּעַל אוֹ שֶׁמָּסְרוּ שְׁלוּחֵי הָאָב לִשְׁלוּחֵי הַבַּעַל, שֶׁאֵין הַבַּעַל מֵיפֵר בַּקּוֹדְמִין.
human_translation: This is the principle, which is taught in And these are the vows, to include the father handed over to the messengers of the husband, or where the messengers of the father handed over to the messengers of the husband. that the husband cannot nullify previous
llm_translation: "This is the principle" that is taught regarding "and these are the vows," to include the case where the father entrusted his daughter to the messengers of the husband, or where the messengers of the father entrusted her to the messengers of the husband, that the husband does not annul the prior ones."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ תֵּשַׁע נְעָרוֹת נִדְרֵיהֶן קַיָּימִין: בּוֹגֶרֶת וְהִיא יְתוֹמָה. נַעֲרָה וּבָגְרָה וְהִיא יְתוֹמָה.
human_translation: nine young women whose vows are upheld a grown woman and she is an orphan; a young woman, and has reached her majority, and she is an orphan;
llm_translation: It was taught in a Mishnah: Nine maidens, their vows are valid. A Bogeret, and she is an orphan. A Na'arah, and she is a Bogeret, and she is an orphan.

hebrew_text: נַעֲרָה שֶׁלֹּא בָּגְרָה וְהִיא יְתוֹמָה. בּוֹגֶרֶת וּמֵת אָבִיהָ. נַעֲרָה בּוֹגֶרֶת וּמֵת אָבִיהָ. נַעֲרָה שֶׁלֹּא בָּגְרָה וּמֵת אָבִיהָ. נַעֲרָה שֶׁמֵּת אָבִיהָ וּמִשֶּׁמֵּת אָבִיהָ בָּגְרָה. בּוֹגֶרֶת וְאָבִיהָ קַיָּים. נַעֲרָה בּוֹגֶרֶת וְאָבִיהָ קַיָּים. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אַף הַמַּשִּׂיא בִּתּוֹ הַקְּטַנָּה וְנִתְאַלְמְנָה אוֹ נִתְגָּרְשָׁה וְחָזְרָה אֶצְלוֹ — עֲדַיִין הִיא נַעֲרָה.
human_translation: a young woman who had not reached her majority, and she is an orphan; a grown woman and her father died; a young woman, a grown woman, and her father died; a young woman who had not reached her majority, and her father died; a young woman, and her father died, and after her father died she reached her majority; a grown woman and her father is alive; a young woman, a grown woman, and her father is alive. Rabbi Yehuda says: even one who married off his minor daughter, and she was widowed or divorced and she returned to him, she still a young woman,
llm_translation: A girl who has not reached maturity and she is an orphan. She reached maturity and her father died. A girl who reached maturity and her father died. A girl who has not reached maturity and her father died. A girl whose father died and from the time her father died she reached maturity. She reached maturity and her father is alive. A girl who reached maturity and her father is alive. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even one who marries off his young daughter and she becomes a widow or divorced and returns to him - she is still considered a young girl.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: זוֹ דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. אֲבָל חֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים, שָׁלֹשׁ נְעָרוֹת נִדְרֵיהֶן קַיָּימִין: בּוֹגֶרֶת, וִיתוֹמָה, וִיתוֹמָה בְּחַיֵּי הָאָב.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said Rav said: This the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, But the Rabbis say three young women whose vows are upheld A grown woman, and an orphan, and an orphan in her father’s lifetime,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara said Rav Yehudah said Rav: This is the statement of Rabbi Yehudah. But the sages say, three young girls their vows are upheld: a Bogeret, an orphan, and an orphan during the lifetime of her father.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״קֻוֽנָּם שֶׁאֵינִי נֶהֱנֶה לְאַבָּא וּלְאָבִיךָ אִם עוֹשָׂה אֲנִי עַל פִּיךָ״, ״שֶׁאֵינִי נֶהֱנֵית לְךָ אִם עוֹשָׂה אֲנִי עַל פִּי אַבָּא וְעַל פִּי אָבִיךָ״ — הֲרֵי זֶה יָפֵר.
human_translation: Deriving benefit from father or from your father is konam for me if I prepare for you; Deriving benefit from you for me if I prepare for father or for your father, can nullify
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "Your father and your mother say to you, 'We do not benefit from you,' and you do it according to their word," "You say to them, 'I do not benefit from you,' and you do it according to the word of your father and the word of your mother" - this is considered annulment.
